Pierced, or thrust, with the zuj~ [q. v.] of a spear. (S, TA.) And Cast at therewith. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A large bucket (garobN) not made round, but having its two lips [or opposite edges] put together, and then sewed. (K.)

1 zajarahu * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zajura , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. zajorN, (S, A, Msb,) He chid him, by a cry, by his voice, or by reproof: (S, * K, * TA:) he checked him, restrained him, or forbade him, with rough speech: (TA:) or prevented, hindered, restrained, or withheld, him: or forbade, or prohibited, him: [by any kind of cry or speech:] as also ↓ Azdjrhu; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) the latter originally Aztjrhu: (Msb, TA:) Eano ka*aA from [doing] such a thing: (A, * Mgh, TA:) and Eani Als~uwo'i from evil. (TA.) ― -b2- zajara Alkaloba, (K,) and Als~abuEa, (TA,) and zajara bihi (K,) (assumed tropical:) He cried out to, or at, the dog, (K,) and the beast of prey, (TA,) in order that he might forbear, refrain, or abstain. (K, TA.) [See a tropical ex. voce HinowN.] ― -b3- zajara AlbaEiyra (tropical:) He incited the camel to quickness: (TA:) he drove, or urged, the camel, (S, K, TA,) and incited him with a peculiar cry, so that he became excited, and went on: (TA:) he said to the camel Hawobi: and zajara Aln~aAqapa (assumed tropical:) He said to the she-camel Halo: (AZ, TA:) and zajara Alganama (tropical:) He (a pastor) cried out to, or at, the sheep or goats: (A, Mgh, TA:) and in like manner, to or at, a horse or the like, and a camel, and a beast of prey, with a high, or loud, voice, and vehemently: (TA:) and Alr~iyHu tazojuru Als~aHaAba (tropical:) [The wind drives the clouds]. (A.) ― -b4- zajorN signifies The driving away with crying or a cry: and by subsequent applications, sometimes, (assumed tropical:) the driving away: and sometimes (assumed tropical:) the crying, or crying out, or a cry. (B, TA.) ― -b5- zajara AlT~aAy^ira, (K,) aor.
zajura , inf. n. zajorN; (TA;) and ↓ Azdjrhu; (K;) (tropical:) He chid the bird, auguring evil from it. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And zajara AlT~ayora (tropical:) He threw a pebble at the birds, and cried out; and if, in flying, they turned their right sides towards him, he augured well from them; but if their left sides, evil. (A.) ― -b7- Hence, (A,) zajorN also signifies (tropical:) The auguring from the flight, alightingplaces, cries, kinds, or names, of birds: (S, A, K:) you say, huwa yazojuru AlT~ayora He augurs from the flight, &c., of birds: (A:) or zajorN signifies the auguring well from a bird's or some other thing's sunuwH [or turning the right side towards one, or the contrary], and evil from its buruwH [or turning the left side towards one, or the contrary]. (Zj.) And zajara guraAba Albayoni means (assumed tropical:) He went away, departed, or journeyed. (Har p. 308.) ― -b8- [Hence,] it also signifies (tropical:) The practising of divination: (K:) or a species thereof: you say, zajarotu A^an~ahu yakuwnu ka*aA waka*aA I have divined that it is so and so. (S, L.) [See also zaAjirN] ― -b9- zajarato bimaA fiY baTonihaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) cast forth what was in her belly. (K, TA.)

6 tazaAjaruwA Eani Almunokari * [They checked, restrained, or forbade, one another, with rough speech; or] they prevented, hindered, or withheld one another; or they forbade, or prohibited, one another; from abominable, foul, or evil, conduct. (A, Msb.)

7 Anzjr * and ↓ Aizodajara He, being chidden, by a cry, by the voice, or by reproof; or being checked, restrained, or forbidden, with rough speech; (TA;) or being prevented, hindered, restrained, or withheld; or being forbidden or prohibited; refrained, forbore, or abstained; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) Eano ka*aA from [doing] such a thing. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- ↓ A@zodujira, in the Kur liv. 9, means He was driven away. (TA.) ― -b3- Anzjr He (a dog) became urged, or incited, by a cry, to pursue the game. (Mgh.)
8 Aizodajara * , for Aizotajara, trans. and intrans.: see 1 and 7; each in two places.

Q. Q. 1
(accord. to the S). zanojara: see art. znjr.

zajorN * inf. n. of 1. (S, A, Msb.) ― -b2- A crying at camels [&c.], and an urging or inciting of them. (TA.) ― -b3- A cry by which one chides, i. e., either checks or urges, a beast &c.; like Saho to a man, and Eadaso to a mule, &c. (The lexicons, passim.) -A2- See also what next follows.

zajarN * (Az, O, K) and ↓ zajorN (IDrd, O, K) Large fish, (K,) [i. e.] a species of large fish, (IDrd, O,) with small scales: (TA:) IDrd says, thus called by the people of El-'Irák, but I do not think the appellation to be genuine Arabic: (O:) pl. zujuwrN. (O, K.)

zajorapN *
A cry. (Mgh.)

zajuwrN * (tropical:) A she-camel that will not yield her milk abundantly until chidden: (A, K, TA:) or that yields her milk abundantly to her young one if beaten, but does not if let alone: (TA:) or (K, TA, but accord. to the CK “ and ”) a she-camel that knows [her young one] with her eye, but repudiates it with her nose [when she smells it]: (S, K:) and a she-camel that inclines to the young one of another, and not to her own, but only smells it, and refuses to yield her milk to it; syn. EaluwqN. (K.) ― -b2- It is also applied, metaphorically, as an epithet to war. (A, TA.)

[
zaj~aArN * One who chides, &c., much, or often.]

zaAjirN * [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- [Hence,] kafaY
biAlquroA=ni zaAjirFA (tropical:) [The Kur-án suffices as a chider, checker, restrainer, or forbidder]. (A, TA.) And Alz~aAjiru (assumed tropical:) The exhorter, on the part of God, in the heart of the believer; i. e. the light shed into it, [or what we term the light of nature,] that invites him to the truth. (KT.) ― -b3- Alz~aAjiraAtu, in the Kur xxxvii. 2, means (tropical:) The angels who are the drivers of the clouds. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- zaAjirN also signifies (tropical:) A diviner; because, when he sees that which he thinks to be of evil omen, he cries out with a high, or loud, and vehement, voice, forbidding to undertake the thing in question. (Zj, TA.) ― -b5- A^abuw zaAjirK (assumed tropical:) The crow; because one augurs by means of it. (Har p. 662.)

[
zaAjirapN * a subst. formed from the epithet zaAjirN by the addition of p. Its pl. occurs in the saying,] kar~irato EalaY samoEihi AlmawaAEiZu waAlz~awaAjiru (tropical:) [Exhortations, and chiding or restraining speeches, were repeated in his ears]. (A, TA.)
zinojiyrN * and zinojiyrapN: see art. znjr.

A^azojaru * A camel having a looseness in the vertebræ of his back, arising from disease, or from galls, or sores, produced by the saddle: (O, K: *) [or having a fracture in his back;] like A^axozalu. (O.)

mazojarN * [A place of zajor, i. e. chiding, &c.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa min~iY mazojara Alkalobi, an elliptical phrase, meaning (tropical:) [He is, in relation to me, or min~iY is here used in the sense of EinodiY, i. e., in my estimation,] as though he were in the mzjr of the dog; (Sb, TA;) [i. e., as though he were to be chidden like the dog, and driven away;] said by Z to be tropical. (TA.)

mazojarapN * [A cause of zajor, i. e. chiding, &c.: a noun of the same class as maboxalapN &c.; pl. mazaAjiru]. A poet says,
mano kaAna laA yazoEumu A^an~iY $aAEiru
faloyadonu min~iY tanohahu AlmazaAjiru
i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He who will not assert that I am a poet, let him approach me:] preventing causes forbid him. (TA.) And one says, *ikoru A@ll~`hi mazojarapN lil$~ayoTaAni (tropical:) [The remembrance, or the mention, of God is a cause of driving away the devil]. (A, TA.)

muzodajarN * , in the Kur liv. 4, (Bd, TA,) is [an inf. n.,] syn. with AizodijaArN, (Bd,) meaning (assumed tropical:) Depulsion, and prevention, or prohibition, from the commission of sinful actions; (TA;) or from punishment: or it there means a threatening: and some read maz~ajarN, changing the d into z, and incorporating it [into the preceding letter]. (Bd.)

1 zajila * , (MA, K,) aor.
zajala , (K,) inf. n. zajalN, (MA, K, KL, and Har p. 240,) He uttered his voice, or a cry; or made a sound, or cry: (MA, KL:) or he raised his voice, (K, Har,) to evince emotion. (Har.) ― -b2- [It seems to be indicated in the K that it signifies also He played, or sported: and He, or it (i. e. a company of men), raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises: and He trilled, or quavered, and prolonged his voice; or prolonged it, and modulated it sweetly. See the next paragraph.]

zajalN * inf. n. of zajila: (MA, K:) [and used as a simple subst:] i. q. SawotN [as an inf. n., meaning The uttering of the voice, or of a sound, or cry: or, as a simple subst., a voice, sound, or cry]: (S:) or a high, or loud, voice: such have the angels when celebrating the praises of God: (TA:) [and] a vehement sound. (Ham p. 627.) [Hence,] saHaAbN *uw zajalK Clouds having a thundering: (TA:) [and] so ↓ saHaAbN zajilN. (S.) ― -b2- A clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises, or of crying or shouting or noise. (K.) ― -b3- [A low, or faint, sound: hence,] zajalu Aljin~i means EaziyfuhaA [i. e. The low, or faint, sound of the jinn, or genii, that is heard by night in the deserts; and said to be a sound like drumming: or the sound of the winds in the atmosphere, imagined by the people of the desert to be the sound of the jinn]. (TA.) ― -b4- A trilling, or quavering, and prolonging of the voice; or a prolonging of the voice, and modulating it sweetly. (K.) A poet likens it to the voice of one urging on camels by singing to them, and to the playing on a reedpipe. (Sb, TA.) ― -b5- Also Play, or sport. (K.) ― -b6- And A species of verse, well known; [a vulgar sort of unmeasured song or balled;] in this sense post-classical. (TA.)

zajilN *
Raising his voice; as also ↓ zaAjilN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saHaAbN zajilN: see zajalN And gayovN zajilN Rain accompanied by the sound of thunder. (TA.) And nabotN zajilN A plant, or herbage, in which, or among which, the wind makes a sound. (K.)
zajolapN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

zujolapN * The sound, or voice, or noise, of men; as also ↓ zajolapN. (K.) ― -b2- And A company, a collection, or an assemblage: (K:) or a party, or company, of men, (S, K,) peculiarly: (TA:) as also ↓ zajolapN: (K:) pl. of the former zujalN. (S.)

zaAjilN * : see zajilN. ― -b2- It is also applied to a song, or singing, [meaning Loud,] in the saying,
wahuwa yugan~iyhaA ginaA='F zaAjilaA
[And he sings to her, or to them (probably referring to camels), with a loud song or singing]. (TA.)

1 zajaA * , (S, K,) aor. yazojuw, (S,) inf. n. zajaA='N (S, K, and Ham p. 78) and zajowN (K and Ham) and zujuw~N, (K,) It (a thing) went, or became urged on or along, quickly. (Ham ubi suprà: there indicated by the context, but not expressed.) ― -b2- It (a bad piece of money) passed, or had currency. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- It (an affair) was, or became, easy; and right, in a right state, or right in its direction or tendency. (K, TA.) Hence the trad., laA tazojuw SalaApN laA yuqoraA^u fiyhaA bifaAtiHapi AlkitaAbi i. e. [A prayer in which the opening chapter of the Book (meaning the Kur-án) is not recited] will not be right. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, inf. n. zajaA='N, said of the [tax called] xaraAj, It was, or became, easy of collection. (S.) ― -b5- zajaA='N also signifies The acting with penetrative energy, and effectiveness, in an affair. (S, K.) One says, h`*aA AlA^amoru qado zajawonaA Ealayohi [app. meaning This affair, we have effected it, or accomplished it; like as one says, maDayonaA EalaY AlA^amori]. (T, TA.) And EaTaA='N qaliylN yazojuw xayorN mino kaviyrK laA yazojuw [A small gift that is effective is better than much that will not be effective]. (S.) -A2- One says also, DaHika Hat~aY zajaA i. e. [He laughed until] his laughing became stopped, or cut short. (S, K. *) -A3- See also what next follows, in two places.

2 zj~Ahu * , (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tazojiyapN, (S, TA,) He pushed it gently, (S, Msb, TA,) in order that it might go on; as also ↓ AzjAhu; and ↓ zajaAhu, aor. yazojuwhu, inf. n. zajowN: and this last, he drove it, or urged it on, gently; (TA;) [and so zj~Ahu and ↓ AzjAhu, as will be shown by what follows:] or ↓ zajaAhu signifies [simply] he drove it, or urged it on: and he pushed it: and so [app. in both of these senses] zj~Ahu and ↓ AzjAhu. (K.) Hence, i. e. from zaj~ayotuhu meaning “ I pushed it gently, ” (Har p. 304,) one says, kayofa tuzaj~iY AlA^ay~aAma (S, Har) i. e. kayofa tudaAfiEuhaA [How dost thou strive with the days in pushing them on, or making them to pass away?]: (S:) or kyf tadofaEuhaA [how dost thou push on the days? and thus may mean also kyf tdAfEhA]: (Har:) [or how dost thou make the days to pass away? for] zj~Y AlA^ay~aAma means he made the days to pass away: (MA:) [or how dost thou pass the days? for it is also said that] tazojiyapN signifies the passing [one's] days. (KL.) [zj~Y AlA^ay~aAma may be well rendered He made the days to pass away by means of exertion; and so dafaEahaA and daAfaEahaA. Har (ubi suprà) uses the phrase A^uzaj~iY A^ay~aAmFA musowad~apF as meaning I push on evil and hard days.] ↓ AzjY Al$~aYo'a, also, inf. n. A_izojaA='N, is expl. by Az as signifying daAfaEa biqaliylihi [app. meaning He strove to push on life, or to repel want or the like, with little of the thing]: and accord. to a saying heard by him from a man of the tribe of Fezárah, nuzaj~iYdunoyaAnaA [or the correct reading may be ↓ nuzojiY, and accord. to either reading the phrase may be rendered We strive to push on life, or to repel want &c., with little of our worldly possessions,] means we content ourselves in respect of our worldly possessions with scanty sustenance. (TA. [See also 5.]) One says also AlA_ibila ↓ A^azojayotu I drove the camels. (S.) And waladahaA ↓ Albaqarapu tuzojiY The [wild] cow drives her young one. (S.) Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba ↓ tuzojiY The wind drives along the clouds: (S:) or drives along gently the clouds; as also tuzaj~iyhi, but in an intensive sense. (Msb.) In like manner, saHaAbFA ↓ yuzojiY is said of God, in the Kur [xxiv. 43]: and in the same [xvii. 68], rab~ukumu A@l~a*iY lakumu A@lofuloka fiY AlbaHori ↓ yuzojiY [Your Lord is He
who driveth along for you the ship in the sea]. (TA.) And a poet says,
↓ zaj~ayotuhu biAlqawoli waA@zodajayotuhu
i. e. [I drove him with speech, and] urged him on: for AizodajaAhu signifies saAqahu [like zaj~aAhu &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And zj~Y HaAjatiY He made easy the attainment of my want. (TA.) -A2- zj~Y Alr~umoHa i. q. A^azaj~ahu q. v. in art. zj. (TA in that art.)
4 A^azojawa see 2, in ten places. AzjY also signifies He made money, or bad money, to pass, or be current. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

5 tazaj~ayotu bika*aA *
I contented myself with such a thing: a rájiz says,
tazaj~a mino dunoyaAka biAlbalaAgi
[Content thyself with what is sufficient of thy worldly possessions]. (S. [See also 2.])
8 A_izotajawa see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

A^azojaY *
More penetrating and effective in an affair than another: (S, K:) so in the saying, fulaAnN A^azojaY bih`*aA AlA^amori mino fulaAnK [Such a one is more penetrating and effective in this affair than such a one]. (S, K. *)

muzojFY * , applied to a horse [or other beast], That is driven, or urged on, (yzjY, [i. e. yuzojaY,]) in his pace, by little and little. (Ham p. 158.) ― -b2- A small, or scanty, thing; (S, Er-Rághib, TA;) or such as is mean, or paltry; that may be pushed and driven away because of the little account that is made of it. (Er-Rághib, TA.) biDaAEapN muzojaApN means Small, or scanty, merchandise; little in quantity: (S, K:) and so it is said to mean in the Kur [xii. 88]: or, as in some copies of the S, little, or mean, or paltry, merchandise: (TA:) or mean, or paltry, merchandise, rejected by every one to whom it is offered: (A, TA:) or merchandise wherewith the days are pushed on (tudofaEu [i. e. made to pass away by means of exertion]) because of its scantiness: (Msb, TA: [for muzojaApN bihaA:]) or, accord. to the shereef El-Murtadà, merchandise driven along portion after portion, scantily and feebly: (TA:) or merchandise in respect of which a lowering of the price is demanded on account of its badness (fiyhaA A_igomaADN); (Th, TA;) not in perfect condition: (Th, K, TA:) thus, too, it is expl. as used in the Kur: and some say that what is there mentioned consisted of fruit of the terebinth-tree, or of Sanawobar [app. here meaning pine-cones]: some say, of commodities of the Arabs of the desert, wool, and clarified butter: and some say, of deficient pieces of money. (TA.)

muzaj~FY *
Weak: so termed because of his lagging behind, and requiring to be urged on: (Ham p. 441:) or anything not perfect in nobility, nor in any other praiseworthy quality: or, as some say, one driven to generosity against his will: (TA:) and also, (TA,) applied to a man, i. q. muzal~ajN [q. v., app. here meaning deficient in manliness, or manly virtue, or the like]. (S, TA.) [Alz~amaAnu Almuzaj~aY, a phrase used by Har, is expl. (p. 429) as meaning Haq~uhu A^ano yuzaj~iyhi Aln~aAsu, i. e. Time that requires men to push it on, or to make it to pass away by means-of exertion.]
mizojaA='N * A man who urges on much the camel, or beast, that he rides. (TA.)

1 zaH~ahu * , (S, L, K,) aor.
zaHu3a , (S, L,) inf. n. zaH~N; (L;) and ↓ zaHozaHahu; (L;) He removed him, or it, from his, or its, place: (S, L, K:) and he pushed, or thrust, away, him, or it: (L, K:) or the latter, he removed him, or it, far away; placed, or put, him, or it, at a distance, far away, or far off: (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb:) and the former signifies also he drew, dragged, or pulled, away, him, or it, in haste. (L, K.) You say, ↓ zaHozaHahu Eanohu He removed him, or it, far away; (S, K;) or pushed, or thrust, away; and removed; him, or it; (TA;) from it; (S, K;) i. e. from his, or its, place. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 182], Eani Aln~aAri waA^udoxila Aljan~apa faqado faAza ↓ famano zuHoziHa, i. e. [And he] who shall be removed [from the fire of Hell], or removed far away [therefrom, and made to enter Paradise, shall attain good fortune]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 zaHozaHa * : see above, in three places: -A2- and see also the paragraph here following.

R. Q. 2 tazaHozaHa *
He, or it, removed, or became removed; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) and (Mgh, Msb) removed, or became removed, far away: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and accord. to Es-Semeen, ↓ zaHozaHa is likewise used in an intrans. sense, as well as a trans.; but MF says that its use in an intrans. sense is strange. (TA.) You say, daxalotu EalaY fulaAnK fatazaHozaHa liY Eano majolisihi, i. e. [I went in to such a one, and] he removed [for me from his sitting-place]. (Mgh, Msb. *)

zaHozaHN *
Distance: so in the saying, huwa bizaHozaHK minohu [He, or it, is at a distance from him, or it]. (S, K.) Az says that, accord. to some, this is a reduplicative word from zaAHa, aor. yaziyHu, meaning taA^ax~ara; and some hold it to be from Alz~awoHu meaning “ the driving vehemently, ” as also Al*~awoHu. (TA.)

zaHozaAHN *
Distant; remote. (K.)

mutazaHozaHN *
A place to which one removes, or may remove, [in an absolute sense, as is implied in the A, or] far away. (Ham p. 655.) One says, maAliY Eanohu mutazaHozaHN [There is not for me any place to which to remove from him, or it]. (A.)

1 zaHara * , aor.
zaHara , and
zaHira , (K,) inf. n. zaHiyrN (A, K) and zuHaArN and zuHaArapN, (K,) He emitted the voice, (K, * TA,) or (K, TA, in the CK “ and, ”) the breath, with a moaning; (A, K;) [or he breathed hard; as appears from what follows;] in work, or labour, or in difficulty. (TA.) You say, samiEotu lahu zaHiyrFA [I heard him breathe hard; or emit the voice, or the breath, with a moaning]. (A.) And of a woman bringing forth, you say, zaHarato, aor.
zaHara and
zaHira , inf. n. zaHiyrN, She breathed hard. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zaHara said of a niggardly man, (assumed tropical:) He, being begged of, deemed the begging grievous, or troublesome, (K, TA,) and moaned thereat. (TA.) ― -b3- zaHara, (A, K,) aor.
zaHara and
zaHira , (K,) inf. n. zaHiyrN (S, A, K) and zuHaArN (S, K) and zuHaArapN; (K;) [and app. zuHira also; (see mazoHuwrN;)] and ↓ tzH~r; (A, K;) and ↓ zH~r, inf. n. tazoHiyrN; (K;) [all signify] He was, or became, affected with a looseness of the bowels: (S, A:) or with a violent looseness of the bowels, and with a griping pain in the belly, and a discharge of blood. (K.) ― -b4- And zaHarato bihi A^um~uhu, and Eanohu ↓ tzH~zt, (tropical:) His mother brought him forth. (A, K.) -A2- zaHarahu biAlr~umoHi, accord. to the K, signifies He broke, or clave, his head with the spear: but IDrd says that this is not of established authority. (TA.) -A3- zuHira, like EuniYa, He was, or became, niggardly, or tenacious. (K.)

2 zaH~ara see 1. -A2- zH~r Aln~aAqapa, inf. n. tazoHiyrN, He put a ball (kurap) into a nose-bag (mixolaAp), and inserted it into the vulva of the she-camel whose young one had died during the period between the time [that should have been that] of bringing him forth and a month of the last part thereof, [i. e. during the last month of her proper period of gestation,] and left it for a night, having stopped up her nose, then drew forth the ball, having prepared another young camel, which he then showed to her, the nose being still stopped up, whereupon she thought that it was her young one, and that she had at that time brought it forth, then he unstopped her nose, and brought it near, and she affected it, and yielded her milk. (K, TA.)
3 zAHrhu * (tropical:) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility, (A, K, TA,) and behaved angrily (Ainotafaxa) to him. (TA.)

5 tazaH~ara see 1, in two places. ― -b2- huwa yatazaH~aru bimaAlihi $uHFA (assumed tropical:) [He yields his property with pain, (app. from tazaH~arato said of a woman in child-birth,) by reason of niggardliness]; as though he moaned, and strained himself; or moaned, being niggardly. (TA.)
zuHarN * : see zaH~aArN.
zaHorapN * [inf. n. of un. of zaHara; An emission [of the voice or] of the breath with a moaning: (A:) [or a hard breathing: (see 1:) it is said to be] like zaforapN [q. v.]. (TA.)
zaHoraAnu * : see zaH~aArN.

zuHaArN * [an inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Also] A certain disease that affects the camel, (K, TA,) in consequence of which he suffers from a violent looseness of the bowels, until, or so that, the extremity of his rectum turns inside-out, and nothing comes forth from it. (TA.)

zaH~aArN * [One who breathes hard; (this meaning being indicated, though not expressed, in the S;) or who emits the voice, or the breath, with a moaning: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) Niggardly; tenacious; who moans on being
begged of; (TA; [in which it is said to be with damm; but this is a mistake, occasioned by an incorrect point in the L;]) as also ↓ zuHarN and ↓ zaHoraAnu and ↓ mazoHuwrN. (K, * TA.) A poet says,
waEinoda Alfaqori zaH~aArFA A^unaAnaA
A^araAka jamaEota masoA^alapF waHiroSFA
[I see thee to have combined begging and covetousness, and in poverty to be niggardly, with moaning]: (S, TA: in the former thus, in two copies, in the present art. and in art. An: in the TA zuH~aArFA:) A^unaAnFA is said by IB to be [here] an inf. n. of A^an~a, like A^aniynFA. (TA.)

mazoHuwrN * A man affected with a looseness, or with a violent looseness, of the bowels, and with a griping pain in the belly, and a discharge of blood. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

1 zaHafa * , aor.
zaHafa , inf. n. zaHofN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zuHuwfN (Msb, K) and zaHafaAnN, (K,) He, or it, (an army, Mgh, Msb, * or a company of men, Msb) walked, marched, or went on foot, A_ilayohi [to him, or it]; (S, K;) and [generally] did so by little and little; (accord. to an explanation of zaHofN in the TA;) crept, or crawled, along; or went, or walked, leisurely, or gently: (Mgh:) and ↓ tzH~f A_ilayohi, (S, K,) as also ↓ AzdHf, (K,) i. q. tm$~Y, (S, K,) i. e. he walked [with slow steps, or] heavily, with an effort, to him, or it: (TK:) and mi$oyapu zaHafaAnK means a gait in which is a heaviness of motion. (TA.) One says of a child, before he walks, (S, Msb, K,) or before he stands, (T, TA,) yazoHafu [He drags himself along] (S, Msb, K) EalaY AlA^aroDi [upon the ground], or EalaY A@sotihi [upon his posteriors]: (TA:) or zaHafa alone, said of a child, he went along slowly, by little and little, upon his posteriors: (Bd in viii. 15:) and to the zaHof of children is likened the marching of two bodies of men going to meet each other for fight, when each of them marches gently, or leisurely, towards the other, before they draw near together to smite each other: and one says likewise of a child, before he walks, EalaY ↓ yatazaH~afu AlA^aroDi, or, as in the T, EalaY baTonihi, i. e. he drags himself along [upon the ground, or upon his belly]. (TA.) ― -b2- zaHafa Ald~abaA [The young locusts not yet winged] went on, or forwards: (S, O, K:) ma$aY in this explanation in the K should be maDaY, as in the S and A. (TA.) ― -b3- zaHafa said of an arrow, (assumed tropical:) It fell short of the butt, and then slid along to it. (S, * Msb.) ― -b4- Also, said of a camel, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zaHafa , inf. n. zaHofN and zuHuwfN, and zaHafaAnN, (TA,) He became fatigued, and dragged his foot, or the extremity of his foot; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^azoHafu: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or this latter signifies he (a camel) became fatigued, (K, TA,) and stood still with his master: and raAHilatuhu mina AlA_iEoyaA='i ↓ A^azoHafato His saddle-camel stood still from fatigue: or, accord. to El-Khattábee, correctly, A^uzoHifato Ealayohi: (TA:) or this is a mistake, occurring in the Fáïk; and it is correctly with fet-h: (Mgh:) and accord. to the T, zaHafa signifies he (a camel) became fatigued, so that he stood still with his master: (TA:) or, as some say, zaHafa said of one walking, or marching, [i. e., of a man and of a beast,] (Msb, TA,) accord. to AZ, whether fat or lean, (Msb,) aor.
zaHafa , inf. n. zaHofN and zaHafaAnN, or, as AZ says, zaHofN and zuHuwfN, (TA,) signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also, (TA,) he became fatigued, (Msb, TA,) in walking, or marching. (TA.) ― -b5- And zaHafa Al$~ajaru (tropical:) The trees became in a state of gentle motion, by the influence of the wind. (TA.) -A2- zaHafa Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. zaHofN, He dragged the thing along gently. (TA.)
2 zH~f Albayota biAlz~aH~aAfapi * [He swept the house, or chamber, with the zH~Afp, q. v.]. (TA.)
3 zaAHafuwnaA * , inf. n. muzaAHafapN, They fought with us. (TA.)

4 A^azoHafa see 1, in the latter half, in two places. ― -b2- A^azoHafa said of a man means His camel, or his horse or the like, became fatigued. (S.) ― -b3- AzHf lanaA banuw fulaAnK The sons of such a one became a zaHof to us, (K, TA,) i. e., an army marching to us to fight with us. (TA.) ― -b4- And AzHf fulaAnN Such a one attained to the utmost of that which he sought, or desired. (K, * TA.) -A2- AzHf said of long journeying, It fatigued the camels. (TA.) ― -b2- AzHft Alr~iyHu Al$~ajara (tropical:) The wind put the trees into a state of gentle motion. (TA.)
5 tazaH~afa see 1, in the former half, in two places.

6 tzAHfwA *
They drew near, one to another, in fight. (IDrd, Z, K.) They walked, or marched, one to, or towards, another; as also ↓ AzdHfwA. (TA.)
8 AzdHf * [originally AizotaHafa]: see 1, first sentence: and see also 6.

zaHofN *
An army, or a military force, marching by little and little, or leisurely, to, or towards, the enemy, (S, A, K, TA,) or heavily, by reason of their multitude and force: (A, TA:) or a numerous army or military force; an inf. n. used as a subst.; (Mgh, Msb;) because, by reason of its multitude, and heaviness of motion, it is as though it crept, or crawled, along: (Mgh:) accord. to Az, from zaHafa EalaY A@sotihi, said of a child: (TA:) not applied to a single individual: (IKoot, Msb:) pl. zuHuwfN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A swarm of locusts. (TA.) ― -b3- far~a mina Alz~aHofi, occurring in a trad., means He fled from war with unbelievers; and from encountering the enemy in war. (TA.) ― -b4- A_i*aA laqiytumu A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA zaHofFA, in the Kur [viii. 15], means, accord. to Zj, zaAHifiyna, i. e. [When ye meet those who have disbelieved] marching by little and little [in consequence of their great number, to attack you]. (TA.)

zaHofapN * [inf. n. of un. of 1; A walk, &c.]. ― -b2- naAru Alz~aHofatayoni The fire of the $iyH and the A^alaA='; because it quickly blazes in them [and then subsides]; (S, K;) so that one walks, or creeps, from them [and back to them]: (S:) or the fire of the Earofaj; (M, A;) because it quickly takes effect upon it; so that when it blazes, those who warm themselves at it walk, or creep, from it; then it soon subsides, and they walk, or creep, back to it: (M, TA:) and the like is said by IB; wherefore, he adds, it is called A^abuw sariyEK. (TA.) It was said to a woman of the Arabs, “ Wherefore do we see you to be scant of flesh in the posteriors and thighs? ” and she answered, A^arosaHatonaA naAru Alz~aHofatayoni [The fire of the $iyH and the A^alaA=', or of the Earofaj, has rendered us scant of flesh in the posteriors and thighs]. (S.)
zuHafapN * , (K,) or zuHafapN zuHalapN, A man (TA) who does not travel about in the countries: (K, TA:) so in the Moheet. (TA.)
zaHuwfN * : see zaAHifN, in two places. ― -b2- [Also, accord. to Freytag, occurring in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Going along slowly.]

zaH~aAfapN * , in the dial. of Egypt, signifies maA yuzaH~afu bihi Albayotu [i. e. The thing, generally a palm-branch, with which the house, or chamber, is swept, to remove the dust and cobwebs from the roof and walls]. (TA.)

zaHanofafapN * One who creeps along (yazoHafu) upon the ground, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) either from fatigue or old age. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A man (TA) whose heel-tendons nearly knock against each other. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.)

zaAHifN * [part. n. of 1; Walking, &c.]. ― -b2- (tropical:) An arrow that falls short of the butt, and then slides along to it: (S, * Msb, TA: *) pl. zawaAHifu. (Msb.) ― -b3- A camel fatigued, and dragging his foot, or the extremity of his foot; (K;) as also ↓ zaAHifapN, in which the p is added to denote intensiveness: (Msb:) or the latter is applied, in the sense expl. above, to a she-camel; (S, K;) and so ↓ zaHuwfN; (K;) or this last signifies a she-camel that drags her hind legs or feet: and ↓ muzoHifN, applied to a he-camel, has the former of these meanings: (S:) [see also saHuwfN, said to be a dial. var. of zaHuwfN:] the pl. of ↓ zaAHifapN is zawaAHifu; (S, Msb, K;) and the pl. of ↓ zaHuwfN is zuHufN. (TA.) Also Fatigued and motionless; whatever it be, whether lean or fat; and so ↓ muzoHifN. (TA.) And, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, [simply] Fatigued; (TA;) and so ↓ muzoHifN; applied to a camel: (K:) or the latter, so applied, signifies fatigued, and standing still with his owner: the former is applied to the male and to the female; and its pl. is zawaAHifu: it is said to be also the name of a certain camel; but Th denies this. (TA.)
zaAHifapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mazoHafN * : see mazoHafapN.
muzoHifN * : see zaAHifN, in three places. ― -b2- saHaAbN muzoHifN (tropical:) Clouds moving slowly, because carrying much water; likened to fatigued camels. (TA.)

mazoHafapN * a n. of place, sing. of mazaAHifu, (TK,)
which signifies The places of the creeping of serpents; (S, K, TA;) and the marks, or tracks, of the passage thereof: (TA:) and ↓ mazoHafN, likewise signifies the mark, or track, of a serpent, upon the ground; like masoHafN. (TA in art. sHf.) ― -b2- mazaAHifu also signifies The places of fighting of a party, or people. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The places of pouring [of the water] of the clouds; (TA;) the places where falls the rain of the clouds. (K, TA. [In the CK, Als~aHaAbu is erroneously put for Als~aHaAbi.])

mizoHaAfN * A camel wont, or accustomed, to become fatigued, (S, K, TA,) and to drag his foot, or the extremity of his foot, (S,) or to stand still with his owner: (TA:) or (tropical:) a she-camel that quickly becomes attenuated, or chafed, or abraded, or worn, in the sole of the foot: (A, TA:) pl. mazaAHiyfu (S, TA) and mazaAHifu. (TA.)

1 zaHala * , (S, K,) aor.
zaHala , (K,) inf. n. zuHuwlN (S, K) and zaHolN (Ham p. 125) and mazoHalN, (S,) He removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance; (S, K, TA, and Ham ubi suprà;) and went back or backwards, drew back, receded, or retreated; (TA;) Eano makaAnihi [from his place]; as also ↓ tzH~l. (S, K.) Hence, in a trad., AizoHalo Ean~iY faqado nazaHotaniY, meaning [Remove thou, &c., from me,] for thou hast exhausted me of what I possessed. (TA.) And yazoHalu Eani AlA^amuwri (K, TA, in the CK AlA^amori,) He removes, withdraws, or retires far away, from affairs. (TA.) ― -b2- And He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote. (TA.) ― -b3- And zaHala Eano maqaAmihi, aor.
zaHala , (K,) inf. n. zaHolN and zuHuwlN and mazoHalN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) quitted its station, or standing-place; (K, TA;) as also ↓ tazaHowala: (K:) in some copies of the K, in the explanation of this phrase, zal~a is put in the place of zaAla. (TA.) ― -b4- And zaHalato She (a camel) held back, hung back, or lagged behind, in her course, or journeying. (K.) ― -b5- And zaHala He (a man, TA) was, or became, fatigued, tired, or jaded. (K, TA.)
2 zaH~ala see what next follows.

4 AzHlhu *
He removed him, or it, far away; as also ↓ zH~lhu, inf. n. tazoHiylN. (K.) ― -b2- And AzHlhu A_ilayohi (tropical:) He, or it, constrained him to betake himself, or repair, or have recourse, to him, or it. (K, TA.)
5 tazaH~ala see 1, first sentence.

Q. Q. 1 zaHowalahu Eano makaAnihi *
He made him, or it, to slip (A^azal~ahu, [probably a mistranscription for A^azaAlahu he removed him, or it, like as zal~a is put in some copies of the K in the place of zaAla in a case mentioned above,]) from his, or its, place. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2 tazaHowala * [quasi-pass. of Q. Q. 1]: see 1.
zaHilN * and ↓ ziHoliylN Removing, withdrawing, or retiring to a distance; (S, K, TA;) and going back or backwards, drawing back, receding, or retreating; (TA;) from a place. (S, K, TA.)

zuHalN * A man who removes, withdraws, or retires far away, from affairs, (K, * TA,) whether they be good or evil: (TA:) fem. with p. (K.) -A2- zuHalu, imperfectly decl., (S, K,) like Eumaru, (S,) because it is a proper name and deviates from the original form [which is app. Alz~aAHilu, reg. part. n. of 1], (Mbr, TA,) [The planet Saturn;] a certain star, of those called Alxun~asu; (S, K;) so called because it is remote; and said to be in the Seventh Heaven. (TA.) gulaAmu zuHala [The young man, or slave, of Saturn] is [a surname of] Abu-l-Kásim the well-known astronomer or astrologer. (K.)
zuHalapN * A man who does not travel about in the countries. (K.) [See also zuHafapN.] ― -b2- And A certain beast that enters its hole with its hinder part foremost. (K.)
ziHal~N * A camel that drives far away the [other] camels, pressing against them so as to remove them, in the coming to water, and then drinks. (K.)
zuHoluwlN * : see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also Light in body. (TA.)

ziHoliylN * : see zaHilN. ― -b2- Also Quick, or swift: (K:) mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.) ― -b3- And A place that is strait and slippery, consisting of smooth stones; as also ↓ zuHoluwlN: (K:) and so ziHoliyfN. (Aboo-Málik, TA.)

naAqapN zaHuwlN *
A she-camel which, when she comes to the watering-trough, and the driver (Al*~aAy^idu, in the copies of the K erroneously written Alr~aAy^idu, TA) strikes her face, turns her rump to him, and ceases not to recede until she comes to the water-ing-trough. (Lth, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And EuqobapN zaHuwlN [in the CK erroneously written EaqabapN, A stage of a journey] far-extending. (K, TA.)

zayoHalapN *
A proud and self-conceited gait. (K.)

mazoHalN * an inf. n. of zaHala. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And also A place to which one removes, withdraws, or retires far away. (S, TA.) Ibráheem Ibn-Kuneyf En-Nebhánee says,
wamaA liA@moriy^K Eam~aA qaDaY A@ll~`hu mazoHalu
i. e. And there is not, for a man, a place to which to go far away from that which God has decreed. (Ham p. 125.) And one says, A_in~a liY Einodaka lamazoHalFA, meaning munotadaHFA [i. e. Verily there is, for me, with thee, ample scope, or freedom, or liberty]. (S, TA.)

Q. 1 zaHolafahu * , (S, K,) inf. n. zaHolafapN, (S,) He rolled him, or it, down or along. (S, K.) ― -b2- And He pushed, impelled, repelled, or drove away, or back, him, or it. (S, K.) [Hence,] one says, zaHolafa A@ll~`hu Ean~aA $ar~aka May God put away, or ward off, from us thy mischief. (TA.) ― -b3- zaHolafa lifulaAnK A^alofFA He gave to such a one a thousand. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- zaHolafa AlA_inaA='a He filled the vessel. (Sgh, K.) ― -b5- zaHolafa fiY AlkalaAmi He hastened, or was quick, in speech. (Sgh, K.)

Q. 2 tazaHolafa *
He, or it, rolled down or along. (S, * K, * TA.) One says, yatazaHolafuwna fiyhi [They roll down it]; namely, a smoothed descending, or sloping, place. (IAar, T, S.) ― -b2- And He, or it, became pushed, impelled, repelled, or driven away or back. (S, K.) [Hence,] El-Ajjáj says,
waAl$~amosu qado kaAdato takuwnu danafaA
A^adofaEuhaA biAlr~aAHi kaYo tazaHolafaA
[And the sun had almost become near to setting, and to turning yellow; I repelling it with the palm of the hand in order that it might be warded off; tazaHolafaA being for tatazaHolafa]. (S.) See also the next paragraph. ― -b3- One says also tazaHolafati Al$~amosu meaning The sun inclined to setting: or declined from the meridian, at midday. (TA.)

Q. 4 AizoHalaf~a * , as also AizolaHaf~a, (Mgh, K,) He was, or became, far; he stood, or kept, aloof; (A 'Obeyd, Mgh, TA;) he removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance; (A 'Obeyd, Mgh, K, TA;) as also ↓ tazaHolafa; (TA;) Eano ka*aA from such a thing: (Mgh:) for ex., from adultery, or fornication. (A 'Obeyd, Mgh, TA.)

zuHoluwfN *
Smooth rock: to which is likened the portion of flesh and sinew bordering the backbone, when fat. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

ziHoliyfN *
A slippery place. (TA.) [See also what next follows: and see ziHoliylN.]

zuHoluwfapN * The traces of the sliding of children from the top to the bottom of a hill: (As, S, K:) of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh: in the dial. of Temeem, with q [in the place of f]: (S:) or [a sloping slide, or rolling-place; i. e.] a smoothed descending, or sloping, place; (IAar, S, K;) because they roll down it (yatazaHolafuwna fiyhi): (S:) or a slippery place of a mountain of sands, upon which children play; and likewise on smooth rock: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) pl. zaHaAliyfu and zaHaAlifu. (S.)

zaHaAlifu * a pl. of zuHoluwfapN. (S.) ― -b2- HumurN zaHaAlifu AlS~uqoli Asses having smooth and fat bellies. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) -A2- Also Small dawaAb~ [i. e. reptiles, or insects], having legs, that walk, resembling ants: (K:) or, as in the O, having legs resembling ants. (TA.)

[
mutazaHolifN * , accord. to Freytag, occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning Smooth, applied to rock.]
Q. 1 zaHolaqapN * [inf. n. of zaHolaqa] The rolling [a thing] down; syn. daHorajapN. (S, K.) You say, zaHolaqa AlHajara, i. e. daHorajahu [He rolled down the stone]. (TK.)

Q. 2 tazaHolaqa *
He, or it, rolled down; syn. tadaHoraja: (S, K:) or he slid, or slipped, upon his posteriors. (TA.)
ziHoliqN * A violent wind. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
ziHoliyqN * : see the next paragraph.

zuHoluwqapN *
i. q. zuHoluwfapN; (S, * K;) meaning [A sloping slide, or rolling-place; or] the traces of the sliding of children from above to below: (TA:) of the dial. of Temeem: pl. zaHaAliyqu: (S:) which likewise signifies slippery places; as also ↓ ziHoliyqN. (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A grave: (K, TA:) because one slips into it. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. A^urojuwHapN; i. e. [A seesaw;] a piece of wood [or a plank] which children lay upon an elevated place, and a number sit upon one end of it, and a number upon the other [end]; and when one of the two parties is heavier, the other rises, and threatens to fall; whereupon they [app. who are looking on] call out to them, A^alaA xal~uwA A^alaA xal~uwA [Now leave ye! now leave ye what ye are doing!]. (K. [See also A^urojuwHapN.])
muzaHolaqN * [Rolled down: see Q. 1. ― -b2- And] Smooth. (TA.)

1 zaHamahu * , (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
zaHama , inf. n. zaHomN (Msb, K) and zaHomapN (Msb) and ziHaAmN, with kesr; (K; [but see what here follows, and see also zaHomapN below;] and ↓ zAHmhu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. muzaAHamapN (Msb, TA) and ziHaAmN; (Msb;) i. q. DaAyaqahu [i. e. He straitened him, meaning, in this instance, by pressure; and properly, being in like manner straitened by him]: (K in explanation of zaHamahu, and TA in explanation of zAHmhu:) or i. q. dafaEahu [he pushed him, or repelled him]; generally meaning [he pushed against him] in a strait, or narrow, [or crowded,] place: (Msb in explanation of zaHamahu, and app. in explanation of zAHmhu also:) [or i. q. daAfaEahu, which often signifies the same as dafaEahu; but more properly, he pushed him, &c., being pushed, &c., by him: for] zaHamaniYa Aln~aAsu means daAfaEuwniY [i. e. The people pushed against me; or pushed me, &c., being pushed, &c., by me;] in a strait, or narrow, [or crowded,] place: (Mgh:) [or pressed, crowded, or thronged, me:] and muzaAHamapN is syn. with mudaAfaEapN: (TA in art. dfE:) ↓ AizodaHamahu in the place of zaHamahu is a mistake. (Mgh.) One says, zaHama Alqawomu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA The people straitened one another; syn. taDaAyaquwA; [or pressed, crowded, or thronged, one another;] in a sitting-place, or place of assembly: (Msb:) as also ↓ AzdHmwA, (Msb, K, * TA,) in whatever place it be; (Msb;) and ↓ tzAHmwA. (K, * TA.) One may also use the pass. form of zaHama, i. e. zuHima [meaning He was straitened, by pressure; &c.]; and that of zaAHama, i. e. ↓ zuwHima [meaning the same]. (Msb.) -A2- ↓ zaHima zuHomapF He gobbled a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful: so in the “ Nawádir; ” as also zahimahaA. (TA.) 3: see above, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, zaAHama EalaY Alr~iy^aAsapi waA^araAdahaA (assumed tropical:) [He strove for headship, or command, and desired it]. (IAar, TA in art. rA^s.) [And hence the prov. zaAHim biEawodK A^awo daEo: see art. Ewd.] ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] zAHmhu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He treated him, or behaved towards him, with roughness, rudeness, hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (TA. [I find this explanation noted down by me as taken from the TA, but without any reference to the art. from which I obtained it. It is not in the present art.]) ― -b4- zAHm Alxamosiyna He (a man, TA) approached, (K, TA,) and reached, or attained, (TA,) the [age of] fifty [years]; (K, TA;) as also zaAhamahaA. (TA.)
6 tazaAoHama see 1, and 8. ― -b2- tzAHmt AlA^amowaAju and ↓ AzdHmt The waves dashed against each other. (TA.) See a verse cited below, voce zaHomN.

8 A_izotaHama see 1, in two places; and see also an ex. in a verse cited below, voce zaHomN. One says also, AzdHmwA EalaY ka*aA and Ealayohi ↓ tzAHmwA [They pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together, upon, or against, such a thing]. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, by way of metaphor, AzdHm AlguramaA='u (tropical:) [The creditors were, or became, numerous and pressing]. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also 6.

zaHomN * [originally an inf. n.,] i. q. qawomN muzodaHimuwna [A party, or company of men, straitening one another by pressure; pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging, one another; i. e. a press, crowd, or throng]. (K, * TA.) A poet says,
↓ jaA='a bizaHomK maEa zaHomK faA@zodaHamo
Almawoji A_i*aA Almawoju A@lotaTamo ↓ tazaAHuma
[He brought a crowd with a crowd, and they pressed, one against another, like the dashing together of the waves when the waves beat one another]: he uses [here] an inf. n. not conformable to the verb. (ISd, TA.)

zuHomN * , with damm, a name of Mekkeh: (K, * TA:) so says Th: but ISd says that the name commonly known is ruHom [or A^um~u ruHomK or A^um~u Alr~uHomi]: (TA:) or it is A^um~u Alz~uHomi [probably, I think, a mistranscription for A^um~u Alr~uHomi]. (K, TA.)

zaHomapN * [an inf. n. of zaHamahu accord. to the Msb] i. q. ↓ ziHaAmN [likewise an inf. n. of zaHamahu accord. to the K, and of zaAHamahu accord. to the Msb: both signify A straitening, pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging]. (S.) ― -b2- zaHomapu AlwilaAdapi The moaning, or hard breathing, (zaHorap,) with which the child comes forth; as also zajomap and zakomap. (K in the present art. and in art. zjm.)

zuHomapN *
A gobbet, morsel, or mouthful. (TA.) See 1, last sentence.
ziHaAmN * : see zaHomapN.

mizoHamN *
i. q. kaviyru Alz~iHaAmi or $adiyduhu [i. e. One who straitens, pushes, presses, crowds, or throngs, much or vehemently]. (K.) Hence, manokibN mizoHamN [A shoulder that pushes vehemently]. (TA.)

huwa say~idu qawomihi gayoru muzaAHamK *
i. q. gayoru mudaAfaEK, (K in art. dfE, q. v.)

muzaAHimN * , (T, TA,) or A^abuw muzaAHimK, (T, K, TA,) or Aibonu muzaAHimK, (M, TA,) The elephant: (T, M, K:) and a bull having horns: so in the T, on the authority of IAar: (TA:) or a bull having the horns broken. (M, K, TA) ― -b2- muzaAHimN is also the name of A certain horse. (K, * TA.)

1 zax~ahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
zaxu3a , inf. n. zax~N, (TA,) He pushed him, or thrust him, (S, A,) or made him to fall, (K,) into a depressed place, or a deep hollow or cavity: (S, A, K:) [or he pushed him, or thrust him, in any manner; for] zax~N signifies, accord. to IDrd, any pushing, or thrusting. (TA.) You say, zux~a fiY Aln~aAri, (A,) or zux~a bihi fiY Aln~aAri, He was pushed, or thrust, and thrown, or cast, into the fire [of Hell]. (TA.) And zux~a fiY qafaAhu (A, TA) He was pushed, or thrust, on the back of his neck: or he was pushed, or thrust, on the back of his neck, and expelled. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of Aboo-Moosà, mano yat~abiEi AlquroA=na yahobiTo bihi EalaY riyaADi Aljan~api wamano yat~abiEohu AlquroA=nu yazux~a fiY qafaAhu Hat~aY yaqo*ifa bihi fiY naAri jahan~ama [Whosoever follows the Kur-án as his guide, it will make him to alight upon the gardens, or meadows, of Paradise; and whomsoever the Kur-án follows as a punisher, it will push, or thrust, upon the back of his neck, until it shall cast him into the fire of Hell]. (S.) One says also of lambs or kids, tuzax~u, meaning They are driven; and impelled from behind them. (TA.) And of a driver, zax~a AlA_ibila He drove the camels quickly, and urged them on. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zax~a bibawolihi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He cast forth his urine; (K, TA;) and propelled it. (TA.) And zax~ato biAlmaA='i, and zax~ati AlmaA='a, She (a woman) ejected the [seminal] fluid. (TA. [See zax~aAxapN.]) ― -b3- Hence also, (TA,) zax~a AlmaroA^apa, (S, * A, * K,) aor. as above, (S, A,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He compressed the woman; (A, K;) as also ↓ zaxozaxahaA, (K,) inf. n. zixozaAxN. (TA.) ― -b4- And zax~ahu biAlr~umoHi i. q. zaj~ahu [He pierced him, or thrust him, with the pointed iron foot of the spear]; like zalaxahu. (TA in art. zlx.) ― -b5- And zax~a, (K,) and zax~a binafosihi, (TA,) [as though meaning “ he propelled himself, ”] He leaped: (K, TA:) thus, sometimes a man leaps a nahor [here meaning a rivulet for irrigation], putting his misoHaAp in the middle of it. (TA.) ― -b6- And zax~a, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He went quickly; [as though propelling himself:] (TA:) he (a driver) went, or journeyed, a violent, or rigorous, pace. (K, TA.) -A2- zax~a, (S, K,) [aor., accord. to analogy,
zaxi3a ,] inf. n. as above, (S,) He (a man) was, or became, angered, or enraged. (S, K. [See also zax~apN.]) -A3- zax~a Aljamoru, (S, A, K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, Alxamoru, (TA,) aor.
zaxi3a , (S, K,) with kesr, (S,) and
zaxu3a , with damm, [which is anomalous,] (TA,) inf. n. zaxiyxN (S, * A, * K) and zax~N, (K,) The live coals glistened: (K:) or glistened vehemently: (S, A:) and in like manner, AlHariyru [the silk]. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 zaxozaxa AlmaroA^apa * : see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
zax~N * : see the next paragraph.

zax~apN * : see mazax~apN. -A2- Also, (S, L,) and ↓ zax~N, (L,) [or the former is a simple subst. and the latter is an inf. n., (see 1, last sentence but one,)] Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and anger, or rage: (S, L:) but zax~apN is said to have been heard in this sense only in a verse of Sakhrel-Gheí. (TA.)

zux~apN * The young ones of sheep or goats: of the measure fuEolapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; like quboDapN and gurofapN; so called liA^an~ahaA tuzax~u, i. e. because they are driven, and impelled from behind them: from these, it is said in a trad. that no contribution to the poor-rates is to be taken. (TA.)
zax~aA='u * : see what next follows.
zax~aAxapN * A woman who ejects the [seminal] fluid on the occasion of jimaAE; (K, TA;) as also ↓ zax~aA='u. (TA.)

mazax~apN * The vulva of a woman; (K, TA;) because it is the place of Alz~ax~u. (TA. [See zax~a AlmaroA^apa.]) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A wife; (S, A, K;) as though she were the place of Alz~ax~u; (TA;) as also ↓ mizax~apN and ↓ zax~apN. (K.)
mizax~apN * : see what next precedes.

1 zaxara * , (S, A, K,) aor.
zaxara , inf. n. zaxorN and zuxuwrN (K) and zaxiyrN, so in the A, (TA,) It (the sea) became full; or rose, and became full; as also ↓ tzx~z: (K:) or both, said of the sea, its flow, or tide, rose, or became full: (JK, A:) or the former, [or each,] said of the sea, it increased, and its water became abundant, and its waves rose. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a valley) flowed with much water, which rose high: (S, K:) it flowed copiously, and its torrent became full: or it flowed with abundance of water, and its waves rose. (TA.) ― -b3- zaxarati Alqidoru, (K,) aor.
zaxara , inf. n. zaxorN, (TA,) The cooking-pot boiled, or began to do so: (K, TA:) and in like manner, AlHarobu [war, or the war; i. e. raged, or began to do so]. (A, * K.) And zaxara Alqawomu The people, or party, became in a state of commotion for the purpose of going forth to execute some affair, (AA, JK, K, TA,) or for war. (JK, A, K.) ― -b4- [zaxarati Alr~iyHu The wind blew strongly, or vehemently. (Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.)] ― -b5- zaxara said of a plant, or herbage, It became high, or tall; (A, K;) and so said of anything. (JK.) ― -b6- And, said of a man, He boasted (As, A, K) bimaA Einodahu [of what he possessed], (As, K,) or bimaA layosa Einodahu [of what he did not possess]; (A;) as also ↓ tazaxowara: (K:) or this latter signifies he magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; and threatened. (TA.) -A2- zaxara, (K,) inf. n. zaxorN, (TA,) He filled a thing. (K.) ― -b2- It (the herb, or herbage,) fattened, and rendered comely, the cattle. (JK, K.) ― -b3- He caused a man to be affected with emotion [app. by reason of mirth or joy]; syn. A^aToraba. (JK, K.) ― -b4- zaxarati Alr~iyHu Als~aHaAba The wind drove along the clouds. (JK.) ― -b5- zaxara Ald~iq~a i. q. A^a*oraAhu fiY Alr~iyHi [He threw, or scattered, the fine part, or particles, (accord. to the TK the flour and bran,) in the wind], (JK, K, TA,) with the mi*ar~ap [or instrument with which grain is scattered]. (TA.) -A3- See also what next follows.
3 zaAoxara ↓ zaAxarotuhu fazaxarotuhu I vied with him in boasting, and surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (JK, A, K. *)
5 tazax~ara see 1, first sentence.
Q. Q. 2 tazaxowara * : see 1.

zaxorapN * [Fulness of the sea]. One says, raA^ayotu AlbiHaAra falamo A^ara A^agolaba minohu zaxorapF waAljibaAla falamo A^ara A^aSolaba minohu SaxorapF [I have seen the seas, but I have not seen one more surpassing in fulness than he is in bountifulness; and the mountains, but I have not seen one more firm in rock than he is in heart]. (A.)
zuxoriY~N * , applied to a plant, or herbage, &c., (TA,) Tall; (JK, K, TA;) as also ↓ zuxaAriY~N. (JK.)
zixoriy~apN * , (JK,) or zixoriyapN, like hiboriyapN, (O, TA,) A plant, or herbage, full-grown; (IDrd, JK, O, TA;) as also ↓ zixoriyrN. (JK.)
zixoriyrN * : see what next precedes.

[
zaxuwrN * A wind blowing violently. (Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.)]
zaxowarN * : see the next paragraph.

zuxaAriY~N * A plant, or herbage, full-grown, full of juice, luxuriant, or abundant and dense, (K, TA,) and in blossom; (TA;) as also ↓ zaxowariY~N and ↓ zaxowarN. (K, TA.) See also zuxoriY~N. ― -b2- makaAnN zuxaAriY~u Aln~abaAti [A place having its plants, or herbage, full-grown, full of juice, luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and in blossom]. (S.) ― -b3- And zuxaAriY~u Aln~abaAti The blossoms, and the beauty and brightness, of plants, or herbage. (K.) [Hence,] A^axa*a zuxaAriy~ahu It (a plant, or herbage,) blossomed: (JK:) or became luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and put forth its blossoms; as also jun~a, inf. n. junuwnN: (As, TA:) or obtained its full supply of moisture: (A, TA:) or acquired its due degree of beauty and brightness: (TA:) or became tall. (A.) Also It (any affair, or thing,) became complete, or perfect, and in a sound, or good, state. (A, TA.) And A^axa*ati AlA^aroDu zuxaAriy~ahaA The land had tall herbage: (A, TA:) when such is the case, it is termed A^aroDN ↓ zaAxirapN. (TA.)
zaxowariY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- kalaAmN zaxowariY~N Speech in which is self-magnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence, (JK, K, TA,) and threatening. (TA.)
zax~aArN * : see the next paragraph.

zaAxirN * A sea full, or flowing with much water, and rising high: (S, TA:) and a valley flowing with a copious and high tide of water: and ↓ zax~aArN, also, is applied as an epithet to a sea [in a similar, but intensive, sense]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN baHorN zaAxirN wabadorN zaAhirN (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a full sea, meaning bountiful, and a shining full moon, meaning illustrious]. (A, TA.) The saying of the Hudhalee, describing a woman,
jawaAdN biquwti AlbaToni waAlEiroqu zaAxiru
means Liberal with the food of the belly in the time of hunger, when [the vein is full, and] the blood and the tempers are excited: or it means, and her lineage is high; for the vein of the generous flows fully with generousness. (S, TA.) One says also Eiroquhu zaAxirN meaning (assumed tropical:) He is generous, increasing [in generosity], or abounding [therein]. (AO, S, K, TA.) And zaAxirN signifies High nobility. (AA, K.) ― -b2- See also zuxaAriY~N, last sentence. ― -b3- Also Rejoicing, joyful, glad, or happy. (A, K.)

[
zaAxirapN * a subst. from zaAxirN, rendered such by the affix p.] zawaAxiru [is its pl., and] signifies Watercourses; or channels of water. (JK.) ― -b2- And Herbs: so in the saying, Aikotahalato zawaAxiru AlwaAdiY [The herbs of the valley became tall, full-grown, or of their full height and in blossom]. (A, TA.)

A^azoxaru * [More, and most, full, &c.]. One says, huwa mina AlbuHuwri A^azoxaruhaA wamina Albuduwri A^azoharuhaA (assumed tropical:) [He is, of the seas, the most full, meaning, of the bountiful, the most bountiful; and of the full moons, the most shining, meaning, of the illustrious, the most illustrious]. (A, TA.)

Q. 1 zaxorafapN * signifies The adorning, ornamenting, decorating, or embellishing, of a thing, (KL, and Har p. 3,) primarily, with zuxoruf, i. e. gold: (Har ib.:) and hence, (Har,) the adorning, &c., of falsehood, or a lie: (KL, Har:) and the falsifying or adulterating [of speech &c.]. (KL.) You say, zaxorafa Albayota, inf. n. zaxorafapN, He adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished, the house, or chamber, &c.; and rendered it complete: and zuxorifa is said of anything as meaning It was adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished. (TA.) And zaxorafa AlkalaAma He arranged, or rightly disposed, or put into a right or proper state, the speech, or language: (TA:) and i. q. raq~a$ahu [i. e. he embellished it; generally meaning, with lies]. (S, A, K, in art. rq$.) [This verb is mentioned and explained by Freytag as on the authority of the K, in which it is not found in this art.]

Q. 2 tazaxorafa *
He (a man) adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished, himself. (TA.)

zuxorufN *
Gold: (Fr, S, M, K:) so in the Kur xvii. 95: and this, accord. to ISd, is the primary meaning. (TA.) ― -b2- Then applied to Any orna-
ment, decoration, or embellishment: (ISd, TA:) anything adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished: (Ham p. 784:) and particularly applied to the decorations, and pictured works, in gold, with which the Kaabeh was ornamented in Pagan times. (TA.) The colours of the plants or herbage, of land, (K, TA,) red and yellow and white: its ornature, consisting in blossoms and flowers: or its perfection: so in the Kur x. 25. (TA.) And The furniture, or utensils, of a house or tent. (TA.) ― -b3- Anything varnished, or embellished with a false colouring, or falsified, is likened thereto [and so termed]. (S, TA.) [Hence,] zuxorufu Alqawoli The ornature of speech; (TA;) the fair appearance, or comeliness, of speech, produced by the embellishing with lies: (K, TA:) so in the Kur vi. 112: (TA:) or it there means varnished falsehoods. (Bd.) ― -b4- [Its pl.] zaxaArifu signifies The lines, or streaks, [that are seen on the surface] of water. (S, K.) ― -b5- And Ships: (T, K:) or ornamented, or decorated, ships: (M, TA:) or the ornature of ships, with which they are decorated. ('Eyn, TA.) ― -b6- Also Certain insects that fly upon the water, (T, O, K,) having four legs, resembling the common fly; (O, K;) small flies, having four legs, that fly upon the water: (M, TA:) the sing., zuxorufN, is expl. by Kr [in the Munjid] as meaning a kind of flying thing. (TA.)

muzaxorafN *
Adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished: (S, TA:) [&c.: see the verb.]

1 zar~a * , aor. yazur~u, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zar~N, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He buttoned a shirt [&c.]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) as also ↓ zr~r, inf. n. tazoriyrN; (Mgh; [and so in the present day;]) or the latter verb [relates to several objects, or means he buttoned a shirt &c. with many buttons; for it] has an intensive signification. (Msb.) You say, Auzoruro Ealayoka qamiySaka, and zur~ahu, and zur~ihi, and zur~uhu, Button upon thee thy shirt. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He narrowed his eyes [as when one draws together the edges of a vest in buttoning it]. (K, * [in which, in this instance, as in others, only the inf. n. of the verb zar~a is mentioned,] and TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He collected, or drew together, vehemently, or forcibly. (A, Msb, K *) ― -b4- zar~ahaA [referring to the pieces of cloth composing a tent] He made in them what are called A^azoraAr [pl. of zir~N, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b5- And zar~a, aor. as above, (S, A, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, K,) (tropical:) He drove away. (S, A, K, TA. [In the TA, the inf. n. is expl. by Al$~ak~u as well as AlT~arodu; but the former is a mistranscription for Al$~al~u, the reading in the S.]) One says, huwa yazur~u AlkataAy^iba biAls~ayofi (tropical:) He drives away the troops with the sword. (S, A.) ― -b6- (tropical:) He bit another. (S, * A, K. *) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) He pierced, or thrust, another, (K, TA,) with a spear. (TK.) ― -b8- He plucked out hair. (K, * TA.) ― -b9- He shook goods, or household furniture, or the like, to remove dust &c. (O, K: * only the inf. n. is mentioned in the latter.) -A2- zar~a, (K,) aor. yazir~u, (TA,) He increased in intelligence, (K, TA,) and in probations, or experiences. (TA. [See also zarira, below, in this paragraph.]) -A3- Also, aor. yazir~u, inf. n. zariyrN, It (a spear-head) gleamed, or glistened. (A.) And zar~ato Eayonuhu, aor. tazir~u, (S,) inf. n. zariyrN, (S, K,) His eye gleamed, or glistened. (S, K. *) And EayonaAhu tazr~aAni fiY raA^osihi His eyes gleam, or glisten, in his head. (Fr, S, * A, TA.) -A4- zarira, like samiEa, [by rule zar~a, sec. pers. zarirota, aor. yazar~u,] He acted wrongfully, injuriously, or unjustly, to his adversary, or antagonist. (K.) ― -b2- And He became intelligent after having been foolish, or stupid. (K. [See also a signification of zar~a, above.])
2 zar~a3a see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see also 4.
3 zAr~hu * , (A,) inf. n. muzaAr~apN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He bit him, being bitten by him. (S, * A, K. *)
4 Azr~hu * , (A'Obeyd, S, Msb,) and ↓ zr~rhu, (A,) He put A^azoraAr [i. e. buttons, or, as some say, loops for buttons,] upon it, namely, a shirt [&c.]. (A'Obeyd, S, A, Msb.)

5 tzr~r *
It (a shirt [&c.]) had A^azoraAr [i. e. buttons, or, as some say, loops for buttons,] put upon it. (S, TA.)

R. Q. 1 zarozara * , (S, K,) inf. n. zarozarapN, (TA,) He (a zurozuwr [or starling]) uttered a cry, or cries. (S, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of the zurozuwr. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b3- zarozara biAlmakaAni He continued, or remained fixed, or stationary, in the place. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tazarozara *
He, or it, was, or became, in a state of motion, or commotion. (K.)
zar~N * an inf. n. of zar~a [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K. *) -A2- See also zir~N.
zur~N * : see what next follows.

zir~N * , (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ zur~N, (ISk,) app. in the same sense, (Az,) and ↓ zar~N has been also mentioned, but this is doubtful, (MF,) A button (IAar, A, Msb, TA) of a shirt, (IAar, S, A, Msb, K,) and of other things, as, for instance, of a curtain: (MF, TA:) or the loop into which a button is put: (ISh:) the latter, accord. to Az, is the right meaning: (TA:) [but the former is that to which the word is generally applied:] the former is also called ziyrN, by a change of the first r: (IAar:) pl. [of pauc.] A^azoraArN (S, A, Msb, K) and [of mult.] zuruwrN. (K.) [Hence the saying,] huwa A^alozamu liY mino zir~iY liEurowatihi [He is more fast to me than my button to its loop]. (A.) And A^aEoTaAniyhi bizir~ihi (tropical:) He gave it to me altogether. (A.) ― -b2- Alz~ir~u [The star ξ of Gemini;] one of the two stars called AlhanoEapu. (Kzw.) ― -b3- zir~N also signifies (tropical:) A certain piece of wood at the upper extremity of the pole of a tent: (A, K: *) pl. A^azoraArN: (TA:) the upper end of the tent-pole is inserted into it: (L:) or the AzrAr of a tent (xibaA=') are certain pieces of wood which are sewed into the upper parts of the pieces of cloth which compose the tent, the lower ends of which [pieces of cloth] are upon the ground: and zar~ahaA signifies “ he made in them [namely the said pieces of cloth] such pieces of wood. ” (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The socket in which the head of the upper bone of the arm turns; (A, K; *) resembling the half of a nut: (A:) or the head itself of that bone: (TA:) and the extremity of the hip-bone, in the socket. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A certain small bone, (K,) resembling the half of a nut, (TA, [but this is probably a misplaced insertion, from the A, ubi suprà,]) beneath the heart, of which it is the support. (K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) The edge, (K,) or each of the two edges, (TA,) of a sword. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b7- One says, A_in~ahu lazir~N mino A^azoraAri AlA_ibili (S, * A, K *) (tropical:) Verily he is one who keeps close to the camels; (A;) a good pastor of them. (S, A, K. [Accord. to the A, it seems to be from zir~N signifying “ a button. ”]) You term also zir~u maAlK (assumed tropical:) One who drives camels, or the like, vehemently; accord. to some; but the preceding meaning, given in the K, is the more correct: (TA:) or it signifies one acquainted with the right management thereof; (K, TA;) who manages them well; (TA;) as also maAlK ↓ zurozuwru. (K.) ― -b8- zir~u Ald~iyni (assumed tropical:) The support, or prop, of the religion; (Abu-l-'Abbás, K;) like the small bone called zir~, which is the support of the heart: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) applied, in a trad., to 'Alee: in another relation, it is zir~u AlA^aroDi, meaning he between whom and the earth is a mutual dependance, and without whose existence one would repudiate the earth and mankind: or, accord. to Th, he by whom the earth becomes firm, like as a shirt does by means of its zir~ [or button]. (TA.)

zar~apN *
Intellect, or intelligence. (O, TA.)

zir~apN * The mark left by a bite: (K, TA:) or, as some say, a bite itself. (TA.) And A wound with the edge of a sword. (TA.) -A2- J says, When camels are fat, you say, bihaA zir~apN: but this is a mistake for bahaA zirapN, (Sgh, K,) which is pl. of buhozuwrapN. (TA in art. bhzr.)

zariyrN * , applied to a man, (O, TA,) Light, or active; and sharp, or acute, of mind, with quickness of perception, and of intelligence, understanding, sagacity, skill, or knowledge; as also ↓ zarozaArN; (O, K; [in the CK, AlzakiY~u is erroneously put for Al*~akiY~u;]) which is also expl. as signifying light, or active, and quick; (TA;) and ↓ zuraAzirN, (K,) of which the pl. is zaraAziru. (TA.) -A2- Also A certain plant, (O, K.) having a yellow blossom, (O,) with which one dyes: (O, K:) in this sense, a Pers., or foreign, word. (O.)
zurozurN * : see zurozuwrN.
zarozaArN * : see zariyrN. Accord. to As, it signifies A man whose eyes glisten. (TA.)

zurozuwrN * [The starling;] a certain bird, (IDrd, S, O, K,) as also ↓ zurozurN, (IDrd, O, K,) resembling the lark: pl. zaraAziyru. (TA.) -A2- marokabN zurozuwrN A narrow mrkb [or animal, or thing, upon which one rides or is carried; accord. to the TK, meaning a beast; for it is there added that one says
HimaArN zurozuwrN, meaning a narrow ass]. (O, K. *) -A3- zurozuwru maAlK: see zir~N last sentence but one.
zuraAzirN * : see zariyrN.
mizar~N * An ass [app. meaning a wild ass] that bites much. (S, * TA.)
mazoruwrN * is used by El-Marrár El-Fak'asee as meaning A she-camel's nose-rein; because it is plaited and tied. (S.)

1 zarobN * [as an inf. n.] signifies The constructing a zariybap, (K, TA,) i. e. an enclosure of wood, (TA,) for sheep, or goats: (K, TA:) you say, zarabotu Alganama, aor. A^azorubuhaA, inf. n. zarobN: (TA:) [or this, I think, is a mistake for what here follows:] zarabotu liloganami, aor. A^azorubu, inf. n. zarobN (Ks, S:) [i. e. I constructed an enclosure of wood for the sheep or goats: this meaning is plainly indicated, though not expressed, in the S and TA:] but in some copies of the K, in the place of binaA='u Alz~ariybapi liloganami, as explaining Alz~arobu, we find bnAt Alzrybp Algnm [meaning that ↓ banaAtu Alz~ariybapi signifies sheep, or goats]. (TA.) ― -b2- And zaraba Albahoma fiY zarobihaA or zariybatihaA He put the bhm [i. e. lambs or kids, or young lambs or kids,] into their place [or enclosure of wood]. (A. [And the like is said in the Ham p. 195.]) -A2- zariba, aor.
zaraba , (K, TA,) said of water, (TA,) It flowed; (K, TA;) like sariba. (TA.)

7 Anzrb Albahomu fiY Alz~arobu *
The bhm [i. e. lambs or kids, or young lambs or kids,] entered into the zrb [or enclosure of wood]. (A, TA. *) ― -b2- And Anzrb AlS~aAy^idu (S, TA) fiY qutoratihi (TA) (assumed tropical:) The hunter, or sportsman, entered into his lurking-place. (S, TA.)
9 Azrb~ * , inf. n. AizoribaAbN, It (a plant, or herb,) became yellow, or red, while having in it greenness. (K, TA.)

zarobN *
A place of entrance. (AA, S, A, K.) ― -b2- And hence, accord. to AA, (S,) the same word, (S, A, K,) and ↓ zirobN, (ISk, S, K,) as some pronounce it, (ISk, S,) and ↓ zariybapN, (S, A, K,) (assumed tropical:) The place of sheep or goats; (A, K, TA;) [i. e.] an enclosure of wood for sheep or goats: (S:) [said in the TA to be tropical; but not so accord. to the A:] pl. of the first (A, K) and second (K) zuruwbN, (A, K,) and of the last zaraAy^ibu. (A.) ― -b3- And, as being likened thereto, (A,) zarobN and ↓ zariybapN signify also (tropical:) The lurking-place (qutorap) of a hunter, or sportsman, (S, A, K,) or of an archer, or a shooter: (TA in explanation of the former word:) both signify a well [or pit] which the hunter, or sportsman, digs for himself that he may lie in wait therein for the game. (TA.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph.

zirobN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also A channel in which water flows; (K;) and so ↓ zarobN. (TA.) It is said in a rejez of Kaab,
tabiytu bayona Alz~irobi waAlkaniyfi
She passes the night between the channel of water and the concealing, or protecting, place: meaning that she is fed in the enclosures for camels &c., [fiY AlHZAy^r, thus I read for AlHDAy^r (an evident mistranscription) in the TA,] and among the tents, or houses; not in the pasture-land. (TA.)

zirobiY~N * and zurobiY~N, (K,) or, accord. to the L [and the A], on the authority of IAar, ↓ zarobiy~apN, also said to be written zirobiy~apN and zurobiy~apN, (TA,) are sings. of ↓ zaraAbiY~u, (K, TA,) which signifies namaAriqu [app. as meaning Small pillows]: (S, A, K:) and carpets: or any things which are spread, and upon which one leans, or reclines: (A, K:) the like of this is said by Zj in explaining a phrase in which it occurs in the Kur lxxxviii. 16: or, accord. to Fr, it signifies carpets (TanaAfis) having a fine nap, or pile: (TA:) also, [particularly,] (A,) carpets (quTuwE, A, or TanaAfis, Har p. 377) of the fabric of El- Heereh; and the like thereof in fabric: (A, and Har ubi suprà:) or ↓ zrby~p signifies [simply] a carpet (TinofisapN): and a carpet (bisaAT) having a nap, or pile: and a [piece of leather that is spread upon the ground, such as is called] niTaE: and the like thereof in make. (TA. [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.]) [Hence,] one says, AlbagoDaA='i bayonahumo mabovuwvapN ↓ zaraAbiY~u (tropical:) [The embellished coverings of vehement hatred are spread between them; i. e. vehement hatred concealed by fair professions &c. subsists between them]. (A.) The following saying, of Artáh Ibn-Suheiyeh,
wanaHonu banuw Eam~K EalaY *aAti bayoninaA
fiyhaA bigoDapN watanAfusu ↓ zaraAbiY~u
is expl. by En-Nemiree as meaning (assumed tropical:) [And we are sons of a paternal uncle, but] upon our enmity is a comely covering beneath which it is latent; [therein are vehement hatred and envious competition;] zaraAbiY~u signifying [properly] carpets of sundry colours: (Ham p. 196:) it is also said to mean, in this instance, (assumed tropical:) [concealed] enmities, and sayings that give pain; [the former of these two meanings being] from zarabotu Albahoma fiY Alz~ariybapi, i. e. A^adoxalotuhu: [the latter of them app. suggested by another reading, namely, zaA^aAnibu in the place of zaraAbiY~u; mentioned and thus explained in the Ham ubi suprà: the poet, therefore, is supposed to have meant, upon our state of union, or concord, (*At bynnA having two contr. significations,) have supervened concealed enmities, &c.:] or, as some say, the reading in the deewán of Artáh is zaraAy^ibu, as though pl. of ↓ zariybapN, which is likewise made to denote enmity because it is made to enter (tuzorabu, i. e. tudoxalu,) into the heart; or which may be metaphorically applied to a place of enmity latent in the bosom, from the same word as signifying the “ place in which are put lambs, or kids, and sheep, or goats: ” or, supposing the right reading to be ↓ zaraAbiY~u, the poet may very properly mean, upon the vacant space between our tents, or houses, are carpets (TanaAfis and busuT) spread for us, and we sit thereon, near together in the places, but with the hearts remote: (idem p. 195:) but with the reading zaA^aAnibu, mentioned above, occurs another variation, thus: EalaY *aAka bayonanaA zaA^aAnibu; meaning, notwithstanding that, between us are sayings that give pain. (Idem p. 196.) ― -b2- ↓ wayolN lilz~arobiy~api, occurring in a trad., is said to mean (tropical:) Wo to those who go in to lords, or princes, and, when they say what is evil, or say anything, say, He has spoken truth: such persons being likened, in respect of their variable conduct, to one of the zaraAbiY~ mentioned above in the first sentence of this paragraph; or to sheep, or goats, which are thus called in relation to the zarob, i. e. the enclosure to which they repair, because they are obsequious to the lords, or princes, and follow their steps with the submissiveness of sheep or goats to their pastor. (TA.) ― -b3- Accord. to El-Muärrij, (TA,) ↓ zaraAbiY~u is applied to plants, as meaning Such as have become yellow, or red, while having in them greenness: (K, TA:) and when they saw the colours in carpets and other articles of furniture that are spread, they likened them to such plants. (TA.)

zarobiy~apN * and zirobiy~apN and zurobiy~apN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- [Golius, finding the second and third of these words expl. by the Pers. $AdrwAn, (which is often applied by Arabs in the present day to “ an artificial fountain that throws up water, ”) has erroneously, as Freytag has observed, supposed that they may signify “ Euripus, fons in altum saliens. ”]
zariybapN * : see zarobN, in two places: and see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The lurking-place of a beast of prey. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also zirobiY~N.
zaraAbiY~u * : see zirobiY~N, in five places.

ziroyaAbN * , (in the CK zirobAb,) an arabicized word, (K, TA,) from [the Pers.] zaro A=bo, the hemzeh [in A=bo, for A^aAbo,] being changed into Y, (TA,) Gold: (IAar, K:) or the water thereof [i. e. water-gold; which may be deemed the more correct, as agreeing with the original]. (K.) ― -b2- And Anything yellow. (K.) -A2- Also A certain black singingbird; (MF, TA;) called also Abw zwlq, [app. a mistranscription for Abw zryq, as in Freytag's Lex., i. e. A^abuw zurayoqK,] accord. to the book entitled “ Mantik et-Teyr. ” (TA.)

mizoraAbN *
i. q. mirozaAbN [q. v., said to be not a chaste word]. (K.)
mazorubaAnN * : see marozubaAnN, in art. rzb.

Q. 1 zarojanapN * (as an inf. n. TK) i. q. taxaArujN [q. v.]: (K) one says, zarojanuwA, meaning taxaArajuwA. (TK.) ― -b2- And The being deceitful, wicked, dishonest, or dissimulating, and mischief-making; or very deceitful &c.: and the act of deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, or outwitting: (K:) one says, zarojanahu, meaning He deceived him, deluded him, &c. (TK.)

zarajuwnN * , (S, K,) which is also written zurojuwnN, like EuSofuwrN, is mentioned in art. zrj and also in
the present art. by the author of the K, though he charges J with error in mentioning it in this art. because muzar~ajN is used by a rájiz as meaning “ intoxicated: ” whereas J is not in error, but is right, in doing thus; for the n is radical accord. to the generality of the lexicologists and the authors on inflection, like the s in qarabuwsN; and the rájiz above referred to elided the n in forming muzar~ajN because he imagined it to be augmentative: (MF in art. zrj:) it signifies Wine; (S, K;) and is a Pers. word, (As, Sh, Seer, S,) originally zrkwn, [i. e. zaroGuwno,] (Sh, TA,) meaning “ goldcoloured: ” (As, Sh, Seer, S:) or it signifies, (S, Mgh,) or signifies also [like as does EinabN, of which the primary signification is “ grapes ”], (K,) the grape-vine; (ISh, S, Mgh, K;) n. un. with p; (ISh, TA;) and pl. zaraAjiynu: (Mgh:) it has this meaning in the dial. of Et-Táïf: (ISh, TA in art. zrj:) or the shoots of a grape-vine: (Mgh, K:) thus in the dial. of Et-Táïf and ElGhowr: (TA in the present art.:) or a shoot that is planted, of a grape-vine. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain red dye. (El-Jarmee, S, K.) ― -b3- And Water that remains or stagnates, or collects, or remains long and becomes altered, or becomes yellow and altered, in a rock: (K in art. zrj:) or clear water that remains or stagnates, &c., in a mountain. (MF, TA.)

1 zarida * , aor.
zarada , (S, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. zarodN, (S, L, Msb,) or zaradN; (TA; [but this I find not in any other lexicon;]) or zarada, (A, Mgh,) or this also, aor.
zaruda , inf. n. zarodN and zaradaAnN; this latter form of the verb being mentioned by IDrd in the Jm, and ISd in the M, and IKtt in the Af'ál; but it is disapproved by Th, and asserted by his expositors to be vulgar; (TA;) and ↓ Aizodarada, (S, * A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. AizodiraAdN (S, A) and muzodaradN; (A, TA;) and ↓ tzr~d; (A, TA;) and AizodaAra, mentioned by 'Amr El-Mutarriz, but this is the most strange; (TA;) He swallowed (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) a morsel, or mouthful, (S, A, Msb, K,) or water, (Mgh,) [and medicine; for] you say dawaA='N ↓ SaEobu Almuzodaradi [A medicine difficult to swallow]. (A, TA.) And one says of a man swearing, HaS~aA='a ↓ tazar~adahaA and tazab~adahaA Ha*~aA='a (tropical:) [He swallowed it; meaning, took it hastily; i. e. the oath]. (A, TA.) -A2- zaradahu, aor.
zaruda (S, K) and
zarida , (TA, and so in a copy of the S, as well as
zaruda ,) or zarada Haloqahu, (A, TA, [in my copy of the A written zar~ada,]) inf. n. zarodN, (S,) He strangled him, or throttled him, or squeezed his throat; syn. xanaqahu, (S, K,) or EaSara Haloqahu. (A.) And zaradahu He took him, or seized him, by his throat. (TA.) ― -b2- zarada Ald~iroEa, (K,) inf. n. zarodN, (S, A,) He fabricated the coat of mail, by inserting the rings one into another; i. q. saradahaA: (K:) Alz~arodu is like Als~arodu, meaning the inserting (tadaAxul [an intrans. inf. n. here used as though it were trans., as is shown in the S in art. srd,]) of the rings of a coat of mail, one into another: (S:) [or, as Z says,] zarodu Ald~iroEi means saroduhaA, because the coat of mail consists of narrow, or close, rings: (A:) the z is said to be a substitute for s. (L, TA.)

2 zr~d Eayonahu EalaY SaAHibihi * (tropical:) He was angry with his companion, and looked sternly, austerely, or morosely, at him; i. e. he contracted his eye in looking at him, and did not open it until he had satisfied it with gazing at him. (A, TA.)
5 tazar~ada see 1, in two places.
8 Aizodarada * , inf. n. AizodiraAdN and muzodaradN: see 1, in two places.
zarodN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

zaradN * , (S, A, K,) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (A,) A coat of mail; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ zarodN, which is an inf. n. used as a subst. [and therefore used as a sing. and a pl., and applied, as is also zaradN to anything made of mail, a piece of mail, and rings in general, like sarodN, q. v.], (A,) and ↓ zaradiy~apN: (mentioned as syn. with diroEN in art. drE in the Msb and in the TA, on the authority of IAth:) the pl. of ↓ zarodN is zuruwdN. (TA.) [See also raforafN and mgofarN.]

zaridN *
Quick in swallowing: (K:) but in the Nawádir el-Aaráb, food that is soft, and quick in descending [in the throat]. (TA.)

zurodapN * [The quantity that is swallowed at once; like juroEapN and buloEapN;] a morsel, or small mouthful: so in the saying, Zan~a fulaAnN A^an~iY zurodapN lahu (tropical:) [Such a one thought that I was a morsel for him]. (A, TA.)

zarodaAnN *
A guest: as though he throttled his companion. (A, TA.)

zaradaAnN * The vulva of a woman: (K, TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) so called because it swallows (yazodaridN), or because it compresses (yazorudu [in the CK yazodaridu again]), (K, TA,) i. e. yaxonuqu, (TA,) the A^uyuwr, by its straitness. (K, TA.)
zaradiy~apN * : see zaradN.

ziraAdN * (S, K) and ↓ mizoradN (K) A cord by which the throat of a camel is compressed, in order that he may not eject his cud therefrom and bespatter his rider. (S, K.) The former word is also expl. in the K by mixonaqapN, [in some copies of the K mixofafap,] which signifies the same. (TA.)
ziraAdapN * The art of fabricating coats of mail; (A, TA;) as also siraAdapN. (TA.)

zar~aAdN *
A strangler or one who throttles, or squeezes the throat; syn. xan~aAqN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And A fabricator of coats of mail; (S, A, K;) as also sar~aAdN. (TA.)
mazoradN * [The place of strangling or throttling; like ↓ muzar~adN; meaning] the fauces; (S, K, TA;) the throat, or gullet. (TA.)
mizoradN * : see ziraAdN.

muzar~adN * : see mazoradN. One says, A^axa*a bimuzar~adihi, like A^axa*a bimuxan~aqihi, [properly He, or it, seized his throat, or throttled him, or choked him,] meaning (tropical:) he, or it, straitened him. (A, TA.)

mazoruwdN *
Strangled, throttled, or having his throat squeezed. (TA.) And, applied to the fauces [or throat], Squeezed, or compressed. (S.)
Q. 1 zarodamahu * , (S, K,) inf. n. zarodamapN, (TA,) He squeezed his throat: (S, K:) or he throttled him; or strangled him: (K:) as also zarodabahu. (TA.) ― -b2- And He swallowed it. (K.)

zarodamapN * inf. n. of the verb above.
