(TA.) -A2- Also The place of swallowing: (S, K:) or the galoSamap [or epiglottis]: (K:) or, as some say, it is [the part] beneath the Huloquwm [or windpipe: or, app., the part beneath the head of the Hlqwm]: and in it, or upon it, is set the tongue: some say that the word is Pers. [in origin; app. holding it to be arabicized from the Pers. zarodamano, which signifies the “ windpipe ”]. (TA.)
ziraATN * : see siraATN.

1 zaraEa * , aor.
zaraEa , (K,) inf. n. zaroEN (S, TA) and ziraAEapN, (TA,) He sowed, or cast seed; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ AizodaraEa, (S, Msb, K,) originally AizotaraEa, the t being changed into d in order that it may agree with the z, (S, K,) for d and z are pronounced with the voice as well as the breath, whereas t is pronounced with the breath only: (S, TA:) [or the latter verb, as appears from an explanation of it to be found below, may signify he sowed for himself.] They say, mano zaraEa HaSada [He who sows reaps]. (TA.) And [they use this verb transitively, saying,] zaraEotu Albur~a waAl$~aEiyra [I sowed wheat and barley]: and in like manner, zaraEotu Al$~ajara [I sowed the trees; or sowed the seeds which should produce the trees: or it may signify I planted the trees]. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed.) And zaraEa AlHub~a laka fiY Alquluwbi karamuka waHusonu xuluqika (tropical:) [Thy generosity and the goodness of thy disposition have sown love for thee in the hearts]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., mano kaAnato lahu A^aroDN faliyazoraEohaA A^awo liyamonaHohaA A^axaAhu faA_ino A^abaY faliyumosiko A^aroDahu [Whoso hath land,] let him sow it [or let him lend it, or give it, to his brother; and if he refuse, let him retain his land]. (TA.) ― -b2- zaraEa AlA^aroDa, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zaroEN, (Msb,) signifies [also] (tropical:) He ploughed up, or tilled, or cultivated, the land, or ground, for sowing. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence [the saying in a trad.], A_i*aA zaraEato h`*ihi AlA^um~apu nuziEa minohaA Aln~aSoru (tropical:) When this nation shall employ itself altogether with agriculture and the affairs of the present world, and turn away from warring against unbelievers and the like, aid shall be withdrawn from it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- zaraEahu A@ll~`hu signifies God caused it, or made it, to grow, vegetate, or
germinate; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and, to increase; (Mgh;) namely, AlHarova [the seed-produce]. (Mgh, Msb;) The verb is properly thus used of divine affairs, exclusively of human: (Er-Rághib:) and hence the saying in the Kur [lvi. 63-4], A^afaraA^ayotumo maA taHoruvuwna A^aA^anotumo tazoraEuwnahu A^amo naHonu Alz~aAriEuwna (S, * Er-Rághib) Now think ye, what ye sow, do ye cause it to grow, or are We the causers of growth? (Bd:) or, as some say, do ye cause it to increase, or are We the causers of its increase? the Harov [or sowing] being ascribed to them, and the zaroE [or causing to grow] exclusively to God: when the latter is ascribed to a man, it is because he is an agent as a means of making to grow; as when you say, A^anobat~u ka*aA (assumed tropical:) I was a means of causing such a thing to grow. (Er-Rághib.) [In like manner,] you say, zaroEFA ↓ AizodaraEa, meaning (tropical:) [He raised seed-produce, i. e., was a means of causing it to grow,] for himself, in particular. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] one says, with respect to a child, zaraEahu A@ll~`hu (tropical:) May God render him sound and strong; syn. jabarahu: (S, K, TA:) like as one says A^anobatahu A@ll~`hu: and in like manner, zaraEa A@ll~`hu waladaka liloxayori (tropical:) [May God render thine offspring sound and strong, or rather, cause thine offspring to grow up, for the doing, or enjoyment, of what is good]. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] zuriEa lahu baEodu $aqaAwapK (tropical:) [An increase was made for him after adversity; or] he obtained property after want; for the verb in this instance is like EuniYa. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

3 muzaAraEapN * is of the measure mufaAEalapN, [denoting a mutual action,] from Alz~iraAEapu, (Mgh,) and its signification is well known; (S;) i. e. (tropical:) The making a contract, or bargain, with another, for labour upon land, [to till and sow and cultivate it, as is indicated in the Mgh and Msb,] for a share, or portion, of its produce, (Msb, K, TA,) the seed being from the owner of the land. (K, TA.) [You say, zaAraEahu (tropical:) He made with him a contract, or bargain, such as is above described; and in like manner, xaAbarahu, and A=karahu. The doing this is forbidden, because of the uncertainty of the result.]

4 AzrE *
It (a plant, or herbage,) had, or became in the state of having, zaroE [i. e. produce of its seed; i. e. it grew from its seed]: (TA:) and, said of zaroE [or seed-produce], it became tall: (K:) or, as some say, it produced its leaves: and it attained to the proper time for its being reaped. (TA.) ― -b2- AzrE Aln~aAsu signifies A^amokanahumu Alz~aroEu [expl. in the TK as meaning The men, or people, became able to sow seed; i. e., became possessors of seed: but I rather think that it means they had seedproduce within their power, or reach; they became able to avail themselves thereof; or they attained to a season when they had seed produce]. (K.)

5 tzr~E A_ilaY Al$~ar~a *
i. q. tsr~E [He hastened, or made haste, to do evil, or mischief]. (Sgh, K.)
8 AizodaraEa * , originally AizotaraEa: see 1, in two places.

entryFree.key: A^asotazoriEu A@ll~`ha waladiY lilobir~i waA^asotaroziquhu lahu mina AlHil~i

div2.entryFree: 10 A^asotazoriEu A@ll~`ha waladiY lilobir~i waA^asotaroziquhu lahu mina AlHil~i * (tropical:) [I beg God to make my offspring grow up for piety, and I beg of Him means of subsistence for them, or him, of such kind as is of lawful attainment]. (TA.)

zaroEN * , originally an inf. n., [see 1,] (Mgh, Msb, TA,) used as a subst. properly so termed, signitying Seed-produce; what is raised by means of sowing; (Mgh, Msb;) what is sown; (K, TA;) while in growth, [i. e. standing corn, and the like,] (K and TA voce A^azoraEa,) and also after it has been reaped; (S and Msb and K in art. rfE, &c.;) its predominant application is to wheat and barley; (TA;) but it signifies also plants, or herbage, [in general,] such as one reaps; or, as some say, only while fresh and juicy: (Msb:) [and often a sown field:] pl. zuruwEN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Offspring, or children; or a child. (IDrd, K, TA.) You say, h`w^ulaA='i zaroEu fulaAnK (tropical:) These are the offspring, or children, of such a one. (IDrd, TA.) And huwa zaroEu Alr~ajuli (tropical:) He is the offspring, or child, of the man. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The seed, or seminal fluid, of a man. (TA.) ― -b4- [And (assumed tropical:) The fruit, or harvest, of a man's conduct; as though it were the produce of what he sowed.] One says, biy^osa Alz~aroEu zaroEu Almu*onibi (assumed tropical:) [Very evil is the fruit, or harvest, of conduct; the fruit, or harvest, of the conduct of the sinner]. (TA.)

zaroEapN * and ↓ zuroEapN and ↓ ziroEapN and ↓ zaraEapN A place in which to sow. (AHn, Sgh, K.) You say, maA fiY AlA^aroDi zaroEapN, &c., (K,) or zaroEapN waAHidapN, &c., and in like manner, EalaY AlA^aroDi, (TA,) There is not in the land, (K,) or upon the land, (TA,) a place, (K,) or a single place, (TA,) in which to sow. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [The first also app. signifies An ear of corn: see sabalN.]

zuroEapN * : see zaroEapN. ― -b2- Also Seed, or grain, for sowing, or that is sown; syn. ba*orN. (K.) You say, A^aEoTiniY zuroEapF A^azoraEu bihaA A^aroDiY [Give thou to me seed that I may sow therewith my land]. (TA.) [See also zariyEapN.] ― -b3- And (tropical:) The young one of a qabojap [generally meaning a partridge]. (Z, TA.)
ziroEapN * : see zaroEapN.
zaraEapN * : see zaroEapN.

zariyEN * [i. q. ↓ mazoruwEN Sown: &c.: see zariyEapN]. ― -b2- Seed produce that is watered by the rain. (Ham p. 657.) ― -b3- And hence, (tropical:) Anything soft, or tender; as being likened thereto. (Id.)
ziraAEapN * [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.: and] The business, or occupation, of sowing, (tropical:) ploughing up, tilling, or cultivation, land. (Mgh, * Msb, * TA.)

zariyEapN *
A thing that is sown; (IDrd, K;) sometimes used in this sense; as though meaning ↓ mazoruwEapN: (IDrd:) or grain that is sown: zar~iyEapN, with teshdeed, is wrong. (IB.) [See also zuroEapN.]
zar~aAEN * : see zaAriEN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A calumniator: (IAar:) one who sows rancours in the hearts of friends. (TA.)

zir~iyEN * (tropical:) What grows in land that has been left unsown for a year or more, from what has become scattered upon it in the days of the reaping; (K;) i. e., of the grain; mentioned by Sgh, on the authority of ISh; and by Z, who says that it is also called kaAv~N. (TA.)
zar~aAEapN * : see mazoraEapN, in two places.

zaAriEN * [act. part. n. of 1:] i. q. ↓ zar~aAEN (TA) [One who sows:] (tropical:) one who ploughs up, tills, or cultivates, land: (Mgh:) pl. zur~aAEN. (TA.) By this pl., in the Kur xlviii. 29, are meant Mohammad and his Companions, the inviters to El-Islám. (Zj.) ― -b2- Causing to grow, vegetate, or germinate: (S, TA:) causing to increase: (TA:) pl. with wn. (S, TA.) -A2- Also The name of a certain dog: (Ibn-'Abbád, IF, K:) whence A^awolaAdu zaAriEK meaning (tropical:) dogs. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, K.)

mazoraEapN * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and mazoruEapN (Sgh, L, K) and mazoriEapN (K) A place of zaroE [or seed-produce]; as also ↓ muzodaraEN; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ zar~aAEapN; (Ham p. 657;) or this last signifies land that is sown: (TA:) pl. of the first mazaAriEu; (TA;) and of ↓ the last zar~aAEaAtN. (Ham, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] Ald~unoyaA mazoraEapu AlA=xirapi (tropical:) [The present world is the place in which is produced the fruit, or harvest, to be reaped in the world to come]. (TA.)
mazoruwEN * and mazoruwEapN: see zariyEN and zariyEapN.
muzodaraEN * : see mazoraEapN.
muzodariEN * (tropical:) One who raises seed-produce (yazodariEu zaroEFA) for himself, in particular. (TA.)

zaraAfapN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ zuraAfapN (Msb as on the authority of A'Obeyd [but not found by me elsewhere in the sense here assigned to it]) and ↓ zaraAf~apN, [which is of a rare form, like HamaAr~apN, q. v.,] (A'Obeyd, IF, S, Msb, K,) this last mentioned by El-Kanánee, (A'Obeyd, S,) and by Kzz in his Jámi', but not known to A'Obeyd on any other authority than that of El-Kanánee, and the first is said by him (A'Obeyd) to be preferable, (TA,) A company, or congregated body, of men: (S, Msb, K:) or ten thereof: (K, TA:) accord. to some copies of the K what is termed an Ea$iyrap [i. e. a small portion of a tribe, &c.,] thereof: (TA:) pl. zaraAfaAtN (IF, S, Mgh, Msb) and zaraAf~aAtN: (IF, Msb:) in a poem of Lebeed, zar~aAfaAt, with teshdeed to the r. (TA.) One says, A^ataAniY Alqawomu ↓ bizaraAf~atahimo [or bizaraAfatihimo, i. e. The people, or party, came to me with their whole company; meaning, all together]. (TA.) -A2- Also zaraAfapN and ↓ zuraAfapN, (S, O, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) the latter, only, mentioned by IDrd, (TA,) who says, I doubt whether it be a genuine Arabic word, or not, (Msb, TA,) but some say that the latter is vulgar, (TA,) and ↓ zaraAfapN and ↓ zuraAf~apN, (O, L, Msb, K,) but the first of these four is the most chaste, (L, TA,) [The camelopard, or giraffe;] a certain beast, (S, K, [in the Mgh erroneously said to be a beast of prey,]) of beautiful make, the fore legs of which are longer than its kind legs; (TA;) said to be
called by a name signifying jamaAEapN because it has the form of an assemblage of animals; (Msb;) in Pers. called A^u$oturo GaAwo Palanok, (S, Mgh, K,) i. e. camel-ox-leopard, (TA,) because it has resemblances to the camel and the ox and the leopard: (K, TA:) pl. zaraAfaY, or zuraAfaY, or zaraAfiY~u, (accord. to different copies of the K, the last accord. to the TA,) like zaraAbiY~u. (TA.)
zuraAfapN * : see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
zaraAf~apN * and zuraAf~apN: see the first paragraph; the former in three places.

Q. 1 zarofana Sudogayohi *
He disposed the hair hanging down upon each of his temples in the form of a zuirofiyn [or ring]: (S, * K:) but this is postclassical. (S.)

zurofiynN * and zirofiynN, (S, Mgh, K,) or the latter is the correct word, for there is no word of the measure fuEoliylN in the language, (Az, TA,) [though the former is agreeable with the Pers. word which is the original,] A ring of a door: (Mgh, K:) or [a ring] in a general sense: (K:) pl. zaraAfiynu, occurring in a trad. as applied to rings of a coat of mail belonging to the Prophet, by which rings it was suspended: (TA:) arabicized, (S, K,) from the Pers. [zurofiyno]. (S.) ― -b2- The latter also signifies A company of men [app. disposed in the form of a ring]. (TA.)

1 zariqa * , (MA, TA,) [aor.
zaraqa ,] inf. n. zaraqN (S, MA, KL, TA) and zuroqapN, (MA,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He had that colour of the eye which is termed zuroqap [q. v.]; (S, TA;) [i. e.] he was blue-eyed; (KL;) or gray-eyed; (MA, PS;) or of a greenish hue in the eye [so I render the Pers. explanation sbz J$m $d]. (MA.) And zariqato Eayonuhu; (S, K;) and Eayonuhu ↓ Azrq~t, inf. n. AizoriqaAqN; (S;) and Eayonuhu ↓ AzrAq~t, (S, MA,) inf. n. AizoriyqaAqN; (S;) His eye was of the colour termed zuroqapN; (S, K;) [i. e.] his eye was gray; (MA;) [&c.] ― -b2- And zariqa, (TK,) inf. n. zaraqN, (K, TK,) He (a man, TK) was, or became, blind. (K, * TK.) ― -b3- [And zariqa Aln~aSolu, inf. n. zaraqN, is app. used as signifying The iron head or blade of an arrow &c. was, or became, very clear or bright: see zaraqN, below.] ― -b4- And zariqa AlmaA='u The water was, or became, clear; as also ↓ Azrq~. (Msb.) -A2- zaraqato Eayonuhu naHowiY His eye turned towards me so that the white thereof appeared; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^azoraqato and ↓ Aizoraq~ato. (Fr, K.) -A3- zaraqahu, (Mgh,) or zaraqahu bimizoraAqK, (S, K,) or birumoHK, (Msb,) aor.
zaruqa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. zaroqN, (Mgh, Msb,) He cast at him, (S, Mgh, K,) or he thrust him, or pierced him, (Mgh, Msb,) with a mzrAq [or javelin], (S, Mgh, K,) or with a spear. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zaraqahu biEayonihi, and bibaSarihi, (tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at him; he cast his eye at him. (TA.) ― -b3- zaraqati Alr~aHola, (S, TA,) or AlHimola, (TA,) She (a camel) made the saddle, (S, TA,) or the load, (TA,) to shift backwards: (S, TA:) and HimolahaA ↓ A^azoraqato, (K,) inf. n. A_izoraAqN, (TA,) She (a camel) made her load to shift backwards. (K.) [See also 2.] -A4- zaraqa, aor.
zaruqa and
zariqa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. zaroqN, (Msb,) said of a bird, i. q. *araqa [i. e. It muted, or dunged]. (S, Msb, K.)

2 zr~q * , accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, “ i. q. Pers. JkAnyd, Fecit ut stillaret, stillatim emisit: ” but it appears from my copy of the KL that this should be zh~q; for I there find tazohiyqN (not tazoriyqN) expl. by the Pers. JkAnydn: then, however, immediately follows, in that copy, another explanation: ― -b2- and The shifting backwards of a camel's saddle from his back: therefore it seems that either tazoriyqN is there omitted before this second explanation, (see 1, last sentence but one, and see 7,) or tazohiyqN is there a mistake for tazoriyqN.]
4 A^azoraqa see 1, in two places.

7 Anzrq *
It (an arrow) passed through, and went forth on the other side: (Lth, K:) and in like manner a spear. (K in art. zrnq.) ― -b2- He, or it, passed, so as to go beyond and away. (TA.) ― -b3- He entered into a burrow, and lay hid. (K in art. zrnq.) ― -b4- It (a camel's saddle, S, K, and a load, TA) shifted backwards. (S, K, TA. [In the CK, Alr~ajulu is erroneously put for Alr~aHolu. See an ex. in art. zhq, conj. 4.]) ― -b5- He (a man, As) laid himself down on his back. (As, K.)
9 A_izoraq~a see 1, in three places.
11 A_izoraAoq~a see 1, second sentence.
Q. Q. 2 tazaworaqa * , (K, TA,) in some of the copies of the K tazarowaqa, (TA,) He (a man, TA) cast [forth] what was in his belly: (K, TA:) so says Fr. (TA.)

zaraqN * [inf. n. of zariqa, q. v.: and] i. q. zuroqapN, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- Blindness: (K:) in this sense also an inf. n. of which the verb is zariqa. (TK.) ― -b3- The quality of being very clear or bright, in the iron head or blade of an arrow &c. (ISk, S. [See, again zariqa, of which it is app., in this sense likewise, an inf. n.]) ― -b4- A sort of taHojiyl [i. e. whiteness in the legs, or in three of the legs, or in the two kind legs, or in one kind leg, beneath the knees and hocks, or beneath the hocks, or beneath the hock, of a horse,] not including the border of the pastern next the hoof: (AO, K:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the K “ and ”) a whiteness not surrounding the bone altogether, but [only] a whiteness of the hair (waDaHN) upon a part thereof. (K, TA.)

zaroqapN *
A certain bead (xarazapN) for the purpose of fascination, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) with which women fascinate [men]. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

zuroqapN *
A certain colour, (Msb, K,) well known; as also ↓ zaraqN: (K:) it is [in various things; but is generally expl. as being] in the eye: (JK, S:) [a blue colour, (see 1, first sentence,) whether light or dark or of a middling tint, but generally the first;] sky-colour, or azure; (TK;) [blueness of the eye;] or grayness of the eye; (PS;) [or a greenish hue in the eye: (see again 1, first sentence:)] accord. to ISd, whiteness, wherever it be: and a xuDorap [by which may be meant greenness, or dust-colour intermixed with blackness or deep ask-colour,] in the sawaAd [here meaning iris] of the eye: or, as some say, a whiteness overspreading the sawaAd of the eye [app. when a person becomes blind: see 1, third sentence; and see also A^azoraqu]. (TA.) [In the present day it is often improperly used as meaning A black colour.]

zuroqumN *
Having, in an intense degree, that colour of the eye which is termed zuroqap; (S, K; *) applied to the male and the female; (K;) [i. e.] applied also to a woman: (S:) accord. to Ibn-'Osfoor, it is [used as] a subst.; [or, app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates;] not [as] an epithet with a subst.; (MF, TA;) but accord. to Lh, one says rajulN zuroqumN and AimoraA^apN zaroqaA='u: the m is augmentative. (TA.)
zaroqamapN * [Intenseness of zuroqap, i. e. blueness, or grayness, in the eye;] the attribute denoted by the epithet zuroqumN. (Lh, TA.)
zurayoqN * [and app. A^abuw zurayoqK (see ziroyaAbN)] A certain bird. (K.)

zurayoqaA='u * [dim. of zaroqaA='u fem. of A^azoraqu] (tropical:) A mess of crumbled bread (variydapN) dressed with milk and olive oil: (JK, Z, K:) likened, because of its seasoning, to the eyes that are termed zuroq (Z, TA.) -A2- Also A certain small beast, resembling the cat. (Lth, K.)

zur~aqN *
A certain bird used for catching other birds; (IDrd, S, K;) between the [species of hawk called] baAziY and the baA$aq [or sparrow-hawk]: (IDrd, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, the white baAziY [or falcon]: (S, TA:) [but] it is said in the A, laA yuqaAsu Alz~ur~aqu biAlA^azoraqi [The zur~aq is not to be compared with the A^azoraq], which latter is the bAzY: (TA:) the pl. is zaraAriyqu. (S, K.) -A2- And A whiteness in the forelock of a horse; (K, TA;) or in the hinder part of his head, behind the forelock. (O, TA.) And Some white hairs in the fore leg of a horse; or in his hind leg. (TA.) -A3- Also Sharp-sighted: mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)
zar~aAqN * , applied to a man, Very deceitful; or a great deceiver. (TA.)

zar~aAqapN * , with fet-h and teshdeed, A short javelin; i. e. a spear shorter than the mizoraAqN: pl. zaraAriyqu. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. minoDaHapN; (IAar, L and K in art. nDH; in some copies of the K, zur~aAqap; and in the CK zarAfap;) i. e. An instrument made of copper, or brass, for shooting forth naphtha [into a besieged place]. (L in that art.)
zuronuwqN * : &c.: see art. zrnq.

zaworaqN *
A sort of safiynap [or boat]; (S;) [a skiff
i. e.] a small safiynap; (K;) or a small qaArib: pl. zawaAriqu. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, [referring to a she-camel,] niEomato zaworaqu Albaladi; [making it fem., because] meaning niEomato safiynapu AlmafaAzapi [Excellent, or most excellent, is the boat, or skiff, of the desert, or waterless desert.] (S, TA.)

A^azoraqu *
Of the colour termed zuroqap [q. v.]; (Msb, TA;) and ↓ A^azoraqiY~N signifies the same: (TA:) an epithet applied to a man, signifying having what is termed zuroqap of the eye: (S:) blue, (KL,) [whether light or dark or of a middling tint, but generally the first;] sky-coloured, or azure; (TK;) blue-eyed; (MA, KL;) gray-eyed; (MA;) [or having a greenish hue in the eye: &c.: (see zuroqapN:)] fem. zaroqA='u: (S, Msb:) pl. zuroqN. (Msb.) [In the present day it is often improperly used as meaning Black: and is applied to a horse, an ass, a mule, a bird, and any animal, and sometimes to other things, as meaning gray, or ash-coloured.] ― -b2- [And Blind; properly by reason of a bluish, or grayish, opacity of the crystalline lens; i. e., by what is commonly termed a cataract in the eye.] wanaHo$uru A@lomujorimiyna yawomay^i*K zuroqFA, in the Kur [xx. 102], means [And we will congregate, or raise to life, on that day, the sinners, or unbelievers,] blind; (Bd, K, * TA;) because the black of the eye of the blind becomes blue, or gray: (Bd:) Zj says that they will come forth from their graves seeing, as they were created at the first, and will become blind when congregated: (TA:) or the meaning is, thirsty: (Th, TA:) or with their eyes become blue, or gray, by reason of intense thirst: (ISd, TA:) or blue-eyed, or gray-eyed, (zuroqa AlEuyuwni,) because Alz~uroqapu is the worst of the colours of the eye, and the most hateful thereof to the Arabs, for the Greeks were their greatest enemies, and are zuroq. (Bd.) ― -b3- Applied to the iron head or blade of an arrow &c., Very clear or bright: (ISk, S, K:) and zuroqN [used as a subst.] means spearheads (S, K) or the like; (K;) because of their colour; (S, TA;) or because of their clearness, or brightness; (TA;) or polished iron heads or blades of arrows &c. (Ham p. 313.) And Clear water: (IAar, S, Msb:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, AlEaduw~u AlA^azoraqu The sheer enemy: or [the fierce enemy;] the enemy that is vehement in hostility; because zuroqap of the eyes is predominant in the Greeks and the Deylem, between whom and the Arabs is a confirmed enmity. (Har p. 148.) ― -b5- AlA^azoraqu The baAziY [i. e. hawk, or falcon: because of his colour]: pl. as above. (TA. [See also zur~aqN.]) ― -b6- And The leopard. (TA.) ― -b7- Alz~aroqaA='u Wine: (K:) [app. because of its clearness:] so says AA. (TA.) ― -b8- And the name of A horse of Náfi' Ibn-'Abd-El-'Ozzà. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

A^azoraqiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. -A2- Also sing. of AlA^azaAriqapu, (TA,) which is the appellation of A certain sect of the [heretics, or schismatics, called] xawaArij, (S, K,) or Haruwriy~ap; (TA;) so called in relation to Náfi' Ibn-ElAzrak, (S, K,) who was [of the family] of EdDool Ibn-Haneefeh: (S:) they asserted that 'Alee committed an act of infidelity by submitting his case to arbitration, and that Ibn-Muljam's slaughter of him was just; and they pronounced the Companions [of the Prophet] to have been guilty of infidelity. (TA.)

mizoraAqN *
A javelin; i. e. a short spear, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) lighter than the Eanazap. (Mgh, Msb.) -A2- Also A camel that makes his load to shift backwards. (Az, K.)

div2.head: Quasi zrqm
div2.entryFree: zuroqumN * and zaroqamapN are expl. in art. zrq.

1 zarima * , (S, K,) aor.
zarama , (K,) inf. n. zaramN, (TA,) said of one's urine, (S, K,) and of his flow of tears, and of his speech, (K,) and of his oath, (TA,) and of anything that had gone back, (S,) It became interrupted, or stopped; or it stopped; or ceased; (S, K;) as also ↓ AizoraA^am~a. (K.) And so the former verb said of a sale. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a dog, (S, K,) and of a cat, (K,) His dung, (S, K,) or dry dung, (K,) stopped in his rectum. (S, K.) -A2- zaramahu: see 4. ― -b2- zaramato bihi She (his mother, S) brought him forth. (S, K.)

2 zar~ama see 4. ― -b2- zr~mhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. tazoriymN, (TA,) He, or it, rendered him zarim, i. e. niggardly, or avaricious: (S:) or it (time, or fortune,) cut off from him good, good things, or prosperity. (TA.)

4 Azrmhu *
He, or it, interrupted it, stopped it, or caused it to cease; namely, one's urine, and his flow of tears, and his speech; as also ↓ zaramahu, aor.
zarima , (K,) inf. n. zaromN; (TA;) and ↓ zr~mhu, (K,) inf. n. tazoriymN. (TA.) ― -b2- And He interrupted, or stopped, his (another's) urine. (As, S, K.) -A2- A^azoramato She (a camel) interrupted her flow of urine by little and little. (AA, TA.)

8 AizodiraAmN * The act of swallowing [a thing]: (S, K:) mentioned in the S in art. zdrm or zrdm [accord. to different copies]; (TA;) and in the K, as an art. by itself; the reason whereof is not apparent; for it appears to be of the measure AifotiEaAlN; not AifoEilaAlN. (MF, TA.)

Q. Q. 4 AizoraA^am~a * , (S, K,) inf. n. Aizoriy^omaAmN: (S:) see 1. ― -b2- [Also] He shrank, or drew himself together: (A'Obeyd, S:) or he shuddered and shrank. (TA.) ― -b3- And He was angry. (AZ, TA.)
zrm * [app. zaromN] Dung, or dry dung, stopping in the rectum of a dog or cat. (TA. [See 1, third sentence.]) -A2- zaromN Caution. (K.)

zarimN * Anything becoming interrupted, or stopped; stopping, or ceasing; as also ↓ A^azoramu. (TA.) Scanty, or little in quantity, and becoming interrupted, or stopped: so in the phrase rajulN zarimu Ald~amoEi: or this signifies [simply] a man whose tears are becoming interrupted, or stopped. (TA.) ― -b2- A she-camel that interrupts her flow of urine by little and little. (AA, TA. [Thus used as a fem. epithet without p.]) ― -b3- A dog, and a cat, whose dung, or dry dung, has stopped in his rectum. (TA.) ― -b4- Straitened [app. in his means of subsistence]. (S.) ― -b5- Niggardly, or avaricious. (S.) ― -b6- Low, object, mean, or ignominious, whose near kinsfolk are few; (IAar, K;) as also ↓ zariymN. (TA.) ― -b7- One who does not remain fixed, or settled, in any place. (As, K.)
zariyamN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zuraA^omiymN * : see muzoray^im~N.
A^azoramu * : see zarimN. ― -b2- Also The cat. (ISd, K.)

muzoray^im~N *
Shrinking, or drawing himself together; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also ↓ zuraA^omiymN; (Th, K, TA; [in the CK zarAmiyom;]) each with damm: (TA:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, muzoray^im~N signifies shuddering and shrinking; with the r before the z; and AZ doubted whether the word having this meaning were muzoray^im~N or muzoray^im~N; but Az says that the former is the right, with the z before the r and that it is thus accord. to Ibn-Jebeleh. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Angry. (AZ, TA.) ― -b3- And Silent. (IB, TA.)

zaronabN *
A certain perfume: or certain sweetsmelling trees: (K:) or a species of sweet-smelling plant: (S:) it consists of slender round twigs, between [maA bayona, misprinted mlyn,] the thickness of the large needle and the thickness of writingreeds, black inclining to yellowness, not having much taste nor odour, its little odour being of a fragrant kind like that of the citron: (Ibn-Seenà, book ii. p. 168:) [Freytag says, as on the authority of the K, but he seems to have taken it from the TK, that, “ accord. to some, it signifies the leaves of a sweet-smelling plant, which has the name of rjl AljrAd, locusts' foot: ” and he adds, as though on the authority of Ibn-Seenà ubi suprá, “ salix Aegyptiaca: ” referring also to Sprengel, Hist. rei. herb., t. i. p. 270:] also saffron: (K:) it is of the measure faEolalN; (S, TA;) and is a genuine Arabic word, though asserted by Ibn-El-Kutbee to be arabicized. (TA.) A rájiz says,
yaA biA^abiY A^anoti wafuwki AlA^a$onabu
kaA^an~amaA *ur~a Ealayohi Alz~aronabu
[O, with my father thou shouldst be ransomed, and thy mouth that is cool and sweet, as though zaronab were sprinkled upon it]. (S.) In the trad. of Umm-Zara, where it is said, Almas~u mas~u A^aronabK waAlr~iyHu riyHu zaronabK [The feel is the feel of a hare, and the odour is the odour of zaronab], IAth says that it signifies saffron; and she may mean the sweetness of his odour, or the perfume of his garments among the people. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The [dung such as is termed] baEor of wild animals. (K.) -A2- Also, [and, as appears from what follows, ↓ zaronabapN likewise, if this be not a mistranscription,] The vulva of a woman: (K, * TA:) or such as is large: or the external portion thereof: (K:) or a piece of flesh (K, TA) within the zrwAn [a mistranscription for zaradaAn, a name for the vulva], (TA,) behind the kayonap [or kayon, q. v.]: (K, TA:) behind the ↓ zaronabap is another piece of flesh: so says IAar. (TA.)
zaronabapN * : see the next preceding sentence, in two places.

Q. 1 zaronaqapN * [as inf. n. of zaronaqa] The irrigating [land] by means of the zuronuwq [here app. meaning rivulet]. (Mgh, K.) ― -b2- And The setting up a [pillar-like structure such as is termed] zuronuwq by a well. (K.) -A2- One says also, zaronaqotuhu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TK,) meaning I clad him [app. fiY Alv~iyaAbi in the clothes: see Q. 2]: or zaronaqotu All~ibaAsi A_iy~aAhu I put the clothing upon him; or clad him therewith. (TK) -A3- And laA yuzaroniquka A^aHadN EalaY faDoli zayodK [No one will exceed to thee the excel-lence of Zeyd]. (TA. [It is there indicated that this is from zaronaqapN as syn. with ziyaAdapN.]) -A4- [See zaronaqapN as a simple subst. below.]

Q. 2 tazaronaqa *
He drew water by means of the zuronuwq, (Mgh, K, TA,) or the zuronuwqaAni, (TA,) for hire. (Mgh, K, TA.) Hence the saying of 'Alee, laA A^adaEu AlHaj~a walawo tazaronaqotu, meaning I will not omit, or neglect, the pilgrimage, though I should draw water by means of the zrnwq, or zrnwqAn, and perform it with the hire obtained thereby: thus it is explained: another explanation will be found in what follows. (Mgh, TA.) -A2- tzrnq fiY Alv~iyAbi He clad, and covered, himself in the clothes. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, [it is said,] because implying concealment of the excess [of the price] in the sale, (TA,) tzrnq also signifies taEay~ana, (Mgh, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, tagay~ara,]) from Alz~aronaqapu meaning AlEiynapu; (Mgh;) i. e. He bought on credit, for an excess [in the amount of the price]. (TK.) And accord. to some, walawo tazaronaqotu, in the saying of 'Alee mentioned above, means walawo taEay~anotu, (Mgh,) i. e. walawo taEay~anotu Eiynapa Alz~aAdi waAlr~aAHilapi [though I should buy on credit, for more than the current price, the travelling-provision and the camel to be ridden]: (TA:) but the former explanation is the more likely. (Mgh.)

zaronaqapN * inf. n. of zaronaqa. (TK. [See Q. 1, above.]) -A2- Also i. q. EiynapN; (IAar, JK, Mgh, K;) i. e. The buying of a thing from a man on credit, for more than its [current] price: (JK, Fáïk:) or the doing thus, and then selling it to him, or to another, for less than the price for which it was purchased. (TA.) ― -b2- And Increase, excess, or addition; syn. ziyaAdapN. (K.) [For zaronaqapN in this and the following senses, Freytag, in his Lex., has written zaronaq.] ― -b3- And Debt. (K, TA. [In the CK, Ald~iynu is erroneously put for Ald~ayonu: and it is there added, “ as though arabicized from zaronaho; i. e. Al*~ahaba labisa: ” but what this should be I know not, unless it be a mistranscription for Al*~ahabu layosa; for, in Pers., zaro means “ gold, ” and naho is a negative.]) -A3- Also Perfect, or consummate, beauty. (K.)

zuronuwqN * , as some pronounce it, is by others pronounced zaronuwqN, which is of a strange form, [said to be] of the measure faEonuwlN, (IJ, TA,) mentioned by Kr on the authority of Lh: (TA:) [the dual] zuronuwqaAni, (S, Mgh, K,) mentioned by J in art. zrq, the n being regarded by him as augmentative, but by the author of the K as radical, (TA,) also pronounced zaronuwqaAni, (K,) signifies Two pillarlike structures (manaArataAni) constructed by the head of a well, (S, Mgh, K,) on the two sides thereof; (K;) or two walls; or two posts; (Mgh;) across which is placed a piece of wood, (S, Mgh,) called the naEaAmap; (S;) and to this is suspended the pulley by means of which the water is drawn: (S, Mgh:) or two structures like the signs set up to show the way, by the brink of a well, of clay or of stones: (TA:) accord. to the S, (TA,) if of wood, they are called diEaAmataAn: or, as El-Kilábee says, if of wood, they are called naEaAmataAni, and the crosspiece is called the Eajalap, and to this the large bucket is suspended: (S, TA:) pl. zaraAniyqu. (TA.) ― -b2- zuronuwqN also signifies A rivulet; (Sh, Mgh, K;) app. a rivulet in which runs the water that is drawn by means of the zrnwq. (Sh, Mgh,* TA.)

zironiyqN *
i. q. zironiyxN [i. e. Arsenic]; an arabicized word; (K;) as is also the latter [q. v.]. (TA.)

muzaroniqN *
A setter-up of what are termed zaronuwqaAni. (TA.)

zironiyxN * [Arsenic;] a well-known kind of stone [or mineral, for it is a metal]; of which there are several species; one species is white [i. e. white arsenic]; and another is red [i. e. realgar, or red arsenic, also called sandarac]; and another is yellow [i. e. orpiment, or yellow arsenic]: (K, TA:) it is an arabicized word from the Pers. [zaroniyxo or zaroniyqo or zaroniYo or zaronaho]. (Msb.)

1 zaraY Ealayohi * , (S, Msb, K,) or zaraY Ealayohi fiEolahu, (Mgh, TA,) aor. yazoriY, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. ziraAyapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) with kesr, (Msb, TA,) but by some written with fet-h, (TA, [zarAyap, thus in the CK and in one of my copies of the S and in my MS. copy of the K,]) and zaroYN (Msb, K) and zaroyapN (Msb [perhaps a mistranscription for what next follows]) and mazoriyapN and mazoraApN and zuroyaAnN, with damm, (K,) but accord. to the copies of the T and M zarayaAnN; (TA;) and Elyh ↓ tzr~Y, (S, Msb, K,) and Elyh ↓ AzrY, but this is of rare occurrence, (K,) and ↓ AizodaraAhu; (Msb;) He blamed, found fault with, or reproved, (Lth, AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) him, (S, Msb, K,) or his deed; (Mgh, TA;) or was angry with him, with the anger that proceeds from a friend: (S, TA:) and reproached him, upbraided him, or blamed him angrily or severely: (Lth, TA:) and he mocked, scoffed, or laughed, at him; derided him; or ridiculed him. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 4, last sentence but one.

4 AzrY bihi * , inf. n. A_izoraA='N, He held it (i. e. a thing, S, Msb, or a case, or an affair, K) in little, or light, or mean, estimation, or in contempt; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ AizodaraAhu. (Mgh.) And i. q. qaS~ara bihi [app. here meaning (in like manner as it is rendered below in this paragraph) He fell short of that estimation which was required by him, or due to him]; and ↓ AizodaraAhu, i. e. he contemned, or despised, him; [and so, app., ↓ AstzrAhu; (see muzodarK;)] or made him to be contemned or despised; syn. Haqarahu or Haq~arahu. (S, accord. to different copies. [But whether this last explanation be here meant to relate to AzrY bh and AzdrAh or to the latter alone, is not clear.]) He lowered his condition, or estimation. (Ham p. 117.) He brought against him the imputation of a fault, or vice, or the like, ('Eyn, K, TA,) or a thing, or an affair, or an action, whereby he desired to involve him in confusion. (ISd, K, TA.) AzrY biEilomihi and bihi ↓ zaraY, mentioned, but not explained, by Lh, are thought by ISd to signify qaS~ara bihi [app. meaning He fell short of that estimation which was required by, or due to, his knowledge]. (TA.) AzrY Ealayohi: see 1.
5 tazar~aYa see 1.
8 AizodaraAhu * : see 1: and see also 4, in two places.
10 A_isotazoraYa see 4.
zariY~N * , applied to a skin for water or milk (siqaA='N) [Of middling size;] between small and large. (ISd, K.)

zaArK EalaY A_inosaAnK *
Blaming, finding fault with, or reproving, a man; or being angry with him, with the anger that proceeds from a friend; and being displeased with him: thus in a verse of Mejnoon cited voce AisotadaAma: (S, TA:) making no account of a man, and disapproving his conduct. (AA, Msb, TA.)
mizoraA='N * A man who blames, or finds fault with, people [app. much, or habitually]. (K,* TA.)

muzodarK *
Contemning, or despising; as also ↓ musotazorK. (K, and in some copies of the S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] The lion. (K.)
musotazorK * : see the next preceding paragraph.
ziyzamN * and ziyzimN: see art. zm.

R. Q. 1 zaEozaEapN * signifies The moving, agitating, shaking, or putting into a state of motion or commotion, (Lth, S, K,) a thing, (S,) or a tree, (Lth, K,) and the like, (K,) by the wind: (Lth, K:) or any vehement moving or agitating or shaking; or putting into a state of vehement motion or commotion. (K.) You say, zaEozaEotuhu I moved it, agitated it, shook it, &c. (S.) And zaEozaEati Alr~iyHu Al$~ajarapa, inf. n. zaEozaEopN, The wind moved, or agitated, or shook, &c., the tree; as also zaEozaEato bihaA, which may be a dial. var. of the former, or the verb in this case may be made trans. by means of the b because it has the meaning of dafaEato bihaA. (TA.) You say also, zaEozaEahu, inf. n. as above, meaning
He moved it, agitated it, shook it, &c., vehemently, desiring to pull it out or up or off, and to remove it. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] zaEozaEotu AlA_ibila (tropical:) I drove the camels roughly, or violently; urged them on. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tazaEozaEa *
It became moved, agitated, shaken, or put into a state of motion or commotion: (S, K:) [or it became moved, agitated, shaken, &c., vehemently:] quasi-pass. of zaEozaEatohu Alr~iyHu. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] tazaEozaEati AlA_ibilu (tropical:) The camels went roughly, or violently, being so driven, or urged on. (TA.)

riyHN zaEozaEN * and ↓ zaEozaEaAnN and ↓ zuEaAziEN, (S, K,) the last with damm, (K, TA,) but written by J with fet-h, (TA,) [and so I find it in one copy of the S, but in another copy with damm,] and ↓ zaEozaAEN, (Sgh, K,) A wind that agitates things, shakes them, or puts them into a state of motion or commotion: (S, K, TA:) and ↓ riyHN zuEozuwEN [signifies the same; or] a violent wind. (IJ.) ― -b2- [And hence,] sayorN zaEozaEN (tropical:) An agitating, or a jolting, pace; (S, [but not there explained, though the meaning is there implied,] Sgh, K;) a vehement pace. (L.)

zaEozaEapN * [see R. Q. 1]. ― -b2- zaEaAziEu [which is its pl. when it is used as a simple subst.] signifies (tropical:) The calamities, or adversities, of fortune; (K, TA;) like zalaAzilu. (TA.) One says, kayofa A^anota fiY h`*ihi Alz~aEaAziEi (tropical:) How art thou in these calamities, or adversities? so in the L and the Moheet and the A. (TA.)
zaEozaEaAnN * : see zaEozaEN.

zaEozaAEN * : see zaEozaEN. ― -b2- Also [Vehement motion, agitation, or shaking;] a subst. from zaEozaEahu as signifying “ he moved it, ” &c., “ vehemently: ” and metaphorically used by Ed-Dahnà in allusion to the *akar. (TA.)
zuEozuwEN * : see zaEozaEN.

zaEozaAEapN *
i. q. $id~apN [Vehemence; strength; &c.]. (IB.) ― -b2- A troop, or force, of many horsemen, (K, TA,) in a state of motion or commotion. (TA.)
zuEaAziEN * : see zaEoziEN.

muzaEozaEN *
i. q. faAluw*N [A kind of sweet food: see the latter word]. (IAar, K.)

1 zaEabotuhu Ean~iY * , [aor.
zaEaba ,] inf. n. zaEobN, I pushed, thrust, drove away, or repelled, him, or it, from me. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zaEaba said of a torrent, aor. and inf. n. as above, It was impelled in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another; in a valley: (S, TA:) [it was, or became, copious, and drove along, one portion impelling another; like ↓ AizolaEab~a:] it ran. (TA.) ― -b3- If you say raEaba with the unpointed r, (S, TA.) or thus and also zaEaba, aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) you mean It filled the valley. (S, TA.) And the latter, It filled everything: said of rain. (TA.) And He filled a vessel. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] zaEaba AlmaroA^apa, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, is a tropical phrase, meaning jaAmaEahaA famalaA^a farojahaA bifarojihi: (TA:) or jaAmaEahaA famalaA^a farojahaA maniy~FA: (K, * TA:) [neither of which explanations needs translation:] but, accord. to some, this is said only of one that is large, or bulky. (TA.) ― -b5- zaEaba Alqirobapa He took up and carried the water-skin, it being full: (K, TA:) he carried it filled; as also zaA^abahaA: (TA:) and both signify he carried it in his bosom: (TA in art. zA^b: [see also 8:]) the former also signifies he was impelled onwards (tdAfE) by it, carrying it, by reason of its weight. (TA in the present art.) ― -b6- zaEaba biHimolihi, said of a camel, (K, TA,) i. q. AisotaqaAma [app. meaning He went right on, straight on, or undeviatingly, with his load]: (TA:) or, as also bihi ↓ AzdEb, he went along with his load oppressed by its weight: or he was impelled onwards (tadaAfaEa) by it: (K, TA:) or mar~a yazoEabu bihi he went along quickly with it: or he went along easily with it; namely, his load. (TA.) ― -b7- zaEaba AlwaAdiY The valley became filled, (K, TA,) so that the several parts, or portions, of the torrent impelled one another. (TA.) ― -b8- zaEaba fiY qayoy^ihi He vomited much, so that one portion [of the vomit] impelled on another. (TA.) ― -b9- zaEabati Alqirobapu i. q. dfEt maA='ahaA [The water-skin propelled its water: or the right reading is probably dafaqato maA='ahaA, i. e., poured forth its water; or poured it forth with vehemence]. (TA.) ― -b10- zaEaba also signifies He cut off, or divided off; and so ↓ AzdEb. (K, TA.) You say, zaEaba lahu mina AlmaAli, and ↓ AzdEb, as also Azdhb, He cut off, or divided off, for him [a portion] of the property, or wealth. (TA.) And zaEabotu lahu zuEobapF mina AlmaAli, and zaEobapF, (S, K, *) and ziEobFA, (K,) I gave to him a part, or portion, of the property, or wealth: (S, K:) or a full, or an ample, or abundant, portion thereof. (TA.) ― -b11- zaEaba Al$~araAba, aor. and inf. n. as above, He drank all the wine, or beverage. (TA.)

5 tzE~b *
He was brisk, lively, or sprightly; (K, TA;) and quick. (TA.) ― -b2- He was, or became, angered, or enraged. (K.) ― -b3- tzE~b fiY A^akolihi wa$urobihi He was immoderate in his eating and his drinking; he ate and drank much. (K.) -A2- tzE~b Alqawomu AlmaAla The people, or party, divided among themselves the property, or wealth; (K;) divided it into parts, or portions. (TA.)

8 AizodaEabotu Al$~aYo'a *
I carried the thing; took it up and carried it; or carried it off or away; syn. Hamalotuhu: you say, mar~a bihi faA@zodaEabahu [He passed by it and carried it off or away]. (S.) [See also Azdgb.] ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 4 AizolaEab~a * : see 1, second sentence; and see also art. zlEb.

zaEobN *
Muchness, copiousness, abundance, or a large quantity or number. (TA.)
ziEobN * : see what next follows.
zaEobapN * : see what next follows.

zuEobapN * and ↓ zaEobapN A part, or portion, that is given, of property, or wealth; (S, K; *) as also ↓ ziEobN: (K:) or a full, or an ample, or abundant, portion, that is given, thereof; and so zuhobapN. (TA.) [See 1, last sentence but one.]
zaEuwbN * : see what next follows, in two places.

zaAEibN * A torrent driving along, one portion of it impelling another; (A, TA;) as also ↓ zaEuwbN [but app. in an intensive sense; and ↓ muzolaEib~N, also, has the same, or a similar, meaning]: or the first and ↓ second signify a torrent filling the valley: and the first is also applied to rain, as meaning filling everything. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A guide of the way, one who is a frequent traveller. (S, K.)

zumoHN zaAEibiY~N * , (A,) and rimaAHN zaAEibiy~apN, (A, K,) A spear, (A,) and spears, (A, K,) so called in relation to a certain man named Zá'ib (zaAEibN), (A, K,) of El-Khazraj, who made spear-heads: (A:) so says Mbr: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the spears thus termed are such as quiver much (Eas~aAlapN), which, when shaken, have a motion like the torrent termed zaAEibN, of which one portion impels another: the Y being that of the rel. n.; to give intensiveness to the signification, as in A^aHomariY~N: (A:) or (tropical:) such that, when they are shaken, their kuEuwb [i. e. knots, or joints, or their internodal portions,] are as though they ran one into another, (K, TA,) by reason of its pliancy: so says As: and this meaning is tropical; for it is from the phrase mar~a yazoEabu biHimolihi meaning “ he went along [impelled by his load, or] easily with his load: ” accord. to another explanation, zAEbY~ applied to a spear means such that, when it is shaken, the whole of it is [in appearance] impelled in its several parts by the impetus of one part acting upon another, as though its hind part ran into its fore part: (TA:) or zaAEibiy~apN signifies spears, (S, TA,) universally. (TA.) You say also sinaAnN zaAEibiY~N (S, TA) A spear-head of Zá'ib. (TA.)
muzolaEib~N * : see zaAEibN; and see also art. zlEb.
1 zaEaja * : see 4. ― -b2- Also i. q. Tarada [He drove away, &c.]. (K.) -A2- And [i. q. zaEaqa, meaning] He called, called out, cried out, or shouted. (K.)

4 AzEjhu *
He disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried, him; (IDrd, S, K;) and removed him from his place: (S, A, Msb, K:) and ↓ zaEajahu signifies the same. (IDrd, K.) You say, A^azoEajotuhu Eano mawoDiEihi, (Msb,) or mino maHal~ihi, (A,) and mino bilaAdihi, (L,) I removed him, or unsettled him, from his place, and from his country. (A, L, Msb.) And it is said in a trad., raA^ayotu Eumura yuzoEiju A^abaA bakorK, meaning I saw 'Omar rousing Aboo-Bekr, and not suffering him to remain still. (TA.) And in another, AlHalifu yuzoEiju Als~iloEapa wayaHomaqu Albarakapa, meaning, accord. to Az, [Swearing] lowers in estimation [the commodity that one desires to recommend thereby and does away with the
blessing thereof]: or, accord. to IAth, causes it to be easy of sale and to go forth from the hand of its owner [but does away with the blessing thereof]. (TA.) A_izoEaAjN [is the inf. n.; and as inf. n. of the pass. verb,] signifies [The being disquieted, &c.; and hence,] the quitting of home. (Har p. 392.)

7 AnzEj *
He was, or became, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried; (S, K;) and was, or became, removed, or unsettled, from his place: (S, A, L, Msb, K:) it may be thus used as quasipass. of AzEj: (Kh, Msb:) or it should not be so used: (Msb:) it is, however, agreeable with analogy, as is also ↓ AzdEj: (L:) but the word commonly used in its stead is $axaSa: (L, Msb:) zaEaja in this sense is not allowable. (L.)
8 AzdEj * : see what next precedes.

zaEajN *
Disquietude, disturbance, or agitation: (K, TA:) a subst. [not an inf. n.] in this sense. (TA.)
mizoEaAjN * An unquiet woman, who remains not still, or settled, in one place. (S, A, K.)

1 zaEira * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
zaEara , (Msb, K,) inf. n. zaEarN, (S, A, Msb, K,) His hair, (S, A, Msb,) and his plumage, (A,) was, or became, scanty, (S, A, Msb,) and thin; (A;) as also ↓ AzEAr~: (A:) and it (hair, and plumage, K, and fur, TA) was, or became, scanty, and thin; (K, TA;) as also ↓ AzEr~ and ↓ AzEAr~. (K.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) His good things, or wealth, or his beneficence, became scanty, or wanting; he became poor; or he became niggardly. (TA.) ― -b3- And, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) It (the disposition) became evil, or bad: but the verb is seldom used in this sense. (TA.) See zaEaAr~apN.
9 A_izoEar~a see above.
11 A_izoEaAor~a see 1, in two places.
zaEarN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also zaEaAr~apN.
zaEirN * : see A^azoEaru, in two places: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

zuEoruwrN * (assumed tropical:) A man of bad disposition, or illnatured: (S, K:) the vulgar say ↓ zaEirN. (S. [zaEiru Alxuluqi occurs in the TA in art. lZ.]) -A2- A well-known fruit; (S;) the fruit of a well-known tree; (K;) the fruit of a tree, of which there is a red species and a yellow, having a round and hard stone; (Mgh;) a fruit of the desert, in make resembling the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree], and in the taste of which is acidity; (Msb;) it may be the wild nabiq: (Msb, voce sidorN:) AA says that the nulok is the zErwr; and IDrd, that the Arabs do not know it: [it is a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p: (TA:) [the name is now applied to the medlar, or a species thereof: accord. to Golius, the “ mespilum; special. quod genus aronium vocat Dios. i. 169: ”] accord. to ISh, the tree called dulob: (T:) this, says Sgh, is different from what J has mentioned. (TA.)

zaEaAr~apN * , (S, A, Msb, K,) [respecting the form of which see HamaAr~apN,] and zaEaArapN, (S, A, K,) the latter a vulgar form, (S,) and ↓ zaEarN, (A,) (tropical:) Illnature; excessive perverseness or crossness: (S, Msb, K:) nouns having no corresponding verb: (S:) or the verb is ↓ zaEira, but it is seldom used. (TA.)
zayoEarN * (tropical:) A man having little wealth. (K, TA.)

A^azoEarN * A man (S) having scanty hair, (S, A, Msb,) and thin: and a bird having scanty and thin plumage: (A:) fem. zaEoraA='u: (A, Msb:) and hair and plumage that is scanty and thin; as also ↓ zaEirN. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A place having few plants, or little herbage; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ zaEirN: (K, TA: in the CK, zaEorN:) pl. [of the former] zuEorN. (TA.)

1 zaEafahu * , (S, K,) aor.
raEafa , (K,) inf. n. zaEofN, (S,) He, or it, killed him on the spot; (S, K;) as also ↓ AzEfhu, and ↓ AzdEfhu; (K;) the last mentioned by As, as syn. with A^aqoEaSahu: (TA:) or cast, or shot, at him, or smote him, so that he died on the spot, quickly: (L, TA:) and killed him quickly. (S.) ― -b2- See also 4. -A2- zaEafa fiY Hadiyvihi He added, or exaggerated, or he lied, in his discourse, or narration. (Mj, L.)
4 A^aroEafa see above. ― -b2- AzEf Ealayohi He despatched him; or hastened and completed his slaughter; (El-Khárzenjee, K;) as also ↓ zaEafahu, aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.)
8 AzdEfhu * [originally AizotaEafahu]: see 1.

zuEaAfN * , applied to poison, like zuw^aAfN (S, K) and *uEaAfN [meaning Quick in its effect]; and in like manner applied to death: (S:) and ↓ muzoEifN, applied to death, and to a sword, that will not suffer one to linger; killing on the spot; (K;) as applied to a sword, thus expl. by As; as applied to death, expl. by Skr as meaning quick. (TA.)
zuEuwfN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Places of destruction. (IAar, K.)
HisoYN muzoEafN * [Water which the earth imbibes from sand above it, and which, when it reaches what is hard, is arrested thereby,] such as is not sweet. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

muzuEifN * : see zuEaAfN. ― -b2- AlmuzoEifu is also the name of a certain sword, (K, TA,) belonging to 'AbdAllah Ibn-Sebreh, one of the braves of El-Islám; thus accord. to Az: (TA:) or this is with r; (Sgh, K;) and is thus found in the handwriting of Mohammad Ibn-El-' Abbás El-Yezeedee, with a dot beneath the r, to show that it is not z. (Sgh, TA.)

AlmizoEaAfapu *
The serpent; (K;) as also AlmizoEaAmapu. (TA.) [Accord. to Freytag, mizoEaAfapu Alr~iyqi occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning The serpent: or the lion.]
[See also art. *Ef, passim.]

Q. 1 zaEofara *
He dyed a garment, or piece of cloth, with zaEofaraAn [or saffron]. (S, A, Msb, K.)

zaEofaraAnN *
A certain dye and perfume, (TA,) well-known; (Msb, K;) [namely, saffron:] if it be in a house or chamber, the [lizard called] saAm~u A^aboraSa will not enter it: (K:) pl. zaEaAfiru. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The rust of iron: pl. as above. (K.)

muzaEofarN * A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with zaEofaraAn [or saffron]. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- [The kind of sweet food called] faAluw*N, (K, TA,) and also called mulaw~aSN and muzaEozaEN. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A lion of the colour termed warod [or red inclining to yellow]: (S, K:) because its [natural] colour is such: or because having upon him marks of blood. (TA)

1 zaEaqa * , aor.
zaEaqa , (K,) inf. n. zaEoqN, (TA,) He called out, or cried out. (K, TA.) You say; zaEaqotu bihi, inf. n. as above, I called out, or cried out, to him: (S:) of the dial. of Syria. (TA.) ― -b2- And zaEaqa bidawaAb~ihi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He drove away his beasts: (K:) or he called out, or cried out, to his beasts, and drove them away quickly. (TA.) ― -b3- And zaEaqahu, (K,) and zaEaqa bihi, (TA, as from the K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n. in both cases, (TA,) He frightened him; as also ↓ AzEqhu: and ↓ A^azoEaquwhu They frightened him: (K:) or they frightened him so that he became brisk, lively, or sprightly: (TA:) or you say, Alxawofu Hat~aY zaEiqa ↓ AzEqhu [Fear affected him so that he became brisk, lively, or sprightly, yet fearful]: accord. to As, one says ↓ A^azoEaqotuhu, and the epithet applied to the object is ↓ mazoEuwqN, differing form rule; but accord. to El-Umawee, one says zaEaqotuhu, and the epithet so applied is ↓ mazoEuwqN. (S.) ― -b4- zaEaqati Alr~iyHu Alt~uraAba The wind raised the dust: or made it to go to and fro: syn. A^avaAratohu, (K,) or A^amaAratohu. (IB.) ― -b5- zaEaqatohu AlEaqorabu The scorpion stung him. (L, K.) ― -b6- zagaqa Alqidora, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put much salt into the cooking-pot; as also ↓ AzEqhA. (K.) -A2- zaEiqa, aor.
zaEaqa , (K,) inf. n. zaEaqN; (TA;) and zuEiqa, like EuniYa; and ↓ AnzEq: He feared by night: (K:) but in the T, the restriction to the night is not added; nor is it in the instance of the last of these verbs in the O. (TA.) ― -b2- And zaEiqa, aor.
zaEaqa , (S, K, TA,) inf. n. zaEaqN; (S, TA;) and zuEiqa; (K; [but only the former accord. to the TA, as in the S;]) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, (S, K,) but with fear; (S;) as also ↓ AnzEq. (S. [This meaning of the last verb is indicated, but not expressed, in the S.]) -A3- zaEuqa, (K,) inf. n. zaEaAqapN (TK) [and zuEuwqapN], It (water) was, or became, bitter, (K, TA,) so that it could not be drunk [by reason of its bitterness, or saltness, or bitterness and saltness, or burning saltness, or intense bitterness or saltness: see zuEaAqN]. (K.)

4 A^azoEaqa see above, in five places. -A2- A^azoEaquwA Als~ayora [app. for fiY Als~ayori] They made haste [in the journey, or rate of going]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) -A3- AzEq also signifies He produced, or fetched out, by
labour [in digging], water such as is termed zuEaAq. (TA.) And AzEqwA They, in digging, came upon water such as is termed zuEaAq. (K.)

7 A_inozaEaqa see 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- AnzEqt Ald~awaAb~u The beasts hastened, or went quickly. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And AnzEq Alfarasu The horse went forward, or before. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

zaEiqN *
Fearing, or fearing by night. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Brisk, lively, or sprightly, (S, K,) but with fear. (S.) [See also mazoEuwqN.] ― -b3- hawolN zaEiqN Vehement terror. (TA.) -A2- biy^orN zaEiqapN A well of which the water is such as is termed zuEaAq. (TA.)

[
zaEoqapN * inf. n. un. of zaEaqa; A call, or cry: pl. zaEaqaAtN.]

zuEaAqN *
A disposition to take fright and run away at random. (IF, O, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (IF, O,) as an epithet applied to a mountain-goat, Wont to take fright and run away at random. (IF, O, K.) -A2- Also Salt water: (S:) or very salt water; like HuraAqN: (TA in art. Hrq:) or water that is bitter, (mur~N galiyZN, Lth, O, K, both of which epithets, applied to water, signify the same, TA in art. glZ,) so that it cannot be drunk (Lth, O, K) by reason of its bitterness, or saltness, or bitterness and saltness, or burning saltness, or intense bitterness or saltness: (Lth, O:) used alike as sing. and pl. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, A^akalotuhu zuEaAqFA, meaning I ate it with so much salt in it that it was bitter. (Lth, O.) See also mazoEuwqN.
zaEiyqN * : see mazoEuwqN.

zaE~aAqN *
One who drives away the beasts, and cries out after them. (TA.) [See also zaAEiqN.] ― -b2- Applied to a horse, A good goer; or strong to walk, or go: (Ibn-' Abbád, K:) and also (Ibn- ' Abbád) very quick. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)
zuEoquwqapN * The young of the qaboj, (Lth, K, TA,) which means the Hajal [or partridge], and [sometimes] the karawaAn [or stone-curlew]: pl. zaEaAqiyqu. (TA.)
zaAEiqN * One who calls out, or cries out, to his beasts, and drives them away quickly: or who drives them, and cries out to them vehemently. (TA.) [See also zaE~aAqN.]

mizoEaqN *
Quick: so in the phrase sayorN mizoEaqN [a quick pace or journeying]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) And one says also, nazaEa fiY Alqawosi nazoEFA mizoEaqFA, (Ibn- ' Abbád, K,) i. e. [He drew the bow] quickly. (TA.) -A2- It signifies also miqolaAEN tuqolaEu bihi AlA^araDuwna [app. meaning An implement with which the lands, or fields, are broken up]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

mazoEuwqN *
Frightened; as also ↓ zaEiyqN: (K:) [or frightened so as to be rendered brisk, lively, or sprightly, with fear:] see 1, in two places. [See also zaEiqN.] Applied to a colt, Frightened, and sharp in spirit: (S:) or, applied to a man, sharp in spirit: and, applied to a colt, well fed. (TA.) ― -b2- A^aroDN mazoEuwqapN Land rained upon by vehement rain falling in large drops. (K, TA.) -A2- TaEaAmN mazoEuwqN Food having much salt put in it; (S, K;) as also ↓ zuEaAqN. (TA.) And qidorN mazoEuwqapN A cooking-pot in which much salt has been put. (TA.)

1 zaEila * , (S, K,) aor.
zaEala , (K,) inf. n. zaEalN; (S, TA;) and ↓ tzE~l; (K;) He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; (S, K, TA;) and he exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a horse) curvetted, pranced, leaped, sprang, or bounded, without his rider. (K.) ― -b3- And He writhed, or cried out and writhed, by reason of hunger. (TA.) ― -b4- [In the modern language, He was, or became, weary: one says, zaEilotu minohu I was, or became, weary of it.]

4 AzElhu * [in the CK erroneously written zAEalahu] It (pasture, and fatness, TA) rendered him [i. e. a beast] brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And AzElhu mino makaAnihi He, or it, removed him, or unsettled him, from his place. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)
5 tazaE~ala see 1.

zaEilN *
Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; (S, TA;) as also ↓ A_izoEiylN: (K:) the former is applied in this sense to a horse; and ↓ the latter, as well as the former, to an ass, [i. e. a wild ass,] as meaning brisk, lively, &c., and curvetting, prancing, leaping, springing, or bounding: and the former signifies also exulting, or exulting greatly, or excessively, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: pl. zuE~alN, applied by Tarafeh to male ostriches. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Writhing, or crying out and writhing, by reason of hunger. (S, K.)

zuEoluwlN *
Light, or active, (Kr, K,) in spirit and in body: (TA in art. zgl:) accord. to Kr and Ibn-' Abbád, with E and with g: in the “ Mu- sannaf ” of A'Obeyd, with g only. (TA.)

zaEolaAnu *
Writhing, or crying out and writhing, having no rest; as also ↓ mutazaE~ilN. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the modern language, Weary: (see 1, last sentence:) and having its fem. with p.]
A_izoEiylN * : see zaEilN, in two places.
mutazaE~ilN * : see zaEolaAnu.

1 zaEama * , (S, Msb,) aor.
zaEuma , (Msb, MS, JM, [not mentioned in the S nor in the K, app. because well known,]) inf. n. zaEomN and zuEomN and zEomN, (S, Msb, K,) the first of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (Msb, TA,) the second of the dial. of [the tribe of] Asad, (Msb,) or Benoo-Temeem, (TA,) and the third of the dial. of some of [the tribe of] Keys; (Msb;) [generally best rendered He asserted; for it mostly relates to a thing not certainly known: or] he said; (S, Msb, K;) as in the phrases zaEamati AlHanafiy~apN [The Hanafees said or asserted, or have said or asserted,] and zaEama siybawayohi [Seebaweyh said or asserted, or has said or asserted]; (Msb;) [and zaEama A^an~ahu ka*aA He said, or asserted, that it was thus;] either truly or falsely: (K:) mostly used in relation to a thing respecting which there is doubt, (Sh, Az, Msb, K,) and which is not certainly known: (Sh, Az, Msb:) or it is mostly used in relation to that which is false, or that respecting which there is doubt, or suspicion: (El-Marzookee, Msb:) or, as those skilled in the language of the Arabs say, in relation to a thing of which the speaker doubts, and does not know whether it may not be false: (Lth:) or zaEama zaEomFA means he related a piece of information not knowing whether it were true or false. (IKoot, Msb.) Hence the saying, zaEama maTiy~apu Alka*ibi [i. e. (assumed tropical:) zaEama is the conveyer, or vehicle, (properly the camel, or beast, that serves as the conveyer,) of lying]. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., biy^osa maTiy~apu Alr~ajuli zaEamuwA [(assumed tropical:) Very evil, or bad, is the man's conveyer zaEamuwA]: i. e., when a man desires to journey to a country, or town, he mounts his camel, or beast, that serves to convey him, and journeys until he accomplishes the object of his want: therefore, that with which the speaker prefaces his speech, and by means of which he attains the object of his desire, when he says zaEamuwA ka*aA waka*aA, is likened to the camel, or beast, by means of which he attains the object of want: for zaEamuwA is [generally] said only in the case of a narration that has no authority whereon to rest, and that contains no proof. (TA.) IKh says that Alz~aEomu is used in relation to that which is discommended; and that its primary signification is said by some of the expositors of the Kur-án to be The act of lying: (TA: [this signification is also given in the K, as being contr. to the first:]) some say that it is metonymically used in this sense: (Msb:) and it is expl. as having this meaning in the Kur [vi. 137], where it is said, faqaAluwA h`*aA lil~`hi bizaEomihimo, i. e. [And they have said, “ This belongeth unto God, ”] with their lying. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- [Sometimes] zaEamahu signifies He described him, or it. (Har p. 204.) ― -b3- And sometimes zaEama signifies He promised: whence the saying of ' Amr Ibn-Sha-s,
taquwlu halakonaA A_ino halakota waA_in~amaA
EalaYA@ll~`hu A^arozaAqu AlEibaAdi kamaA zaEamo
[Thou sayest, or she says, “ We perish if thou perish: ” but verily upon God lie the means of subsistence of mankind, i. e. it lies upon Him to supply these, as He has promised]. (TA.) ― -b4- Alz~aEomu is used also in the sense of AlZ~an~u: (Msb, TA:) one says, fiY zaEomiY ka*aA [In my opinion it is thus]. (Msb.) [Hence, likewise,] zaEamotaniY ka*aA, (K,) aor. tazoEumuniY, (TA,) Thou thoughtest me to be thus. (K, TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
faA_ino tuzoEumiyniY kunotu A^ajohalu fiykumu
faA_in~iY $arayotu AlHiloma baEodaki biAljaholi
[And if thou think me such that I used to be ignorant, or to act ignorantly, among you, know
that I have purchased intelligence since I was with thee (baEodaki being for baEoda EahodiY biki) in exchange for ignorance]. (TA. [The meaning of tzEmynY is there indicated by the context.]) ― -b5- It is also used in the sense of AlAiEotiqaAdu: whence the saying in the Kur [lxiv. 7], zaEama A@l~a*iyna kafaruw A^ano lano yuboEavuwA [They who have disbelieved our revelations have believed, or firmly believed, that they shall not be raised from the dead]. (Msb.) ― -b6- Sometimes, also, zaEama is used in the sense of $ahida: as in the saying of En-Nábighah,
zaEama AlhumaAmu biA^an~a faAhaA baAridN
[app. meaning The magnanimous chief bore witness that her mouth was cool]. (TA.) -A2- zaEama bihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zaEuma (S, Msb) and
zaEama , (Msb,) inf. n. zaEomN (S, Msb, K) and zaEaAmapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He was, or became, responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, for it; (S, Msb, K;) namely, property. (Msb.) ― -b2- And zaEama, like qatala, (Msb,) or zaEuma, like karuma, (TA,) aor.
zaEuma , inf. n. zaEaAmapN, He was, or became, chief, lord, master, or prince, (Msb, TA,) of a people, (TA,) or EalaY qawomK [over a people]; (Msb;) or spokesman of a people. (TA.) -A3- See also 4, in two places. -A4- zaEima, aor.
zaEama , (S, K,) inf. n. zaEamN (S, TA) and zaEomN, (TA,) He coveted, or eagerly desired. (S, K.) [Like its syn. TamiEa, it is trans. by means of fiY.] One says, ↓ zaEima fulaAnN fiY gayori mazoEamK, i. e. TamiEa fY gayori maToEamK [Such a one coveted a thing not to be coveted; meaning, a thing of which the attainment was remote, or improbable: see art. TmE]. (TA.) And ' Antarah says,
Eul~iqotuhaA EaraDFA waA^aqotulu qawomahaA
zaEamFA laEamoru A^abiyka layosa bimazoEami
(S,) i. e. I became enamoured of her unintentionally, [or accidentally,] while I was slaying her people; eagerly desiring her love: by the life of thy father, I swear, this is not a [fit] occasion for eager desire: i. e. I can not attain to holding communion of love with thee, [or with her,] any day, while there is this conflict and hostility between the two tribes: (EM p. 222:) layosa bimazoEamK meaning layosa bimaTomaEK : (S:) or, [as some relate it,]
zaEomFA warab~i Albayoti layosa bimazoEami
[eagerly desiring: by the Lord of the House (i. e. the Kaabeh), &c.]. (TA. [zaEomFA is there expressly said to be thus: but the measure does not require its being so.])
3 zAEm * , (K,) inf. n. muzaAEamapN, (TA,) i. q. zaAHama [q. v.]: (K:) the E is a substitute for the H. (TA.)

4 AzEm *
He made a person to be such as is termed zaEiym; (Msb, TA;) as meaning responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee. (Msb.) You say, A^azoEamotuka AlmaAla, (Msb,) or Al$~aYo'a, (TA,) I made thee, or have made thee, responsible, &c., (Msb, TA, *) [for the property, or the thing;] i. e. zaEiymFA bihi. (Msb, TA.) -A2- He made one to covet, or eagerly desire. (S, K.) You say, A^azoEamotuhu. (S.) [And A^azoEamotuhu fiY Al$~aYo'i I made him to covet, or eagerly desire, the thing; like as you say, A^aTomaEotuhu fiyhi. See zaEima.] -A3- He obeyed (K, TA) the zaEiym [i. e. chief, lord, or prince]. (TA.) -A4- It (an affair) was, or became, possible. (K.) ― -b2- It (milk) began to become good, or pleasant; [or fit to be drunk;] as also ↓ zaEama, (K,) inf. n. zaEomN. (TA.) ― -b3- AzEmt said of a young she-camel, or of one full-grown, She was thought to have fat in her hump. (IKh, TA. [The TA states it to have been asserted by IKh that the verb is only used in this sense, or (for the passage is ambiguous) in this sense and the first mentioned above.]) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or ↓ zaEamato, (TA, [but this I think to be probably a mistranscription,]) said of the earth, or land, (AlA^aroDu,) It put forth the first of its plants, or herbage. (IAar, K, TA.)

5 tzE~m *
i. q. taka*~aba [q. v.]: (S, K:) [it seems here to mean He spoke falsely; and to be trans.; for] a poet says,
A^ay~uhaA Alz~aAEimu maA tazaE~amaA
[app. meaning O thou asserter of that which thou hast spoken falsely]. (TA. [This hemistich is there cited as an ex. of tzE~m as expl. in the K; and I find no other explanation of this verb.])

6 tazaAEamaA *
They two competed in discoursing of a thing, and differed respecting it: accord. to Z, it means they talked of, or related, zaEamaAt, i. e. [mere assertions, or] stories in which no confidence was to be placed. (TA.) Sh says that Alt~azaAEumu is mostly used in relation to a thing respecting which there is doubt. (TA.) -A2- One says also, tzAEm Alqawomu, meaning The people, or party, became responsible, one for another: and hence, tzAEmwA EalaY ka*aA they leagued together, and aided one another, against such a thing. (TA.)

zuEomN * [originally an inf. n. of zaEama, like zaEomN and ziEomN,] is a word used by the vulgar as meaning kiborN [i. e. Pride; and, as often used in the present day, pretension: because implying false, or vain, assertion]. (TA.)
zaEamN * and ↓ zaEaAmapN Responsibility, answerableness, amenableness, or suretiship; substs. from zaEama bihi : (Msb:) or the latter is an inf. n. (S, K.)

zaEimN * , applied to roasted meat, (K, TA,) Dripping with its gravy; or succulent, and dripping with its juice or fat; (TA;) having much grease, or gravy; quickly flowing [therewith] over the fire. (K.)

zaEomapN * [inf. n. of un. of zaEama; An assertion; &c.: pl. zaEamaAtN]. One says, h`*aA walaA zaEomataka and wlA zaEamaAtika [meaning This I think, and I think not to be true thine assertion and thine assertions]; A^atawah~amu being understood after lA : these words are used as meaning the rejection of what has been said by the person to whom they are addressed. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, zaEomatika and zaEomaAtika.]) They said also, zaEomapN SaAdiqapN laA=tiyan~aka [i. e. It is a true assertion: I will assuredly come to thee]; using the nom. case : though they said, yamiynFA SaAdiqapF laA^afoEalan~a [i. e. I swear “ a true oath : I will assuredly do ” such a thing]; using the accus. case. (Ks, TA.) And one says, taHaAdavaA biAlz~aEamaAti, meaning They two talked of, or related, each to the other, [mere assertions, or] stories in which no confidence was to be placed. (Z, TA.)
zuEomiY~N * (with damm, TA) Mendacious: and veracious: (K:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (TA.)
zuEomuwmN * : see the next paragraph.

zaEuwmN * , a fem. epithet, (S, K, &c.,) applied to a she-camel, and to a sheep or goat, Of which one doubts whether there be in her fat or not, (S, K,) and which is therefore felt with the hands, in order that one may know if she be fat or lean: (S:) or a sheep or goat of which one knows not whether there be in her fat or not: (As, TA:) or, as some say, of which men assert that there is in her marrow. (TA.) And, as a fem. epithet, Having little fat: and having much fat: thus bearing two contr. senses: as also ↓muzoEamapN [app. in both senses]: (M, K:) and ↓mazoEuwmapN also signifies having little fat; of which people, when they eat of her, say to her owner, “ Didst thou assert her to be fat? ” applied to a she-camel. (TA.) -A2- Also Impotent in speech; (K;) and so ↓zuEomuwmN. (S, * K.)

zaEiymN *
Responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xii. 72], waA^anaA bihi zaEiymN [And I am responsible for it]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The chief, lord, master, or prince, or a people; (Msb, K;) or [in the CK “ and ”] their spokesman: (K:) their chief is thus called because he speaks for them; like as he is called qayolN and miqowalN: (Ham p. 705:) pl. zuEamaA='u. (K.) -A2- Also Described; syn. mawoSuwfN. (Har p. 204.)

zaEaAmapN * : see zaEamN. ― -b2- Also High, or elevated, rank or condition or state; or nobility. (K.) And Chiefdom, lordship, mastery, or princedom: (IAar, S, K:) [accord. to the Msb, an inf. n. in this sense:] thus expl. by IAar as occurring in the following verse of Lebeed: (TA:)
wawitorFA waAlz~aEaAmapu lilogulaAmi
taTiyru EadaAy^idu AlA^a$oraAki $afoEFA
(S and TA in the present art. and in art. Ed) [The portions of inheritance of the sharers fly away, two together and singly; but the chiefdom is for the boy]: by his saying $afoEFA wawitorFA, he means that the male's share of inheritance is like that of two females [so that he has two portions when the female has one]: but other explanations, those here following, are given of AlzEAmp as used in this verse. (TA. [See also EadiydapN.]) ― -b3- A weapon, or weapons; syn. silaAHN. (S, K.) So, accord. to J, in the verse of Lebeed: for, he says, they used, when they divided the inheritance, to give the weapon, or weapons, to the son, exclusively of the daughter. (TA.) ― -b4- A coat of mail: (K:) or coats of mail: and thus it is
expl. by IAar as used in the verse of Lebeed. (TA.) ― -b5- The chief's share of spoil. (K.) ― -b6- And The best and most of the property of an inheritance and the like: (K:) and thus, also, it has been expl. as used in the verse of Lebeed. (TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ zaE~aAmapN, An animal of the ox-kind; [probably meaning one of the wild species;] syn. baqarapN. (K.)
zaE~aAmapN * : see the next preceding sentence.

mazoEamN * A thing, or an affair, -in which no confidence is to be placed; (S, K;) this saying, or asserting, it to be thus, and this saying, or asserting, it to be thus: (S:) [pl. mazaAEimu.] One says, fiY qawolihi mazaAEimu (S, TA) i. e. [In his saying are things in which no confidence is to be placed; or] no confidence is to be placed in his saying. (TA.) And h`*aA A^amorN fiyhi mazaAEimu This is an affair that is not right; (TA;) [wherein are things] respecting which there is dispute. (K, TA.) And zaEama gayora mazoEamK He said that which was not good, or right, or just; and asserted what was impossible. (Msb.) -A2- Also A thing that is, or is to be, coveted, or eagerly desired; syn. maTomaEN. (S, TA.) See two exs. near the end of the first paragraph.
muzoEamN * : see its fem., with p, voce zaEuwmN.

A^amorN muzoEimN *
A thing, or an affair, that makes one to covet, or desire eagerly. (TA.)
mazoEuwmN * : see its fem., with p, voce zaEuwmN.

mizoEaAmapN *
A serpent. (K.)

huwa muzaAEamN *
No confidence is to be placed in him, or it. (So in the TA. [But I incline to think it a mistranscription for fiyhi mazaAEimu. See mazoEamN.])

1 zagiba * , aor.
zagaba , (Msb, K,) inf. n. zagabN; (Msb;) and ↓ zg~b, (JK, S, A, K,) inf. n. tazogiybN; (S;) and ↓ AzgAb~; (K;) It, or he, was, or became, downy; or had upon it, or him, what is termed zagabN meaning as expl. below; (JK, S, K;) in any of its senses: (TA:) said of a young bird, (JK, S, A, Msb,) meaning [as above, or] its zagab [or down] grew forth: (A:) or its feathers were small: and, said of a boy, or a young child, his zagab [or downy hair] grew forth: (Msb:) and ↓ Aizolagab~a is also said of a young bird [in the same sense as the verbs above: (see art. zlgb:) or] as meaning its feathers came forth. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baHorN yazogabu (assumed tropical:) A sea, or great river, that becomes [foaming, or] in a state of commotion, and full. (JK.)
2 zag~aba see the preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and that here following.

4 Azgb * , said of a grape-vine, (S, K,) i. e., app., accord. to [J and] F, like A^akorama, but accord. to others of the leading lexicologists it seems to be [↓ Azgb~,] like AiHomar~a; as also ↓ AzgAb~; It produced what resembled zagab [or down], at the knots of the shoots, whence the bunches of grapes would grow: (TA:) this it does when the sap flows in it, (S, K, TA,) and it begins to produce leaves. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A'Obeyd, in applying to the truffles termed banaAtu A^awobara the epithet mzgbp, [written in art. wbr in copies of the K ↓ muzogibapN, and in the T and S and M ↓ muzag~ibapN, but in the present art. in the TA it seems to be indicated that it is probably ↓ muzogib~apN,] signifying having zagab [i. e. down], assigns to it a verb [which may be A^azogabato or ↓ zag~abato or ↓ Aizogab~ato, meaning They had, or produced, a kind of downy substance]. (TA.)

8 Azdgb maA EalaY AlxiwaAni *
He took away, or swept away, [or devoured,] the whole of what was on the table of food: like Azdgf. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. zEb.]
9 A_izogab~a see 4, in two places.
11 A_izogaAob~a see 1: ― -b2- and see also 4.
Q. Q. 4 Aizolagab~a * : see 1; and see also art. zlgb.

zagabN * [Down:] or the yellow [down resembling] small hairs upon the feathers of the young bird: (S:) or small and soft hair and feathers: or each of these when first coming forth: (A, K:) i. e. (TA) the small and soft hair when it first appears, of a young child, (Msb, TA,) and of a colt [or foal]; (JK, * TA;) and likewise of an old man, when his hair becomes thin and weak; (Msb;) and the feathers when they first appear, (Msb, TA,) of the young bird: (TA:) and small feathers that do not become long nor good: (JK, Msb:) n. un. with p: (TA:) and what remains upon the head of an old man when his hair has become thin. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^axa*ahu bizagabihi (assumed tropical:) He took it at its commencement, or in its first and fresh state. (JK, K.) And A^axa*ahu bizagabi raqabatihi [lit. He took him by the down of his neck;] meaning (assumed tropical:) he overtook him. (JK.)
zagibN * : see A^azogabu, in three places.
zugabN * : see A^azogabu.

zugaAbapN * and ↓ zugaAbaY The smallest of zagab [or down]: (JK, K:) or something less in quantity than zagab: or something smaller than zagab. (TA.) One says, maA A^aSabotu minohu zugaAbapF (JK, A, K, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [I obtained not from him, or it,] as much as what is termed zgAbp: (L, TA:) or (tropical:) the least thing: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) anything. (K.)
zugaAbaY * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^azogabu * [Downy;] having upon it, or him, what is termed zagab; as also ↓ zagibN: fem. of the former zagobaA='u; and pl. zugobN. (TA.) You say faroxN A^azogabu [A downy young bird]: (A:) and firaAxN zugobN [downy young birds]. (S.) And rajulN ↓ zagibN [A downy man]: (JK:) or ↓ rajulN zagibu Al$~aEari [a man having downy hair]. (Msb, TA.) And raqabapN zagobaA='u [A downy neck]. (JK, A, Msb.) And qiv~aA='u A^azogabu (AHn, A, TA) (tropical:) [A species of cucumber] having upon it what resembles the zagab [or down] of fur, which falls off by degrees when they become large, leaving them smooth. (AHn, TA.) [For another epithet of similar meaning, see 4, in three places.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A species of fig, (AHn, K,) larger than the waHo$iY~ [or wild], upon which is zagab [or down]: when stripped of this, it comes forth black: it is large, thick, and sweet: but it is a worthless sort of fig. (AHn, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a horse, Black and white; or white in the hind legs as high as the thighs; syn. A^abolaqu. (K.) And [in like manner] applied to a mountain, Of which the whiteness is intermixed with its blackness; as also ↓ zugabN. (JK, K, TA. [In some of the copies of the K, for mina AljibaAli, we find mn AlHibaAli: that the former is the right reading, contr. to the assertion of Freytag app. based on the explanation in the TK, appears from its being added that the fem.] Alz~agobaA='u is the name of a certain mountain in El-Kibleeyeh; (K, TA;) in some copies of the K, El-Kabaleeyeh. (TA.)
muzogibapN * , or muzag~ibapN, or muzogib~apN: see 4.

Q. 1 zagobara *
It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) had what is termed zigobir, or zigobur, &c., i. e. ziy^obir [or nap]. (O, K.)

zigobirN * , (O and TA, and so in a copy of the K,) or zagobarN, or zigobarN, (as in two different copies of the K,) and zigoburN, (O and TA, and so accord. to a copy of the K,) or zagoburN, (accord. to another copy of the K,) of a garment, or piece of cloth, i. q. ziy^obirN [i. e. The nap: see ziy^obirN, in art. zbr]. (O, K.) [Hence, app., supposing zagobarN to be a dial. var., having the signification expl. above,] A^axa*a Al$~aYo'a bizagobarihi He took the thing altogether, (O, K, * TA,) leaving nothing of it; as also bizaA^obarihi, and bizawobarihi. (O, TA.)

Q. 1 zagoradapN * The braying that is reiterated (L, K) in the fauces, or throat, (L,) or in the jawof [meaning chest], (K,) of the camel: (L, K:) an inf. n., of which the verb is zagorada: you say, zagorada AlbaEiyru. (TK.) ― -b2- Hence the zagoradap of women on the occasions of rejoicings. (TA.) [One says, of a woman, zagoradato, more commonly in the present day zagoraTato, meaning She uttered shrill, quavering, or rapidly-reiterated, sounds, or cries of joy: which sounds, or cries, are termed ↓ zagaAriydu, and now more commonly zagaAriyT.]
zagaAriydu * : see above.

4 Azglhu * , inf. n. A_izogaAlN, He poured it out, or forth. (TA. [And zagalahu app. signifies the same.]) One says, A^azogala mino EazolaA='i AlmazaAdapi AlmaA='a He poured forth, from the spout of the leathern water-bag, the water. (TA.) And mino siqaAy^ika ↓ A^azogilo liY zugolapF, (S,) or mino A_inaAy^ika, (K, [in the CK Azogalo, i. e. Aizogalo, from zagalahu,]) Pour thou out, for me, somewhat (S, K) [or a gulp or mouthful] of milk from thy skin, (S,) or from thy vessel. (K.) See also 1, in two places. One says also, A^azogalati Aln~aAqapu bibawolihaA (S, K) and bihi ↓ zagalato (K) The she-camel ejected her urine (S, K, TA) in repeated small quantities (↓ zugolapF zugolapF), and interrupted it. (S, TA.) And A^azogalati AlT~aEonapu biAld~ami, like A^awozagat [i. e. The wound made with a spear or the like emitted blood in repeated gushes]. (S, K.) ― -b2- A^azogalato waladahaA She suckled her child. (JK, TA.)
