And Azgl faroxahu He (a bird) fed his young one with his mouth, or bill: (S, K:) [and Argl is a dial. var. thereof.] -A2- A^azogalota, said by 'Ásim to Mis'ar, when the latter was reading, or reciting, to him, and did so incorrectly, means Thou hast become like the zugoluwl, i. e. young infant: mentioned by Z: (TA:) or he said A^azogalota, which is a dial. var. of the former verb. (TA in art. rgl.)

zagalN *
i. q. gi$~N [meaning Adulterated, or counterfeit, coin: so in the present day]. (TA.) [See also zugaliY~N.]

zugolapN *
A mouthful, or the quantity that fills the mouth; of milk [&c.]; heard in this sense by Az from an Arab of the desert; (TA;) a gulp of wine or beverage [&c.]: pl. zugolN [perhaps a mistranscription for zugalN: if not, it is a coll. gen. n.]. (MA.) See 4. ― -b2- The quantity that is emitted, or poured forth, at once, [without interruption,] of urine, (S, K,) &c. (K.) See, again, 4. ― -b3- The quantity that one spirts forth from his mouth, of wine or beverage. (K.) -A2- Alz~ugolapu also signifies The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (El-Hejeree, K.)

zugaliY~N * [A maker of adulterated, or counterfeit, coin; a meaning indicated in the TA, and obtaining in the present day:] an epithet from Alz~agalu, used by the vulgar and by persons of distinction. (TA.)

zugoluwlN *
Light, or active, (Kr, JK, S, K,) in spirit and in body, (IKh, TA,) and quick; an epithet applied to a man: (JK:) mentioned by Kr with E and with g: (TA:) in the “ Musannaf ” of A'Obeyd, with g only. (TA in art. zEl.) ― -b2- Also A young infant: (JK, S, K:) pl. zagaAliylu. (TA.) One says SiboyapN zagaAliylu Little children. (TA.) And kayofa zugoluwluka How is thy little one? (A, TA.) ― -b3- And An orphan. (IKh, TA.) ― -b4- And The young one of the pigeon. (TA.) ― -b5- [Freytag explains it as signifying also “ Pallus ovis, cameli lactens; ” but whether this be intended to express a single meaning is not clear to me: ― -b6- also, on the authority of Dmr, as signifying A man light in respect of dignity and manners: app. as being likened to a young child.]
zaguwlN * , applied to [the young one of] a camel and [of] a sheep or goat, Persistent in suching. (K.)
muzogilN * [without p because applied only to a female,] A woman suckling her child. (JK, TA.)

mazogalapN *
A drinking-vessel that holds a [zugolap i. e.] gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once [of wine or beverage]. (MA.)

1 zaf~a AlEaruwsa * , (K,) or zafafotuhaA, (S,) or zaf~atohaA Aln~isaA='u, (Msb,) aor.
zafu3a , (Msb, K,) inf. n. zaf~N (S, Msb, K) and zifaAfN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and ↓ Azf~hA, (K,) or AzffthA, (S,) or Azf~thA AlnsA='; (Msb;) and ↓ Azdf~hA, (K,) or AzdffthA, (S,) [or Azdf~thA AlnsA=';] A_ilaY zawojihaA; all signify the same; (S, Msb, * K;) i. e. He, [or I,] or the women, sent [or conducted] the bride [with festive parade or pageantry, and generally with music,] to her husband: (Msb, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, zf~ AlErws is a metaphorical phrase, from zafozafapu Aln~aEaAmi; because she is conducted with joyous alacrity. (TA.) -A2- zaf~a, aor.
zafi3a , inf. n. zafiyfN (S, K) and zaf~N and zufuwfN, (K,) or zafiyfN is a simple subst., (Msb,) said of an ostrich, (S, K,) and of a camel, (S,) &c., (K,) He hastened, or was quick; (S, K;) as also ↓ Azf~: (IAar, K:) accord. to Lh, said of a man and of others; and ↓ Azf~, he says, is the more unusual of the two: (TA:) or zaf~a, aor.
zafi3a , is said, in this sense, of a man: and, accord. to the Mj, said of an ostrich, inf. n. zafiyfN, it means he hastened, or was quick, so that a [sound such as is termed] zafiyf was heard to be produced by his wings: (Msb:) or zaf~N and ↓ A_izofaAfN are like *amiylN [which signifies the going a gentle pace; or a pace above that which is termed AlEanaqu, and above that which is termed Alt~azay~udu]: (K, * TA: [in the CK, Alz~amiyl is put for Al*~amiyl:]) or the first running of the ostrich: (K:) or zafiyfN has this last meaning: (TA:) or signifies the going quickly and with short steps: (Lh, TA:) or the going quickly, with short steps, and quietly. (TA.) You say, zaf~a Alqawomu fiY ma$oyihimo The people, or party, hastened, or were quick, in their walking, or marching, or going along: and hence, in the Kur [xxxvii. 92], faA^aqobluwA A_ilayohi yazif~uwna, (S,) i. e. [And they advanced towards him] hastening, or going quickly. (Fr, TA. [But there are other readings, for which see Bd.]) [Hence also,] one says zaf~a raA^oluhu, meaning (tropical:) He was, or became, light of intellect, lightwitted, or irresolute. (S, Z, TA. [See also art. rA^l]) ― -b2- zaf~a, inf. n. zafiyfN (O, K) and zaf~N, (K,) said of a bird, (O, K,) in his flight, (O,) He cast himself: ('Eyn, O, K:) or he spread his wings: and so ↓ zafozafa [app. in either sense]: (K:) and the latter, he moved [or flapped] his wings in running. (TA.) ― -b3- zaf~ati Alr~iyHu, (S, K,) aor.
zafi3a , (S,) inf. n. zafiyfN and zufuwfN, (TA,) The wind blew along, (S, K,) not violently: (S:) or blew gently and continually: (TA:) and ↓ zafozafat signifies the same: (K, TA:) or the latter, inf. n. zafozafapN, signifies it blew violently: so in the T: or it blew gently: (TA:) or zafozafapN signifies the moaning (Haniyn) of the wind, and its sounding among the trees. (S.) ― -b4- zaf~a, (O, K,) inf. n. zafiyfN, (TA,) said of lightning, It shone, or gleamed. (O, K, TA.)

4 Azf~ * , inf. n. A_izofaAfN, intrans.: see 1, in three places. -A2- Azf~ AlEaruwsa: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Azf~hu He made him to hasten, or go quickly; (S, L, K;) namely, a camel, (S, L,) and an ostrich. (S.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning He led him to do light, vain, things.]
8 Azdf~ AlEaruwsa * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Azdf~ AlHimola He carried, took up and carried, or raised upon his back, the load. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

10 Astzf~hu Als~ayolu * , (Ibn-' Abbád, A, O, TA,) thus correctly, but in the copies of the K Als~ayoru, (TA,) The torrent found it light to carry (Aisotaxaf~ahu, Ibn-' Abbád, A, O, K), and took it away. (Ibn- ' Abbád, A, O, TA.)

R. Q. 1 zafozafa * , [inf. n. zafozafapN,] said of a man, He walked in a comely manner. (TA.) ― -b2- zafozafapN also signifies The running vehemently. (K.) ― -b3- And A certain manner, or rate, of going, of camels, said to be beyond, or above, what is termed Alxababu. (TA.) ― -b4- Said of a bird: see 1, latter part. ― -b5- And zafozafat said of the wind: see, again, 1, latter part. The inf. n. signifies The wind's putting in motion the dry herbage, and making a sound therein: (K, TA:) you say, of the dry herbage, zafozafatohu Alr~iyHu [The wind put it in motion, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- The inf. n. signifies also The noising, or noise-making, of a procession, or company of men riding or walking along. (IDrd, K.) ― -b7- And The sounding of an arrow when it is twirled round upon the nail [of the left thumb: see dar~a Als~ahomu, in art. dr]. (TA.) ― -b8- It is related in a trad., that the Prophet said to a woman, maA laki tuzafozafiyna, (O, K, TA, in some copies of the K tuzafozifiyna,) with damm to the first letter; (K) to which she replied “ The fever, may God not bless it; ” and he said “ Revile not thou the fever, for it does away with the sins of the sons of Adam like as the blacksmith's skin with which he blows his fire does away with the dross of the iron: ” (O, TA:) the meaning is, [What aileth thee] that thou art made to tremble, or quake? (turoEadiyna: O, K, TA: in some copies of the K turoEidiyna:) [see also mazofuwfN:] or it is with fet-h to the t, (O, K, TA,) i. e. tazafozafiyna [for tatazafozafyna, from ↓ tazafozafato], (O,) meaning, that thou tremblest, or quakest? (O, K:) or it is with kesr to the [latter] z,
[tuzafozifiyna,] meaning, that thou moanest, as does he who is sick: (TA:) or, as some relate it, it is with r [in the place of the z, i. e. tuzaforifiyna, having the second of the meanings expl. above in this sentence, or nearly so]. (K.)
R. Q. 1 tazaforafato * : see the next preceding paragraph, last sentence.

zif~N *
Small feathers of the ostrich, (S, K,) and (S, in the K “ or ”) of a bird (S, K) of any kind: (K:) or small feathers, like down, beneath the thickset feathers: (IDrd, O, TA:) accord. to some, only of the ostrich: (O, TA:) [pl., app., zifaAfN: see zafaAzifu.] One says A^aloyanu mino zif~i Aln~aEaAmi [More soft than the small feathers of the ostrich]. (TA.)

zaf~apN * (tropical:) A time; one time; syn. mar~apN: (K:) one says, jiy^otuhu zaf~apF, or zaf~atayoni, (tropical:) I came to him once, or twice. (TA.) A single act of zafiyf [i. e. hastening, or going quickly]. (TA. [This seems to be the primary signification.])

zuf~apN *
A company, or congregated body, of men. (O, K.) Hence the saying of the Prophet to Bilál, on the occasion of the marriage of Fátimeh, A^adoxili Aln~aAsa EalaY~a zuf~apF zuf~apF, meaning Bring thou in the people to me company after company. (O, TA.)
zafafN * , in a male ostrich, The quality of having abundant and dense zif~, i. e. small feathers. (S, K.)

zafuwfN * : see zafozafN. ― -b2- Hence it is applied to a she-camel, as being likened to an ostrich in her quickness; (TA;) meaning [Quick: or] good in pace, and quick. (Ham p. 750.) And Alz~afuwfu is the name of a certain horse that belonged to Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir. (O.) ― -b3- Also A twanging bow. (TA.)

zafiyfN * (S, K) and ↓ A^azaf~u and ↓ zif~aAniY~N, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) or ↓ zif~aAnN, without Y, (L, TA,) Quick, (Ibn-'Abbád, S, L, K,) like *afiyfN, (S,) and light. (L, TA. [In the CK the explanation is omitted.]) -A2- It is also an inf. n.: (S, K, &c.:) or a simple subst. (Msb.) [See 1, in several places.)
zif~aAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zif~aAniY~u * : see the next preceding paragraph.

zafozafN * and ↓ zafozaAfN [the latter of which is omitted in the CK] A wind that blows violently, with continuance; as also ↓ zafozaAfapN, (K, TA,) or zafozafapN: (CK:) or ↓ zafozaAfapN and zafozafN a wind making a moaning (Haniyn), and sounding among the trees: (S:) or zafozafN a quick, or swift, wind: or zafozafapN and ↓ zafozaAfapN and ↓ zafozaAfN a violent wind, having a zafozafap, i. e. sounding: the pl. of zafozafN is zafaAzifu. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (i. e. the first and second words,) Light [in motion or action]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And The ostrich; (K;) so called because of his lightness of pace; or because of his zafozafap, meaning his moving [or flapping] of his wings when running; (TA;) and so ↓ zafuwfN. (K.)
zafozaAfN * , and with p: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

zafaAzifu * pl. of zafozafN. ― -b2- It is also used by a Hudhalee poet [app. referring to birds] as meaning *awaAtu zifaAfK [i. e., supposing zifaAf to be pl. of zif~N, agreeably with analogy, Having small, downy, feathers]. (TA.)

[
zaAf~N * act. part. n. of zaf~a in the phrase zaf~a AlEaruwsa: fem. with p: pl. of the latter zawaAf~u. Hence,] zaHafato zawaAf~uhaA, a phrase mentioned by Lh, meaning All~awaAtiYzafafonahaA [i. e. The women who conducted her to her husband walked along gently]. (TA.)
A^azaf~u * A male ostrich having abundant and dense zif~, i. e. small feathers. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also zafiyfN.

mizaf~apN *
A [vehicle of the kind called] miHaf~apN in which, or upon which, the bride is sent [or conducted] to her husband. (Kh, S, K.)

[
mazofuwfN * pass. part. n. of zaf~a in a sense not mentioned, and perhaps not used. Hence,] baAta mazofuwfFA a phrase meaning bAt tuzafozifuhu Alr~iyHu [i. e. He passed the night made to tremble, or quake, by the wind]. (TA.)

2 zf~t *
He smeared a receptacle [such as a wine-skin and a wine-jar] with zifot. (Msb.)

zifotN * [Pitch: or tar: or a sort of pitch: or crude pitch:] i. q. qaArN: (A, Mgh, K:) or qiyrN: (Msb:) or qaTiraAnN: (A, Msb:) or it is like qiyrN: (S:) it is not the qiyr with which ships are smeared, but [like this inasmuch as] it is also a black substance, with which wine-skins are seasoned; for the qyr of ships dries upon them, whereas the zft of skins does not dry: (TA:) or [crude pitch; i. e.] a produce of the pine, or pitch-tree; which is of two sorts, moist and dry; the latter being either cooked, or congealed of itself; such as flows of itself from the trees is called zft; such as is prepared by cooking, and art, qaTiraAnN. (TK.) [See also kuforN: and see De Sacy's “ Abd-allatif, ” p. 273.] ― -b2- Also, (K, * TA,) i. e. zifotN, (TA,) [not muzaf~atN, which Freytag has supposed to be here intended in the K, and not without some reason, for the passage is ambiguous,] A certain medicine; (K, TA;) a thing that comes forth from the earth, [app. a sort of bitumen, perhaps another name for qaforN yahuwdiY~N bitumen Judaicum, or Jew's pitch,] that is an ingredient in medicines: not the zft commonly known. (TA.)

muzaf~atN *
Smeared with zifot; (S, A, * Mgh, K;) applied to a wine-skin, (A,) or a vessel, or receptacle for wine; i. q. muqay~arN. (TA.) The receptacle thus termed quickly occasions alteration [or fermentation] in the wine [contained in it]. (Mgh.) You say jar~apN muzaf~atapN A jar smeared with zifot. (S.) And it is said in a trad., nahaY Eani Almuzaf~ati [He forbade the use of that skin, or vessel, which is smeared with zft, for the beverage called nabiy*]. (TA.)

1 zafara * , aor.
zafira , (S, K,) inf. n. zafiyrN (S, A, K) and raforN (K) and A_izofiyrN, (M, [like A_iroziyzN, app. an inf. n., or perhaps a simple subst.,]) He drew in his breath to the utmost, by reason of distress: (S:) it originally signifies he drew back his breath vehemently, so that his ribs became swollen out: (Er-Rághib:) zafiyrN is the beginning of the cry of the ass, (Lth, S, A, Er-Rághib,) and of the like, (Lth,) and is generally used in this sense; (Er-Rághib;) and $ahiyqN is the ending thereof; (Lth, S, A, Er-Rághib;) for the former is the drawing in of the breath, and the latter is the sending it forth: (Lth, S:) or the verb signifies he sent forth his breath, after prolonging it: (M, K:) or he sent forth his breath with a prolonged sound: [i. e., he sighed, or uttered a long sigh, or sighed vehemently; or he groaned:] or he filled his chest, by reason of grief, and then sent forth his breath: (TA:) or he breathed, raising his voice, like one moaning, or in grief. (Har p. 20.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zafarati Aln~aAru (assumed tropical:) The fire made a sound to be heard from its burning, or its fierce burning: (K:) and this [sounding] is termed zafiyrN. (TA.) [See also HadomN; where zaforN, its inf. n., is expl., on the authority of AZ, as signifying The flaming, or blazing, of fire.] And AlbaHoru yazofiru bitamaw~ujihi (tropical:) [The sea makes a roaring by its tumultuousness]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- zafarati AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land put forth its plants, or herbage. (TA.) -A2- zafara, aor.
zafira , (S, A, K,) inf. n. zaforN; (S, K;) and ↓ Azdfr; (S, K;) He carried, (S, A, K,) a thing, (K,) or a load, or burden, (S, A,) as, for ex., a filled water-skin. (TA.) You say, yazofiruwna Eanohu AlA^avoqaAla [They bear, or carry, or take off from him, and carry, his burdens]. (A.) ― -b2- He drew, (K, TA,) and carried, (TA,) water. (K, TA.)
2 zaf~ara see the next paragraph.

5 tzf~r * occurs in the Saheeh of El-Bukháree as meaning taxab~aTa [q. v.]: but El-Jelál says, in the Towsheeh, that this is not known in the language of the Arabs. (MF.) -A2- [Freytag explains it as meaning He ate fat food, breaking the fast; like ↓ zf~r; (which latter generally means, in the present day, he rendered greasy;) but this I believe to be post-classical. See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 270.]
8 A_izotafara see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

ziforN *
A load, or burden, syn. HimolN, (S, A, K,) on the back, (K,) or on the head, that is heavy, and in consequence of which the bearer breathes vehemently, or groans (yazofiru): (A:) pl. A^azofaArN. (S, A.) ― -b2- A [water-skin of the kind called] qirobap: (S, K:) a skin in which a pastor carries his water: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- The apparatus of a traveller, (K,) comprising the water-skin &c. (TA.)
― -b4- A lamb; syn. HamalN: so in the Bári'. (K.) This signification and that of HimolN are both correct. (TA.)

zafarN *
A prop of a tree. (K, TA.) -A2- [In modern Arabic, it means Grease, greasy food, or flesh-meat: app. from the Pers. zafaro or zafor, signifying “ filth: ” and hence, obscenity. Hence also the vulgar epithet zifir (app. for zafirN), meaning Greasy: and foul, or filthy: and obscene. See 5.]

zufarN * (tropical:) A sea, (K,) that makes a roaring, (yazofiru,) by reason of its tumultuousness. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A river containing much water, (K,) so that it resembles a sea. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A large gift, (K,) as likened to a sea. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A liberal man; likened to a sea that makes a roaring, (yazofiru,) by reason of its tumultuousness; (A;) as also ↓ zaAfirapN. (TA.) ― -b5- One who carries loads, or burdens; meaning, who has strength to carry water-skins. (K.) [See also zaAfirapN.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) One who has power to bear responsibilities. (Sh, S. *) ― -b7- Hence, (assumed tropical:) A lord, master, chief, or the like: (S:) or, for the same reason, a great lord, or the like; (TA;) as also ↓ zaAfirapN. (K, TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A courageous man. (K, * TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A lion. (K.) ― -b10- See also zaAfirapN, in three places: ― -b11- and zafiyrN.

zaforapN *
A drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress: (S:) [or a drawing-back of the breath vehemently, so that the ribs become swollen out: (see 1:)] or an emission of the breath after prolonging it; as also ↓ zuforapN and ↓ muzodafarN and ↓ muzaf~arN, (K, TA,) or ↓ muzofarN, (as in a copy of the K,) and ↓ muzaf~arapN: (CK, but omitted in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K:) [or an emission of the breath with a prolonged sound; i. e., a sigh, or a long or vehement sigh; or a groan: or an emission of the breath after filling the chest with it by reason of grief: (see, again, 1:)] pl. zafaraAtN, because it is a subst., not an epithet; but sometimes, by poetic license, zaforaAtN. (S.) El-Jaadee says,
yarojiEo EalaY diq~apK walaAhaDami
xiyTa EalaYzaforapK fatam~a walamo
meaning As though he were sewed up after a drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress, so that he seemed to be constantly so drawing in his breath, on account of the largeness of his belly, [and did not become restored to slenderness nor lankness of the belly.] (S.) And another says,
fatasotariyHu Aln~afosu mino zaforaAtihaA
[And the soul finds rest from its drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress; or from its sighs, &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, ↓ all the words above mentioned, [A man] breathing [in the manner above described]; syn. mutanaf~isN; [unless this be a mistranscription for mutanaf~isN meaning the place of (such) breathing; as seems probable from the forms of more than one of these words, and from what follows, and also from an explanation of muzodafarN, below.] (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also zaforapN (K, TA) and ↓ zuforapN (S, K, * TA [but not the other words mentioned above, as is implied in the CK,]) The middle (S, K) of a thing, (K,) or of a horse: (S:) or the chest, or belly: pl. of the former, zafaraAtN. (TA.) One says, ↓ A_in~ahu laEaZiymu Alz~uforapi Verily he is great in the middle: (S, TA:) or in the chest, or belly. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, of a camel, or other beast, maA A^a$ad~a zaforatahu, meaning How strong is the knitting together of his joints! (TA.)
zuforapN * : see zaforapN, in four places.

zafiyrN *
A calamity; a misfortune; (S, K;) as also ↓ zufarN. (TA.)

zaAfirN * One who [carries or] helps to carry loads, or burdens: (TA:) and zawaAfiru [pl. of ↓ zaAfirapN] female slaves that carry water-skins (S) or [other] loads, or burdens. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

zaAfirapN * : see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A bulky camel; (K;) and so ↓ zufarN: (Sgh, K:) because he carries loads, or burdens. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The kaAhil [or withers, or upper portion of the back, next the neck,] with what is next to it. (TA.) [Because loads are borne upon it.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The side, or angle, (rukon,) of a building, (K,) upon which it [mainly] rests, or is supported: pl. zawaAfiru. (TA.) [Hence the expression] limajodihimo zawaAfiru (tropical:) Their glory has props that strengthen it. (A, K. *) ― -b5- (tropical:) A man's aiders, or assistants, (S, TA,) and his kinsfolk, or tribe, syn. Ea$iyrap, (S, A, K,) as also zawaAfiru; because they bear his burdens: (A:) his aiders, or assistants, and particular friends. (TA.) You say, humo zaAfiratuhumo Einoda Als~uloTaAni (tropical:) They are the persons who undertake and perform their business with the Sultán. (S.) And qawomihi ↓ huwa zaAfiru, and zaAfiratuhumo, also, Einoda Als~uloTaAni, (tropical:) He is the chief of his people, and the bearer of their burdens, with the Sultán. (A.) See also zufarN, in two places. ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A company, or congregated body, (K,) of men; (TA;) as also ↓ zufarN. (K, * TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) An army; or a collected portion thereof; or a troop of horse; syn. katiybapN, as also ↓ zufarN. (K.) ― -b8- (tropical:) [A rib: pl. zawaAfiru.] You say farasN $adiydu Alz~awaAfiru (tropical:) A horse having strong ribs. (A.) ― -b9- (tropical:) A bow: (K:) pl. zawaAfiru: (A:) so called as being likened to a rib: (TA:) [or perhaps from its sound.] ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) The part of an arrow exclusive of the feathers: (S, K:) or the part exclusive of two thirds, next the head: ('Eesà Ibn-'Omar, S, K:) or the part from a little below the head to the head: (ISh:) or about a third part of an arrow, and of a spear. (TA.) [Perhaps so called from its sound.] -A2- A^um~u zaAfirapKa The baborap [or female of the babor]. (T in art. Am.)

A^azofaru * A horse large in the sides: (K:) or in the ribs of the sides: or in the chest, or belly: or in the middle: (TA:) pl. zuforN. (K.) ― -b2- Alz~aforaA='u, used as a subst., The pudendum; like AlmaEoTaA='u; syn. Als~awo'apu. (IAar, TA in art. mET.)
muzaf~arN * , or muzofarN, and muzaf~arapN: see zaforapN, in two places.
mazofuwrN * A beast, (K,) or camel, (TA,) having his joints strongly knit together. (K, TA.) You say also, huwa mazofuwru Alxaloqi [He is strongly compacted in make]. (TA.)
muzodafarN * The part of the breast (juw^ojuw^) of a horse from which the breathing termed zafiyr [see 1] proceeds. (AO, O, K.) ― -b2- See also zaforapN, in two places.

A^azofalu * [whether with or without tenween is not shown; but accord. to general opinion, a word of this measure, if not an epithet, is perfectly decl., i. e. with tenween;] Anger; and sharpness, or hastiness of temper. (K.)

A^azofalapN *
A company, or collection, (S, K, TA,) of men, and of camels: (TA:) and ↓ A^azofalaY is like A^ajofalaY, (S,) syn. therewith, (K,) signifying a collection, or an assemblage, of any things. (TA.) One says, jaAw^uwA biA^azofalatihimo (Fr, S, TA) and biA^ajofalatihimo (Fr, TA) They came with their company. (Fr, S, TA.) And jaA=w^uwA A^azofalapF and A^ajofalapF They came in a company. (Fr, S and K * in art. jfl.)
A^azofalaY * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A_izofal~apN *
i. q. xif~apN [Lightness, levity, &c.]: (Sb, S, K:) so in the saying, A^axa*otuhu A_izofal~apN [Lightness, or levity, &c., seized him, or affected him]. (Sb, S.)

1 zafanahu * , (TA, and Har p. 124,) aor.
zafina , (TA,) inf. n. zafonN, (TA, Har,) in its primary acceptation, He pushed, or thrust, or he pushed, or thrust, away, (TA, Har,) vehemently: and he struck [or kicked] with the leg, or hind leg. (Har.) You say, danawotu minohu fazafananiY I approached him, and he pushed me, or thrust me, from him. (TA.) And huwa yazofinu AlmaTiY~a He drives, or urges on, the saddlecamel. (TA.) And Alr~iyHu tazofinu Als~aHaAba and Alt~uraAba [The wind drives along the clouds and the dust]. (TA.) And AlA^amowaAju tazofinu Als~afiynapa [The waves drive along the ship]. (TA.) And AlmuHotaDaru yazofinu binafosihi, i. e. [He who is at the point of death] urges on his soul. (TA.) -A2- And zafana, aor.
zafina , (S, Mgh, Msb, K, in the CK
zafuna ,) inf. n. zafonN (S, Mgh, Msb) and zafanaAnN, (TA,) He danced; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and played, or sported. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Fátimeh, kaAnato tazofinu liloHasani She used to dance to El-Hasan. (TA.)
zafonN * : see what next follows.

zifonN *
A covering which they make over their flat house-tops to protect them from the heat and dew of the sea; (K;) of the dial. of 'Omán; and ↓ zafonN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And Straight and slender palm-branches stripped of their leaves [and cut to certain required lengths], conjoined, one to another, [side by side, by means of split pieces of such branches passing through holes punched in the former,] like the woven mat: (K:) [of such are made chests for cooking utensils and provisions &c.:] of the dial. of Azd. (TA.)

zafuwnN * , applied to a she-camel, i. q. zabuwnN [That pushes, or thrusts, or that pushes, or thrusts, away, or that kicks, or strikes, and pushes, &c., her milker with her hind leg, or with her stiflejoint; or that is wont, or accustomed, to do so]: or lame; as also ↓ zaAfinapN; (K;) as though she danced in her gait, in consequence of lameness. (TA.)

zaf~aAnN *
A dancer: [whence] one says, AlS~uwfiy~apu zaf~aAnapN jaf~aAnapN The Soofees are dancers, providers of food with their jafanaAt [or bowls, which many of them, leading a mendicant-life, as darweeshes, are in the habit of always carrying with them]. (TA.)
zaAfinapN * : see zafuwnN. ― -b2- Also A woman that suffices her man, or husband, in respect of the means of jimaAE. (K.)

ziyafonN * (S, K) and ziyfan~N (K) Tall; (K;) and strong; (S, K;) and some add, light, or active. (TA.) [In one copy of the S, I find it written zayofan; which its measure in poetry shows to be wrong.]

zayozafuwnN * , applied to a she-camel, Swift, (K,) and light, or active: IJ says that it is app. of the measure fayofaEuwlN, from Alz~afonu [as meaning “ the act of dancing ”]; or it may be a quadriliteralradical word: IB says that dayodabuwnN [which see in art. ddn] is similar to it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a bow, That makes a sound, or sounds, in consequence of being put in motion: and in this sense it is said by IJ to be of the measure fayofaEuwlN, from Alz~afonu. (TA.)

rajulN fiyhi A_izofan~apN *
A man in whom is motion, or commotion: and rajulN A_izofan~apN A man in a state of motion, or commotion: mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)

1 zaq~a faroxahu * , said of a bird, aor.
zaqu3a , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. zaq~N; (M, Msb, K;) and ↓ zaqozaqahu, (IDrd, M,) inf. n. zaqozaqapN; (K;) It fed its young one (S, M, K) with its mouth [or bill]; (S, M; *) it ejected food [from its bill] into the mouth of its young one. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, maA zilotu A^azuq~uhu biAlEilomi (tropical:) [I ceased not to instil into him, or to nourish him with, knowledge, or science]. (TA.) -A2- zaq~a bisaloHihi, mostly said of a bird, (M,) or zaq~a bi*aroqihi, said of a bird, (TA,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n.; (M, K, TA;) and ↓ zaqozaqa, (M, TA,) [bisaloHihi or] bi*aroqihi, (TA,) inf. n. zaqozaqapN; (K;) He cast forth his excrement; (M;) it (a bird) muted, or dunged. (M, K, TA.)

2 zq~q * , (M, TA,) inf. n. tazoqiyqN, (S, TA,) He stripped off a hide, or skin, by commencing from the head, (S, M, TA,) in order to make of it a ziq~ [q. v.]. (M, TA.) The doing thus is different from the mode now practised. (S.)

R. Q. 1 zaqozaqa * , inf. n. zaqozaqapN: see 1, above, in two places. ― -b2- [As inf. n. of the same verb,] zaqozaqapN also signifies A bird's uttering its cry, or voice, at dawn: (Lth. K:) or it is a word imitative of the cry, or voice, of the bird; (M, TA;) and he who thus explains it does not restrict it by adding “ at dawn. ” (TA.) ― -b3- Also [as an onomatopæia] A weak laughing. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b4- And The being light, or active, (K, and Har p. 375,) and quick. (Har ibid.) ― -b5- Also a word of the dial. of Kelb, app. meaning The being quick in speech, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) and making one part thereof to follow close upon another. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b6- And The dancing a child; (Lth, S, M, K;) as also ziqozaAqN, [which is likewise an inf. n. of the same verb,] (Lth, M, K,) with kesr. (K.)
zuq~N * one of the names of Wine: (Moheet, K: *) pl., as in the Moheet, ziqaqapN; but accord. to the K, zaqaqapN. (TA.)

ziq~N * [A skin for holding wine &c.:] any receptacle, consisting of a skin, that is used for wine and the like: or, as some say, not thus called unless it be stripped off from the part next the animal's neck: or, accord. to AHn, one in which wine is conveyed: (M:) or a skin for water or milk; syn. siqaA='N: (S, K:) or a skin of which the hair is clipped, not plucked out, (Lth, K,) for wine and the like, (Lth,) or for wine &c.: (K:) or a receptacle, (ZarofN, Msb, and Har p. 335,) of skin, in which are put clarified butter and vinegar and wine: (Har ibid.:) or, as some say, a Zarof smeared with zifot: (Msb:) AHát says that it is such as is smeared with zifot or with qiyr: (TA:) pl. (of pauc., S) A^azoqaAqN (S, M, Msb, K) and A^azuq~N, mentioned by El-Hejeree, (M,) and (of mult., S) ziqaAqN (S, M, K) and zuq~aAnN [in the CK erroneously written ruq~AqN]. (S, M, Msb, K, TA.)

zuq~apN *
A certain small bird; (K;) a certain aquatic bird, that remains still until it is almost seized, and then dives, and comes forth far off: pl. zuqaqN. (M.)
zaqaAqN * : see zaq~aAqN.

zuqaAqN *
A sik~ap [meaning street]: (S, K:) or [rather a by-street, or lane;] a narrow Tariyq [here meaning street], (M,) less than a sik~ap, (M, Mgh, Msb,) whether a thoroughfare or not: (Mgh, Msb:) masc. (S, Msb) and fem.: (S, Msb, K:) Akh says that the people of El-Hijáz make AlT~ariyqu and AlS~iraATu (S, Msb) and Als~abiylu (S) and Als~uwqu and Alz~uqaAqu (S, Msb) and Alkal~aA='u, which is the market of El-Basrah, (S,) fem.; and Temeem make them masc., (S, Msb,) i. e. all of these: (S:) pl. [of pauc., but also used as a pl. of mult.,] A^aziq~apN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of mult.] zuq~aAnN. (Sb, S, M, K.) mano hadaYzuqaAqFA, occurring in a trad., means He who has guided the erring and the blind to his way. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alz~uqaAqu [The strait of Gibraltar;] the passage of the sea between Tanjeh and El-Jezeereh el-Khad- rà, in the west, (K, TA,) by El-Andalus; called zuqaAqu sabotapa. (TA.)

zaq~aAqN * The maker of the [kind of skin called] ziq~. (TA.) -A2- Also, as in the copies of the Moheet and the A [and in the JK], or ↓ zaqaAqN, like saHaAbN, accord. to the K, but the former is probably the right, (TA,) One who drinks water (Moheet, A, K) at the table, (Moheet, K,) while having food in his mouth. (Moheet, A, K.) [As shown in the A, it is an epithet applied to a greedy man.]

zaqozaAqapN *
Light, or active, in her walk; (K, TA;) applied to a woman. (TA.)

muzaq~aqN * A ram skinned from his head to his hind leg; (Lh, TA;) as also ↓ mazoquwqN: (Lh, K, TA:) contr. of muraj~alN (TA) and of marojuwlN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A skin of which the hair is clipped, not cut off. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being like such a skin, (assumed tropical:) A head of which all the hair is cut off. (K, * TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A man having all the hair of his head cut off. (TA.) ― -b4- muzaq~aqapN A large she-camel: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or a she-camel whose skin is filled with fat after her fleshiness. (En-Nadr, TA.)
mazoquwqN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
muzaqozaqN * Any work that is accomplished quickly. (K.)
1 zaqabahu fiY juHorihi * , (JK, S, K, *) and fiYAlkuw~api, (TA,) He made him (a field-rat, S, TA) to enter [into his hole, and into the aperture in a wall]. (S, K, TA.) -A2- See also 7.
2 zq~b * , (AZ, TA,) inf. n. tazoqiybN, (AZ, K, TA,) He (the bird called muk~aA=') sent forth his voice, or cry. (AZ, K.)

7 Anzqb *
He entered (T, S, K) into his hole, (JK, S, K,) said of a field-rat; (JK, S;) as also ↓ zaqaba; (K;) or into a thing; as also Anzbq: (T, TA:) or he entered into it and concealed himself. (IKtt, TA in art. nms.)

zaqabN * , (K,) and TariyqN zaqabN, (Lh, S,) [in which the latter word may be either a substitute for the former or an epithet,] A narrow road or way: (Lh, S, K:) pl. zuqubN: (TA:) and n. un. with p; or this and the pl. are alike. (K, TA.) The phrase maTaAribN zaqabN occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce maTorabN; [the former word being with tenween for the sake of the measure;] or, as some relate it, zuqubN: (S, TA:) in this instance, zqb is a substitute for mTArb: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, mTArb signifies narrow roads or ways, and zqb signifies narrow: (TA:) or TariyqN zaqabN signifies an obscure narrow road or way. (JK.) ― -b2- One says also, ramayotuhu mino zaqabK, meaning I threw, or shot, at him, or it, from a near spot. (JK, K.)

1 zaqomN * is syn. with laqomN [The act of gobbling a thing; i. e. eating it quickly, and hastily; or drawing it with the mouth, and eating it quickly: or swallowing it: (see also 5 and 8:)]: (AA, K, TA:) or laqomN $adiydN [vehement gobbling; &c.]: (TA:) you say, zaqamahu, aor.
zaquma , inf. n. zaqomN, meaning laqimahu [He gobbled it; &c.]. (TK.) [And par-
ticularly] The eating what is termed Alz~aq~uwm, as meaning a certain food in which are dates and fresh butter: (S:) [or so zaqomu zaq~uwmK; for] you say, ↓ zq~m, inf. n. tazoqiymN, he ate Alz~aq~uwm; as also zaqamahu, inf. n. zaqomN. (TA.)
2 zaq~ama see above. -A2- [Freytag explains it as signifying He gave a person a thing to eat; but without indicating his authority.]

4 Azqmhu Al$~aYo'a *
He made him to swallow the thing. (S, K. *)

5 tazaq~umN * is syn. with talaq~umN [The swallowing a thing in a leisurely manner]: (S, K:) [or simply the swallowing a thing: for] you say, tzq~m All~uqomapa [He swallowed in a leisurely manner the gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful: or simply] he swallowed the gobbet. (TA. [See also 1 and 8.]) ― -b2- Also The drinking milk much, or abundantly: and the subst. is zqm [app. ↓ zaqomN, as it is written without any syll. signs; meaning, I suppose, A copious draught of milk]. (TA.) Accord. to IDrd, one says, tzq~m fulaAnN All~abana, meaning Such a one drank immoderately of the milk; or drank the milk immoderately. (S, TA.)

8 Aizodaqamahu *
He swallowed it. (S, K. [See also 1 and 5.])
zaqomN * : see 5.

zaqomapN *
Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Th, K.) One says, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAlz~aqomapi [God smote him, or may God smite him, with the plague, or pestilence]. (TK.)

zaq~uwmN *
Fresh butter with dates; (M, K;) in the dial. of Ifreekeeyeh: (M, TA:) or a certain food of the Arabs, in which are dates and fresh butter. (S.) ― -b2- Also Any deadly food. (Th, TA.) ― -b3- The food of the people of the fire [of Hell]. (ISd, K.) A certain tree in Hell: (K:) [respecting which] I'Ab says that when the saying [in the Kur xliv. 43 and 44] A_in~a $jarapa A@lz~aq~uwmi TaEaAmu A@loA^aviymi [Verily the tree of Alz~aq~uwm shall be the food of the sinner] was revealed, Aboo-Jahl said, “Dates and fresh butter: we will swallow it leisurely:” therefore God revealed [these other words of the Kur, xxxvii. 62 and 63,] A_in~ahaA $ajarapN taxoruju fiY A^aSoli A@lojaHiymi TaloEuhaA kaA^an~ahu ruw^uwsu A@l$~ayaATiyni [Verily it is a tree coming forth in the bottom of Hell, the fruit thereof being as though it were the heads of the devils, or of terrible serpents, foul in aspect, having manes, as expl. by Bd]: (S:) it is thus called after a tree of which a description here follows. (Bd in xxxvii. 60.) ― -b4- A certain tree having small leaves, stinking (dafirap), and bitter, found in Tihámeh: (Bd ubi suprà:) AHn says, (S, TA, [but this passage is only in one of my two copies of the S,]) on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of Azd es-Saráh, that the zaq~uwm is a dust-coloured tree, (S, TA,) having small round leaves, without thorns, (TA,) having a pungent odour (*afirap [perhaps a mistranscription for dafirap i. e. stinking]), and bitter, having knots in its stems, (S, TA,) many in number, and a small and very weak flower, which the bees eat, or lick, for making honey; (S, TA;) its flower is white; and the heads of its leaves are very foul, or ugly: (S, * TA:) [or] a certain plant in the desert (AlbaAdiyap), having a flower resembling in form the jasmine. (K.) ― -b5- Also A certain tree in Areehà [i. e. Jericho], of [the district called] the Ghowr, having a fruit like the date, sweet, with an astringent and bitter quality; the stone of which has an oil greatly esteemed for its beneficial properties, wonderful of operation in dispersing the cold kinds of flatus, and phlegmatic disorders, and pains of the joints, and gout in the foot (niqoris), and sciatica, and the flatus that is confined in the socket of the hip: the weight of seven drachms thereof is drunk three days or five days; and sometimes, or often, it makes to rise and stand the crippled and those who are deprived of the power of motion: it is said that its original was the [species of] A_iholiylaj [or myrobalan] called kaAbuliY~, which the Benoo-Umeiyeh removed (from India, TA), and planted in Areehà; and when it had long remained, the soil of Areehà altered it from the natural character of the Ahlylj. (K.)

1 zakaA^ahu * , (S, K,) aor.
zakaAa , (K,) inf. n. zako'N, (S,) He paid it in ready money, quickly, or promptly; or was quick, or prompt, in doing so. (ISk, S.) [The verb is doubly trans. in this sense:) you say, zakaA^ahu A^alofFA He paid him a thousand (meaning a thousand dirhems, TA) in ready money, quickly, or promptly. (K, TA.) And zakaA^otuhu Haq~ahu, inf. n. as above, I paid him his due; as also nakaA^otuhu Hq~h, inf. n. nako'N. (ISh, TA) ― -b2- And zakaA^ati Aln~aAqapu biwaladihaA, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) The she-camel cast forth her young one at her hind legs, or hind feet, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or at her hind leg, or hind foot: (so in other copies of the K:) or, in labour, cast forth her young one. (T, TA.) And one says also, qabaHa A@ll~`hu A^um~FA zakaA^ato bihi, and lakaA^otu bh, i. e. [May God remove from good, or prosperity, a mother that cast him forth from her womb, or] that brought him forth. (TA.) ― -b3- And zakaA^ahu, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He beat him, or struck him. (K.) So in the phrase zakaA^ahu miAy^apa sawoTK; [He beat him, or struck him, with a hundred stripes of the whip]. (TA.) ― -b4- And zakaA^a jaAriyatahu; He compressed his young woman, or female slave. (K.) -A2- zakaA^a A_ilayohi He had recourse to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; he leaned, or stayed himself, upon him, or it. (AZ, K.)

8 AizodakaA^a minohu Haq~ahu *
He took, or received, from him his due; (K;) as also AntkA^. (TA.)
zukaA^N * : see what next follows, in two places.

zajulN zukaA^apN * (S, K) and ↓ zukaA^N, (K,) and maliYo'N zukaA^apN (S) and ↓ zukaA^N, (TA,) and Aln~aqodi ↓ zukaA='u, (S, K,) A wealthy man, quick, or prompt, in paying: (S, * K:) [or rather this is the meaning when you combine the two epithets mlY' and zkA^p or zkA^: otherwise the meaning is only a man quick, or prompt, in paying: for] you say, latajidan~ahu zukaA^apF nukaA^apF meaning Thou wilt assuredly find him to be one who pays what he owes (TA) without putting off. (K in art. nkA^.)
zukaA='u Aln~aqodi * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mazokaA^N *
A refuge; an asylum; a place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging: [and applied to a man:] a poet says, speaking of Bishr Ibn-Marwán,
waniEoma mazokaA^u mano DaAqato ma*aAhibuhu
[And excellent, or most excellent, is the refuge of him whose ways have become strait]. (TA.)

1 zakara * , (A, K,) aor.
zakura , (TK,) inf. n. zakorN; (TA;) and ↓ zk~r, (K,) inf. n. tazokiyrN; (TA;) (tropical:) He filled (A, K) a vessel, (TA,) or a water-skin. (A.)
2 zak~ara see 1: ― -b2- and 5.

5 tzk~r * (tropical:) It (a child's belly) became large, (K,) or full, (S, A,) so that it was like a zukorap, (A,) and in good condition; (K;) as also ↓ zk~r, inf. n. tazokiyrN. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (beverage, or wine,) became collected (K) in a zukorap. (TA.)

zukorapN *
A certain small receptacle; (Msb;) a receptacle of skin, (A,) or a skin, (K,) or a small skin, (S, Mgh,) for wine, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or for vinegar: (K:) pl. zukarN. (Msb.)

1 zakama * , (K,) inf. n. zakomN, (TA,) He filled a water-skin: (K, TA:) and zakobN signifies the same as zakomN, i. e. the act of filling: this is the primary meaning. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- zakama binuTofatihi (tropical:) He emitted his sperma genitale (M, A, K) like the discharge of mucus from the nose of the mazokuwm. (A.) ― -b4- zakamato bihi A^um~uhu (assumed tropical:) His mother brought him forth [in an absolute sense (as in a saying here following), or], accord. to IAar, easily. (TA.) One says, laEana A@ll~`hu A^um~FA zakamato bihi (assumed tropical:) [May God curse a mother that brought him forth]. (TA.) -A2- zukima He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with zukaAm: (S, Msb, K:) [it is app. from zakamahu; but is thought to be] from A^azokamahu, q. v.; [and therefore] anomalous. (Msb.)

2 zak~amahu * is said by Golius to be syn. with A^azokamahu. But the only mention of zk~m that I find is in art. zkn in the S, where it is said that zk~n Ealayohi and zk~m signify $ab~aha Ealayohi, and lab~asa.]

4 Azkmhu *
He (God, S, Msb) caused him (a man, S) to be affected with zukaAm; (AZ, As, S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ zakamahu. (K.)

zakomapN * : see zukaAmN. -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Progeny: so says
IAar: or, accord. to Yaakoob, it is ↓ zukomapN. (TA.) One says, huwa A^aloA^amu zakomapi sawo'K [or ↓ zukomapi, i. e. He is the basest, most ignoble, or meanest, of evil progeny; or] meaning that he is not a good son. (TA.) -A3- Also The moaning, or hard breathing, (zaHorap,) with which the child comes forth; as also [zaHomapN and] zajomapN. (K, * TA.)

zukomapN * : see zukaAmN. -A2- Also (tropical:) The last of the children of his two parents. (S, K, TA.) You say, huwa zukomapu A^abawayohi He is the last of the children of his two parents. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also zakomapN, in two places. -A3- Also (tropical:) Heavy, and coarse, rough, or rude. (K, TA.)

zukaAmN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ zakomapN, (K,) or ↓ zukomapN, with damm, (Msb,) [A coryza, or catarrhus ad nares; a rheum, in the most usual sense of the term, meaning a defluxion from the head, chiefly from the nose; commonly called a cold in the head;] a defluxion of redundant humour from the two anterior venters of the brain to the nostrils: (K:) well known: (S, Msb:) from zakomN meaning the act of “ filling. ” (TA.)

mazokuwmN * [pass. part. n. of zakama]. You say qirobapN mazokuwmapN A filled water-skin. (TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a man, (AZ, As, S,) Affected with zukaAm: (AZ, As, S, Msb, K:) [regularly formed from zakamahu or zukima; but thought to be] from A^azokamahu; (AZ, As, S, Msb;) [and therefore] anomalous. (Msb.)

1 zakaA * , aor. yazokuw, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. zakaA='N, (S,) or zukuw~N, (Msb, [accord. to which the former seems to be a simple subst.,]) or both, (K, TA,) the latter like Euluw~N, as in the M, but accord. to [some of] the copies of the K zakowN, (TA,) It increased, or augmented; (S, Msb, K, TA;) it received increase and blessing from God; it throve by the blessing of God; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and produced fruit; (TA in art. zkY;) and zakiYa, (K in that art.,) aor. yazokaY, inf. n. zakaApN, (TA in that art.,) signifies the same, (K, TA,) mentioned by ISd, on the authority of Lh, as a dial. var. of zakaA, aor. yzkw; (TA;) and so ↓ AzkY; (Msb, K;) and ↓ tzk~Y: (K in art. zkY:) it is said of seed-produce, (S, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) and of wealth, or cattle &c., and of other things: of anything that increases, or augments, one says yazokuw, inf. n. zakaA='N. (TA.) [This is the primary meaning: or, accord. to some, the primary meaning is, It was, or became, pure:] some say that the root denotes purity: and some, that it denotes a state of increase, or augmentation. (Mgh.) You say also zakati AlA^aroDu The land throve, or yielded increase. (Msb.) And zakaA AlgulaAmu [The boy grew, or throve], inf. n. zukuw~N and zakaA='N, on the authority of Akh. (S.) And zakaA Eamaluhu (assumed tropical:) [His deed, or work, throve]. (K in art. dr.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, AlmaAlu tanoquSuhu Aln~afaqapu waAlEilomu yazokuw EalaY AlA_inofaAqi (assumed tropical:) [Wealth, what one expends diminishes it, but knowledge increases by expending]: zakaA=' being thus predicated of knowledge, though this is not a corporeal thing. (TA.) Accord. to El-Umawee, (S,) said of a man, zakaA, (S, K,) aor. yazokuw, inf. n. zukuw~N, (S,) means He enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; (S, K;) was in a state of abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (S.) And likewise said of a man, (having the same aor. and inf. n., TA,) it means also He was, or became, good, or righteous; (Jel in xxiv. 21, Msb, K, TA;) and pure from sin. (Jel ibid.) [Hence,] h`*aA AlA^amoru laA yazokuw bifulaAnK means This thing, or affair, will not be suitable to such a one; will not befit him. (S.)

2 zk~Ahu * , inf. n. tazokiyapN: see 4. ― -b2- Also He purified him, or it. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Sometimes the agent of the verb in this sense is a man; as in the saying in the Kur [xci. 9], qado A^afolaHa mano zak~aAhaA [Verily he prospereth who purifieth it; namely, his soul]: sometimes it is God; as in [the saying in the Kur xxiv. 21,] wal`kin~a A@ll~`ha yuzak~iY mano ya$aA='u [But God purifieth whom He willeth]: and sometimes it is the Prophet; as in the saying [in the Kur ix. 104], xu*o mino A^amowaAlihimo SadaqapF tuTah~iruhumo watuzak~iyhimo bihaA [Take thou, from their possessions, a poor-rate, whereby thou shalt cleanse them and purify them; where (J says in the S) they say that tuzak~iyhimo means the same as tuTah~iruhumo]; and in the saying [in the Kur ii. 146], yatoluw Ealayokumo A=yaAtinaA wayuzak~iykumo [Who reciteth to you our signs, and purifieth you]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, accord. to what is said in the Kur ix. 104, i. e. because the act which it signifies is believed to purify the performer, or because it is believed to purify, or to occasion an increase of, the rest of his property,] zk~Y maAlahu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, Msb,) He gave the zakaAp [or poorrate] from his property. (S, Mgh.) And zk~Ahu, (S,) or zk~Ahumo, (Mgh,) He took (S, Mgh) his, (S,) or their, (Mgh,) zakaAp [or poor-rate]. (S, Mgh.) ― -b4- zak~ayotuhu also signifies I attributed to him zakaA=', i. e. [purity, or] goodness, or righteousness. (Msb.) [And hence, I praised him.] And zk~Y nafosahu, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He praised himself. (S, Mgh.) The doing this is forbidden in the Kur liii. 33. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Hence, also, tazokiyapu Al$~uhuwdi The pronouncing the witnesses to be veracious, and good, or righteous. (Mgh.) -A2- huwa yuxas~iY wayuzak~iY He plays, and says, “ Is it even or odd [or rather odd or even]?” (TA in art. xsw;) he takes, or holds, something in his hand, and says, “ Is it even or odd [or odd or even]?” (TA in the present art.) [See zakaA below.]

4 AzkAhu *
He (God) made it to increase, or augment; (S, Msb, K;) [made it to thrive; and put it into a good, or right, state, or condition;] namely, seed-produce, (S, Msb, TA,) and wealth, or cattle &c, and any other thing capable of increase; (TA;) as also ↓ zk~Ahu, (Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. tazokiyapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He put it into a bag, or some other receptacle; namely, property: thus expl. by Aboo-Moosà. (Nh, TA.) -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

5 tzk~Y * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He became purified; or he purified himself: (TA:) also pronounced Aiz~ak~aY, aor. yaz~ak~aY. (Bd in xxxv. 19.) ― -b3- And He endeavoured to attain much piety; from Alz~akaA='u. (Bd in lxxxvii. 14.) ― -b4- And He gave the poor-rate. (S.)

zakaA * , (S, K, * TA,) without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; and in like manner xasaA, which is coupled with the former, is without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; (TA;) [but each has Al prefixed to it in the K;] i. q. Al$~afoEu (S, K) mina AlEadadi (K) [or $afoEN, as meaning An even number; a number consisting of pairs; or a single pair]: said to be so called because the pair are more, or more perfect, or better, (↓ A^azokaY,) than is the one. (TA.) You say xasaA A^awo zakaA or xasFA A^awo zakFA [Odd or even?]. (TA.) [See more voce xasaA.]

zakaApN * . or zak`wpN, [accord. to El-Hareeree, to be written with A when prefixed to a pronoun, and also in the dual number, (see De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Arabe, p. 67 of the Arabic text,) but this rule I have not found to be generally observed, even in the best MSS., nor have I in the similar cases of Sal`wpN and Hay`wpN, (to which it is also applied,) in the best copies of the Kur-án,] of the measure faEalapN, [i. e., originally zakawapN,] like SadaqapN [which is one of its syns.]; a noun of the class of homonyms: (IAth, TA:) it signifies Increase, or augmentation, (IAth, Er-Rághib, TA,) as also ↓ zakaA='N [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n.], (Msb,) resulting from the blessing of God; and this is [said to be] the primary meaning; and is considered as relating to the things of the present world and to those of the world to come. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- And Purity. (IAth, TA.) And [particularly] The dryness of the earth or ground; which is its purity from defilement. (TA.) ― -b3- And Purification: a meaning which it is said to have in the saying in the Kur [xxiii. 4], waA@l~a*iyna humo lilz~ak`wpi faAEiluwna, (IAth, Mgh, Er-Rághib, TA,) i. e. And who are acting in their religious service for God's purification of them; or for their purification of themselves: for lilz~ak`wp is not here an objective complement of faAEiluwna; the l therein denoting the aim and the cause. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b4- Also, [as being a mode of purification of oneself,] Good, or righteous, conduct: and in this sense it has been expl. as used in the Kur xviii. 80: or as meaning goodness, or righteousness: (TA:) which ↓ zakaA='N [also] signifies. (Msb.) And Religious service; as being the means of purification: so [accord. to some] it signifies in the saying [in the Kur xix. 14], waHanaAnFA mino ladun~aA wazak`wpF [And the disposition to mercy, or compassion, from us, and religious service]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here means Tuhorap [i. e. purification, or purity]: and [accord. to some, if we except the instances mentioned above in the
next two preceding sentences,] this is the only instance in the Kur-án in which it is used in any other sense than that which next follows. (Kull p. 199.) ― -b5- And [The poor-rate;] the portion, or amount, of property, that is given therefrom, (M, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib, TA,) as the due of God, (Er-Rághib, TA,) by its possessor, (M, K, TA,) to the poor, (M, Mgh, Er-Rághib, TA,) in order that he may purify it thereby: (M, IAth, K, TA:) [in the S it is merely said that “ the zak`wp of property is well known: ” the giving it is obligatory, provided that the property is of a certain amount, and has been in possession eleven months: the portion given varies according to the nature and amount of the property; but is generally a fortieth part thereof, or of its value; i. e. two and a half per cent.:] it is thus termed [for the reason assigned above; or] as being a cause of the hope of increase, (Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) or as causing the soul, or person, to thrive, or grow, by means of good things and blessings [procured thereby], or for both of these reasons. (Er-Rághib, TA.) zakaApu AlfiTori [The alms of the breaking of the fast, given at the end of Ramadán,] is obligatory upon every person of the Muslims, the free and the slave, the male and the female, the young and the old, the poor and the rich; and purifies the faster from unprofitable and lewd discourse: it consists of a SaAE [q. v.] of dates, or of barley, [or of raisins or some other ordinary kind of food,] or half that quantity of wheat. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, voce zakaAp.) [The pl. is zakawaAtN.] ― -b6- Also, [as being an attribution of purity or goodness or righteousness,] Praise. (IAth, TA.) ― -b7- And The pure, or best, part of a thing: (K, TA:) on the authority of Aboo-'Alee. (TA.)
zakaA='N * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K.) See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also [The increase of the earth; or] the fruits caused to come forth by God. (TA.)

zakiY~N *
i. q. ↓ zaAkK, (Akh, S,) which signifies Increasing [&c., as act part. n. of zakaA, q. v.]: (Ham p. 722:) [and growing, or thriving]: applied in this sense to a boy. (Akh, S.) ― -b2- gulaAmFA zakiy~FA in the Kur xix. 19 means [A boy] pure from sins: or growing, or increasing, in goodness and righteousness: (Bd:) or purified by nature: or such as shall in the future become purified. (TA.) And nafosFA zakiy~apF in the Kur xviii. 73 means [A soul, or person,] pure from sins: some read ↓ zaAkiyapF; but the former is more forcible: [or,] accord. to AA, ↓ the latter means that has never sinned: and the former, that has sinned and then been forgiven. (Bd.) [Or] rajulN zakiY~N signifies A good, or righteous, man: and the pl. is A^azokiyaA='u. (Msb, K, * TA.) And also A man enjoying, or leading, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life: pl. as above. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And A^aroDN zakiy~apN Good, fat land. (TA in art zkY.)

zakawiY~N * [generally meaning Of, or relating to, the poor-rate] is the rel. n. of zakaApN; like as HaSawiY~N is that of HaSaApN; because the rel. n. reduces the word to its original form: zakaAy^iY~N is vulgar and wrong. (Msb.)
zaAkK * , and its fem. zaAkiyapN: see zakiY~N, in three places.

A^azokaY *
More, or most, profitable: (Bd in ii. 232:) or better, or best: (Jel ibid:) more, or most, pure: (Bd in xxiv. 28:) more, or most, lawful, (Bd and Jel in xviii. 18,) and good, or pleasant: or more, or most, abundant and cheap. (Bd ibid.) See also zakaA as a noun.

1 zakiYa * , (K,) aor. yazokaY, inf. n. zakaApN, i. q. zakaA, aor. yazokuw, as meaning It increased, or augmented; (Lh, ISd, K, * TA;) and produced fruit: (TA:) and ↓ tzk~Y signifies the same. (K.) -A2- Also He thirsted. (Th, K.)
5 tazak~aYa see above; and see art. zkw.
zakiY~N * : see art. zkw.

1 zalalota * , [third pers. zal~a,] aor. tazil~u; (S, K;) and zalilota, [third pers. likewise zal~a,] aor. tazal~u; (Fr, S, K;) inf. n. zaliylN, (Lh, S, K,) which is of the former verb, (S,) and zal~N, (Lh, K,) also of the former verb, (Msb,) and zuluwlN and zil~iylaY [or, accord. to the S, this is a simple subst.,] and zil~iylaA='u (Lh, K) and mazil~apN, (K,) [all app. of the former verb,] and zalalN, (Fr, S, K,) which is of the latter verb; (Fr, S;) Thou slippedst (K) in mud, or in speech, (S, K,) or in judgment, or opinion, or in religion: (TA:) or you say, zal~a Eano makaAnihi, aor. yazil~u, inf. n. zal~N [&c. as above]; and zal~a, aor. yazal~u, inf. n. zalalN; the former verb of the class of Daraba; and the latter, of the class of taEiba; meaning he, or it, moved away, or aside, [or slipped,] from his, or its, place: and zal~a fiY manoTiqihi, or fiEolihi, aor. yazil~u, like yaDoribu, inf. n. zal~apN, he made a slip, or mistake, in his speech, or his action. (Msb.) faA_ino zalalotumo, in the Kur ii. 205, means But if ye turn away, or aside, from entering thereinto fully: (Jel:) this is the common reading: but some read zalilotumo. (TA.) And you say, zal~a zal~apF He committed a slip in speech and the like. (TA.) Accord. to IAth, zaliylN signifies The passing of a body from one place to another: and ― -b2- hence it is metaphorically used in like manner in relation to a benefit: one says, zal~ato minohu A_ilaY fulaAnK niEomapN, inf. n. zaliylN, meaning (tropical:) A benefit passed, or was transferred, from him, (i. e. a benefactor,) to such a one. (TA.) ― -b3- zal~a, inf. n. zaliylN and zuluwlN, also signifies He (a man) passed along quickly: (ISh, K:) and zal~a, inf. n. zaliylN, he ran: and zaliylN, a light, or an agile, walking or pacing: (TA:) [and zalalN, mentioned above as an inf. n., seems to have the same, or a similar, signification:] a rájiz says, (S,) namely, Aboo-Mohammad El- Hadhlemee, (TA,) or Aboo-Mohammad ElFak'asee, (O,)
A_in~a lahaA fiY AlEaAmi *iY Alfutuwqi
wazalali Aln~iy~api waAlt~aSofiyqi
riEoyapa mawolFY naASiHK $afiyqi
(S in the present art., * and in art. Sfq, * and art. ftq, but in this last with rab~K in the place of mawolFY, and TA,) [i. e. Verily they have, in the year of little rain, (thus Alftwq, as here used, is expl. in the S in art. ftq,) and in the passing along lightly to the place which is the object of the journey, and in the being removed from a tract which they have depastured to a place in which is pasture, (thus AltSfyq, as here used, is expl. in the S in art. Sfq,) the tending of a master honest in his conduct, or desirous of their good, benevolent, or compassionate]: he is speaking of his camels: (S in art. ftq:) he means that they pass along lightly [so I render tazil~u] from place to place in search of herbage: and Alny~p means the place to which they purpose journeying. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence,] zal~a Eumuruhu (assumed tropical:) His life went, or passed, [or glided,] away. (K, TA.) ― -b5- zal~ati Ald~araAhimu, (S, Msb, * K,) aor.
zali3a , (S, Msb,) inf. n. zuluwlN, (S, K,) or zaliylN, (Msb,) The dirhems, or pieces of money, poured out, or forth: (K:) or were, or became, deficient in weight. (S, Msb, * K.) ― -b6- zal~a, inf. n. zalalN, (K,) said of a man, (TA,) [and app. of a wolf, (see A^azal~u,)] He was, or became, light [of flesh] in the hips, or haunches: (K:) or zalalN signifies a woman's having little flesh in the posteriors and thighs. (S.) -A2- zal~a, aor. yazil~u, accord. to analogy, as an intrans. v., from A^azolalotu A_ilayohi meaning “ I gave to him ” of food &c., should signify He took, or received: and hence the saying of the lawyers, wayazil~u A_ino Ealima Alr~iDaY And he shall take, or receive, or the food [if he have knowledge of permission, or consent]. (Msb.) -A3- zul~a i. q. duq~iqa [app. as meaning He, or it, was made, or rendered, thin, or slender]. (IAar, TA.)
2 zal~a3a see the next paragraph, near its end.

4 Azl~hu * , (K,) inf. n. A_izolaAlN, (TA,) He, or it, made him, or caused him, to slip in mud, (K, TA,) or in speech, or in judgment, or opinion, or in religion; (TA;) and ↓ Astzl~hu signifies the same. (S, * MA, K, * PS. [But respecting this latter, see what follows.]) It is said in the Kur [ii. 34], faA^azal~ahumaA Al$~ayoTaAnu EanohaA [And the Devil made them, or caused them, both, to slip, or fall, from it, namely, Paradise (Aljan~ap)]; and one reading is A^azaAlamuhaA, i. e. removed them: or, as some say, it means caused them to commit a slip, or wrong action, in consequence of it [referring to the tree]: or, accord. to Th, caused them to slip in judgment. (TA.) And in the same, iii. 149, ↓ A@sotazal~ahumu Al$~ayoTaAnu The Devil made them, or caused them, to slip: (Jel:) or, as some say, sought to make them commit a slip, or wrong action. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, A^azal~a fulaAnFA A_ilaY Alqawomi He sent forward such a one to the people, or party. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^azal~ahu Eano raA^oyihi He made him to turn from
his opinion. (MA.) ― -b4- And as zaliylN signifies the “ passing ” of a body from one place to another, one says, speaking metaphorically, (IAth, TA,) A^azal~a A_ilayohi niEomapF (tropical:) He did to him a benefit: (S, IAth, K:) whence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., mano A^uzil~ato A_ilayohi niEomapN faloya$okurohaA (assumed tropical:) He to whom a benefit is done [let him be grateful for it]. (A'Obeyd, S, * Mgh, Msb.) And A^azolalotu lahu zul~apF (assumed tropical:) I did to him a benefit: one should not say zllt [thus written, app. for ↓ zal~alotu: but see muzal~ilN]. (TA.) And A^azolalotu A_ilayohi [alone] (assumed tropical:) I gave to him: or I did to him a benefit. (Msb.) And A^azolalotu A_ilayohi mina AlT~aEaAmi wagayorihi (assumed tropical:) I gave to him of the food and other things. (IKtt, TA.) And A^azal~a A_ilayohi mino Haq~ihi $ayoy^FA (assumed tropical:) He gave to him somewhat of his due. (S, K.) And A^azal~a Eanohu niEomapF (assumed tropical:) He drew forth from him a benefit. (TA.)
10 A_isotazola3a see 4, in two places.

R. Q. 1 zalozalahu * , (S, * Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. zalozalapN and zilozaAlN and zalozaAlN and zulozaAlN, (K,) or the first of these is an inf. n. [by universal consent], (S,) and so is the second, but the third is a simple subst., (Zj, S, Msb,) though this and the fourth [which is the least known] have the authority of certain readings of passages of the Kur, namely, xcix. 1 for both of these, and xxxiii. 11 for the latter of them, (TA,) He put it, or him, into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation: (Msb, K, TA:) or into a state of convulsion, or violent motion. (Zj, TA.) You say, zalozala A@ll~`hu AlA^aroDa [i. e. God made the earth to quake: or to quake violently:] (S:) [or] put the earth into a state of convulsion, or violent motion. (Zj, TA) And jaA='a biAlA_ibili yuzaloziluhaA He came with, or brought, the camels, driving them with roughness, violence, or vehemence. (TA.) Some say that zalozalapN is from Alz~alalu fiY Alr~aA^oYi [i. e. “ the making a slip in judgment, or opinion ”]: so when one says, zulozila Alqawomu the meaning is, The people, or party, were turned away from the right course, and fear was cast into their hearts. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aall~`hum~a A@hozimi AlA^aHozaAba wazalozilohumo i. e. [O God, rout, defeat, or put to flight, the combined forces, and] make their state of affairs to be unsound, or unsettled. (TA.) Accord. to IAmb, A^aSaAbati Alqawoma zalozalapN means An affrighting befell the people, or party; from the saying in the Kur [ii. 210], wazuloziluwA Hat~aY yaquwla Alr~asuwlu i. e. And they were affrighted [so that the Apostle said]: (L, TA:) or were vehemently agitated. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b2- maA zalozalotu qaT~u maA='F A^aborada mino maA='i Alvgwbi [or Alv~agabi, as it is written in the explanation of this saying, the latter being app. the right reading], said by Aboo-Shembel, means I have not put into my throat, or fauces, ever, water slipping into it cooler than the water of the vagab [or pool left by a torrent in the shade of a mountain]. (Az, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tazalozala *
It was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, convulsion, or violent motion. (Msb, TA.) You say, tazalozalati AlA^aroDu (S, Msb, TA) The earth [quaked: or quaked violently:] was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, &c.: (Msb:) the verb in this phrase [and in others] is quasi-pass. of R. Q. 1. (S, TA.) And tazalozalato nafosuhu His soul reciprocated in his chest at death. (TA.)

zul~N *
Slippery: (S:) a place in which one slips; (K;) and ↓ zalalN signifies the same; (S, K;) and ↓ zaluwlN [likewise, i. e.] a place in which the foot slips. (TA.) You say maqaAmN zul~N and ↓ zalalN, and maqaAmapN zul~N and ↓ zalalN, [A standing-place] in which one slips. (K.) And zuHoluwqapN zul~N and ↓ zalalN A slippery [sloping slide or rolling-place &c.]. (S.) [See also mazil~apN.]

zal~apN *
A slip (S, Msb, * K) in mud, or in speech; a subst. from 1 meaning as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (S, K:) as also ↓ zil~iylaY: (S: [but this latter is mentioned by Lh and in the K as an inf. n.:]) a slip, or lapse; (K:) a fault, a wrong action, a mistake, or an error; (Msb, K;) or a sin, or crime; (K, * TA;) a fall into sin or crime. (Msb in art. Evr.) One says, zal~a Alr~ajulu zal~apF qabiyHapF The man [made a foul slip; or] fell into the commission of a disapproved, or hateful, or foul, act; or committed an exorbitant, an abominable, or a foul, mistake: whence the trad., naEuw*u biA@ll~`hi mino zal~api AlEaAlimi [We seek protection by God from the slip of the learned man]: and the well-known saying, zal~apN AlEaAlimi zal~apu AlEaAlami [The slip of the learned man is the slip of the world at large]. (TA.) ― -b2- A benefit, or good action; (Mgh, * K;) as also ↓ zul~apN: (K:) a gift. (Msb.) ― -b3- A feast, or repast, that is prepared for guests. (Lth, O, Msb.) One says, Ait~axa*a fulaAnN zal~apF [Such a one made, or prepared, a feast for guests]. (Lth, O, Msb.) Hence, (Lth, TA,) it is also a name for Food that is carried from the table of one's friend or relation: a word of the dial. of El-'Irák: (Lth, Msb, K:) or in this sense it is a vulgar word, (K, TA,) used by the common people of El-'Irák (TA.) And i. q. EurosN [as meaning A marriage-feast]. (ISh, Az, Msb, K.) So in the saying, kun~aA fiY zal~api fulaAnK [We were at the marriage-feast of such a one]. (ISh, Az, Msb, TA.)
zul~apN * : see zal~apN. -A2- Also A straitened state of the breath [unless Aln~afasi be a mistranscription for Aln~afos the soul, which I think not improbable]. (K.)

zil~apN *
Stones: or smooth stones: (K:) pl. zilalN. (TA.)

zalalN * an inf. n. of 1, [q. v,] (Fr, S, Msb, K,) in two [or three] senses. (K.) -A2- See also zul~N, in four places. -A3- Also A deficiency: so in the saying, fiY miyzaAnihi zalalN [In its weight is a deficiency]. (Lh, K.)

zulaAlN *
A certain animal, of small, white body; which, when it dies, is put into water, and renders it cool, or cold: (TA:) [Golius describes it as a worm that is bred in snow; of which Aristotle speaks in his Hist. Animalium, l. ↓. 19; and he adds, on the authority of Dmr, that it is of the length of a finger, generally marked with yellow spots; and swelling in water such as is termed mA' AlzlAl.] ― -b2- Hence, [it is said to be] applied to water, as meaning Cool, or cold: (TA:) or, so applied, sweet: (S:) or sweet, clear, or limpid, pure, easy in its descent, that slips into the throat; as also ↓ zulaAzilN: (TA:) or quick in its descent and passage in the throat, (K, * TA,) cool, or cold, sweet, clear, or limpid, easy in its descent; as also ↓ zaliylN and ↓ zaluwlN and ↓ zulaAzilN. (K.) ― -b3- And Clear, as applied to anything. (TA.)
zaluwlN * : see zul~N: ― -b2- and see also zulaAlN.
zaliylN * : see zulaAlN. ― -b2- Also [The kind of sweet food called] faAluw* [q. v.]. (Sgh, K.)

zil~iy~apN * , an arabicized word from the Pers. ziyluw, (K in art. zlY, in the CK zayoluw, [“ a sort of woollen blanket, ”] A carpet; syn. bisaATN: (K in the present art.:) a certain sort of busuT [or carpets, said by Golius to be generally woollen and villous, but by Freytag to be woollen but not villous]: (Msb:) [in Johnson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict. expl. as meaning a coverlet of woollen, without a pile, neither striped nor painted:] pl. zalaAliY~N. (S, Msb, K.)
zil~iylaY * : see zal~apN.
zalozilN * (S, K) and zalozalN, and MF adds ↓ zulazilN, (TA,) Household-goods; or utensils and furniture of a house or tent; (S, K;) as also zalazN. (Sh, TA.)

zulozulN *
Light, or agile; (TA;) as also ↓ A^azal~u: (IAar, TA:) the former applied as an epithet to a boy, or young man. (TA.) [See also zulozuwlN.] ― -b2- And A skilful player on the drum. (Fr, K.)
zulazilN * : see zalozilN.
zalozalapN * : see what next follows.

zalozaAlN * [Motion, commotion, agitation, convulsion, or violent motion; and particularly an earthquake, or a violent earthquake;] a subst. from R. Q. 1: (Zj, S, Msb:) or an inf. n. of R. Q. 1, as also zilozaAlN and zulozaAlN and ↓ zalozalapN [which last is often used as a simple subst., as such having for its pl. zalaAzilu, and is expl. in Jel xxii. 1 as signifying a violent earthquake]. (K.)

zulozuwlN *
Light, or active, (K, TA,) in spirit and body; (TA;) acute, sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, or ingenious. (K, TA.) [See also zalozulN.] -A2- Lightness, or activity. (K.) ― -b2- Conflict, or fight, and evil condition. (Sh, K.) One says, tarakotu Alqawoma fiY zulozuwlK waEuloEuwlK (As, Sh) i. e. [I left the people, or party.] in conflict, or fight, and evil condition. (Sh, TA.)
zalaAzilu * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Difficulties; (S, TA;) and terrors, or causes of fear. (TA.) [See also zalozaAlN.]
zulaAzilN * : see zualaAlN, in two places.

zaAl~N *
Deficient in weight; applied to a dirhem, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and to a deenár: (TA:) pl. zawaAl~N, (Msb,) or zul~alN. (TA.) One says, mino danaAniyrika zil~alN waminohaA wuz~anN [Of thy deenárs are such as are deficient in weight, and of them are such as are of full weight]. (TA.)

A^azal~u *
Quick, or swift. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- See also zulozulN. ― -b3- Also Light [of flesh] in the hips, or haunches: (AA, S, K:) and having little flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks sticking together; syn. A^arosaHu; (M, TA;) in the copies of the K, erroneously, A^a$aj~u: (TA:) or it signifies one who is more than A^arosaH; (K, * TA;) whose waist-wrapper will not retain its hold: (TA:) fem. zal~aA='u, (S, K,) applied to a woman; i. q. rasoHaA='u: (S:) or having no buttock: pl. zul~N. (TA.) Als~imoEu AlA^azal~u means The wolf that has little flesh in the rump and thighs, (Al*~iy^obu AlA^arosaHu, S, in the K *iy^obN A^arosaHu,) begotten between the wolf and the she-hyena; (S, K; [the words wAlxif~apu wAlqitAlu wAl$~ar~u here immediately following in the CK should be erased; their proper place being in the second of the lines below in that edition, where they are again inserted; as observed by Freytag;]) and this epithet (AlAzl~) is inseparable: (S:) or, accord. to IAth, AlA^azal~u primarily signifies the small in the buttock: and as an epithet applied to the wolf, the light, or active; and it is said to be from zal~a signifying “ he ran. ” (TA.) It is said in a prov., huwa A^asomaEu mina Als~imoEi AlA^azal~i [He is more quick of hearing than the smE that is lean in the rump and thighs; or than the light, or active, smE]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- qawosN zal~aA='u A bow from which the arrow slips, by reason of the rapidity with which it goes forth. (K.)

A_izilozilo * [said by Freytag to be written in the CK zilozilo, but in my copy of that edition it is Aizilozilo,] is a word uttered on the occasion of the zalozalap, (so in copies of the K,) or on the occasions of zalaAzil: (so in the TA:) [app. an ejaculation expressive of alarm, or of distress: the Turkish translator of the K thinks that it is originally A^azulozila, contracted and altered in the vowels for the purpose of alleviating the utterance on account of the straitness of the time:] but IJ says that a word of four radical letters does not receive an augmentative like this as an initial; and holds it to be, as to the letter and the meaning, from AlA^azolu [i. e. “ straitness, distress, ” &c.], and of the measure fiEiloEilo. (TA.)
mazal~apN * : see the next paragraph. [Its primary signification is probably A cause of slipping: compare maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.]

mazil~apN * and ↓ mazal~apN, (S, Msb, K,) the former the more chaste, (Msb,) the latter mentioned by AA, (TA,) A slippery place; (S, Msb, K, TA;) such as a smooth rock, and the like; and such the SiraAT is said to be. (TA.) [See also zul~N.] -A2- The former is also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (K.)
muzal~ilN * One who bestows many benefits (K, TA) and gifts. (TA.)

1 zalaja * , aor.
zalija , inf. n. zalojN and zalajaAnN and zaliyjN; and ↓ Anzlj; He went a gentle pace: and he walked, or ran, quickly: (L:) or zalojN signifies the being quick in going and in other things: and the going quickly: (TA:) and zalajaAnN, the advancing, or preceding, (O, K, TA,) quickly, (O,) or in journeying: (TA: [see also zalaxaAnN:]) or, as some say, the going a gentle pace. (TA.) You say of a she-camel, zalajato, aor.
zalija , inf. n. zalojN, She went swiftly, [appearing] as though she did not move her legs by reason of her swiftness. (Lth, TA.) And zalajato occurring in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, [app. referring to draughts of water,] is expl. as meaning They descended quickly into the entrance of the gullet, by reason of vehemence of thirst. (TA.) You say also, zalajato rijoluhu His foot slipped; as also zalaxato. (AZ, L and TA in art. zlx.) And mar~a yazoliju, inf. n. zalojN and zaliyjN, He, or it, passed, going lightly upon the ground. (S, K.) And, of an arrow, yazoliju EalaY wajohi AlA^aroDi [app. It goes along lightly upon the ground]: and yamoDiY maDaA='F zalojFA [app. meaning the same]. (TA.) And zalaja Als~ahomu, aor.
zalija , inf. n. zuluwjN and zaliyjN, The arrow fell upon the ground, and did not go straight to the animal at which it was shot. (TA. [See also zalaxa.]) ― -b2- zalaja, aor.
zalija , also signifies He escaped from difficulties, troubles, or distresses. (TA.) ― -b3- And He drank vehemently of anything. (TA.) -A2- See also 4.

2 zl~j * , inf. n. tazoliyjN, He uttered, and made current, his words, or speech, (K, TA,) and an ode, or an oration. (TA.) ― -b2- And tazoliyjN signifies also The striving to retain life with a bare sufficiency of the means of subsistence; Alt~azoliyju being expl. by mudaAfaEapu AlEayo$i biAlbulogapi. (K.)

4 Azlj Als~ahoma *
He made the arrow to fall upon the ground, and not to go straight to the animal at which it was shot. (TA. [See also 4 in art. zlx.]) ― -b2- Azlj AlbaAba He closed, or made fast, the door with the mizolaAj [q. v.]; (S, * K;) as also ↓ zalajahu, (K,) inf. n. zalojN. (TA. [See, again, 4 in art. zlj.])

5 tzl~j *
He, or it, slipped, or slid along or down; syn. tazal~aqa: (S, TA:) his foot slipped. (KL. [See also 5 in art. zlx.]) ― -b2- One says of an arrow, yatazal~aju Eani Alqawosi or ↓ yanozaliju [It slips from the bow]. (S and K, accord. to different copies.) -A2- Also He persevered, or persisted, in drinking the beverage called nabiy*, (Lh, K, TA,) and wine; (Lh, TA;) like tsl~j. (TA.)
7 A_inozalaja see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see also 5 and zaluwjN, and mizolaAjN.

zalojN * , as an epithet applied to a place, (S, TA,) Slippery; syn. [zaloqN and] zalaqN; [like zaloxN;] as also ↓ zalajN (S, K) and ↓ zaliyjN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also zaAlijN. -A2- [Explained by Freytag as meaning “ Quod aliquis in jaculando multum tollit manum, ut majori vi mittat telum, ” on the authority of Meyd, it is app. a mistranscription for zaloxN, q. v.; or it may be a dial. var. of the latter.]
zalajN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

zulujN *
Smooth rocks; (K;) because the feet slip from them. (TA.)

zalajaY * , like jamazaY [in measure and meaning], and ↓ zaliyjapN, (K, TA,) and ↓ zaluwjN, (TA,) applied to a she-camel, Quick, or swift, (K, TA,) in pace, or journeying: or, as some say, that quickly finishes in being milked. (TA.)
zilaAjN * : see mizolaAjN.

zaluwjN *
Quick, or swift; (K;) as also ↓ zaAlijN, applied to anything. (Ham p. 764.) See also zalajaY. [And see zaluwxN.] ― -b2- An arrow, such as is called qidoH, that slips (↓ yanozaliju) quickly from the hand, (K, TA,) or from the bow. (TA.) See also zaAlijN. ― -b3- Applied to a well, i. q. zaluwxN [q. v.]. (TA in art. zlx.) ― -b4- EuqobapN zaluwjN A far-extending, long [stage of a journey]; (Lh, K;) as also zaluwqN. (Lh, K in art. zlq, and TA. [In the CK, in this art. and in art. zlq, EaqabapN: in my MS. copy of the K, in this art., EqabpN; but in art. zlq, EuqobapN, which is the right reading. See also zaluwxN.]) So in the saying, sironFA EqbpF zaluwjFA [We journeyed a farextending, long stage]. (Lh, TA.)
zaliyjN * : see zalojN: ― -b2- and its fem., with p: see zalajaY.

zaAlijN * : see zaluwjN. ― -b2- Also An arrow that slips (yatazal~aju or yanozaliju [see 5]) from the bow; (S, K;) and so ↓ zaluwjN [q. v.]: (K:) or an arrow that is shot by the archer, and falls short of the butt, striking violently upon a rock, and bounding up from it to the butt: but such is not reckoned muqaroTis: (AHeyth, TA: [see also zaAlixN:]) and ↓ zalojN, as though an inf. n. used as an epithet, an arrow that falls upon the ground, and does not go straight to the animal at which it is shot. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Escaping from difficulties, troubles, or distresses. (K.) ― -b4- And Drinking vehemently (K) of anything. (TA.)

[
mizolajN * , written in Freytag's Lex. mizolj, there expl. as meaning Quickly, or swiftly, passing; on the authority of the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.]

muzal~ajN *
Small in quantity or number: (K:) a mean, paltry, small, or little, gift: (S, TA:) one hat is imperfect, or incomplete: and anything that is not done superlatively, excellently, consummately, thoroughly, or soundly: (TA:) anything low, base, vile, mean, paltry, inconsiderable,
or contemptible. (K. [See also muzal~axN.]) ― -b2- Love (Hub~ [in the CK, erroneously, Hab~]) that is not pure, or not genuine. (K.) ― -b3- Having little taste. (Ham p. 404.) ― -b4- Small in body. (Ham ibid.) ― -b5- And hence, (Ham ibid.,) A man (K) deficient, or defective, (K, Ham,) in manliness, or manly virtue or moral goodness, (Ham,) and weak: (TA:) or defective in make: and deficient in prudence, or discretion, and precaution, or sound judgment, or firmness of mind or of judgment: (TA:) and niggardly. (K.) ― -b6- One who is consociated with a people, not being of them: (S, K, TA:) or, as some say, i. q. daEiY~N [i. e. one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; &c.]. (TA.) ― -b7- Also Life striven to be retained (mudaAfaEN) with a bare sufficiency of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

mizolaAjN * (S, K) and ↓ zilaAjN (K) [A kind of latch, or sliding bolt; like mizolaAqN and mizolaAxN;] a [thing like the] migolaAq, except that it is opened with the hand, whereas the mglAq is not to be opened save with the key: (S, K:) a wooden thing by means of which one closes or makes fast [a door]: (Ham p. 764; in explanation of the former word:) so called because of the quickness with which it slips (↓ lisuroEapi A@nozilaAjihi): but ISh describes the kind of mzlAj used by the people of El-Basrah as having a crooked iron key, which slips into a hole in the door, by means of which the door is locked: pl. mazaAliyju. (TA.) -A2- Also the former word, applied to a woman, Having little flesh in her posteriors, or posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks, sticking together; syn. rasoHaA='u. (S, K.)

1 zalaxato rijoluhu * , aor.
zalaxa , inf. n. zuluwxN, His foot slipped; (AZ, A, L, TA;) like zalajato; (AZ, L, TA;) as also ↓ tzl~xt. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of water, zalaxa Eani AlS~axorapi (tropical:) [It slipped, or slid down, from the rock]. (A, TA.) And of an arrow, yazolaxu EalaY wajohi AlA^aroDi vum~a yamoDiY (tropical:) [It slides along upon the ground; then penetrates]. (A, TA. [See also zalaja.]) And zalaxa fiY ma$oyihi (tropical:) He hastened, or was quick, in his going, or gait. (A, TA.) [See also zalaxaAnN.] And zalaxa mino fiyhi kalaAmN (tropical:) [Speech slipped from his mouth]. (A.) -A2- zalaxahu biAlr~umoHi, aor.
zalixa , (K,) inf. n. zaloxN, (TA,) i. q. zaj~ahu [He pierced him, or thrust him, with the pointed iron foot of the spear]; (K;) as also zax~ahu. (TA.) ― -b2- And zalaxa raA^osahu, inf. n. zaloxN, He broke his head so as to slit, or cleave, the skin; syn. $aj~ahu. (Kr, TA.) -A3- zalixa, aor.
zalaxa , (K,) inf. n. zalaxN, (TA,) He was, or became, fat. (K.) zalixato is said of camels, meaning They were, or became, fat. (TA.)
2 zl~xhu * , inf. n. tazoliyxN, He made it, or rendered it, smooth. (K.) ― -b2- [And app. He, or it, made him to slip: see its pass. part. n., below.] ― -b3- See also a verse cited voce zul~axapN.

4 Azlx qadamahu *
He, or it, made his foot to slip. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Azlx Als~ahoma (tropical:) [He made the arrow to slide along upon the ground: see 1, third sentence]. (A, TA. [See also 4 in art. zlj.]) ― -b3- Azlx AlbaAba He closed, or made fast, the door with the mizolaAx [q. v.]. (A, TA.)
