You say, [so in my copy of the A, but app. it should be “ you do not say, ”] A^azolaxotu AlbaAba when you require, for opening it, a key. (A. [See, again, 4 in art. zlj.])
5 tzl~x * [He, or it, slipped, or slid along or down]: see 1, first sentence: and see zul~axapN. [See also 5 in art. zlj.]

zaloxN *
A slippery place, from which the feet slip because of its moistness (S, K) or its smoothness; (K;) for it is [like smooth rock, or is] smooth rock; (S, TA;) as also ↓ zalixN. (K.) And one says also mazal~apN zaloxN [using the latter word as a corroborative]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) Slippery; (S, A, TA;) applied to a standing-place, (S,) or to a place [absolutely]; (A, TA;) like zalojN; (S, TA;) as also ↓ zalixN. (A, TA. [In this sense, zaloxN is said in the A to be tropical: app. because it is an inf. n. used as an epithet.]) It is also applied to a well (rakiy~ap), meaning Smooth and slippery at its top [or mouth], so that he who stands upon it slips into it; (TA;) and so ↓ zaluwxN, (S, TA,) and zaluwjN. (TA.) -A2- Also The limit, or extreme limit, to which an arrow is shot: (S, K:) a rájiz says,
mino maAy^apK zaloxK bimir~iyxK gaAlo
[app. meaning From a hundred fathoms, a limit, or an extreme limit, to which one shoots with a long four-feathered arrow rising in its flight so as to exceed the usual limit; from three hundred to four hundred cubits being said to be the limit, or extreme limit, to which an arrow is shot; and gaAlo being used by poetic license for gaAlK]: (S:) or, accord. to ADk, zlx here signifies the furthest limit to which an arrow is shot by him who endeavours to shoot it to the utmost distance: or, accord. to Lth, the raising the hand, or arm, in shooting an arrow to the furthest possible distance: so says Az; who adds that he had not heard this last explanation on any other authority than that of Lth, but hoped it might be correct. (L, TA.) [See also zalojN.]
zalixN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
zulaxapN * : see zul~axapN, below.

zalaxaAnN * and zaloxaAnN (assumed tropical:) The advancing, or preceding, accord. to the K, in going, or gait, but accord. to the parent-lexicons, in haste, or quickly; as also zljAn [i. e. zalajaAnN, which is an inf. n.; and in like manner zalaxaAnN and zaloxaAnN, accord. to the TK, are inf. ns., of which the verb is zalaxa, aor.
zaluxa ; though it is more probably
zalaxa ]. (TA.)
zaluwxN * : see zaloxN. ― -b2- Also A quick, or swift, she-camel. (TA. [See also zaluwjN.]) ― -b3- And Eqbp zaluwxN [i. e. EuqobapN, see zaluwjN,] A long, far-extending [stage of a journey]. (TA.)
zul~axN * : see the next paragraph.

zul~axapN *
A sloping slide (zuHoluwfapN, S, K) down which children slide. (S. [In one copy of the S, ↓ yatazal~axu minohaA AlS~iybaAnu: in two other copies, yatazal~aju: and in one of these, EalayohaA is put in the place of minohaA.]) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A pain that attacks in the back, (A, K,) which consequently becomes hard, or rigid, and rough, (K,) depriving one of the power of motion (A, K) by reason of its violence: (A:) and some pronounce the word ↓ zulaxapN, without teshdeed to the l; and some, erroneously, with j: (TA:) or it is a disease that attacks in the back and the side: (ISd, TA:) [and ↓ zul~axN appears to signify the same, or to be a coll. gen. n.: for] AA cites the following verse:
waSirotu mino baEodi AlqawaAmi A^abozaxaA
Ald~ahoru biZahoriY zul~axaA ↓ wazal~axa
[app. meaning, And I have become, after goodliness of stature, or symmetry, or justness of proportion, protuberant in the breast and hollow in the back; and time has produced, in my back, pain that deprives me of the power of motion]. (S, TA.)
EanaqN zal~aAxN * (assumed tropical:) A vehement [pace of the kind termed] Eanaq [q. v.]. (TA.)
zaAlixN * (tropical:) An arrow that slides along (yazolaxu) upon the ground, and then penetrates. (A, TA. [See also zaAlijN.])

muzal~axN * , applied to a man, (tropical:) Mean, ungenerous, or sordid; [as though] repelled, and made to slip, from generosity: ― -b2- and hence, applied to living, or sustenance, or means of subsistence, and to a gift, mean, paltry, scanty, or deficient. (A, TA. [See also muzal~ajN.])
mizolaAxN * [A kind of latch, or sliding bolt; also called mizolaAjN, q. v., and mizolaAqN;] a thing with which doors are made fast without its being [itself] made fast [or locked]. (A, TA.)

Q. 4 AizolaEab~a * , (K,) inf. n. AizoliEobaAbN, (S in art. zEb,) said of a torrent, It was, or became, copious, and impelled in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another. (S, K.) Accord. to the S, and AHei, the l is augmentative; [as it is said with equal reason to be in Aizolagab~a;] but accord. to the K, it is radical, and therefore this is its proper place, not art. zEb. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. Aizolagab~a, [q. v.,] said of hair. (TA in art. zlgb.) ― -b3- And AzlEb~ Als~aHaAbu The clouds were, or became, dense, or thick. (K.)

muzolaEib~N * A torrent that is copious, and impelled in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of
one part, or portion, acting upon another, (S in art. zEb, and K, and TA,) having much rubbish or many small particles or fragments [borne on its surface]. (TA.) [See also zaAEibN.] ― -b2- Also a dial. var. of muzolagib~N, [q. v.,] applied to a young bird. (TA.)

Q. 4 Aizolagab~a * , said of a young bird, Its feathers came forth: (S in art. zgb, and K:) or its feathers began to come forth, (Lth, TA,) before their becoming black. (TA.) Also said of plumage, It began to come forth. (Lth, TA.) And said of hair, (S in art. zgb, and K,) as also AzlEb~, (TA,) It grew forth after having been shaven: (S, K:) it began to grow forth, soft: and said of the hair of an old man, i. q. AizogaAb~a [it was, or became, downy]. (TA.) Accord. to the S, and AHei and IKtt and others, it belongs to art. zgb, like as AizolaEab~a is held by them to belong to art. zEb; but accord. to the K, the l is radical, and therefore this is its proper place. (TA.)
1 zalafa * : see 2: -A2- and see also 8, in three places.

2 zl~fhu * , (O, TA,) inf. n. tazoliyfN, (O,) He did it previously, or beforehand; namely, a thing; (IAar, O, TA;) as, for instance, an evil action; (O, TA;) and so ↓ zalafahu; (IAar, TA;) syn. A^asolafahu, (O, TA,) and qad~amahu. (IAar, O, TA.) ― -b2- zl~f Aln~aAsa, inf. n. as above, He disquieted, or agitated, the people, step by step: (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, TA:) accord. to Z, said of a guide. (TA.) ― -b3- zl~f fiY Hadiyvihi, (inf. n. as above, K,) He added, or exaggerated, in his discourse, or narration; (IDrd, O, K;) as also *r~f. (IDrd, O.)

4 Azlfhu *
He made, brought, or drew, him, or it, (namely, a thing, TA,) near. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvi. 90 and 1. 30], waA^uzolifati A@lojan~apu lilomut~aqiyna And Paradise shall be brought near to the pious: meaning, accord. to Zj, that their entrance thereinto shall become near, and their view thereof. (TA.) [bihi ↓ Azdlf also signifies the same as Azlfh (agreeably with analogy); as is shown by what here follows:] it is said in a trad. of Mohammad El-Bákir, maA laka mino Eayo$ika A_il~aA la*~apN tazodalifu bika A_ilaY HimaAmika [i. e. There is not remaining to thee, of thy life, save a pleasure that brings thee near to thy predestined term]. (O, TA.) And ↓ Azdlfhu means He, or it, brought him near to destruction. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He collected it together; (Msb, TA;) namely, a thing. (Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvi. 64], waA^azolafonaA vam~a AlA=xariyna [And we collected there the others]. (TA.)
5 tazal~afa see the next paragraph.

8 Aizodalafa * , (Mgh, Msb,) originally Aizotalafa, (Msb,) or AizodalafuwA, and ↓ tzl~fwA, (S, O, L, K,) He, or they, approached, or drew near: (Mgh, O, L, Msb, TA: in the K, tafar~aquwA is erroneously put for taqar~abuwA: TA:) or (O, accord. to the K “ and ”) advanced; or went forward, or before: (S, O, K:) A_ilayohi [to him, or it], (Mgh, K,) and minohu [which means the same, as after danaA &c.]: (TA, and Har p. 452:) [and ↓ zalafa and zalafuwA, inf. n. app. zalofN and zalafN, signify the same: for] you say also, A_ilayohi ↓ zalafa He drew near to him, or it: and lahu ↓ zalafonaA We advanced, or went forward, to him, or it: (TA:) and zalofN signifies the act of advancing, or going forward, (A'Obeyd, S, TA,) from place to place; as also zalafN. (TA.) One says, Azdlf Als~ahomu A_ilaY ka*aA The arrow approached, or drew near, to such a thing. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad., faA_i*aA zaAlati Al$~amosu faA@ozodalifo A_ilaY A@ll~`hi fiyhi birakoEatayoni, meaning taqar~abo [i. e., When the sun declines from the meridian, then seek thou to draw near unto God therein by means of the prayers of two rek'ahs]. (TA.) -A2- See also 4, in two places.
zalofN * : see zulofapN.
zulofN * : see its accus. case voce zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

zilofN *
A meadow; syn. rawoDapN; (TS, K;) and so ↓ zalafapN: (IB, TA:) thus the latter is expl. as occurring in a trad. relating to Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj, in which it is said, vum~a yurosilu A@ll~`hu maTarFA fayagosilu AlA^aroDa Hat~aY yatorukahaA kaAlz~alafapi [Then God will send rain, and it will wash the earth so that it will leave it like the meadow]: but in this instance, several other meanings are assigned to it: see zalafapN below. (TA.)
zalafN * : see zulofapN, in two places: -A2- and see also zalafapN, in five places.
zulufN * : see its accus. case voce zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

zulofapN *
i. q. qurobapN [i. e. Nearness, with respect to rank, degree, or station]; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ zulofaY, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) and ↓ zalafN. (IDrd, O, K.) [It would seem that it means also Nearness with respect to place or situation: for SM immediately adds,] hence, in the Kur [lxvii. 27], falam~aA raA^awohu zulofapF, [as though meaning But when they shall see it in a state of nearness: but] Zj says that the meaning is, but when they shall see it (i. e. the punishment) near (qariybFA): and several authors say that zulofapN is sometimes used in the sense of qariybN, as is stated in the 'Ináyeh. (TA.) And Station, rank, grade, or degree; as also ↓ zulofaY, (S, O, K, TA,) and ↓ zalofN, (TS, K,) and ↓ zalafN: (K, TA:) pl. of the first zulafN: (S, * TA:) or (K) ↓ zulofaY is a quasi-inf. n.; (S, K;) and such it is in the saying in the Kur [xxxiv. 36], wamaA A^amowaAlukumo walaA A^awolaAdukumo biA@l~atiY tuqar~ibukumo EinodinaA zulofaY, as though meaning A@zodilaAfFA [i. e. And neither your riches nor your children are what will bring you near to us in advancement: but here it may be well rendered, in station]: (S:) accord. to Ibn- 'Arafeh, zulofaY signifies the bringing very near: (TA:) the saying of Ibn-El-Tilimsánee that it is pl. of zulofapN is very strange, and unknown; the correct pl. of this last word being zulafN. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- Also A portion (S, K) of the first part (S) of the night, (S, K,) whether small or large: so accord. to Th: or, accord. to Akh, of the night absolutely: (TA:) pl. zulafN and zulafaAtN (S, K) and zulufaAtN and zulofaAtN: or zulafN signifies the hours, or periods, (saAEaAt,) of the night, commencing from the daytime, and the hours, or periods, of the daytime, commencing from the night: (K:) and its sing. is zulofapN. (TA.) wazulafFA mina All~ayoli, in the Kur [xi. 116], means And at sunset and nightfall (the magorib and the Ei$aA='): (Zj, TA:) some read ↓ zulufFA, with two dammehs; which may be a sing., like HulumN; or a pl. of zulofapN, like as busurN is of busurapN, with damm to the s in each: [but this is not a parallel instance; for busurN is a coll. gen. n. of which busurapN is the n. un., and the latter is not of the same measure as zulofapN:] and some read ↓ zulofFA, which is a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of zulofapN, like as dur~N is of dur~apN; (K, TA;) or pl. of ↓ zaliyfN, like as qurobN is of qariybN, and gurobN of gariybN: (TA:) and some read ↓ zulofaY, in which the alif [written Y] is a denotative of the fem. gender. (K, TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

zalafapN *
A full [reservoir of water such as is called] maSonaEap: (S, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] ↓ zalafN: (S:) so, accord. to Sh, in the trad. mentioned voce zilofN: (TA:) or ↓ zalafN signifies full watering-troughs, (K,) as pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of zalafapN: (TA:) or a full watering-trough. (K.) Also A [bowl such as is called] SaHofap: (K;) and so ↓ zulofapN; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) of which the pl. is zulafN: (TA:) or a full SaHofap; and its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is ↓ zalafN. (Lth, TA.) Also A green [vessel of the kind called] A_ij~aAnap: (K:) so says AO: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] ↓ zalafN; and ↓ mazaAlifu likewise signifies green A^ajaAjiyn [app. as an anomalous pl. of zalafapN or of zalafN, like as ma$aAbihu is of $abahN]; both, also, mentioned on the authority of AO. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A mother-of-pearl-'shell, or an oyster-shell; syn. SadafapN: (K:) Kt says that Alz~alafap in the trad. mentioned above voce zilofN has been expl. as meaning the maHaArap, i. e. the Sadafap; but he adds, I know not this explanation, unless a pool of water be called mHArp because the water returns (yaHuwru) to it and collects in it. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A smooth rock: (K:) so, too, said to mean in the same trad.: and some read Alzlqp. (TA.) And Rugged ground. (K.) And Swept ground. (K.) And An even part of a soft mountain. (K.) Pl. (K) [or rather coll. gen. n.] in all these senses (TA) ↓ zalafN. (K.) ― -b4- See also zilofN. ― -b5- Also A mirror: (O, K: [in the CK, AlmaroA^apu is put in the place of AlmiroA=pu:]) [like zalaqapN:] mentioned by IB on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, and by Sgh on that of Ks: and so, too, it is said to mean in the trad. mentioned above; the earth being likened thereto because of its evenness and cleanness: (TA:) or the face thereof; (K;) as is said by IAar. (TA.)
zulofaY * : see zulofapN, in four places.

EuqobapN zaluwfN * [A stage of a journey] far-extend-
ing: (O, K:) so says IF. (O.) [In the CK, EaqabapN is erroneously put for EuqobapN.]

zaliyfN *
Advancing; or going forward, or before. (O, K. [It is said in the TA that Almutaqad~imu as the explanation of Alz~aliyfu is erroneously put in the copies of the K for Alt~aqad~umu: but this assertion is app. itself erroneous.]) See zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

[
A^azolafu * expl. by Golius as on the authority of the KL, and by Freytag after him, as meaning Parvo naso præditus ejusque recto ac parvo mucrone, is a mistake for A^a*olafu, thus written in my copy of the KL.]

[
A^azolafapN * and A^azolafaY expl. by Freytag as meaning Copia parva, cœtus hominum parvus, as on the authority of El-Meydánee, are app. mistakes for A^azofalapN and A^azofalaY.]

mazolafapN *
Any town (qaroyapN) that is between the desert and the cultivated land: pl. mazaAlifu: (S, * K:) the latter is syn. with baraAgiylu, signifying the towns (bilaAd) that are between the cultivated land and the desert; (S;) or, between the desert and the baHor [i.e. sea or great river]; such as El-Ambár and El-Kádiseeyeh. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [The pl.] mazaAlifu also signifies Places of ascent; or steps, or stairs, by which one ascends: (K:) because they bring one near to the place to which he ascends. (TA.) -A2- For the pl. mazaAlifu, see also zalafapN.

1 zaliqa * , aor.
zalaqa , (K,) inf. n. zalaqN; (TA;) and zalaqa, aor.
zaluqa , (K,) inf. n. zaloqN; (TA;) He slipped; syn. zal~a; (K, TA;) for which *al~a is erroneously put in [some of] the copies of the K. (TA. [See also 5.]) And zaliqato rijoluhu, (S,) or Alqadamu, (Msb,) aor.
zalaqa , inf. n. zalaqN, (S, Msb,) His foot, (S,) or the foot, (Msb,) slipped, (S,) or did not remain firm, or fixed, in its place. (Msb.) The former is also said of an arrow, [app. as meaning It slid along the ground,] like zahiqa [q. v.]. (JK in art. zhq.) ― -b2- zaliqa bimakaAnihi and zalaqa, He was, or became, disgusted by, or with, his place, or he loathed it, and removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, from it. (K, TA.) ― -b3- zalaqato, said of a she-camel, She was, or became, quick, or swift. (O, TA.) -A2- zalaqahu: see 4. ― -b2- zalaqahu Eano makaAnihi, aor.
zaliqa , (K,) inf. n. zaloqN, (TA,) He removed him from his place. (K, TA.) Hence the reading of Aboo-Jaafar and Náfi', [in the Kur lxviii. 51,] waA_ino yakaAdu A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA layazoliquwnaka biA^aboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily they who have disbelieved almost] smite thee with their evil eyes so as to remove thee from thy station in which God has placed thee, by reason of enmity to thee. (TA. [Or this reading may be rendered agreeably with the common reading: see 4.]) ― -b3- zalaqa raA^osahu, (S, K,) aor.
zaliqa , inf. n. zaloqN, (S,) He shaved his head; as also ↓ Azlqhu; and ↓ zl~qhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tazoliyqN: (S:) IB says that, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, it is only zabaqahu, with b; and that Alz~aboqu means the plucking out; not the shaving: but accord. to Fr, one says of him who has shaved his head qd zlqh, [whether with or without teshdeed is not shown,] and Azlqh. (TA.)

2 zl~q * , [inf. n. tazoliyqN,] He made a place slippery, (K, TA,) so that it became like the mazolaqap; and thus too though there be no water therein. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to the O and K, [the inf. n.] tazoliyqN also signifies The anointing the body with oils and the like, so that it becomes like the mazolaqap; to which is added in the O, and though it be without water: but this is a confusion of two meanings; one of which is the first expl. above in this paragraph; and the other is, the anointing the body with oils and the like; as in the L and the Tekmileh. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 4. ― -b4- And see 1, last sentence. ― -b5- zl~q AlHadiydapa He made the iron thing to be always sharp. (K.) ― -b6- rl~qhu bibaSarihi, inf. n. as above, He looked sharply, or intently, at him, or it. (Ez-Zejjájee, TA.) ― -b7- See also 2, last sentence, in art. dlS.

4 Azlqhu *
He made him to slip; as also ↓ zalaqahu. (K.) All the readers except those of El-Medeeneh read, [in the Kur lxviii. 51,] waA_ino yakaAdu A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA layuzoliquwnaka biA^aboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily those who have disbelieved] almost make thee to fall by their looking hard at thee, with vehement hatred: so accord. to El-'Otbee: or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) [almost] smite thee with their [evil] eyes: (TA:) [it is also said that] Azlq fulaAnFA bibaSarihi means (tropical:) he looked at such a one with the look of a person affected with displeasure, or anger: (K:) or so naZara A_ilaY fulaAnK faA^azolaqahu bibaSarihi: (Jm, TA:) and in this sense, also, is expl. the saying in the Kur mentioned above. (TA.) One says also Azlq rijolahu, (S,) or Alqadama, (Msb,) He made his (another's) foot to slip, (S,) or he made the foot not to remain firm, or fixed, in its place; and so ↓ zal~aqahaA. (Msb.) ― -b2- Azlqt, said of a camel, (S, K, TA,) and of a mare, (TA,) She cast her young one; syn. A^asoqaTato; (S, TA;) or A^ajohaDato [q. v.]: (K:) or she (a mare) cast forth her young one completely formed: or, as some say, [her fœtus] not completely formed: (JK:) and you say also, Azlqt bijaniynihaA, like A^amolaSato bh [q. v.]: (Abu-l- 'Abbás, TA in art. mlS:) or Azlqt waladahaA is said of a female [of any kind], and means she cast forth her young one before it was completely formed. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence.

5 tzl~q *
He, or it, slipped, or slid, along; (KL;) like tzl~j. (S and TA in art. zlj. [See also 1.]) One says, tzl~qt Algud~apu bayona Aljilodi waAll~aHomi [The ganglion slipped about between the skin and the flesh]. (M in art. dyS.) ― -b2- [Also It was, or became, smooth, or slippery: a signification indicated in the M, in art. mls, where it is coupled with AisotawaY.] ― -b3- He anointed his body with oils and the like. (JK.) ― -b4- He ornamented, or adorned, himself; (Aboo-Turáb, K, TA;) as also tzb~q: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) and led an easy, and a soft, or delicate, life, so that his colour, and the exterior of his skin, had a shining, or glistening. (K, TA.)
zaloqN * : see the next paragraph.

makaAnN zalaqN * , (S,) or zalaqN [alone], (K,) which is originally an inf. n., (S,) and ↓ zaliqN and ↓ zaloqN (K) and ↓ zalaAqapN and ↓ mazolaqN and ↓ mazolaqapN, (S, K, TA, [the last two erroneously written in the CK mizolaq and mizolaqap,]) all signify the same; (K;) A slippery place; a place on which the foot does not remain firm, or fixed. (S, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xviii. 38], fatuSobiHa SaEiydFA zalaqFA, i. e., [So that it shall become] smooth ground, with nothing in it, or with no plants in it: or, accord. to Akh, such that the feet shall not stand firmly upon it. (TA.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Mohammad Ibn-Besheer, (Ham p. 551,)
qad~iro lirijolika qabola AlxaTowi mawoqiEahaA
famano EalaA zalaqFA Eano gir~apK zalajaA
[Appoint for thy foot, before the stepping, its place upon which it shall fall, or, as in the Ham p. 522, simply its place, (mawoDiEahaA,)] for he who goes upon a slippery place, in consequence of inadvertence, slips]. (TA.) ― -b2- zalaqN also signifies The rump of a horse or similar beast. (S, K, TA.)

zaliqN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Applied to a man, Quickly angry (O, K) at what is said. (O) ― -b3- And, (T, S, K,) as also ↓ zumaliqN (T, S, and K in art. zmlq) and ↓ zum~aliqN and ↓ zumaAliqN, (S, and K in art. zmlq,) applied to a man, (T, S,) Qui semen emittit quum verba mulieri facit, sine congressu: (T, TA:) or qui semen emittit ante initum. (S, K.)

zalaqapN *
A smooth rock; (K;) as also zalafapN. (K in art. zlf.) ― -b2- And, (AZ, K,) as also the latter word, (AZ, TA,) A mirror. (AZ, K. [In the CK, AlmaroA^apu is erroneously put for AlmiroA=pu.])

naAqapN zaluwqN *
A quick, or swift, she-camel; (AZ, K;) as also zaluwjN. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And EuqobapN zaluwqN [and zaluwjN and zaluwxN, in the CK, erroneously, EaqabapN,] A far-extending [stage of a journey]. (K, TA.)

zaliyqN *
i. q. siqoTN [meaning A young one, or fœtus, that falls from the belly of the mother abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, or dead, but having the form developed, or manifest]. (S, K.)
zalaAqapN * : see zalaqN.
zul~ayoqN * The smooth peach; (S, K;) called in Pers. $iyfotaho ranoG. (S.)
zumaliqN * and zum~aliqN and zumaAliqN: see zaliqN.

ziyHN zayolaqN *
A wind swift in its passage. (Kr, TA.)
Alz~aAluwqu * the name of a shield belonging to the Prophet; meaning That from which the weapon slips off, so that it does not wound the bearer. (TA.)
A^azolaqu * (K in art. dlS) Hairless and glistening in body. (TK in that art.)
mazolaqN * : see zalaqN.
mazolaqapN * : see zalaqN. [Hence,] one says, huwa EalaY mazolaqapi AlbaATili [He is on the slippery way of false religion or the like]. (MF voce jaAd~apN, q. v.)

mizolaAqN *
i. q. mizolaAjN, (K,) a dial. var. of the latter word, [q. v.,] meaning The thing by means of which a door is closed, or made fast, and which is opened without a key. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also A mare [or other female (see 4)] that often casts her young; (S, K;) i. e., that usually does so; and applied in this sense to a camel. (TA.)

Q. 1 zaloqama *
He swallowed a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful. (TA.) -A2- [The inf. n.] zaloqamapN signifies [also], accord. to IB, The being wide, broad, or ample. (TA.)
zuloqumN * The sea; from zaloqamapN meaning as expl. above; as also qulozumN. (IKh, TA.)

zuloquwmN *
i. q. HuloquwmN [The windpipe]. (IDrd, S in art. zqm, L, and K.) ― -b2- Also The xuroTuwm [i. e. nose, or fore part thereof,] of a dog: and of a beast of prey: and, accord. to IAar, [the proboscis] of an elephant. (TA.)

1 zalama * , (aor.
zaluma , inf. n. zalomN, TK,) He cut off one's nose [and app. anything projecting, or prominent: see 2: and see also 8]. (ISh, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He made his gift little, or small, in quantity or amount; (S, K;) [as though he cut off something from it;] in [some of the copies of] the S, [but not so in mine,] ↓ zl~m. (TA.) ― -b3- He filled (S, K) a water-ing-trough, or tank, (S,) or a vessel; (K;) as also ↓ zl~m, inf. n. tazoliymN. (AHn, K.)

2 zl~m Als~ahoma * , (S, K, *) inf. n. tazoliymN, (K,) He cut [or pared] the arrow, and made its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship, good: (S:) [he shaped it well:] or he made it even and supple. (K.) And zul~ima is said of anything as meaning Its edges were pared off. (TA.) [Hence,] zl~m Alr~aHaY He made the mill-stone round, and took from its edges. (K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
kaA^aroHaA='i raqodK zal~amatohaA AlmanaAqiru
[Like the mill-stones of Rakd (a mountain so called) which the picks have rounded by taking from their edges]: he likens the foot of the camel to a mill-stone from the edges of which the maEaAwil have taken, (S, TA,) and which they have made even. (TA.) And zal~amotu AlHajara signifies I cut the stone, and prepared it properly for a millstone. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- zl~m gi*aA='ahu (assumed tropical:) He made his food, or nutriment, bad, [i. e. fed him ill,] (K, TA,) so that his body became small. (TA.)

8 Aizodalama *
He cut off one's head. (ISh, K.) And He extirpated one's nose. (K.)
zalomN * or zulomN, whence the phrase huwa AlEabodu zalomFA: see zalomap.

zalamN * and ↓ zulamN An arrow without a head and without feathers: pl. A^azolaAmN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) which was applied to those [divining-] arrows by means of which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance sought to know what was allotted to them: (S, K:) they were arrows upon which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance wrote “ Command ” and “ Prohibition; ” (Mgh, Msb;) or upon some of which was written “ My Lord hath commanded me; ” and upon some, “ My Lord hath forbidden me; ” (Har p. 465;) or they were three arrows; upon one of which was written “ My Lord hath commanded me; ” and upon another, “ My Lord hath forbidden me; ” and the third was blank; (Bd in v. 4;) and they put them in a receptacle, (Mgh, Msb,) and when any one of them desired to make a journey, or to accomplish a want, (Mgh,) or when he desired to perform some affair, (Msb,) he put his hand into that receptacle, (Mgh, Msb,) and took forth an arrow; (Msb;) and if the arrow upon which was “ Command ” [or “ My Lord hath commanded me ” (Har ubi suprà)] came forth, he went to accomplish his purpose; but if that upon which was “ Prohibition ” [or “ My Lord hath forbidden me ” (Har)] came forth, he refrained; (Mgh, Msb;) and if the blank came forth, they shuffled them a second time: (Bd ubi suprà:) or, as some say, the AzlAm were white pebbles, upon which they thus wrote, and by means of which they sought to know what was allotted to them in the manner expl. above: (Har ubi suprà:) or, accord. to Az, the AzlAm [were arrows that] belonged to Kureysh, in the Time of Ignorance, upon which were written “ He hath commanded ” and “ He hath forbidden, ” and “ Do thou ” and “ Do thou not; ” they had been well shaped (zul~imato) and made even, and placed in the Kaabeh, the ministers of the House taking care of them; and when a man desired to go on a journey, or to marry, he came to the minister, and said, “ Take thou forth for me a zlm; ” and thereupon he would take it forth, and look at it; and if the arrow of command came forth, he went to accomplish that which he had purposed to do; but if the arrow of prohibition came forth, he refrained from that which he desired to do: [it is said that] there were seven of the arrows thus called with the minister of the Kaabeh, having marks upon them, and used for this purpose: (Jel in v. 4:) and sometimes there were with the man two such arrows, which he put into his sword-case; and when he desired to seek the knowledge of what was allotted to him, he took forth one of them. (TA.) Some say that the A^azolaAm are The arrows of the game called Almayosir: but this is a mistake. (TA.) The seeking to obtain the knowledge of what is allotted to one by means of the AzlAm is forbidden in the Kur v. 4. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, A^azolaAmu Albaqarapi (tropical:) The legs of the [wild] ox or cow: likened to the arrows called AzlAm because of their slenderness: or, accord. to the A, because of their strength and hardness. (TA.) [Hence, likewise,] the former of the two words (zalamN) signifies also (assumed tropical:) A strong and light or active boy: pl. as above: (TA:) [app. because] a poet likens [such] a boy to an arrow of the kind thus called. (S, TA. *) -A2- Also, both words, (K,) the latter on the authority of Kr, (TA,) A cloven hoof: (K:) accord. to some, peculiarly of the ox-kind: (TA:) or the [projecting] thing that is behind it: (S, K:) pl. as above. (K, * TA.) -A3- And the latter of the same two words, (AA, S,) or each of them, (K,) [The hyrax Syriacus;] one of the [animals called] wibaAr [pl. of waborN]: pl. as above. (AA, S, K.)
zulamN * : see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

huwaAlEabodu zalomapF * and ↓ zulomapF and ↓ zalamapF and ↓ zulamapF, [the last omitted in some copies of the K,] (S, K,) and also with n in the place of the l, (S and K in art. znm) (assumed tropical:) He is one whose proportion, or conformation, (S, K,) or whose cut, (K,) is that of the slave: (S, K:) or he is the slave in truth: (Ks, S:) or he resembles the slave as though he were he: (Lh, K:) it is as though one said, ↓ hw AlEbd mazoluwmFA, i. e. he is the slave, being thus created by God, so that every one who looks at him sees the characteristics of the slaves impressed upon him: and it is a prov. applied to him who is low, ignoble, or mean: (Meyd:) [i. e.,] one says thus in disapproval (fY Alnkrp [i. e. fiY Aln~akarapi] or fY Aln~akirapi): (Lh: so in different copies of the S:) and in like manner one says of the female slave [hiYa AlA^amapu zalomapF &c.]: (Lh, S, K:) As said, huwa AlEabodu zalomapu, using the nom. case, without tenween; but IAar said, hw AlEbd zalomapF, using the accus. case, with tenween: so in the handwriting of 'Abd-Es-Selám El-Basree: (TA:) and accord. to Lh, one says, yaA fataY ↓ h`*aA AlEabodu zalomFA, (so in some copies of the S,) or ↓ zulomFA, (so in other copies of the S, and in the TA,) with damm, (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) This is the slave in proportion, or conformation, and in cut, O young man: (S, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, truly. (TA.)
zulomap * : see the next preceding paragraph.

zalamapN * [A kind of wattle]: zalamataA AlEanozi means the zanamataAni of the she-goat: (K:) or, accord. to Kh, zalamapN signifies a certain appertenance of goats; a thing hanging from their Huluwq [here meaning throats, externally,] like the [kind of ear-ring called] quroT; the animal having two of such things: if an appertenance of the ear, it is called zanamapN, [q. v.,] with n. (S, TA.) See also A^azolamu. -A2- See also zalomap.
zulamap * : see zalomap.
zaliymN * : see muzal~amN.
naAYN zulaAmiY~N * : see zunaAmiY~N, in art. znm.

A^azolamu * (K) and ↓ muzal~amN, (A'Obeyd, K,) as also [A^azonamu and zanimN and] muzan~amN [applied to a camel], (TA,) Having the end of the ear cut, (A'Obeyd, K,) a [portion termed] ↓ zalamap or zanamap being left [hanging] to it: (A'Obeyd, TA:) this is done only to camels of generous race, (A'Obeyd, K,) and to sheep or goats: the fem. of the first is zalomaA='u: (K:) [see also zanimN: or] A^azolamu, fem. as above, is applied to a goat, as meaning having what are termed zalamataAni [dual of zalamapN expl. above]. (S.) ― -b2- AlA^azolamu AljadaEu signifies The mountain-goat; (K;) agreeably with the original meaning; (TA;) and so ↓ Almuzal~amu: (K:
[in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted between the words AlwaEilu and AlS~agiyru Aljuv~api:]) and Alz~alomaA='u signifies The female mountain-goat. (Kr, K.) ― -b3- And also, i. e. AlAzlm Alj*E, (K,) because it is [as though it were] always ja*aE, not becoming old, (TA,) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, (S, K,) that is hard, or rigorous, (K,) in its course, (TA,) abounding with trials (K) and deaths: accord. to Yaakoob, so called because deaths hang upon it, and follow it. (TA.) They said, A^awodaY bihi AlA^azolamu Alja*aEu and AlA^azonamu Alja*aEu, [q. v.] i. e. (assumed tropical:) Time, or fortune, [&c.,] destroyed it; relating to a thing that has gone, and passed, and of which one has despaired. (TA.) [See also art. j*E.] ― -b4- Alz~alomaA='u also signifies The female of the hawk kind. (Kr, K.)

muzal~amN * , applied to an arrow, (S, K, TA,) like ↓ zaliymN, (S, K,) Cut [or pared], (ISk, S,) and made good in its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship: (ISk, S, K:) [well shaped:] or made even and supple: (TA:) and in like manner the former, with p, applied to a staff (EaSFA). (S.) ― -b2- See also A^azolamu, in two places. ― -b3- Also (i. e. muzal~amN) (assumed tropical:) Short [as though cropped] in the tail. (ISk, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Small in body: (K: [in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted before the words explaining this meaning:]) and so muzan~amN: (IAar, TA:) and the former, rendered small in the body by being badly fed: (TA:) or [simply] badly fed. (S.) ― -b5- Applied to a man, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Light, (TA,) or, like muqa*~a*N, made light, (S,) in form, figure, or person: so says ISk: (S, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) short, light, or active, and Zariyf [app. as meaning either elegant in form, or clever]; (M, K;) likened to a small arrow: (M:) and, with p, applied to a woman as meaning (assumed tropical:) not tall; like muqa*~a*apN. (S.) ― -b6- Applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) Of middling make; muqotadiru Alxaloqi or muqotadaru Alxlq: (so in different copies of the K:) thus expl. in the M. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) Small [or scanted]; applied to a gift. (TA.)
mazoluwmN * : see zalomap.
zil~iy~apN * [expl. in art. zl, q. v.,] sing. of zalaAliY~u. (K.)

1 zam~ahu * , (K,) aor.
zamu3a , inf. n. zam~N, (TA,) He tied, or bound, it: fastened it; or made it fast. (K.) ― -b2- zam~a AlbaEiyra, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) He attached, (ISk,) or put, (Mgh,) or tied, or fastened, (Msb,) to the camel, (ISk, Mgh, Msb,) the zimaAm [q. v.], (ISk, Mgh,) or his zimaAm; (Msb;) he put in the camel's burap, or his xizaAm, [each meaning a nose-ring,] or his xi$aA$ap, [or xi$aA$, a wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose,] the zimaAm, and tied it, or fastened it, in order to restrain him thereby; (Har p. 329;) i. q. xaTamahu: (S, K:) and ↓ zam~ama AljimaAla [He attached A^azim~ap (pl. of zimaAm) to the camels], (TA,) or AljimaAlu ↓ zum~ima [The camels had A^azim~p attached to them]; (S) with teshdeed because relating to several objects. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, zam~a nafosahu (assumed tropical:) He restrained, or withheld, himself. (Mgh.) And zum~ati AlA^alosinapu (assumed tropical:) The tongues were restrained, or withheld. (Har p. 329.) And maA A^atakal~ama bikalimapK Hat~aY A^axoTimahaA waA^azum~ahaA (assumed tropical:) [I say not a saying until I qualify it to be used with cogency or efficiency]. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence also, (Mgh,) zam~a Aln~aEola, (S, Mgh, TA,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He attached a zimaAm [q. v.] to the sandal; (S, Mgh, TA;) as also AlnEl ↓ Azm~. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b5- [Hence likewise,] zam~a biA^anofihi, said of a camel, (assumed tropical:) He raised [his nose, and consequently] his head, by reason of a pain in it. (K.) And the same phrase, (S, K,) said of a man, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He elevated his nose, from pride; (K;) or he magnified, or exalted, himself; or was proud; (S, K; *) as also ↓ Aizodam~a; (K;) and ↓ zAm~, inf. n. muzaAm~apN. (TA.) ― -b6- And zam~a biraA^osihi (tropical:) He raised his head; (K, TA;) inf. n. as above: (TA:) [and so zam~a raA^osahu: for] you say, A^axa*a Al*~iy^obu saxolapF raA^osahu ↓ fa*ahaba bihaA zaAm~FA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The wolf took a newborn lamb or kid, and went away with it] raising [his head], (S, TA,) or ↓ zam~FA i. e. raising with it his head: (TA:) and you say of the wolf, zam~ahaA and ↓ Aizodam~ahaA, both meaning the same, (S, K,) i. e. He took it, namely, the new-born lamb or kid, raising his head, or its head, (accord. to different copies of the K,) with it. (TA.) ― -b7- zam~a Alqirobapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He filled the water-skin. (K, TA.) -A2- zam~ati Alqirobapu, [aor., accord. to rule,
zami3a ,] inf. n. zumuwmN, (tropical:) The water-skin became full: thus the verb is intrans. as well as trans. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And zam~a said of a camel's tush, (assumed tropical:) It rose. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He went forward, or onward; or before, or ahead; (S, K, TA;) as some say, (TA,) in journeying: (S, K, TA:) in this sense, the inf. n. is zam~N. (TA.) -A3- Also, (inf. n. zam~N, A'Obeyd, TA,) He spoke, or talked. (A'Obeyd, K, TA.) ― -b2- One says also of the sparrow, yzm~ biSawotK lahu DaEiyfK [app. yazim~u, as it is intrans., meaning The sparrow chirps with a feeble voice peculiar to it]: and thus do large hornets. (TA.)
2 zam~a3a see 1, second sentence, in two places.

3 zaAoma3a see 1. -A2- You say also, xarajotu maEahu A^uzaAm~uhu, and A^uxaAzimuhu, i. e. A^uEaAriDuhu [meaning (assumed tropical:) I went forth with him taking a different way from his until we both met in one place: see xaAzamahu]. (TA.)
4 A^azoma3a see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

7 Anzm~ *
It was, or became, tied, or bound; fastened; or made fast. (K.)
8 A_izotama3a see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, Azdm~ Al$~aYo'a A_ilayohi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He stretched forth the thing to him. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 zamozamapN * [as inf. n. of zamozama, and also as a simple subst.,] A distant sounding or sound, such as is confused and continued. (K.) You say, of a thing, zamozama, meaning It made a distant sound, confused and continued: and samiEotu zamozamapF I heard a distant sound, confused and continued. (TK.) ― -b2- The sounding, or sound, of thunder: (AZ, S:) or the consecutive reiteration of the sound of thunder; which is the best kind of sounding thereof, and the surest symptom of rain. (M, K.) One says, Alr~aEodu yuzamozimu The thunder sounds with consecutive reiteration. (TK.) Accord. to AHn, the zamozamap of thunder is [The sounding thereof] when it is not loud and clear. (TA.) ― -b3- The speaking, or speech, of the Magians, on the occasion of their eating, (S, IAth,) with a low voice: (IAth:) or the gibbering, or uttering gibberish or jargon, one to another, of the Persians, or other foreigners, (taraATunu AlEuluwji,) over their eating, while they are [in a manner] speechless, not making use of tongue nor of lip [so as to articulate]; it being a sound which they roll in their noses and their fauces, but such that they understand one another: (K:) or zamozama, said of a Magian, means He affected, or constrained himself, to speak, on the occasion of eating, while closing his mouth: whence the saying, waA@nohawohumo Eani Alz~amozamapi [And forbid ye them from the affecting, &c.]. (Mgh.) ― -b4- The crying [or roaring], or the cry [or roar], of the lion. (K.) You say of him, zamozama [He cried, or roared]. (TA.) ― -b5- It is also [The uttering, or utterance, of a sound, or of the voice,] from the chest, when it is not clear. (TA.) ― -b6- Also The crying [or whinnying or neighing], or the cry [or neigh], of the horse: [see muzamozimN:] so in the saying, Hawola AlS~il~iyaAni Alz~amozamapu [Around the Sl~yAn (a kind of plant, or herbage,) is whinnying or neighing]: (Meyd:) this is a prov., applied to a man who hovers round about a thing, and does not make apparent his desire: (Meyd, TA:) or to a man who is served for the sake of his wealth: (Meyd:) the Sl~yAn is one of the most excellent kinds of pasture: and the prov. means that the cries and clamour that one hears are for the desire of what is to be eaten and enjoyed: Z says, (TA,) the Sl~yAn is cut for the horses that do not quit the tribe; (Meyd, TA;) and they neigh, or whinny, (tuzamozimu, and tuHamoHimu,) around it: (TA:) some relate it otherwise, saying Hawola AlS~ulobaAni [around the crosses], pl. of SaliybN; and Alz~amozamapu [they say] means the crying, or cry, of the worshipper thereof. (Meyd.) -A2- zamozama also signifies He kept, guarded, or took care of, a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- And zamozamotu AlmaAla, inf. n. zamozamapN, I collected together the cattle, or property, and drove back, or put back, the outer ones, or outer portions, of what had become scattered thereof. (TA.)
R. Q. 2 tazamozama * , said of a camel, He brayed; syn. hadara. (K. [See also R. Q. 1, which has nearly the same meaning.]) ― -b2- tazamozamato bihi $afataAhu His lips moved with it. (TA.)
zam~N * [an inf. n. used in the sense of an act. part. n.]: see zaAm~N: ― -b2- and see also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

zamam * is thought by ISd to be used only as an adv. n.: (TA:) [but see what follows.] wajohiY zamama bayotihi means My face is towards his house. (K.) An Arab of the desert said, laA waA@l~a*iY wajohiY zamama bayotihi maA kaAna ka*aA waka*aA, meaning [No, by Him]
towards whose house [is my face, it was not thus and thus, or such and such things did not happen]. (S.) ― -b2- One says also, daAriY mino daArihi zamamN, (S,) or daAriY zamama daArihi, (K, TA, in the CK zamamu,) (tropical:) My house is near to his house. (S, K, TA.) ― -b3- And A^amoruhumo zamamN (assumed tropical:) Their affair, or case, is conformable to the just mean; like A^amamN: (S, K:) or easy, not exceeding the due measure, bound, or limit. (Lh, TA.)

zimaAmN *
A thing with which one ties or binds, fastens, or makes fast: (K:) meaning [the noserein of a camel; i. e.] the cord that is tied to the burap [or xizaAm, each meaning nose-ring of a camel], or to the xi$aA$ [or wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose], and to which, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. to the end of which, (S, TA,) is tied the miqowad [or leading-rope]: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and (afterwards, Msb) also applied to the miqawod (S, Msb, TA) itself: (Msb:) pl. A^azim~apN. (Msb, K.) [See also xiTaAmN.] It is said in a trad., laA zimaAma walaA xizaAma fiY AlA_isolaAmi [There shall be no nose-rein nor nosering by which to lead a man in El-Islám]: meaning a practice of the devotees of the Children of Israel, who used to attach rings and reins to the noses, like as is done to the she-camel in order that she may be led thereby. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zimaAmu AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) That by means of which the thing, or affair, subsists, and is conducted, or managed, and ordered. (TA.) And A^aloqaY fiY yadihi zimaAma A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) [He put in his hand, or power, the means of conducting his affair, or the conduct of his affair]: and yuS~arifu A^azim~apa AlA^umuwri (assumed tropical:) [He disposes as he pleases the various means of conducting the affairs]. (TA.) And huwa EalaY zimaAmK mino A^amorihi (assumed tropical:) He is on the point of accomplishing his affair. (TA.) And Aln~aAqapu zimaAmu AlA_ibili (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel is the leader of the other camels]: said when she goes before them. (TA.) And huwa zimaAmu qawomihi (assumed tropical:) [He is the leader of his people, or party]: and humo A^azim~apN qawomihimo (assumed tropical:) [They are the leaders of their people, or party]. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 261 and 503; and see Quatremère's Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, vol. i., sec. part, pp. 65 and 66.] ― -b3- zimaAmu Aln~aEoli (assumed tropical:) [The zmAm of the sandal] is the thing to which the $isoE is attached, or tied: (S:) or the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it, to which the $isoE is attached, or tied: [but for the latter of these explanations, it seems that we should read the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it: or the thong to which the $isoE is attached, or tied: the $isoE being the thong that passes through the sole, and between two of the toes, and to which the $iraAk is attached: for it appears that the term zimaAm is applied by some to the thong called by others the $iraAk, extending between the leg and the toes: and by some, to what is called by others the $isoE, or qibaAl: to the latter as being likened to the cord that is tied to the camel's nose-ring; and to the former as being likened to the leading-rope which is tied to that cord: it being] a metaphorical term, from the zimaAm of the camel: (Mgh:) it is [said to be] the thong lies upon the back [meaning upper side] of the foot, [extending] from, or [consisting] of, the fore part of the $iraAk, lengthwise: [for the term $iraAk (q. v.) is sometimes used in a larger sense than that above assigned to it:] or it is like the qibaAl, [which is expl. in the same manner as the $isoE, i. e., as] being between the middle toe and that next to it: (Har p. 539:) [and thus it is expl. by J and Mtr and F in another art.;] the qibaAl of the sandal is its zimaAm, (S, and Mgh and K in art. qbl,) i. e. its thong which is (Mgh in that art.) between the middle toe and next to it. (S and Mgh and K in that art.)
zam~amN * or zam~amu: see zamozamN.

zum~aAmN *
Tall herbs, (K,) rising above such as are termed luEaAE. (TA.)

zamozamN *
Copious, or abundant, water; as also ↓ zumaAzimN: (K:) [or] the latter, (Kz, TA,) [and app. the former also,] and ↓ zumazimN, (IKh, TA,) and ↓ zamozaAmN, (Kz, TA,) brackish water; i. e. such as is between salt and sweet. (IKh, Kz, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (accord. to some copies of the S and K,) or zamozamu, (accord. to other copies of the same, and accord. to the Msb,) imperfectly decl., because of the fem. gender and a proper name, (Msb,) the name of The well of Mekkeh, (so in a copy of the S and in the Msb,) or a certain [celebrated] well in Mekkeh, (so in another copy of the S,) [i. e.] a certain well adjacent to the Kaabeh; (K;) so called [because its water is somewhat brackish, or] because of the copiousness of its water; (JM;) as also ↓ zumazim [i. e. zumazimN or zumazimu], (IAar, TA,) and ↓ zumaAzimN [or zumaAzimu], and ↓ zam~amN or zam~amu, (accord. to different copies of the K,) the last (zam~am) on the authority of IAar. (TA.) The names of this well, collected from trads. and lexicons, have been found to amount to more than sixty. (TA.) ― -b3- zamozam [with or without tenween] is also the name of A celebrated well at El-Medeeneh, which is regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing, and the water of which is drunk and transported [like that of the more celebrated well of the same name at Mekkeh]. (TA.) -A2- zamozamN or zamozamu (accord. to different copies of the S, [used by a poet with tenween, but probably by poetic license, for it is app. a fem. proper name, and therefore imperfectly decl.,]) is also A name of, or for, a she-camel, like EayoTal. (S.)
zimozimN * : see zimozimapN, in two places.
zumazimN * or zumazimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zamozamapN * [inf. n. of R. Q. 1 (q. v. passim); and also used as a simple subst., of which the pl. is zamaAzimu]. You say raEodN *uw zamaAzima and hadaAhida [Thunder having confused and continued, or murmuring, sounds, heard from a distance]. (TA.) And zamaAzimu Aln~aAri The sounds of the blazing of fire. (TA.)

zimozimapN *
A company, or collection, (S, K,) of men, (S, TA,) whatever it be: (TA:) or any collection; as also zmzwm [i. e. ↓ zumozuwmN]: (Ham p. 233:) or fifty, (K,) and thereabout, (TA,) of camels, and of men; (As, K;) as also DimoDimapN; (As, TA;) neither of which words is formed by substitution from the other: (TA:) pl. zmAzm [i. e. zamaAzimu], (Ham ubi suprà,) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ zimozimN, (S, * TA,) occurring in the saying of a rájiz, (S,) Aboo-Mohammad El-Fak'asee, (TA,)
A_i*aA tadaAniY zimozimN mino zimozimi
[When companies draw near to companies]. (S, TA.) Also A distinct number of jinn, or genii: or of beasts of prey. (K.) And A herd of camels among which are no young ones, or little ones; and so ↓ zimoziymN: (K:) or, accord. to EshSheybánee, ↓ zimozimN and ↓ zimoziymN signify large, big, or bulky, camels. (S.)

saHaAbN zamozaAmN *
Clouds thundering, but not loudly and clearly. (AHn, TA.) [Accord. to one passage in the TA, zamozaAmN seems to be expl. by IKh as meaning Thundering much: but the passage appears to be incorrectly transcribed.] ― -b2- See also zamozamN.

zumozuwmN * The best, or excellent, or choice, of camels: or a hundred thereof. (K.) And The best of a people; (K, TA;) the choice, best, or most excellent, portion thereof: in one copy of the K, [and so in the CK,] $ar~uhumo is put in the place of sir~uhumo. (TA.) ― -b2- See also zimozimapN.
zimoziymN * : see zimozimapN, last sentence, in two places.
zumaAzimN * or zumaAzimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zaAm~N * [act. part. n. of zam~a]. zaA^am~ahaA [meaning Attaching a zimaAm to her] occurs used by poetic license for zaAm~ahaA, because of the concurrence of two quiescent letters; like AisowaA^ad~ato for AisowaAd~ato. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Magnifying, or exalting, himself; or elevating his nose, from pride: (S, TA:) [and in like manner ↓ zam~N:] one says, zaA^ayotuhu zam~FA (assumed tropical:) I saw him magnifying, or exalting, himself, &c., not speaking: (TA:) pl. of the former zum~amN. (S, TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b4- Also, accord. to El-Harbee, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Fearing, or afraid; syn. faziEN. (TA.)
ziyzamN * : see what next follows.

ziyziymN * a word imitative of The low, or faint, sound of the jinn, or genii, that is heard by night in the deserts; (TA in this art. and in art. zym;) and so ↓ ziyzamN: (IAar, K * and TA in art. zym:) Ru-beh says,
tasomaEu lilojin~i bihi ziyziymaA
[Thou hearest therein a low, or faint, sound of the jinn by night]. (TA.)

AlA_izomiymu *
One of the nights called layaAliY AlmuHaAqi [meaning the last three nights of the lunar month]. (K.) ― -b2- And The decrescent moon in the last part of the [lunar] month, (K,) when it becomes slender and bow-shaped: Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in this sense without the article Al: and Th says
that A_izomiymN is one of the names of the [moon when it is termed] hilaAl. (TA.)
A_ibilN muzam~amapN * : see what next follows.

baEiyrN mazomuwmN *
A camel having a zimaAm attached to him; syn. maxoTuwmN: and ↓ A_ibilN muzam~amapN camels having A^azim~ap attached to them; syn. muxaT~amapN. (TA.)

farasN muzamozimN fiY Sawotihi *
A horse quavering, or trilling, his voice, [or whinnying or neighing,] and prolonging it. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

zumaAwarodN * , (S and K in art. wrd,) or zamaAwarodN, as in the Commentaries on the Keshsháf, (MF,) or zum~aAwarodN, (MA,) an arabicized word, vulgarly bazomaAwarodN, (S,) or buzomaAwarodN, (K,) and the vulgar appellation is correct, agreeing with the Pers. original, (Shifá el-Ghaleel,) [which is bazomaAwarodN, or] P\x{698}mAwrd, (MA,) A certain kind of food, composed of eggs and flesh-meat: (K:) or thin paste folded together, with flesh-meat within: or the kind of food called luqomapu AlqaADiY, [i. e. small, light, spongy balls, generally about the size of walnuts, made of leavened dough, and eaten with honey poured over,] and also called luqamapu Alxaliyfapi, and narojisu AlmaAy^idapi, and muyas~arN, and muhay~aA^N; and in Khurásán called nawaAlah: (MF:) or nwAlh' bzrGAn: (MA:) [or, as Golius says, on the authority of Meyd, a kind of food made of fine flour, bruised almonds, and honey.]

1 zamuta * , aor.
zamuta , inf. n. zamaAtahu, He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (A, K.)

5 tzm~t *
i. q. tawaq~ara [He showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; or he endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid, &c.]. (A.) One says, maA A^a$ad~a tazam~utahu [How great is his show of gravity, &c.! or his endeavour, or constraint of himself, to be grave, &c.!]. (Fr, S.)

zamiytN *
Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, (IAar, S, A, K, TA,) in his sitting-place: (IAar, TA:) pl. rumataA='u, (A,) or zmt [app. zumotN or zumutN, if not a mistranscription for zumataA='u, which I rather think it to be]. (TA.)

zim~iytN *
Very grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm: (S, K, TA:) forbearing, or clement; quiet; of few words; like Sim~iytN: or, as some say, silent. (TA.)

fulaAnN A^azomatu Aln~aAsi *
Such a one is the most grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, of men. (S.)

1 zamaxa * , (S, K,) or zamaxa biA^anofihi, (L,) aor.
zamaxa , (K,) inf. n. zamoxN, (L,) He exalted, or magnified, himself; was proud; (S, L, K;) behaved proudly, haughtily, or vainly; (S, L;) elevated his nose, from pride; (L;) i. q. $amaxa, or $amaxa biA^anofihi. (TA.)
zamaxN * : see zamuwxN, in two places.
zimoxN * or zimaxN The tree called sum~aAq; as also ZimoxN or ZimaxN. (TA in art. Zmx; but there written without any syll. signs.)

EuqobapN zamuwxN * [in the CK EaqabapN] (JK, A, K) and ↓ zamaxN (K) (tropical:) [A stage of a journey] far-extending, (K,) hard, or difficult. (AZ, IAar, JK, K.) One says, saAra EuqobapF zamuwxFA (tropical:) [He journeyed a long and hard stage]. (A.) ― -b2- And niy~apN zamuwxN (A, and L in art. $mx) and ↓ zamaxN, like $amuwxN and $amaxN, (L in that art.,) (tropical:) A distant, far-reaching, or faraiming, intention, purpose, or design. (A, and L ubi suprà.)

zaAmixN *
i. q. $aAmixN [Proud, &c.]; (S, K;) or $aAmixN biA^anofihi [elevating his nose, from pride]: (A, L:) [pl. zum~axN.] ― -b2- A^unuwfN zum~axN i. q. $um~axN [Noses elevated, from pride]. (S, A.) ― -b3- [Hence,] jibaAlN lahaA A^unuwfN zum~axN, (A, TA,) i. e. TiwaAlN (tropical:) [Mountains having tall, or long, prominences]. (TA.) ― -b4- And kayolN zaAmixN (tropical:) Full measure. (JK, A, K.)

1 zamara * , aor.
zamira and
zamura , inf. n. zamorN (S, Msb, K) and zamiyrN (Msb, K) and zamaraAnN; (ISd, TA;) and ↓ zm~r, inf. n. tazomiyrN; (K;) He [piped, or] played upon (lit. sang in) a reed; (K;) he blew in a mizomaArN. (S, * A, Msb. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] zamara Aln~aEaAmu, (S, K,) and zamarati Alhayoqapu, (A,) or Aln~aEaAmapu, (TA,) aor.
zamira , inf. n. zimaArN (S, A, K) and zumaArN, (TA,) (tropical:) The ostriches, (S, K,) and the she-ostrich, (A, TA,) cried, or uttered their, or her, cry. (S, A, K, TA.) [Said only of the females, or a female:] of the male ostrich one says only EaAr~a. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And zamara biAlHadiyvi (tropical:) He published, or divulged, the story. (A, K.) ― -b4- And zamara fulaAnFA bifulaAnK He excited, or incited, such a one against such a one. (A, * K, TA.) -A2- zamira, (S, K,) aor.
zamara , (K,) inf. n. zamarN, (S,) He had little hair, (S, * K, * TA,) and little wool. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, [hence,] inf. n. as above, (S,) or zamaArapN and zumuwrapN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, S, TA) had little muruwo'ap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (S, K.) ― -b3- And zamira maAluhu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) His property became little, or scanty. (TA in art. qfr.)
2 zam~ara see 1, first sentence.
10 Astzmr * (tropical:) He was, or became, abject, or ignominious, or weak, and small in body, and lean; being abased or brought low. (A, TA.) [See also the part n., below.]
zamorN * : see zumorapN.

zamirN *
Having little hair; (S, A, K;) and having little wool: fem. with p. (A, K.) You say SabiY~N zamirN A child having little hair: and $aApN zamirapN [A sheep, or goat, having little wool or hair]: and ganamN zawaAmiru [Sheep, or goats, having little wool or hair]: (A, TA:) and naAqapN zamirapN A she-camel having little fur: and nabotN zami`rN [app. meaning A plant having few leaves]. (Ham p. 683.) And $aEarN zamirN [Scanty, or thin, hair]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, [hence,] (S, K,) or zamiru Almuruwo'api, (A,) (tropical:) A man (A) having little muruwo'ap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (S, A, * K.) ― -b3- And zamiru AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) A man having little, or scanty, property. (AZ, TA in art. qfr.) ― -b4- And EaTiy~apN zamirapN (tropical:) A scanty, or small, gift. (A, * TA.) -A2- Also Good singing: (Th, TA:) [and] so ↓ zamiyrN. (Az, O, TA.) ― -b2- And Goodly in countenance. (K.)

zamorapN *
A company, or congregated body, of men; (S, K;) as also ↓ zawomarN: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) a party in a state of dispersion: (K:) pl. zumarN: (S, A, K:) you say, jaAw^uwA zumarFA They came in parties in a state of dispersion, one after another: (A:) some say that zumorapN is from ↓ zamorN [originally an inf. n., (see 1, first sentence,) and hence] signifying “ sound, ” because a company of men is not without sound: others, that it signifies a company of few persons; from $aApN zamirapN: (MF:) but the former is the proper derivation, and is confirmed by what is said in the B. (TA.)
zamuwrN * : see the next paragraph.

zamiyrN *
Short; (Kr, K;) applied to a man: (TA:) pl. zimaArN. (Kr, K.) ― -b2- And Beautiful; applied to a boy, or young man; (AA, Th, O, K;) as also ↓ zawomarN (AA, O, K) and ↓ zamuwrN. (K.) ― -b3- See also zamirN.
zimaArapN * The act [or art] of [piping, or] playing upon the reed [or mizomaAr]. (K.)

zam~aArN * (As, S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ zaAmirN, (As, S, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) or scarcely ever used, (S,) or it is not allowable, (Msb,) applied to a man; and ↓ zaAmirapu, (S, Msb, K,) but not zam~aArapN, (S, Msb,) applied to a woman; (S, Msb, K;) A [piper, or] player upon a reed; (K;) one who blows in a mizomaAr. (S, * A, Msb. *) ― -b2- Also zam~aArapN, (assumed tropical:) A fornicatress, or an adulteress: (Th, A'Obeyd, Az, S, K:) so in a trad., in which it is said nahaY Eano kasobi Alz~am~aArapi He prohibited the gain of the fornicatress: (Th, A'Obeyd, Az, S:) so called because she publishes her business: (Th:) some say that the correct word is here ram~aAzap, because such a woman makes signs with her lips and her eyes and her eyebrows: Az says that he holds the former to be the right; and Abu-l- 'Abbás Ahmad says that the latter is wrong, and that the former signifies a beautiful prostitute: but Az adds that the trad. may mean as above, or he prohibited the gain of the female singer, as AHát relates on the authority of As. (TA.)

zam~aArapN * [fem. of zam~aArN, q. v. ― -b2- Also] i. q. mizomaArN, q. v. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A saAjuwr [i. e. collar, or collar of iron,] (O, A, K, TA) that is put upon the neck of a dog. (TA.) ― -b4- And metaphorically used as meaning (tropical:) A jaAmiEap; (A, TA;) [i. e.] A [shackle for the neck and hands, such as is called] gul~. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A bar of iron (EamuwdN) between
the two rings of the [shackle called] gul~: (M, O, K:) so termed because of its sound. (O.) ― -b5- Also A she-ostrich. (Har p. 408.)
zaAmirN * ; and its fem., with p: see zam~aArN.
zawomarN * : see zumorapN: -A2- and see also zamiyrN. ― -b2- Also Playing; or a player. (O.)
muzam~arN * (assumed tropical:) Shackled [with a zam~aArp]. (O, TA.)

mizomaArN *
A musical reed, or pipe; (S, * A, Msb, * K, * TA;) what is called in Persian naAYo [now generally meaning a flute]; (marginal note in a copy of the KT;) as also ↓ zam~aArapN, (K,) [which latter, by many pronounced zum~aArap, and generally so pronounced in Egypt, is applied to a double reed-pipe, figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians,] and ↓ mazomuwrN and ↓ mazomuwrN, (IAth,) the latter like magoluwqN and magoruwdN: (TA:) pl. of the first, (S, A,) and of the last two, mazaAmiyru. (S, * A.) It is related in a trad., that Mohammad, on hearing Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree reciting, said to him, laqado A^uEoTiyta mizomaArFA mino mazaAmiyri A=li daAwuwda (tropical:) [Verily thou hast been gifted with a pipe like that of David himself]; likening the sweetness of his voice and melody to the sound of the mizomaAr; (TA;) as though he had musical pipes in his throat: or mzAmyrA=l dAwwd is here the same as mazomuwraAt daAwuwd: (A:) for, ― -b2- mazaAmiyru daAwuwda also signifies [The Psalms of David;] what David used to sing, or chant, (yatagan~aY bihi, in the CK yutagan~aY bh,) of the Psalms: (K:) and to such is likened the utmost sweetness of voice in reciting: and A=l is said to be here redundant or pleonastic; meaning the person: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) mzAmyr dAwwd signifies kinds of prayer, or supplication: it is pl. of mizomaArN and of ↓ mazomuwrN or muzomuwrN. (So in different copies of the K.)
mazomuwrN * and muzomuwrN: see mizomaArN, in two places.
musotazomirN * (tropical:) Shrinking, and abject, or ignominious, in his own estimation. (K, TA.) [See also its verb.]
zumur~udN * : see the next article.

zumur~u*N * (T, S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and zumur~a*N, (Az, TA,) and accord. to some zumur~udN, with the unpointed d (TA,) or, accord. to IKt, this is a mistranscription, and As says that it is correctly written with the pointed * (Msb,) [The emerald: accord. to some] i. q. zabarojadN; (Sudot;, L, Msb, K;) but Et-Teyfáshee [rightly] says that the zbrjd is a different kind of stone: [see this word:] and Ibn-Sá'id El-Ansáree says that the mine of the zbrjd is said to be near to that of the zm~r*: (TA:) several authors say that the zm~r* differs from the zbrjd in being more green: (MF, TA:) it is an arabicized word [from the Pers. zumorudo]: (S, L, Msb, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (Msb.)

1 zamiEa * , aor.
zamaEa , inf. n. zamaEN, He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect; in consequence of fear: (S, Msb, * K: *) he feared, or was afraid: (K:) he was impatient; or had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and found not patience: (L:) he became disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or in a state of commotion. (Lh.) -A2- zamaEati AlA^aronabu, aor.
zamaEa , (TA,) inf. n. zamaEaAnN, (Lth, K, TA,) The hare was light, or active, and quick, or swift: (Lth, K, TA:) and ↓ AzmEt it ran, (S, TA,) and was light, or active. (TA.) And zamaEa, aor.
zamaEa , inf. n. zamaEaAnN, He went slowly. (ISk, S, K.) Thus the verb has two contr. significations. (K.) And He went with short steps; as also ↓ tzm~E. (TA.)
2 zam~aEa see the next paragraph.

4 A^azomaEotu AlA^amora * , and A^azomaEotu EalaY AlA^amori; (S, K;) the former accord. to Ks.; the latter accord. to Kh, but disallowed by Ks; both, however, are authorized by Fr, as meaning the same, like A^ajomaEotuhu and A^ajomaEotu Ealayohi; (S;) and A^azomaEotu bihi; (TA;) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair: (Fr, S, K:) my determination, resolution, or decision, became fixed upon the affair, (Lth or Kh, S, TA,) to execute it, or perform it, of necessity: (Lth, TA:) or I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair: syn. vabat~u Ealayohi: (K:) and ↓ zam~aEotu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, [in the CK written without teshdeed,]) followed by EalaY before the object, inf. n. tazomiyEN, (TA,) signifies the same: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) AzmE may be formed by transposition from Ezm, or the z may be a substitute for j (IF.) You say, AzmE Almasiyra [and EalaY Almasiyri] He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going, journeying, or departing. (Mgh.) -A2- See also 1. -A3- AzmEt AlHubolapu (assumed tropical:) [The grape-vine, or its branch,] became large in its zamaEap, i. e. knot, or gem, [see zamaEN,] (ISh, K, TA,) and its fruit-stalk was near to coming forth. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- And AzmE Aln~abotu The herbage made its first appearance in a scattered state: (S:) or was not all of it equal, or uniform, but consisted of scattered portions, (K, TA,) at its first appearance, (TA,) one part surpassing another. (K, TA.)
5 tazam~aEa see 1, last sentence.

zamaEN * ; see zamaAEN. -A2- Also pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ zamaEapN, which [is the n. un. of the former, and] signifies A certain excrescence bekind the cloven hoof: (AZ, S, Msb, * K:) or a thing like the nails of sheep or goats, in the part between the shank and foot; every leg having upon it two of the things thus termed (zamaEataAni), as though they were formed of pieces of horn: (Lth, K:) or a certain excrescence projecting above the hoof of the sheep or goat: (TA:) or the pendent hairs in the kinder part of the kind leg, or kind foot, of the sheep or goat, and of the gazelle, and of the hare: (K:) [the pl. of ↓ zamaEapN is zamaEaAtN (occurring in the S and K in the present art., and in the K in art. zwd &c.), and] the pl. of zamaEN is zimaAgN: (AZ, S, K:) see zamuwEN. ― -b2- Hence, as being compared to the zamaE of the cloven hoof, (L,) zamaEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The lower, or baser, or the lowest, or basest, or the refuse, of mankind: (S, L, K:) pl. A^azomaAEN. (L.) One says, huwa mino zamaEihimo, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is of the last of them; (S, L;) and of their followers. (L.) ― -b3- Also, i. e. zamaEN The hairs behind the fetlock [-joint]; (K;) and so zamaEaAtN [pl. of the n. un. ↓ zamaEapN]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Knots, gems, or buds, in the places whence the racemes of the grape-vine come forth: (ISh, K, TA:) accord. to Et-Táïfee, (L in art. kmH,) [the n. un.] ↓ zamaEapN signifies the knot, or gem, in the place whence the raceme of grapes grows forth: (L ubi suprà, and TA:) or, as some say, the berry when it is like the head of a young ant; and the pl. is zamaEaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] zamaEN: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the gem of a leaf: (L in art. kmx:) and zamaEu Alkaromi (assumed tropical:) The leaves that cover what is within them of the raceme of the grape-vine. (TA voce kaAfuwrN.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) An excrescence, or a redundance, (ziyaAdapN,) in the fingers or toes: and the epithet [applied to him who has such] is ↓ A^azomaEu. (K.) ― -b6- And Scattered portions of herbage, here and there; like portions of clouds in the sky. (TA.)
zamaEapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

zamaAEN *
Penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the performance of an affair, and determination, resolution, or decision, to do it; (L, K;) as also ↓ zimaAEN and ↓ zamaEN: (K:) and courage, such that when one has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, he does not turn from it: (K:) and good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (K, TA,) such that when one purposes an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or courage, and great boldness: (S:) and quickness, and hastiness. (S, K.)
zimaAEN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

zamuwEN * : see zamiyEN. ― -b2- Also A hare that runs with short steps, as though it ran upon its ↓ zamaEaAt, (As, T, S, K,) i. e. the pendent hairs on the kinder parts of its kind legs: (T, TA:) or such as, when it approaches its habitation, goes upon its zamaEap, (K, TA,) and with short steps, (TA,) in order that its foot-marks may not be traced: (K, TA:) and (K, TA, but in the CK “ or ”) such as is quick, or swift, and brisk, or sprightly. (K, TA.)

zamiyEN * A man sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision: (Mgh:) a courageous man, who, when he has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, does not turn from it: (Lth, K: [in the CK, yazomaEu is a mistake
for yuzomiEu:]) and having good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (K, TA,) so that when he has purposed an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or zamiyEu Alr~aA^oYi signifies a man having good judgment: (S:) and zamiyEN signifies also quick; (K;) quick, and hasty; (S;) and so ↓ zamuwEN: (S, K:) pl. of the former zumaEaA='u. (S, K.)

huwa A^azomaEu minohu *
He is more sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision, than he. (Mgh.) -A2- See also zamaEN, last sentence but one.

A^anaA muzomiEN EalaY A^amorK * , [or muzomiEN A^amorFA, or both, and muzomiEN biA^amorK, I am determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair: or] my determination, resolution, or decision, is fixed upon an affair. (Kh, S.) [See 4.]
zimik~N * : see the following paragraph.

zimik~aY * , (Fr, S, K,) with kesr to the z and m, (K,) like zimij~aY [in measure and in meaning, app. from the Pers. zimojiY], (S,) [in the O erroneously written zimak~aY,] and ↓ zimik~N, (Fr, K, TA,) like filiz~N, (TA,) [in the O erroneously written zimak~, and in the CK zamak,] and ↓ zimik~A='u, (TA,) The place of the growth of the tail of a bird: (Fr, S, K:) or the root of the tail of a bird: (M, K:) or the whole tail of a bird: (K:) or sometimes, accord. to Lth, the tail itself is called zmk~Y when it is short (A_i*aA qaSura), (O, TA, *) or, as in some copies [of his book, meaning the 'Eyn], when it is clipped (A*A quS~a). (TA.)
zimik~aA='u * : see the preceding paragraph.

1 zamala * , aor.
zamula and
zamila , inf. n. zamaAlN, He ran, (K, TA,) and went along quickly, (TA,) leaning, or bearing, on one side, raising his other side; (K, TA;) as though he were bearing upon one leg; not with the firmness of him who bears upon both of his legs. (TA.) ― -b2- And zamala (K, TA) fiY ma$oyihi and Eadowihi, aor.
zamula , (TA,) inf. n. zamolN and zamaAlN [the latter accord. to the CK zimaAlN but said in the TA to be with fet-h like the former,] and zamalaAnN (K, TA) and zamalN, (TA as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) said of a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) or of a wild ass, (TA,) He was as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness, (K,) or as though bearing upon his fore legs, by reason of pride, or self-conceit, and briskness, in his going and his running. (TA.) -A2- zamalahu, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He bore it, or carried it; namely, a thing: (Mgh, Msb:) and ↓ Aizodamalahu (S, K,) originally Aztmlh, (TA,) signifies the same; or he took it up and carried it, or he raised it upon his back; syn. AiHotamalahu; (S, K;) at once; (K;) namely, a load: (TA:) like zabalahu and Azdblhu. (TA in art. zbl.) ― -b2- And zamalahu, (IDrd, K,) aor.
zamula , inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He made him to ride behind him, (IDrd, K,) EalaY AlbaEiyri on the camel: (IDrd:) or he rode with him [on a camel, in a maHomil,] so as to counterbalance him; (K, TK:) and so ↓ zAmlhu, (Mgh,) inf. n. muzaAmalapN, (S,) he rode with him so as to counterbalance him (S * Mgh) on a camel, (S,) in the maHomil. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [And zamala gayorahu, aor.
zamula , He followed another:] see zaAmilN.

2 zm~lhu * , (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tazomiylN, (Msb, K,) He wrapped him (S, Mgh, Msb, K *) fiY vawobihi [in his garment], (S, K, *) or fY viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] tazomiylN signifies also The act of concealing. (IAar, K.)
3 zaAomala see 1, last sentence but one. ― -b2- muzaAmalapN also signifies The requiting with beneficence. (AA, TA in art. Hml.)

5 tzm~l * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and Aiz~am~ala, (Mgh, K,) the latter of the measure Aif~aE~ala, (K,) [a variation of the former,] and ↓ Aizodamala, (TA,) He wrapped himself (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) biviyaAbihi [with his garments], (S,) and so tzm~l alone, (TA,) or fiY viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh, TA,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Msb.)

6 tzAmlwA *
i. q. trAjzwA [i. e. They recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz, which is also termed zamal, one with another; or vied in doing so]. (TA.)
8 Aizodamala * : see 5. -A2- Aizodamalahu: see 1.
Q. Q. 1 zawomala * , (TK,) inf. n. zawomalapN, (K,) He drove camels. (K, TK.)

zimolN *
A load, or burden. (K.) It occurs in a trad. as meaning (assumed tropical:) A load of knowledge. (TA.) ― -b2- [Household-goods; or furniture and utensils. (Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) See also A^azomalN.] ― -b3- maA fiY juwaAliqika A_il~aA zimolN means There is not in thy sack save a half. (AA, K.) -A2- See also zamiylN. -A3- And see zum~alN.

zamalN * The kind of verse, or poetry, [more commonly] termed rajaz: [hence,] a poet says,
laA yugolabu Aln~aAziEu maA daAma Alz~amalo
[The drawer of water will not be overcome as long as the zml continues]; meaning, as long as he recites [or chants] the verse termed rajaz [or zamal], he is strong enough to work: thus it is related on the authority of AA: another reading is Alr~amalo: both are correct as to meaning. (IJ, TA.)
zamilN * and zumalN: see zum~alN.

zumolapN *
A company of persons travelling together, or with whom one is travelling; (AZ, K;) as also ↓ zawomalapN: (En-Nadr, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) a company or a collection [in an absolute sense]. (K, TA.)

zimolapN *
Luxuriant, or abundant, and dense [palmtrees such as are termed] jab~aAr: [Aljum~Ar in the CK is a mistranscription:] and a collection of wadiY~ [i. e. small young palm-trees, or shoots cut off from palm-trees and planted]: and young palm-trees exceeding the reach of the hand: (K, TA:) all on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.)
zamalapN * : see A^azomalN, in two places.

zimaAlN *
A limping in a camel. (K.) -A2- And A wrapper that is put over a raAwiyap [or leathern water-bag]: pl. zumulN and A^azomilapN: (Az, K:) you say valaAvapu A^azomilapK. (Az, TA.)

zamiylN *
One who rides behind another (IDrd, S, K) on a camel (IDrd, TA) that carries the food and the household-goods or furniture and utensils; (TA;) and ↓ zimolN signifies the same, (K,) and so does ↓ mazomuwlN: (IDrd, TA:) or one who rides behind another on a horse or similar beast: (TA:) or one who rides with another in a maHomil so as to counterbalance him. (Mgh.) It is metaphorically used in the saying, A^anota faArisu AlEilomi waA^anaA zamiyluka (tropical:) [Thou art the horseman of science, or knowledge, and I am he who rides behind thee]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, A travelling-companion (Mgh, TA) who assists one in the performance of his affairs. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yufaAriqu rajulN zamiylahu, i. e. [A man shall not separate himself from] his travelling-companion. (Mgh.) ― -b3- zamiylaAni means Two men engaged in work upon their two camels: when they are without work, they are called rafiyqaAni. (K.)
zumayolN * and zumayolapN: see zum~alN.
zimoyal~N * : see what next follows.

zum~alN * (S, K) and ↓ zumalN and ↓ zimolN [said in the CK to be like EidapN, but correctly like EidolN,] and ↓ zamilN and ↓ zumayolN (K) and ↓ zum~ayolN and ↓ zum~aAlN (S, K) and ↓ zimoyal~N and ↓ zumayolapN and ↓ zum~ayolapN (K, or this is fem., S) and ↓ zum~aAlapN (K) Cowardly, weak, (S, K, TA,) low, mean, or contemptible; who wraps himself up in his house, or tent; not rising and hastening to engage in warfare; indolently refraining from aspiring to great things. (TA.) [See also A_izomiylN. Accord. to J,] ↓ zum~ayolapN signifies Weak as a fem. epithet. (S.)
zum~aAlN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zum~ayolN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zum~aAlapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zum~ayolapN * : see zum~alN, in two places.

zaAmilN * , applied to a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) or to a wild ass, (A' Obeyd, TA,) That is as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness. (A' Obeyd, K, TA.) [Hence, app., the name of] The horse of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Mirdás Es-Sulamee. (K.) ― -b2- Also One who follows (↓ yazomulu, [in the CK yuzam~ilu,] i. e. yatobaEu,) another. (K.)

zaAmilapN *
A camel (S, Mgh, Msb, K) or other beast
(K) used for carrying (S, Mgh, Msb, K) the goods, or furniture and utensils, of a man (S, Mgh, Msb) travelling, (Mgh, Msb,) and his food; (S, Mgh;) the p denoting intensiveness: (Msb:) or a she-camel upon which are carried the goods, or furniture and utensils, of the traveller: (Har p. 130:) from zamala “ he bore, or carried, ” a thing: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. zawaAmilu. (TA.) [See also zawomalapN.] ― -b2- Afterwards used to signify The Eidol [properly half-load] in which is the pilgrim's travelling-provision, consisting of biscuit, or dry bread, and fruit (vmr [app. a mistranscription for tamor i. e. dates]), and the like. (Mgh.)

zawomalapN *
Camels having their loads upon them: (IAar, M, K: * [in the K, waAlEiyri should be waAlEiyru, or rather waAlA_ibilu:]) and so laTiymapN: EiyrN signifies “ camels laden or not laden: ” (IAar, M:) zawaAmilu may be either its pl. or pl. of zaAmilapN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also zumolapN. -A2- huwa A@bonu zawomalatihaA means He is a knower of it; (IAar, K;) i. e., of the affair. (IAar.) ― -b2- And Aibonu zawomalapa, also, means The son of the female slave. (IAar, K.)

A^azomalN *
A sound: (As, S:) or any mixed, or confused, sound: or a sound proceeding from the prepuce of a horse or similar beast: (K:) it has no verb. (TA.) A poet says,
taDib~u livaAtu Alxayoli fiY HajaraAtihaA
watasomaEu mino taHoti AlEajaAji lahaA A@zomalaA
[The gums of the horses water in the adjacent tracts thereof, and thou hearest, beneath the dust, a sound attributable to them]: he means A^azomalaA, but suppresses the ', as is done in wayolum~ihi [for wayolN liA^um~ihi]. (S.) A^azaAmiylu AlqisiY~ means The sounds of the bows: AazAmyl being pl. of A^azomalN, with Y to give fulness to the sound of the vowel preceding it. (TA.) And ↓ A^azomalapN signifies The twanging sound of a bow. (K, TA.) -A2- taraka A^azomalFA and ↓ A^azomalapF and ↓ zamalapF He left a family, or household. (K.) And xaraja fulaAnN waxal~afa A^azomalahu [Such a one went forth, and left behind him his family, or his family and his cattle]: and xaraja biA^azomalihi He went forth with his family and his camels and his sheep or goats, not leaving behind him aught of his property. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] A^axa*ahu biA^azomalihi [in one of my copies of the S, A^azomalahu,] He took it altogether; (S, K;) namely, a thing. (S.) And He took it with its A^avaAv [or utensils and furniture]; as also ↓ biA^azomulihi and ↓ A^azomalatihi (K) and ↓ zamalatihi. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And ↓ EiyaAlaAtN A^azomalapN i. e. Numerous [families or households]. (S, K. *)
A^azomulN * , whence A^axa*ahu biA^azomulihi: see the next preceding paragraph, last sentence but one.
A^azomalapN * : see A^azomalN, in four places.
A_izomawolN * : see A^uzomuwlapN.

A_izomiylN *
A shoemaker's knife (S, K, TA) with which he cuts the leather. (TA.) [In the TA, in art. *rb, it is expl. as meaning A shoemaker's A_i$ofaY with which he sews: but this I have not found elsewhere.] ― -b2- Also An iron (K, TA) like the new moon [in shape], (TA,) that is put at the end of a spear, for the purpose of catching wild oxen. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And The [implement called] miToraqap [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A great, or vehement, eater; likened to the [shoemaker's] knife: (TA:) or strong: and also weak; (K, TA;) low, mean, or contemptible: (TA: [like zum~alN:]) thus having two contr. significations. (K.)

A^uzomuwlapN * (AA, S, K) and (S, K) some say (S) A_izomawolapN, (S, K,) the latter accord. to As and Sb and Ez-Zubeydee, (TA,) and ↓ A_izomawolN, (S, TA,) which is said by IJ to be quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, because the w in it is not a letter of prolongation, for the letter before it is with fet-h, (TA,) applied to a mountain-goat and to one of other animals, Vociferous: (AA, S, K, TA:) or the first, [or, app, any of the three,] applied to a mountain-goat, such as, when he runs, leans, or bears, on one side: so accord. to AHeyth: Fr explains the first or second as applied to a horse, meaning that runs swiftly: and in like manner to a mountain-goat. (TA.)

muzam~alapN *
A certain thing in which water is cooled: of the dial. of El-'Irák: (K:) applied by the people of Baghdád to a green [jar such as is called] jar~ap or xaAbiyap, in the middle whereof is a perforation, in which is fixed a tube of silver or lead, whence one drinks; so called because it is wrapped (tuzam~alu i. e. tulaf~u) with a piece of cloth of coarse flax, or some other thing, between which and the jar is straw: it is in their houses in the days of summer: the water is cooled in the night by means of the [porous earthen bottles called] bar~aAdaAt; then it is poured into this mzm~lp, and remains in it cool. (Har p. 548.)
mazomuwlN * : see zamiylN.
muz~am~ilN * , originally mutazam~ilN, A man wrapped with [or in] his garments: occurring in the Kur lxxiii. 1. (TA.)
