Q. 1 zamolaqa * , inf. n. zamolaqapN, He did the act denoted by the epithet zumaliqN expl. in art. zlq voce zaliqN. (TA.) ― -b2- zamolaqapN in asses is like hamolajapN [i. e. The going an easy and a quick pace] in a horse. (TA.)

zumaliqN * and ↓ zum~aliqN and ↓ zumaAliqN are expl. in the S in art. zlq [q. v., voce zaliqN]: in the K, in the present art., agreeably with the opinion of Aboo- 'Obeyd. (TA.) [The first is said in the TA, voce vat~N, to be syn. with Ei*oyawoTN, q. v.] ― -b2- The first is also applied to an ass, as meaning Fat; whose back is even by reason of the fat. (Lh, TA.)

zumoluwqN * A boy, or young man, light, or active, upon whom his pursuer can hardly lay hold by reason of his lightness in his running, and his going this way and that, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully; as also ↓ zumaAliqN: thus expl. by Az, on the authority of one of the Arabs: also said to signify light, or active, and inconstant, unsteady, or fickle; and so ↓ zum~aliqN and ↓ zumaAliqN. (TA.)
zumaAliqN * : see zumaliqN: ― -b2- and see also zumoluwqN, in two places.
zum~aliqN * : see zumaliqN: ― -b2- and see also zumoluwqN.

1 zamina * . aor.
zamana , inf. n. zamanN (Msb, K) and zamaAnapN (S, * Msb, K) and zumonapN, (K,) He (a man, S, Msb) had, or was affected with, a malady of long continuance, (Msb,) or what is termed zamaAnapN, expl. below: (K:) he was, or became, afflicted [with what is so termed]: (S:) or he was, or became, crippled. (TK.)

3 EaAmalahu muzaAmanapF * (S, K) and zimaAnFA (Lh, TA) [He bargained, or made an engagement, with him, to work, for a time], (S, K,) from Alz~amanu. (S,) is like mu$aAharapF [and $ihaArFA] (S, K) from Al$~ahoru. (S.)

4 Azmn * [He, or it, continued a long time;] a long time passed over him, or it, (K, * TA,) i. e. a thing. (TA.) You say, Azmn biAlmakaAni He remained, staid, dwelt, or abode, a long time (zamaAnFA) in the place. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Azmn Ean~iY EaTaAw^uhu (tropical:) His gift [was a long time kept back from me, or] was slow, or tardy, in coming to me. (TA.) -A2- Azmn fulaAnFA He (God) made such a one to be such as is termed zamin, i. e. affected with a protracted disease; (Msb, TA;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: or made him to be affected with what is termed [zamaAnapN, expl. below, as meaning] EaAhapN [&c.]. (TA.) It is said also of a disease [as meaning It deprived him of the power to move &c.]. (TA in art. EDb.)

zamanN * an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- And a simple subst. [meaning Continuance for a long time,] from A^azomana in the first of the senses assigned to it above; and so ↓ zumonapN, with damm. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ zamaAnN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Msb,) A time, whether little or much; (S, Msb, K;) thus accord. to Er-Rághib; (TA in art. dhr;) as being a space capable of division: (Msb:) and so says El-Munáwee: (TA:) a time considered with respect to its beginning and its end: (Er-Rághib, MF voce A^amadN:) or i. q. EaSorN [as meaning a space, or period, of time]: (M, K:) [often meaning, without any addition to qualify it, a long time; as in an instance of the usage of the latter word above: (see 4:) what follows here applies to each of these words:] zamaAnN differs in some respects from A=nN and from A^amadN: Sh asserts it to be syn. with dahorN; but AHeyth says that this is a mistake: (TA:) [it is so, however, sometimes, accord. to several authorities, as has been shown in art. dhr; and particularly as meaning fortune, or fate:] IAth says that it is applied to the whole of what is termed Ald~ahoru [as meaning time], and to a
portion thereof: AHeyth says that it is the zmAn [i. e. season] of fruit, of ripe dates, and of heat and cold: and that it may be [a period of] two months [as meaning any one of the six seasons of the solar year] to six months [as meaning the half-year often termed summer and the half-year often termed winter]: (TA:) [thus] it is applied to any one of the four quarters of the year; (Msb, TA;) the first of which [in the order in which they are commonly mentioned by the Arabs, i. e. autumn,] is called by the Arabs [of the classical age] Alr~abiyEu, but vulgarly Alxariyfu; called by the former name because the first rain is therein, giving growth to [the herbage called] the rabiyE; and called by the latter name because the fruits are gathered therein; and it commences when the sun enters Libra: the second [i. e. winter] is called Al$~itaA='u; and commences when the sun enters Capricornus: the third [i. e. spring] is AlS~ayofu, vulgarly called Alr~abiyEu; and commences when the sun enters Aries: the fourth [i. e. summer] is AlqayoZu, vulgarly called AlS~ayofu; and commences when the sun enters Cancer: (Msb:) * * The two following tables exhibit the principal divisions of the Arabian Calendar. it is also applied to the time, or period, of the reign, rule, prefecture, or the like, of a man: [and to the life-time of a man:] with the philosophers, it signifies the measure of the motion of the ninth (or greatest) sphere (Alfalak AlA^aTolas): (TA:) [and there are various other explanations belonging to the conventional language of the schools, not to the proper language of the Arabs: (see the “ Dict. of the Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans: ”)] the pl. (of zamanN, Msb) is A^azomaAnN and A^azomunN and (that of zamaAnN, Msb) A^azominapN. (S, Msb, K.) [The dim. of zamanN, i. e. zumayonN, see below.] In the following trad., A_i*aA taqaAraba lamo takado ruw^yaA Almuw^omini tako*ibu ↓ Alz~amaAnu [When the time becomes contracted, the dream of the believer will scarcely ever, or never, be false], what is meant is the end of time; and the approach of the resurrection; because when a thing becomes little, its extremities contract: or what is meant is the day's and the night's becoming equal; for the interpreters of dreams assert that the times [of dreams] most true of interpretation are the season of the breaking forth of the blossoms and that of the ripening of the fruit, which is when the day and the night become equal: or what is meant is the coming forth of El-Mahdee, when the year will be like the month, and the month like the week, and the week like the day, and the day like the hour, deemed short because deemed delightful: (K in art. qrb:) or it alludes to the shortness of lives and the scantiness of blessings. (TA in that art.) In another trad. it is said, kaAnato taA^otiynaA A^azomaAna xadiyjapa, meaning [She used to come to us] in the life-time [lit. times] of Khadeejeh. (TA.) And one says also, maA laqiytuhu mu*o ↓ zamanapK, meaning ↓ m* zamaAnK [i. e. I have not met him for a long time past: but in this case, accord. to the more approved usage, one should say mu*o zamanapN and mu*o zamaAnN, or muno*u zamanapK and muno*u zamaAnK]. (Lh, K, * TA.) (For authorities, and further information, see the words here mentioned, and more particularly nawo'N and rabiyEN; under the latter of which it is said that the third and last of the Six Seasons are called by some, respectively, Alr~abiyEu Alv~aAniY and Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu; and also that the appellations of the 3rd and 4th months are differently pronounced by different persons; and that some exclude the wasomiY~ from the rains called Alr~abiyEu: and for the Calendar of the Mansions of the Moon, see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.) The months are said to have received the names here given to them from Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, an ancestor of Mohammad, about two centuries before El-Islám. These months were lunar; and from this period, with the view of adapting their year to the solar, the Arabs added a month, which they called Aln~asiYo'u, at the end of every three years, until they were forbidden to do so by the Kur-án (ch. ix.): but the months still retrograded through the seasons, though much more slowly. The abolition of the intercalation was proclaimed by Mohammad at the pilgrimage in the tenth year of the Flight.

zaminN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ zamiynN, (K, TA,) applied to a man, (S, Msb, TA,) Having, or affected with, a malady of long continuance; (Mgh, Msb, TA; *) as also ↓ muzomanN; (Har p. 182;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: (TA:) or having what is termed zamaAnapN [expl. below], i. e. EaAhapN: (K, TA:) or afflicted [with what is so termed]: (S:) pl. zaminuwna, (K, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and zamonaY, (Msb, K, TA,) [likewise] of the former, (Msb,) or of the latter, as also zamanapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa faAtiru Aln~a$aATi zaminu Alr~agobapi (tropical:) [He is remiss in respect of briskness or promptness, powerless in respect of desire]. (TA.)
zumonapN * : see zamanN, second sentence.

zamanapN *
A space, or period, or a long space or period, of time. (TA.) See also zamanN, last sentence.
zamaAnN * : see zamanN, third sentence, and again in two places in the latter part of the paragraph.
zamiynN * : see zaminN.

zumayonN * [dim. of zamanN]. You say, laqiytuhu *aAta Alz~umayoni, meaning thereby taraAxiY Alwaqoti; (S, K;) [i. e. I met him some time ago;] like as one says *aAta AlEuwayomi, meaning bayona AlA^aEowaAmi: (S:) or meaning fiY saAEapK lahaA A^aEodaAdN [in a time consisting of some, or several, subdivisions]: (TA:) or *aAta Alz~umayoni means mu*o valaAvapN A^azomaAnK [three seasons ago; or, app., three or more, to ten; (agreeably with an explanation of *aAta AlEuwayomi voce *uw;) by AzmAn being app. meant periods of two, or three, or six, months]; (T in art. *uw;) and the like is said by IAar. (TA in art. SbH.)

zamaAnapN * an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (S, * Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst.] it signifies also A disease, or an evil affection, syn. A=fapN, (S,) or EaAhapN, (K,) in animals: (S:) [and particularly, in a man, a disease of long continuance: or such as cripples, or deprives of the power to move or to stand or to walk: (see zamina and zaminN:)] or want of some one or more of the limbs, or members; and privation of the powers, or faculties. (Har p. 315.) And i. q. dahorN [app. as meaning An evil event or accident, a misfortune, or a calamity]. (KL.) ― -b3- Also Love. (K.)

[
saAEapN zamaAniy~apN *
A while; an indefinite short time; as distinguished from saAEapN falakiy~apN, which is an astronomical hour: and so, often, saAEapN alone.]
muzomanN * : see zaminN.

muzominN *
Of long continuance; of long standing; over which a long time has past. (TA.) [You say maA='N muzominN Stale water.] And suEaAlN muzominN [Chronic cough]. (K voce maSoTakaA.)
Q. 1 zamohara see the next paragraph.

Q. 4 Aizomahar~ato *
They (the stars) shone, (S, K,) and were intensely bright. (TA.) ― -b2- It (the eye) became red by reason of anger, (K,) on the occasion of some distressing event; (TA;) as also ↓ zamoharato. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b3- Azmhr~ It (the face) grinned, so as to display the teeth; or became contracted, with a stern, an austere, or a morose, look. (K.) ― -b4- It (a day) became intensely cold. (K.)

zamohariyrN *
Intense cold. (S, K.) Such is prepared by God as a punishment for the unbelievers in the latter state. (TA.) In the Kur lxxvi. 13, zamohariyrFA means Hurting cold: (Bd:) or [simply] cold: (Jel:) or, accord. to some, it there has the meaning next following. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- The moon; (K;) in the dial of Teiyi. (TA.)

muzomahir~N *
Laughing so as to show the teeth: (K:) from the likeness to the shining of stars. (TA.) ― -b2- Angry: (K:) or violently angry. (S.)

1 zanV3a see 4, in five places. -A2- zan~a EaSabuhu, [aor., accord. to rule,
zani3a , or the sec. pers. may be zaninota, and the aor.
zana3a , and the inf. n., in this case, rananN, which see below, but the TK makes its aor. to be
zanu3a , and the inf. n. zan~N,] His sinews dried up. (K.) ― -b2- zan~a fa*an~a means Hqn fqTr [which may be rendered He kept in, or retained, his urine, and then dribbled it, or his urine was kept in, or retained, and then dribbled]. (TA. [See zin~iynN.])

4 A^azonanotuhu *
I thought him to possess good or evil; as also ↓ zananotuhu, aor.
zanu3a , inf. n. zan~N: or both mean I imputed, or attributed, to him good or evil: (Msb:) or fulaAnFA bixayorK ↓ zan~a or bi$ar~K he thought such a one to possess good or evil; like A^azan~ahu; syn. Zan~ahu bihi: (K:) or, accord. to Lh, one says, A^azonanotuhu bimaAlK and bixayorK I thought him to possess [property and (as appears from what is said below on his authority) wealth]: but ↓ zananotuhu is what the vulgar say, and is wrong. (TA.) And A^azonanotuhu bi$aYo'K, (S,) or bika*aA, (K,) and also bk*A ↓ zananotuhu, (Har p. 112,) [and accord. to Golius ↓ Aizotananotuhu, mentioned by him as from the S, but not found therein by Freytag, nor by me in either of my copies,] I suspected him of a thing, or of such a thing: (S, K, and Har ubi suprà:) [but] Lh says, laA yakuwnu AlA_izonaAnu fiY Alxayori [app. meaning that A^azan~a is not said in relation to that which is good: see what is cited on his authority above]. (TA.) And Azn~hu biAlA^amori He suspected him of the thing, or affair; like A^aZan~ahu. (S.) And huwa yuzan~u bika*aA [He is suspected of such a thing]. (S.) Hassán says,
HaSaAnN razaAnN maA tuzan~u biriybapK
i. e. [Chaste, staid,] she is not suspected of evil: [in which tuzan~u may be from ↓ zun~ato or from A^uzin~ato:] but some restrict themselves to the quadriliteral verb [Azn~]. (Msb.)
8 A_izotana3a see 4.

zan~apN *
A suspicion: whence the saying, ↓ A^abuw zan~apK $ar~N minohu A^axuw zan~apK The ape, or baboon, or monkey, (Alqirodu,) worse than he is the person who has conceived a suspicion: (A, TA:) [for] ― -b2- A^abuw zan~apK, (so in three copies of the S and in my MS. copy of the K,) or ↓ Abw zin~apK, (thus in the CK and TK and JM, [in the second and third of which it is expressly said to be “ with kesr, ” which, however, the author of the K should have added, accord. to his usual practice, if he meant it to be thus,]) signifies Alqirodu. (S, K.)
A^abuw zin~apK * : see what next precedes, in two places.

maA='N zananN * , and miyaAhN zananN, [which suggests that zananN is an inf. n. used as an epithet,] A water, and waters, small in quantity, and narrow: (K:) [for] zananN signifies strait, or narrow; like zanaA='N and zaniY~N [which do not belong to this art.]: (TA:) or maA='N zananN means [a place of water] of which one knows not whether there be in it water or not. (K.)

Zil~N zanaAnN *
Short [or contracted] shade; like zanaA='N [mentioned in art. znA^]. (K.)

zunaAnaY *
A fluid like mucus, that falls from the noses of camels: (K:) but the more approved word is *unaAnaY. (TA.)
zanaAniY~N * A man who suffices for himself, without any other. (K.)
zan~aAnN * One who opines, or conjectures, much; i. q. Zan~aAnN. (TA.)
zin~iynN * One suppressing his urine and his ordure: occurring in a trad.: or, as some say, it is zib~iynN, [q. v.,] with b. (TA. [But see 1, and see also what here follows.])

A^azan~u * One suppressing his urine [or his ordure]; syn. HaAqinN: such is one of the persons forbidden, in a trad., to act as A_imaAm to others. (TA in art. nSr: mentioned also, but not expl., in the present art. in the TA.) [See also the next preceding paragraph.]

1 zanaA^a fiY Aljabali * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zanaAa , (Msb, K, *) inf. n. zano'N and zunuwo'N, (S, Msb, K,) He ascended the mountain. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- zanaA^a A_ilayohi, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. zunuwo'N (S, K) and zano'N, (K,) He (a man, S) had recourse to it (a thing, TA) for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging. (S, K.) ― -b3- And He approached it, or drew near to it; (K, TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.) [Hence,] zanaA^a Alxamosiyna, (S,) or liloxamosiyna, inf. n. zano'N, (TA,) He drew near to the [age of] fifty [years]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- zanaA^a said of the shade, (S, K,) It became short; (S;) it contracted, shrank, or drew together. (K.) ― -b5- Said of a place, (TA in art. znw,] It was, or became, strait, or narrow; and zanaA, without ', inf. n. zunuw~N, is a dial. var. thereof in this sense. (ISd, K, TA; all in art. znw.) ― -b6- Said of the urine, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
zanaAa , (S, TA,) or
zanuAa , (Msb,) inf. n. zunuwo'N (S, Msb, TA) and zano'N, (TA,) It became retained, or suppressed. (S, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b7- Also He, or it, clave to the ground. (K.) ― -b8- He hastened, or made haste. (K.) ― -b9- And He was, or became, affected with a lively emotion, either of joy or of grief; syn. Tariba. (K.) -A2- See also 2, in two places: and see 4. ― -b2- zanaA^a is also expl. in the K as signifying xanaqa [He throttled, or strangled]: but [SM says,] I have not found any of the leading lexicologists to have mentioned this, unless it be a mistranscription for Haqana [a meaning assigned to this verb below: see 4]. (TA.)

2 zan~A^ Ealayohi * , inf. n. tazoniy^apN, He straitened, or oppressed, him; made strait, or close, to him; (S, K, TA;) as also Elyh ↓ zanaA^a. (TA.) The verb occurs without ', written zan~aY, by poetic license, in a saying of a rájiz cited in art. $dx, as an ex. of the word $aAdixapN. (S.) And Ealayohi AlHijaArapa ↓ zanaw^uwA occurs in a trad. as meaning They made the stones strait, or close, to him, or upon him. (TA.)

4 AznA^hu fiY Aljabali *
He made him to ascend the mountain. (Msb, K, * TA.) ― -b2- AznA^hu also signifies A^alojaA^ahu: (S, K, TA:) so in the saying, AznA^hu A_ilaY AlA^amori [He constrained him to have recourse to, or to do, the thing]. (TA.) ― -b3- AznA^ bawolahu He retained, or suppressed, his urine; (Msb, K; *) as also ↓ zanaA^ahu; the latter verb being trans. as well as intrans. (Msb.)

zanaA='N *
Straitness, or narrowness; syn. DiyqN. (S. [So in my copies: perhaps a mistranscription for Day~iqN, a meaning mentioned in the next sentence.]) -A2- Strait, or narrow; syn. Day~iqN: you say makaAnN zanaA='N [A strait, or narrow, place]: and biy^orN zanaA='N [A narrow well]: so in the Fáïk. (TA.) ― -b2- Short (S, K) and compact, or contracted: (K:) applied to a man: and to shade. (S.) ― -b3- Retaining, or suppressing, his urine; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ zaAniy^N. (Msb.) So in a trad. in which it is said that a man is forbidden to pray when he is znA='; (S, TA;) or where it is said that the prayer of one who is ↓ zaAniy^ will not be accepted: (Msb:) or the latter word in this case means one who is ascending a mountain; because he has not full power [to pray], or because he is straitened by being out of breath. (TA.) -A3- Also, [app. because of its narrowness,] A grave. (TA.)

zaniYo'N *
A small skin for water or milk. (K.) [See also zaniY~N, in art. znw.]
zaAniy^N * : see zanaA='N, in two places.

A^azonaA^u *
More, or most, strait: so in the saying kaAna laA yuHib~u mina Ald~unoyaA A_il~aA A^azonaA^ahaA [He used not to love, of worldly enjoyments, or blessings, save the more, or most, strait thereof]. (MF.)

Q. 2 tazanobara EalayonaA *
He behaved proudly, or haughtily, to us, (K, * TA,) and frowned, or looked sternly, austerely, or morosely. (TA.)

Alz~anobaru *
The lion. (K.)

zunoburN *
Small, or young, (K, TA,) and light, or active: applied to a boy. (TA.) ― -b2- See also zunobuwrN.

zanobariY~N *
Large, or bulky; applied to a ship: (K:) you say safiynapN zanobariy~apN a large, or bulky, ship: (TA:) or zanobariy~apN signifies a sort of large, or bulky, ship. (S in art. zbr.) ― -b2- Also Heavy; applied to a man. (K.)
zinobaArN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

zunobuwrN * [The hornet, or hornets; a large sort of wasp;] a stinging kind of fly; (K;) a certain kind of flying thing that stings; (T, TA;) i. q. daborN, (S,) or dubuwrN; (TA;) and ↓ zunobuwrapN signifies the same, (K,) [or app. is the n. un.,] and so does ↓ zinobaArN; (S, K,) a dial. var. mentioned by ISk: (S:) [being a coll. gen. n.,] znbwr is [sometimes] made of the fem. gender: the pl. is zanaAbiyru: (S:) and Alz~anaAbiyru sometimes means the flies of the meadows or gardens (*ubaAbu Alr~awoDi). (Ham p. 324.) ― -b2- Also A young ass that is able to bear burdens. (K.) ― -b3- And A large rat: pl. zanaAbiru, occurring in poetry [app. for zanaAbiyru]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, [as an epithet,] Light, or active; clever, or ingenious; (K, TA;) mentioned by Abu-l-Jarráh, from a man of the Benoo-Kiláb, and he adds that it means light, or active; (TA;) quick in reply; (K, TA;) and so ↓ zunoburN. (K.) -A2- Also, and ↓ zinbiyrN and ↓ zinobaArN, A certain tree, (K, TA,) of large size, (TA,) resembling the dulob [or plane-tree], (K, TA,) but not wide, the leaves of which are like those of the nut-tree in appearance and scent, having blossoms like those of the Eu$ar [q. v.], white tinged [with another colour], and having a fruit exactly like the olive, which, when fully ripe, becomes intensely black and very sweet, and is eaten by men like ripe dates, has a stone like that of the gubayoraA=' [or fruit of the service-tree], and dyes the mouth like as does the mulberry: it is planted. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the same three words, A species of the tiyn [or fig], called by the people of the towns and villages the tiyn HulowaAniY~; (IAar, K, TA;) one of the strange trees of the desert: pl. zanaAbiyru. (IAar, TA.)
zinobiyrN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zunobuwrapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
A^axa*ahu bizanawobarihi * is like A^axa*ahu bizawobarihi, (K, TA,) meaning He took it altogether; mentioned in art. zbr. (TA.)

A^aroDN mazobarapN *
A land abounding with zanaAbiyr [or hornets, pl. of zunobuwrN; the n being rejected in its formation]: (S in art. zbr, and K:) similar to A^aroDN maEoqarapN and mavoEalapN, meaning *aAtu EaqaAriba and vaEaAliba. (S.)

zanobaqN * [mentioned in the S and Msb in art. zbq] Oil of jasmine: (S, K:) or this is called duhonu Alz~anobaqi, and is of the dial. of El-'Irák; (Az, TA;) [for] it is said that zanobaqN signifies the jasmine [itself]: (Msb:) or, as some say, it is a certain flower, which is put into $ayoraj [i.e. oil of sesame, or, as being likened thereto, because of its clearness, white oil before it becomes altered], and the like, and of which is [thus] made an [odoriferous] oil; like as is done with other species of flowers. (MF.) [In the present day, this name is applied to several species of plants: namely, Mogorium sambac of Juss., Lam., Desfont.: ― -b2- Nyctanthes sambac of Linn.; nyctanthes undulata in notis Amœn. academ. 4, p. 449: (Delile, Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 8:) ― -b3- and Iris germanica of Linn.; or Iris sambac of Forsk.: (Idem, no. 26:) ― -b4- also the lily.] ― -b5- Also The [musical reed, or pipe, called] zam~aArap, (AA, T, TA,) or mizomaAr. (Aboo-Málik, K.) ― -b6- A^um~u zanobaqK Wine: (IAar, K, and T in art. Am:) or wine such as is termed fayohajN and qinodiydN. (IAmb, TA in art. fhj.)

zanobaAqN *
A certain herb, or leguminous plant, hot, burning, or biting, to the tongue, and that causes headache. (K.)
zinobiylN * and zanobiylN dial. vars. of zabiylN, mentioned in art. zbl [q. v.]: pl. zanaAbiylu. TA.)

Alz~anoju * and Alz~inoju, (AA, S, Msb, K,) the latter being a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) both of them chaste, (TA,) [but the latter is the more common,] and ↓ Alz~unuwju (S, K) and ↓ Almazonajapu, (K,) A certain nation of the blacks; (S, Msb, K;) [the inhabitants of the country called by us “ Zanguebar, ” including the “ Zingis ” of Ptolemy, near the entrance of the Red Sea, and a large portion of inner Africa:] their country is beneath, and to the south of, the equinoctial line; and beyond them is [said to be] no habitation, or cultivation: [sometimes applied to the Negroes absolutely; for] some say that their country extends from the western parts of Africa nearly to Abyssinia, [comprehending the whole of Nigritia properly so called, or at least the whole of the countries of the Negroes known to the Arabs of the classical ages,] and that part of it is on the Nile of Egypt: (Msb:) the n. un. is ↓ zanojiY~N and zinojiY~N, (AA, A'Obeyd, ISk, S, K,) like as ruwmiY~N is of ruwmN: (TA:) and ↓ A^azonujN occurs as a broken pl., meaning the divisions and subtribes [of that nation]: so says AAF, and so in the M. (TA.)
zanojiY~N * and zinojiY~N [of which the latter is the more common, A man, and a thing, of, or belonging to, or relating to, the zanoj or zinoj]: see the preceding paragraph.
Alz~unuwju * : see the first paragraph.
A^azonujN * : see the first paragraph.
Almazonajapu * : see the first paragraph.

zanojabiylN * [Ginger; amomum zinziber;] a certain plant growing in the country of the Arabs, in the land of 'Omán, (AHn, TA,) and in El-Yemen also; (TA;) well known: (S:) [or the root thereof;] a certain root, or roots, (accord. to different copies of the K,) creeping beneath the ground; (K, TA;) burning, or biting, to the tongue; (TA;) growing like the stalks of the papyrus, (K, TA,) and the raAsan [mentioned below]: there is no wild sort of it; nor is it a tree that is eaten fresh like as herbs, or leguminous plants, are eaten; but it is used in a dry state; and its conserve is the best of conserves; and the best thereof is what is brought from the country of the Zinj and China: (TA:) it has a property that is heating, or warming, digestive, lenitive in a small degree, strengthening to the venereal faculty, (K, TA,) clearing to the phlegm, (TA,) sharpening to the intellect, (K * TA,) and exhilarating: (TA:) if mixed with the moisture of the liver of the goat, and dried, and pulverized, and used as a collyrium, it removes the film [upon the eye], and obscurity of the sight. (K, TA.) ― -b2- It is mentioned in the Kur, where it is said, [lxxvi. 17 and 18,] kaAna mizaAjuhaA zanojabiylFA EayonFA fiyhaA tusam~aY salosabiylFA [The admixture whereof shall be znjbyl, a fountain therein named Selsebeel]: i. e. it shall have the flavour of znjbyl [or ginger], which the Arabs esteem very pleasant: it may mean that znjbyl is [essentially] in the wine of Paradise: or that it is the admixture thereof: or that it is a name for the fountain whence this wine is taken, and which is named Selsebeel also. (Az, O, TA.) As some assert, (ISd, TA,) it means also Wine [absolutely]. (S, ISd, K.) ― -b3- zanojabiylu AlkilaAbi A certain herb, or leguminous plant, the leaves of which are like [those of] the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia], and the twigs are red: it clears the [discoloration of the face termed] kalaf, and the [spots in the skin termed] nama$; and it kills dogs; (K;) wherefore it is named in relation to them. (TA.) ― -b4- zanojabiylu AlEajami i. q. AlA^u$oturogaAzu [a word of Persian origin, now applied by Arabs to A species of carline thistle]. (K.) [Accord. to Freytag, Horminum, or salvia silvestris: but this, I believe, is what is called in Pers. A^u$oturogaAn.] ― -b5- zanojabiylu Al$~aAmi i. q. Alr~aAsanu [Inula helenium, common inula, or elecampane]. (K.)

Q. 1 zanojara * , (Lth, K,) inf. n. zanojarapN, (S in art. zjr,) He [fillipped, or] struck the thumb upon, or against, the middle finger with the fore finger: (S in art. zjr:) or he fillipped with the nail of his thumb and that of his fore finger: (Lth, A, K: *) you say zanojara lahu, meaning he put the nail of his thumb upon that of his fore finger, and then fillipped with them to him, (Lth, A, *) saying walaA mivola h`*aA [Nor, or not even, the like of this will I give thee]; (Lth;) meaning thus, walaA A^uEoTiyka mivola h`*aA. (A.) The subst., (S,) or the name of this [action], (Lth,) is ↓ zinojiyrN. (Lth, S.)

zinojiyrN * [A fillip, such as is described above]: see what immediately precedes. ― -b2- A nail-paring: as also zinoqiyrN: both foreign words introduced into the Arabic language: mentioned in the T among quadriliteral-radical words. (TA.) ― -b3- A
whiteness [or white speck] seen on the nails of young persons; (AZ, K;) likewise called fuwfN and wabo$N; (AZ, TA;) as also ↓ zinojiyrapN. (AZ, K.) ― -b4- Accord. to IAar, ↓ this last signifies What the end of the thumb [or of the thumb-nail] takes from the extremity of the tooth when a man [presses the former against the edge of an upper front tooth and suddenly lets it go forward, and] says, maA laka EinodiY $aYo'N walaA *iho I have not anything for thee: not even this: (TA:) [i. e. it means anything; always used in a negative phrase.]
zinojiyrapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

zunojuforN *
A certain dye, [or pigment,] well known, (K,) of a red colour, with which one writes as well as dyes; [namely, cinnabar:] its virtue is similar to that of white lead; or, as some say, of $aAdanoj [a kind of stone, used medicinally, from the Persian $aAdonaho]: it is of two kinds, native and factitious: the native is [formed by] the transition of a sulphureous substance into quicksilver: [it is a sulphureous ore of quicksilver:] the factitious [is what is called vermilion, and] is of various sorts. (TA.)

1 zanixa * , aor.
zanaxa (S, K,) inf. n. zanaxN, (S,) said of oil, (S K,) and clarified butter, (JK, L,) and food, (L,) It was, or became, altered [for the worse] (S, K, TA) in odour; (TA;) [stinking, rancid,] bad, or corrupt; like sanixa. (JK.) ― -b2- And, said of a lamb, or kid, He raised his head in sucking, by reason of choking, or of dryness of the fauces. (K.)

zanixN * , applied to oil, (S, K,) and clarified butter, and food, (L,) Altered [for the worse] (S, K, TA) in odour; (TA;) [stinking, rancid, bad, or corrupt; like sanixN: see 1.] ― -b2- A_ibilN zanixapN Camels having their bellies straitened, by reason of thirsting (Kr, K, TA) time after time. (Kr, TA.)

1 zanada Aln~aAra * , aor.
zanida , He produced fire [with a zanod and zanodap]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zanaduwA naAra AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) [They kindled the fire of war]. (A, TA.) -A2- See also 2. -A3- zanida, aor.
zanada , (K,) inf. n. zanadN, (TK,) He (a man, TA) thirsted. (K.) -A4- zanidato, inf. n. zanadN, said of a she-camel, Her womb came forth on her giving birth. (L.)

2 zn~d * , inf. n. tazoniydN, He made his zanod to produce fire. (K.) -A2- He lied. (K.) -A3- He filled (K, TA) a water-skin, or milk-skin; (TA;) as also ↓ zanada, (K, TA,) inf. n. zanodN; and in like manner a watering-trough, and a vessel: and he filled his water-skin, or milk-skin, so that it became like the zanod, i. e. [hard, or firm, being] full. (TA.) ― -b2- [He made, or rendered, narrow. You say,] lilofarasi manoxirN lamo yuzan~ado The horse has a nostril which was not made narrow when he was created. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [He straitened, or scanted; made strait, or scanty: see the pass. part. n. Hence, app.,] zn~d EalaY A^aholihi [He straitened, or scanted, his family; made their circumstances, or subsistence, strait, or scanty, to them;] he was hard, severe, or rigorous, to his family. (L.) ― -b4- He punished beyond his right. (K, TA.) ― -b5- He charged with niggardliness: (TA:) or he, or it, made, or rendered, niggardly, mean, or sordid. (KL.) ― -b6- zun~idati Aln~aAqapu, inf. n. tazoniydN, The she-camel, having a [tumour of the kind called] qaron in her vulva, had her vulva perforated on every side, and leathern thongs inserted in the holes and tied tight: (ISh, TA:) or tazoniydN [as inf. n. of zun~idato] signifies a she-camel's having the vulva perforated with small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, and then tied with [threads or strings of] hair: this is done when her womb comes forth after her having given birth; (S, K;) on the authority of IDrd, with n and Y. (S.) -A4- See also the next paragraph.

4 Aznd * , (K,) said of a man, (TA,) i. q. zaAda [He exceeded, &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] maA yuzoniduka A^aHadN Ealayohi, as also ↓ mA yuzan~iduka, i. q. maA yaziyduka [meaning No one is more sufficient for thee than he: see art. zyd]: (K:) or no one exceeds him to thee in excellence. (TA.) -A2- Aznd fiY wajaEihi i. q. rajaEa [i. e. He relapsed in his pain.] (K.)

5 tzn~d *
He was, or became, straitened, or embarrassed, and contracted in his bosom: (A:) he was, or became, straitened, or embarrassed, so as to be unable to reply, or to answer: and he was angry; (A, K;) and was incensed. (TA.) The saying of 'Adee,
A_i*aA A^anota faAkahota Alr~ijaAla falaA talago
waqulo mivola maA qaAluwA walaA tatazan~adi
[When thou jestest with men, be not altogether foolish, but say like as they have said, and be not straitened, &c.,] some relate with Y [in the last word, saying tatazay~adi: see art. zyd]. (TA.)

zanodN * [A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire;;] the upper one of the two pieces of stick, or wood, (EuwdaAni, S, M, L, K, or xa$abataAni, L,) with which fire is produced [in a manner described below]; (S, M, L, K;) of the masc. gender; (Msb;) [or masc. and fem.: (see miyqaAdN, in art. wqd:)] and ↓ zanodapN is the appellation of the lower one thereof, (S, M, L, K,) in which is the notch, or hollow, (furoDap, M, L, or faroD, A in art. frD,) or in which is a hole (vaqob, S), [whence the fire is produced;] and this is fem.: (S, M:) one end of the zanod is put into the faroD of the zanodap, and the zanod is then [rapidly] twirled round, in producing fire: (A in art. frD:) [the best kind of zanod is made of EafaAr; and the best kind of ↓ zanodap, of marox: (see these two words:)] the dual zanodaAni is applied to the two together; (S, M, L;) [and so, very often, is the sing. zanodN:] one should not say zanodataAni; (S, M, L, K;) for it is a well-known rule that predominance is to be attributed to the masc.: (MF:) the pl. [of mult.] is ↓ zinaAdN, (S, M, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) which is also syn. with zanodN, (Kr, L,) and zunuwdN (L) and [of pauc.] A^azonudN and A^azonaAdN, (S, M, L, K,) the last anomalous [accord. to general opinion because the medial radical is not an infirm letter]; (TA;) and pl. pl. A^azaAnidu. (L.) Hence one says, A_in~ahu lawaAriY Alz~anodi, (TA,) or waAriY Alz~inaAdi, (A,) (tropical:) [lit. He is one whose zanod produces fire, or whose zinaAd produce fire,] alluding to generosity and other commended qualities [of the person to whom it is applied]. (TA.) And warato bika zinaAdiY (tropical:) [lit. My znAd have, or has, produced fire by thy means], (S, A, K,) said by thee to one who has aided, or assisted, thee. (S, K.) And A^anaA muqotadiHN bizanodika wakul~u xayorK EinodiY mino Einodika (tropical:) [lit. I am one who produces fire by means of thy znd, and all the good in my possession is from thee]. (A.) [Hence also,] laA yarud~u bukaAYa zanodFA (assumed tropical:) [My weeping will not bring as a return for it so much as a znd; i. e. it will not avail aught]. (Ham p. 83.) And zanodaAni fiY muraq~aEapK: see art. rqE. And zanodaAni fiY wiEaA='K (assumed tropical:) [Two pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire, in a bag or the like]: a prov. denoting lowness, ignobleness, meanness, or weakness; and applied to two weak persons together. (Meyd.) And layosa fiY jafiyrihi gayoru zanodayoni: see art. jfr. ― -b2- Hence, (A,) (tropical:) Each of the two bones of the fore arm; [the radius and the ulna;] (A, Mgh, L;) one of which is more slender than the other: the extremity of the znd next the thumb is called kuwEN, and that of the znd next the little finger is called kurosuwEN: the rusog [or wrist] is the place of junction of the zanodaAni, and the part where the hand of the thief is cut off: (L:) in this sense masc.; but improperly made fem.: (Mgh:) the two bones above mentioned are called the zanodaAni as being likened to the zndAn with which fire is produced. (A, Mgh. *) And in some one or more of the dialects, AlA^aEolaY mino Alz~anodayoni is The saAEid [q. v.]; and AlA^asofalu mina Alz~anodayni, the *iraAE [q. v.]. (L and TA in art. sEd.) [Also] The part of the fore arm which is divested of flesh: of the masc. gender: pl. zunuwdN. (Msb.) And (L) The part where the extremity of the fore arm joins to the hand [on the side of the thumb and also on the side of the little finger, as is shown by what follows]: there are two parts called together zanodaAni; (S, L, K;) the kuwE and the kurosuwE. (S, L.) -A2- Also A certain thorny tree. (K.)

zanadN *
A durojap (K, TA) consisting of a stone wrapped up in pieces of rag (TA) which is stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, when she is made to take a liking to the young one of another: (K:) it has a string attached to it; and when it distresses her, they pull it out, and she imagines that she has brought forth a young one: so say AO and others. (TA.)
zanodapN * : see zanodN, in two places.
zinaAdN * : see zanodN; of which it is a pl., and with which it is also syn. [In the present day it is commonly applied to A steel for striking fire: and has for its pl. A^azonidapN.]

muzan~adN * [Made, or rendered, narrow]. You say vawobN muzan~adN A garment, or piece of cloth, of little width. (S, K.) And mazaAdapN muzan~adapN [A leathern water-bag] narrow, but long; [such that] when thou seest that there is somewhat in it, [thou lookest again, and] lo, there is nothing in it. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A small, scanty, gift. (A, TA. *) ― -b3- Narrow; (S, K;) niggardly; (S, A, K;) tenacious; (TA;) who will not confer a small benefit: (A:) low, ignoble, mean, or sordid: (TA:) charged with niggardliness, and held to be little: (Ham p. 178:) and i. q. daEiY~N [i. e. one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; &c.]. (K.) And A man quick in becoming angry. (L.)

Q. 2 tazanodaqa * [He adopted, or held, or professed, the tenets of the zinodiyq;] he was, or became, a zinodiyq: (S, * K, * TA:) [generally,] he was, or became, a muloHid [i. e. deviater from the right religion, or an impugner of religions], and without religion; (KL;) [a disbeliever in the world to come and in the Deity, or the unity of the Creator: (see zanodaqapN:) and an asserter of the endlessness of time: see zinodiyqN.]

zanodaqN * , (Th, O, L, K, [in some of the copies of the K, and in my copy of the Msb, zinodiyqN, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,]) and ↓ zanodaqiY~N, A man very niggardly or avaricious. (Th, O, L, K, Msb.)

zanodaqapN * a subst from the verb above mentioned; (S, K;) [The adoption, or belief, or profession, of the tenets of the zinodiyq: generally, deviation from the right religion, or the impugning of religious, and the state of him who is without religion;] disbelief in the world to come and in [the Deity, or] the unity of the Creator: (T, Mgh, Msb:) [and the assertion of the endlessness of time: see zinodiyqN.] ― -b2- Also i. q. DiyqN [as meaning Niggardliness, or avarice: see zanodaqN]. (L, TA.)
zanodaqiY~N * : see zanodaqN.
zunoduwqN * a dial. var. of SunoduwqN [q. v.]; (K;) like as qazodN is of qaSodN. (TA.)

zinodiyqN *
One who is of the vanawiy~ap [or asserters of the doctrine of Dualism]: (S, O, K:) or one who asserts his belief in [the two principles of] Light and Darkness: or one who does not believe in the world to come, nor in the Deity: (O, K:) or one who does not believe in the world to come nor in the unity of the Creator: (T, Msb:) or one who conceals unbelief and makes an outward show of belief: (K:) an arabicized word, (S, Msb,) originally Pers., so they say, (Msb,) from Alz~anodu, which is a book belonging to them [i. e. the book of Zoroaster]: (PS:) [or from the Pers. zanodiyk, meaning magian, or fire-worshipper: and this seems to be its primary meaning; as De Sacy says in his “ Chrest. Ar., ” 2nd ed., ii. 274:] or, accord. to IDrd, it is an arabicized word from the Persian zinodah, (Mgh, [thus in my copy, app. for zanodaho, in which the h may be, as it is in many other instances, an affix denoting some kind of relationship,]) or zanoda kiro, (TA, as from the L, [but not very clearly written, and with an erasure, such as to suggest that the original and right reading may be zanodo Giyro, which may be rendered holder of the Zend, but]) which is expl. as meaning he [who] asserts his belief in the eternity, or the endlessness, of the present world: (Mgh, TA:) or it is arabicized from zano diyn i. e. woman's religion: (O, K:) or the right explanation is this: that it is a term of relation to the zanod, which is the book of Mánee the Magian, who was in the time of Bahrám the son of Hurmuz the son of Sáboor [or Shápoor], and who claimed to be successor to the Messiah, on whom be peace; and, desiring fame, composed this book, which he hid in a tree, and then took forth: Alz~anodu, in their language, is “ explanation; ” and he meant that this was the explanation of the book of Zará- dusht [or Zoroaster] the Persian; and in it he held that there are two gods, Light and Darkness, Light creating good, and Darkness creating evil: (TA:) or, accord. to the “ Mefáteeh el-'Uloom, ” zinodiyqN means a follower of Mánee, and also a follower of Mezdek, who (i. e. Mezdek) appeared in the days of Kubádh, and asserted that possessions and women were in common, and put forth a book which he called znd, which is the book of the Magians, that was brought by Zará- dusht, whom they assert to have been a prophet: and the companions of Mezdek were named in relation to [this] znd; which word, being arabicized, was converted into zinodiyqN: (Mgh:) Th says that zinodiyqN is not of the [genuine] language of the Arabs; (Mgh, TA;) and when the Arabs desire to express the meaning in which it is commonly used, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) which is one who does not hold any religion, and who asserts his belief in the endlessness of time, (Msb,) they say muloHidN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. [a deviater from the right religion, or] an impugner of religions, (Msb,) and dahoriY~N: (Mgh, TA:) some say that it is from Alz~anodaqapu; because the zndyq straitens himself: (L, TA:) an Arab of the desert is related to have explained it as meaning one who looks much into things, or affairs: (Msb:) the pl. is zanaAdiqapN and zanaAdiyqu; (S, O, Msb, K;) the latter being the original pl., and the p of the former being a substitute for the suppressed Y of the latter. (S, O.)

1 zanarahu *
He filled it; (K;) namely, a vessel, and a water-skin. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

2 zn~rhu * ; (Msb;) or ↓ zanarahu, (K,) inf. n. zanorN; (TA;) [but the former is more probably correct, as tzn~r, mentioned below, is its quasi-pass.; or perhaps each is correct;] He put upon him a zun~aAr [or waist-belt]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- zn~r Eayonahu A_ilaY~a (assumed tropical:) He looked hard at me: so in the “ Nawádir: ” (TA: [see also the act. part. n., below:]) or zn~r A_ilaY~a biEayonihi (tropical:) [he looked minutely at me]: and zan~arato Eayonuhu (tropical:) his eye looked minutely. (A.)

5 tz~nr *
He (a Christian [or Jew or Sabian or Magian]) bound a zun~aAr [or waist-belt] upon his waist. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a thing) became slender, or narrow, (A, K,) so as to be like a zun~aAr. (A.)

zun~aAr * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ zun~aArapN (A, K) and ↓ zun~ayorN (K) The thing [meaning waist-belt] that is upon the waist of the Christian (S, * A, * Msb, *K) and Magian; (K;) the thing which the *im~iY~ [or free non-Muslim subject of a Muslim government, who pays a poll-tax for his freedom and toleration, i. e., Christian, Jew, or Sabian,] binds upon his waist: (T, TA:) [accord. to the K, from tazan~ara “ it became slender, or narrow: ” but the reverse is implied in the A: see 5: and it is more probably derived from the Greek ζωνάρη, as observed by Golius, or ζωνάριον, as suggested by Freytag:] pl. zanaAniyru. (A, Msb.) -A2- See also zin~iyrN.
zun~ayorN * : see zun~aArN.

zin~iyrN * , (T, TA,) or ↓ zin~iyrapN, as also ↓ zun~aArapN, (TA,) sing. of zanaAniyru, (T, TA,) which signifies Pebbles: (IAar:) or small pebbles. (A'Obeyd, Kr, ISd, K.) ― -b2- Also zin~iyrN and ↓ zun~aArN (Kr,) or ↓ zin~iyrapN and ↓ zun~aArapN, (TA,) Certain small flies (Kr, K) that are in Hu$uw$ [i. e. gardens, or privies]. (Kr, TA.)
zun~aArapN * : see zun~aArN: -A2- and see zin~iyrN, in two places.
zin~iyrapN * : see zin~iyrN, in two places.
muzan~arapN * A woman tall, and large in body. (K, TA.)
fulaAnN muzan~irN A_ilaYa biEayonihi * (assumed tropical:) Such a one is looking hard at me, and making the eye to project: so in the “ Nawadir. ” (T, TA. [See also the verb, 2.])

1 zanaqahu * , (JK, S, O, K,) namely, a mule, (JK, O,) or a horse, (S, K,) aor.
zaniqa , (O, TA,) inf. n. zanoqN, (JK, TA,) He put a ring in the thin skin beneath the part under his lower jaw, and then attached to it a cord: (JK, O, K:) this ring is put to the head of the refractory mule; and is called ↓ zinaAqapN: (JK, O, TA:) or he put a ↓ zinaAq in the part under his lower jaw, in the skin: (S, O:) every cord with which a beast is tied, [attached to a ring or otherwise] in the skin beneath the part under the lower jaw, is called ↓ zinaAqN [or ↓ zinaAqapN]: (O, TA:) in the K, zunaAqN, like guraAbN; but this is wrong: (TA:) what is in the nose, pierced, is called EiraAnN. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (IDrd, K,) aor.
zaniqa and
zanuqa , (TA,) inf. n. as above, (KL,) He bound his legs by means of the $ikaAl [or zinaAq, q. v.]; namely, a mule's; (IDrd, K;) and in like manner, a horse'. (TA.) [This meaning alone I find in the KL, given on the authority of the Mj: but Golius says, as on the authority of the KL likewise, that it signifies also He fitted a shoe to a horse's foot; followed by an accus.] ― -b3- And zanaqa, (IAar, O,) or zanaqa EalaY EiyaAlihi, aor.
zaniqa ; (K;) and ↓ Aznq; and ↓ zn~q, (IAar, O, K,) inf. n. tazoniyqN; (IAar, O;) (assumed tropical:) He straitened his household,
by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (IAar, O, K.) And zanaqotu EalaY fulaAnK, and ↓ A^azonaqotu, I straitened such a one. (JK.)
2 zan~aqa see above, last sentence but one.
4 A^azonaqa see 1, last two sentences.
zanaqN * The place of the zinaAqN [or zinaAqap]. (S, K.) ― -b2- The thin part of an arrow-head: pl. zunuwqN. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, K.)
zunuqN * : see zaniyqN.

zanaqapN *
A narrow sik~ap [or street]. (S.) ― -b2- A narrow part of a valley. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O.) ― -b3- A bend in a wall; or in a sik~ap [or street]; (Lth, JK, O;) or in a side of a house; or in a narrow, or very narrow, road of a valley, [so I render fiY Euroquwbi waAdK, (see EuroquwbN,)] in which is what resembles a place of entrance and a twisting or winding: a subst. in all these senses, having no verb. (Lth, O.)

zinaAqN * : see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. $ikaAlN [i. e. Hobbles for a horse or the like, having a rope extending from the shackles of the fore feet to those of the hind feet]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The kind of ornament called mixonaqapN [i. e. a necklace, or the like]; (S, O, K; [in this sense correctly said in the K to be like kitaAbN;]) a certain ornament for women, (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O,) of silver. (Ibn-' Abbád, O.)

zaniyqN * [in its primary acceptation is app. syn. with mazonuwqN in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below: ― -b2- and hence,] (tropical:) Firm, strong, or sound; (JK, O, K, TA;) applied to judgment, or an opinion, (JK, O, TA,) and an affair, and management, or exercise of forecast or forethought. (TA.) And ↓ zunuqN [which is app. its pl., or EuquwlN zunuqN,] (assumed tropical:) Perfect understandings or intellects. (IAar, O, K.)
zinaAqapN * : see 1, in two places.

mazonuwqN *
Tied, or bound, with the zinaAq [q. v., or with the zinaAqap]. (TA. [See also zaniyqN.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Suffering a suppression of the urine. (TA.) ― -b3- Almazonuwqu is the name of A horse of ' Ámir Ibn-Et- Tufeyl: (S, K:) and of a horse of ' Attáb Ibn-El-Warkà. (TA.)

2 tazoniymN * [inf. n. of zn~m] The cutting a small portion of the ear of a camel or other animal, and leaving it hanging thereto. (KL. [See zanamapN.]) ― -b2- [And hence,] The act of marking with a sign or token. (KL. [See also the same word as a subst. properly so termed, expl. below.]) ― -b3- And The conjoining any one with a people, or party, to which he does not belong. (KL.) ― -b4- zan~amuwA A_ilaY~a h`*aA AlxaSomu, (inf. n. tazoniymN, TA,) They sent to me this adversary in order that he might contend in an altercation, dispute, or litigate, with me. (K.)

4 Aznm Al$~ajaru * (tropical:) The tress had a ↓ zanamap (K, TA) [i. e. an excrescence] resembling the zanamap of the $aAp [app. here meaning sheep as well as goat; though sheep are said in the S, and in one place in the TA, to have no zanamap]. (TA.)
zanamN * The [projecting] thing that is behind the cloven hoof; also called zalamN; (S, K;) of which it is a dial. var. (S.)

zanimN * A camel having a ↓ zanamap, i. e. a thing [or portion] of the ear cut (S, K) and left hanging down [therefrom], (S,) which is done to camels of generous race (S, K) only; (S;) as also ↓ A^azonamu and ↓ muzan~amN: fem. zanimapN and ↓ zanomaA='u and ↓ muzan~amapN: (S, K:) pl. of pauc. A^azonumu and zanimaAtN. (Yákoot, TA.) [See also A^azolamu.] ― -b2- DaAy^inapN zanimapN (assumed tropical:) A ewe that is held in high estimation; [not signifying having a zanamap, as meaning “ having a kind of wattle; ”] for [it is asserted that] the sheep has no zanamap; that pertaining only to the goat. (S. [But see zanamapN.])

huwa AlEabodu zanomapF * and ↓ zunomapF and ↓ zanamapF and ↓ zunamapF (S, K) i. q. zalomapF &c., (K,) He is one whose proportion, or conformation, is that of the slave: or, as Ks says, (or Lh, TA,) the meaning is, truly. (S.) [See also zalomap.] ― -b2- zanomataA Alfuwqi: see zanamapN.

zunomap * : see what next precedes. -A2- zunomapN also signifies A certain tree, having no leaves, as though it were the zanamap of the $aAp [app. here meaning sheep as well as goat: see zanamapN]. (TA.)

zanamapN * of the ear of a camel: see zanimN: but accord. to El-Ahmar, it is a mark made by cutting off a portion of the ear. (TA.) ― -b2- [Of the ear of a man, it is app. The antitragus and also a small prominence of the antihelix immediately above the antitragus: for it is said that] zanamataA AlA^u*uni signifies two small things (hanataAni) next to the $aHumap [or lobule], opposite to the watarap [an evident mistranscription for watidap i. e. tragus]. (K. [So in all the copies that I have seen.]) ― -b3- Also [A kind of wattle, i. e.] a thing, (Msb,) or piece of flesh, (TA,) hanging from the Haloq [here meaning throat, externally], (Msb, TA,) beneath each ear, (S and A and K in art. rEv,] of the $aAp [i. e., app., sheep as well as goat; though it is said in the S that “ the sheep has no zanamap; that pertaining only to the goat; ” app. because it is uncommon in sheep]. (TA.) [See also zalamapN; and see raEivato and raEovapN and raEovaA='u.] ― -b4- To this is likened the zanamap of a tree: see 4. (TA.) ― -b5- And [as the zanamap of the ear of a camel, or of a goat or sheep, serves to distinguish it,] it signifies also (assumed tropical:) A mark, sign, or token. (TA.) ― -b6- zanamataA Alfuwqi (tropical:) The two edges [or cusps] of the notch of an arrow, (Msb, K, TA,) between which is put the bow-string; (Msb, TA;) as also Alfwq ↓ zanomataA; (K;) but the former is the more chaste: (TA:) also called $aroxaA Alfuwqi. (S in art. $rx, and A and TA.) ― -b7- See also A^u*unaA Alqalobi, voce A^u*unN. ― -b8- Alz~anamapu also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (K, TA,) of which AHn had heard mention made, but remembered not any description: it is said to grow in plain, or soft, tracts, and in the form of the zanamap of the ear; to have leaves; and to be one of the worst of plants. (TA.) ― -b9- See also zanomap.
zunamap * : see zanomap.

zunaAmN *
A calamity, misfortune, or evil accident. (K.) -A2- See also zunaAmiY~N.

zaniymN * , applied to a goat, [and app. to a sheep also,] Having [two wattles, such as are termed] zanamataAni [of which see the sing., zanamapN]; as also ↓ muzan~amN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and ↓ muzan~amN, (tropical:) One adopted among a people to whom he does not belong, (Fr in explanation of the former word as used in the Kur lxviii. 13, and S and K,) to which some add, (TA,) not being needed; as though he were a zanamap among them: (S, TA:) and i. q. daEiY~N [as meaning likewise one who is adopted among a people or by a person (though understood in some other sense by F)]; (Mbr, Mgh, Msb, TA;) conjoined [with them or him]: thus the former was expl. by I 'Ab as used in the Kur ubi suprà: (Mbr, TA:) but Az says that the latter word has only the meaning assigned to it above, voce zanimN as an epithet applied to a camel. (TA.) And the former word, (tropical:) Base, ignoble, or mean; known by his baseness, ignobleness, or meanness, (S, K, TA,) or his evil character, (K, TA,) like as the $aAp [i. e. sheep or goat] is known by its zanamap: (S, TA: [in the latter of which is added, “ because the cutting of the ear is a mark: ” but by its znmp is here meant “ its wattle; ” for the cutting of the ear of the camel is a mark of generous race:]) thus expl. by 'Ikrimeh as used in the Kur ubi suprà. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) The son of an adulteress or a fornicatress. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A commissioned agent, a factor, or a deputy. (TA.) ― -b4- AlA^abad~u Alz~aniymu The lion. (M and K in art. bd, q. v.)

naAYN zunaAmiY~N *
A nAY [or flute], so called because invented by ↓ zunaAm, a skilful zam~aAr [or player upon the musical reed] in the service of Er-Rasheed and El-Moatasim and El-Wáthik: vulgarly called zulaAmiY~; said by Esh-Shereeshee to be thus miscalled by the common people of the West. (TA.)

A^azonamu * , and its fem. (zanomaA='u): see zanimN. ― -b2- AlA^azonamu Alja*aEu i. q. AlA^azolamu Alja*aEu [q. v.]; (K, TA;) meaning (tropical:) Time, or fortune, to which trials are appendant: or, as some say, hard, or rigorous, in its course. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

A^azonamiY~N *
A camel of those called AlA^azonamiy~apu; thus called in relation to [a sub-tribe (baTon) of banuw yarobuwEK or of tamiym named] ↓ banuw A^azonama. (IAar, TA.)
tazoniymN * inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And also a subst. like tanobiytN and tamotiynN, signifying A certain mark of camels. (TA.)

muzan~amN * , and its fem. (with p): see zanimN. ― -b2- See also zaniymN, in two places. ― -b3- Also Small in body; like muzal~amN. (IAar, TA in art. zlm.) ― -b4- Also The young ones of camels. (S, K.) ― -b5- And A certain
stallion [-camel]; (S, K;) accord. to some, who read thus, in a verse of Zuheyr,
magaAnimu $at~aY mino A_ifaAli muzan~ami
[Sundry spoils consisting of the young camels the offspring of Muzennem]: (S:) thus A'Obeyd read, instead of A_ifaAlK muzan~ami, in which the latter word is used for muzan~amapK, [by poetic license,] because A_ifaAlN is of a measure common to masc. and fem. words. (EM p. 120.)
1 zanaA * , [aor. yazonuw,] inf. n. zunuw~N, It was, or became, strait, or narrow; a dial. var. of zanaA^a; (ISd, K, TA;) said of a place. (TA.)

2 zn~Y Ealayohi *
He straitened, or oppressed, him; made strait, or close, to him: (ISd, K:) it occurs thus, without ', by poetic license, for zan~aA^a, in a saying of a rájiz cited in art. $dx, as an ex. of the word $aAdixapN. (S in art. znA^.) -A2- zn~Y also signifies He (a man) became lax in his joints. (TA in art. zn.)
zanaA='N * : see what next follows, and also art. znA^.

zaniY~N *
Strait, or narrow; (K;) as also ↓ zanaA='N: (TA in art. znA^ from the Fáïk; and in art. zn:) the former mentioned in this sense by IAar; (TA;) applied to a bag, or other receptacle. (K, TA.) [See also zaniYo'N, in art. znA^.]
zinawiY~N * rel. n. from zinFY: see the next article.

1 zanaY * , aor. yazoniY, inf. n. zinFY [often written zinFA] and zinaA='N, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) the latter an inf. n. of 3 (S, Mgh, Msb, K) also, (S, Mgh, K,) but said by some to be a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) the former being of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, (Lh, S, Msb, TA,) and the latter of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem, (Lh, TA,) or of the people of Nejd, (S, Msb, TA,) He committed fornication or adultery; (El-Munáwee, Er-Rághib, TA;) bihaA with her: (MA:) but accord. to El-Munáwee, [it seems to be properly a dial. var. of zanaA^a as meaning he mounted; for he says that,] in the proper language of the Arabs, Alz~inaA signifies the mounting upon a thing; and in the language of the law it signifies the commission of the act first mentioned above: it is [thus] syn. with fajara: and in like manner one says of a woman [zanato]: (TA:) ↓ zn~Y, inf. n. tazoniyapN, also signifies the same: (TA:) and so does ↓ zAnY, inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaA='N: (K:) one says of a woman, ↓ tuzaAniY, inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaA='N, meaning tubaAgiY [i. e. She commits fornication or adultery; or prostitutes herself]. (S.) It is said in a prov., laA HuSonuhaA HuSonN walaA Alz~inaA='u zinaA='N [Her continence is not continence, nor the fornication, or adultery, that she commits, fornication, or adultery]: applied to him who does not remain in one state, or condition; neither in good nor in evil: (Meyd:) or to him who refrains from doing good and then is excessive [therein], or from evil and then is excessive therein; not continuing to pursue one way. (TA.) [See also zanoyapN.]

2 zn~Ahu * , inf. n. tazoniyapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) He said to him yaA zaAniY [O fornicator or adulterer]: (S, TA:) or he imputed to him Alz~inaA [i. e. fornication or adultery]; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) and so ↓ zAnAhu, accord. to the copies of the K; but in the M, ↓ AznAhu, which, it is there said, has not been heard except in a trad. of the daughter of El- Hasan. (TA.) -A2- See also 1. -A3- And see 2 in art. znw.
3 zaAnaAhaA * , inf. n. muzaAnaApN and zinaA='N, [He committed fornication or adultery with her.] (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. -A2- And see 2.
4 A^azonaYa see 2.
zinFY * , often written zinFA: see the next paragraph, in two places.

zanoyapN *
A single act of Alz~inaY [i. e. fornication or adultery]: (Msb, TA:) and ↓ zinFY is [used in the same sense, (though properly an inf. n., not of un.,) as is shown by its being] dualized: they say zinayaAni: (TA:) [but this is post-classical:] thus using the dual of zinFY, the lawyers say, qa*afahu bizinayayoni [He reproached him with two acts of fornication or adultery]: (Msb, TA:) but [in this instance, and] in the saying ↓ $ahida EalaY zinaA'ayoni, [which is dual of zinaA='N, properly an inf. n. like zinFY,] or zinayayoni, [He testified, or gave decisive information, respecting two acts of fornication or adultery,] the right word is zanoyatayoni. (Mgh.) One says also, huwa A@bonu zanoyapK, and sometimes ↓ zinoyapK, (K,) but the former is the more chaste, (Az, TA,) meaning ↓ A@bonu zinFY [i. e. He is a son of fornication or adultery]: (K:) or huwa waladu zanoyapK and ↓ zinoyapK, (Mgh, Msb,) and lizanoyapK [huwa] and ↓ lizinoyapK, (Mgh,) with fet-h and with kesr, [meaning as above, or wulida lizanoyapK He is, or was, born of fornication or adultery,] contr. of waladu ri$odapK and liri$odapK, (Mgh,) or contr. of huwa liri$odapK: (Msb:) or ↓ huwa lizinoyapK and lizanoyapK, [He is the offspring of fornication or adultery,] contr. of liri$odapK and lira$odapK: (S:) accord. to Fr, one says, huwa ligay~ipK and lizanoyapK and ligayori ra$odapK, [all meaning the same, and] all with fet-h: accord. to Ks, however, one may say ↓ zinoyap and ri$odap, with kesr, but gay~ap only with fet-h: (TA:) ISk says that znyp and gy~p are both with kesr and fet-h. (Msb.)

zinoyapN * [accord. to analogy signifies A mode, or manner, of fornication or adultery]. See the next preceding paragraph, in five places. -A2- Also The last of a man's children; (K;) like as fijorapN signifies the “ last of a woman's children. ” (TA.)
zinaA='N * [properly an inf. n., but having a dual assigned to it]: see an instance of its dual voce zanoyapN

zinawiY~N * [meaning Of, or relating to, fornication or adultery] is the rel. n. from zinFY; (S, Msb;) the [radical] Y being changed into w because three Ys are deemed difficult of pronunciation: (Msb:) and the rel. n. from zinaA='N [having the same meaning] is ↓ zinaA=y^iY~N. (S.)
zinaAy^iY~N * : see what next precedes.
zan~aA='apN * an appellation applied to A female ape (qirodapN). (S.)

zaAnK * act. part. n. of zanaY: [signifying Committing fornication or adultery: and also a fornicator or an adulterer:] (Msb:) fem. zaAniyapN: (Kur xxiv. 2 and 3:) pl. masc. zunaApN, like quDaApN pl. of qaADK: (Msb:) [and pl. fem. zawaAnK.] yaA zaAniY said to a woman is correct as being [for yaA zaAniyapu, O fornicatress, or adulteress,] apocopated. (Mgh.)
zaAniyapN * fem. of zaAnK [q. v.] ― -b2- Applied to a man, it has an intensive meaning [i. e. One much addicted to fornication or adultery]. (Mgh.)

1 zahida fiyhi * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and Eanohu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
zahada ; (S, K;) [the most usual form of the verb;] and zahada, aor.
zahada ; (S, Msb, K;) which is the most approved form, though MF says otherwise; (TA;) and zahuda, aor.
zahuda ; (Th, K;) inf. n. zuhodN and zahaAdapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and zahodN; (Sb, TA;) He abstained from it; [meaning, from something that would gratify the passions or senses;] relinquished it; forsook it; shunned, or avoided, it; did not desire it; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) contr. of ragiba [i. e. of ragiba fiyhi], (S, K,) and i. q. ragiba Eanohu, (A, Mgh,) and lamo yuridohu, (Mgh,) and tarakahu and A^aEoraDa Eanohu: (Msb:) or he abstained from it, meaning a thing of the lawfulness of which he was sure, so far as to take the least that was sufficient thereof, leaving the rest to God: (MF:) or zahaAdapN relates only to worldly things; and zuhodN, to matters of religion: (Kh, Msb, K:) or both signify the exercising oneself in the service of God, or in acts of devotion; as also ↓ tazah~udN: (KL:) he who makes a difference between zahida fiyhi and zahida Eanohu errs. (Mgh.) ― -b2- zahaAdapN and zuhodN also signify [particularly The being abstinent in respect of eating;] the eating little. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And zahada and ↓ Azhd He straitened his household, by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (TA in art. znq.) -A2- zahadahu, aor.
zahada , (K,) inf. n. zahodN, (TA,) (tropical:) He computed, or determined, its quantity, measure, size, bulk, proportion, extent, amount, sum, or number; or he computed by conjecture its quantity or measure &c., or the quantity of its fruit; as also ↓ Azhdhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. A_izohaAdN; and ↓ zh~dhu, inf. n. tazohiydN: all used in relation to palm-trees. (TA.) You say, zahadotu Aln~axolu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees. (Esh-Sheybánee, S, TA.) And zahadotu AlmaAla (assumed tropical:) I computed by conjecture the quantity, or amount, of the property; or the number of the camels or cattle. (JK.)

2 zh~dhu fiyhi * [and Eanohu] He made him, or caused him, to abstain from it; to relinquish it; to forsake it; to shun, or avoid, it; or to be not desirous of it; (L, Msb;) i. q. zag~abahu Eanohu; (L;) trans. of zahida fiyhi: (Msb:) [i. e.] Alt~azohiydu fiY Al$~aYo'i and Eanohu is the contr. of Alt~arogiybu fiyhi. (S, K. *) ― -b2- And Alt~azohiydu is also (tropical:) syn. with Alt~aboxiylu. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, Alt~aboxiylu.]) One says, Aln~aAsu yuzah~iduwnahu and yubax~iluwnahu (tropical:) [Men, or the people, impute to him, or accuse him of, niggardliness, or stinginess]. (A, TA.) And 'Adee. Ibn-Zeyd says,
wa lalobaxolapu AlA^uwlaY limano kaAna baAxilFA
A^aEaq~u wamano yaboxalo yulamo wa yuzoh~adi
i. e. (assumed tropical:) [And verily the first single act of niggardliness, of him who is acting in a niggardly manner, is most undutious to parents; (app. because generosity is what they enjoin above all things;) and he who is niggardly is blamed, and] is charged with being a niggard, a low or mean or sordid man. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1.

4 Azhd * , (JK, L,) inf. n. A_izohaAdN, (JK, S, L,) He was, or became, one whose property was not desired, because of its littleness; (JK, L;) he possessed little property, (S * L,) which, because of its littleness, was not desired. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1. -A2- Azhdhu: see 1, near the end.

5 tzh~d *
He manifested, or made a show of, zuhod [or abstinence, &c., generally meaning exercise in the service of God, or devotion]: (KL:) [and] he devoted himself to the service of God, or to religious exercises; or applied himself to acts of devotion. (S, Msb.) See also 1.

6 tzAhdwhu * (assumed tropical:) They contemned, or despised, him, or it. (K.) It is said in a trad., of wine-drinkers, tzAhdwA AlHad~a, i. e. they contemned the Had~ [or prescribed castigation]; held it in little, or mean, estimation; regarded it as a small thing. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

8 Aizodahadahu * (assumed tropical:) He reckoned it little. (K.) You say, fulaAnN yazodahidu EaTaA='a fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one reckons little the gift of such a one. (ISk, S.) [See also what next precedes.]

zahodN * (tropical:) A small quantity. (A.) You say, xu*o zahoda maA yakofiyka (JK, S, K) (tropical:) Take thou the small quantity that is sufficient for thee: (A:) or as much as is sufficient for thee. (JK, S.)

zahadN * (tropical:) The poor-rate; syn. zakaApN: (A, K:) mentioned by Aboo-Sa'eed, on the authority of Mubtekir El-Bedawee: so called, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, because of its littleness; the zkAp of property being the least portion of it; or, accord. to the A, because the fortieth part [which is its general proportion] is little. (TA.) So in the saying, maA laka tamonaEu Alz~ahada (tropical:) [What aileth thee that thou refusest the poor-rate?]. (A, TA.)

A^aroDN zahaAdN * (assumed tropical:) Land that does not flow with water except in consequence of much rain: (S:) or land that flows with water in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, JK, and TA in art. H$d;) as also Ha$aAdN; (ISk, TA in art. H$d;) [contr. of A^aroDN ragaAbN: see also zahiydN.] And zahaAdu Alt~ilaAEi (assumed tropical:) The small water-courses. (L.)

zahiydN *
Who eats little; (T, K;) applied to a man; (T;) [and] so zahiydu AlA^akoli; (S;) or zahiydu AlT~aEomi: (A:) and so zahiydN or zahiydapN, (as in different places in the T,) applied to a woman: contr. of [ragiybN and] ragiybapN. (T.) You say, fulaAnN zahiydN ↓ zaAhidN, i. e. [Such a one is abstinent, &c., and] a small eater. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Small in quantity or number: (S, Msb, K:) so applied to a gift. (S.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Contemptible, despicable, mean, or paltry. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A man who possesses, or does, little, or no, good. (A, TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A man (Lh, TA) narrow, or niggardly, in disposition; (Lh, K, TA;) as also ↓ zaAhidN; (K;) fem. of the former with p: (Lh, TA:) a low, ignoble, ungenerous, mean, or sordid, man; such that one does not desire what he possesses; as also ↓ zaAhidN. (L.) ― -b6- huwa zahiydu AlEayoni, and lahu EayonN zahiydapN, (tropical:) He is content with little; contr. of huwa ragiybu AlEayoni and lahu EayonN ragiybapN. (A, TA.) ― -b7- waAdK zahiydN (assumed tropical:) A narrow valley: (JK, K:) or a valley that takes, or receives, little water; (ISh, S, TA;) that is made to flow by a slight quantity of water, even as much as a she-goat voids into it, because it is even and hard: (ISh, TA:) contr. of waAdK ragiybN. (TA in art. rgb.) [See also zahaAdN.] And zahiydu AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) What is narrow, of land; and that from which much water does not come forth: pl. zuhodaAnN. (L.)
zih~iydN * : see the next paragraph.

zaAhidN * act. part. n. of zahida [i. e. Abstaining, or abstinent; relinquishing; forsaking; shunning, or avoiding; not desiring or desirous: and particularly abstaining from, or shunning, or retiring from, worldly pleasures; exercising himself in the service of God, or in acts of devotion; a devotee]: and ↓ zih~iydN has a similar, but intensive, meaning [i. e. abstaining much, or very abstinent; &c.]: pl. of the former zuh~aAdN. (Msb, TA.) See also zahiydN, in three places.

muzohidN * A man possessing little property, (JK, S, A,) so that one does not desire it. (JK.) It is said in a trad., A^afoDalu Aln~aAsi muw^ominN muzohidN, meaning [The most excellent of men is a believer] possessing little property. (S, A.)

1 zahara * and zaharato , (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
zahara , (Msb, K,) inf. n. zuhuwrN, (S, K,) It (a star, TA, and the moon, and a lamp, and the face, K) shone, or glistened; (K, TA;) as also ↓ Azdhr: (K:) it (fire, S, A, K, and the sun, A) gave light; shone; or shone brightly: (S, A, K:) it (a thing) was clear in colour, and gave light, or shone, or shone brightly: (Msb:) and you say also, of the moon and of the sun, zahara [and zaharato], aor.
zahara , inf. n. zahorN; and zahura [and zahurato, aor.
zahura ]. (TA.) ― -b2- zahara Alz~anodu The piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire emitted shining fire; made its fire to shine. (TA.) ― -b3- zaharato bika naAriY (S, A) [lit.] My fire hath become strong and abundant by means of thee: (S:) and zaharato bika zinaAdiY (T, K) [lit.] my pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire have become powerful and abundant [in fire] by means of thee: (K:) meaning, (tropical:) my want hath been accomplished by means of thee: (T, TA:) like wariyato bika zinaAdiY. (S.) ― -b4- zahara, aor.
zahara ; (Msb;) and zahira, aor.
zahara , (K,) inf. n. zaharN; (TA;) and zahura; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was, or became, white; (Msb, K;) and beautiful: (K: [so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K; but omitted in the TA:]) or of a bright white colour: (TA:) or of any shining colour: (AHn, R:) and zahara (assumed tropical:) it (a plant) was, or became, beautiful: (AHn, TA:) and zahira aor.
zahara , (tropical:) he (a man) was, or became, white, or fair, in face. (Msb.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places. -A2- zaharati Al$~amosu AlA_ibila The sun altered the camels. (K.)

4 Azhr *
He made a fire, (S, K,) and a lamp, (A,) to give light, to shine, or to shine brightly. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- A^azoharota zanodiY [lit., Thou hast made my piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire to emit shining fire, or abundant fire; meaning, (tropical:) thou hast made me to accomplish my want: see 1]. (A.) ― -b3- Azhr (AHn, T, S, M, A, Msb, [and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, but SM says that in all the copies of the K it is written ↓ Aizohar~a, like AiHomar~a,]) It (a plant, or herbage, S, K, &c., and a tree, TA) flowered, or blossomed; (AHn, T, S, Msb, &c.;) as also ↓ zahara, aor.
zahara ; (Msb;) and ↓ AzhAr~. (AHn, K.) ― -b4- A^azoharati AlA^aroDu, and ↓ zaharat, The land abounded with flowers. (Zj, TA.)

8 A_izotahara see 1. ― -b2- Aizodahara bihi, (originally Aizotahara, TA,) He took care of it, (S, A, K,) and was mindful of it: (A:) or (so in the TA, but in the K “ and ”) he rejoiced in it; (IAth, K) his face became shining by reason of it: (IAth:) or he was mind ful of it: or [Aizodahiro bihi signifies be thou vigorous, sedulous, earnest, energetic, or diligent, in it; meaning, in the thing that I command thee to do; for] AlAizodihaAru bi$aYo'K means [by implication] thy commanding thy companion to be vigorous, sedulous, earnest, energetic, or diligent, in the thing which thou commandest him to do: (K:) all which significations are from zahorapN in the sense of “ beauty, and brightness. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad. that Mohammad bequeathed to Aboo- Katádeh the vessel from which he performed ablution, and said to him, Aizodahiro bih`*aA faA_in~a lahu $aA^onFA Take thou care of this, and do not lose it, (S, TA,) but be mindful of it, [for it is a thing of importance:] (TA:) or rejoice thou in this; let thy face become shining by means of it: (IAth:) or, accord. to Th, take it up; or charge thyself with it: and he says that this verb is Syriac: A 'Obeyd thinks it to be Nabathean or Syriac: Aboo-Sa'eed says that it is Arabic. (TA.)
9 A_izohar~a and 11: see 4.

zahorN * , a pl., (K,) or [rather a coll. gen. n.] like
tamorN, (Msb,) of which the sing., (K,) or n. un., (Msb,) is ↓ zahorapN, (Msb, K,) which latter signifies, as also ↓ zaharapN, A flower, or blossom, of a plant: (S, Msb, K:) or a yellow flower or blossom; (IAar, K;) and white flowers are called naworN: (IAar:) or a flower or blossom that has become yellow: (IAar, TA:) IKt says that the term zhrp is not applied to a flower until it becomes yellow: or it signifies an open flower or blossom; a flower or blossom before it opens being called buroEuwmN: (Msb:) pl. A^azohaArN, and pl. pl. A^azoAhiyru. (A, * K.) One says, kaA^an~a zahora Aln~ujuwmi zahoru Aln~ujuwmi [As though the flowers of the herbs were the shining of the stars]. (A.) ― -b2- Also ↓ zahorapN (Th, K) and ↓ zaharapN, (K,) or the former only, (TA,) A plant: (Th, K:) but ISd thinks that Th, by this explanation, means the signification first given above: and MF disallows the meaning of a plant as unknown. (TA.)

zihorN *
A want. (K, TA.) So in the phrase, qaDayotu minohu zihoriY [I accomplished what I wanted of him, or it]. (TA.)

zahorapN * : see zahorN, in two places. ― -b2- zahorapu Ald~unoyaA, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and ↓ zaharatuhaA, (AHát, M, K,) the former agreeable with the reading of verse 131 of chap. xx. of the Kur obtaining among the people of the Harameyn, and the latter with that generally obtaining in El-Basrah, (AHát, TA,) [but the latter is disallowed in the Msb, and by MF,] The beauty and splendour of the present world or life; (M, A, K;) its goodliness; (S, M, A, K;) its sweetness, or pleasantness; or the abundance of its goods, conveniences, or comforts; (S, M;) its goods; (Msb;) its finery, (Msb, TA,) or beauty and splendour, and abundance of good things. (TA.)
zuhorapN * (assumed tropical:) Whiteness; (Yaakoob, S, K;) and beauty: (K:) whiteness, or fairness, characteristic of good birth: (S:) or bright whiteness: (TA:) or any shining colour. (AHn, R.)
zaharapN * : see zahorN, in two places: ― -b2- and zahorapN.

Alz~uharapu * [The planet Venus;] a certain star, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) white and brilliant, (TA,) in the third heaven. (K.) ― -b2- Alz~uharu [the pl.]: see A^azoharu, near the end of the paragraph.

zaAhirN * [Shining; &c. See 1.] ― -b2- Applied to a zanod, or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire, Emitting shining fire; making its fire to shine. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a plant, (assumed tropical:) Beautiful: and to the complexion of a man, bright; shining: and i. q. A^azoharu, q. v. (TA.) ― -b4- A^aHomaru zaAhirN (assumed tropical:) Intensely red. (Lh, K.) ― -b5- lifulaAnK dawolapN zaAhirapN (tropical:) [Such a one has a brilliant turn of fortune]. (A.)

yamo$iY Alz~aAhiriy~apa *
He walks with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an inclining of the body from side to side: (K, * TA:) occurring in the poetry of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee. (TA.)

A^azoharu *
Shining; giving light; bright. (Sudot;, K.) Hence, (TA,) AlA^azoharu The moon. (S, K.) And AlA^azoharaAni The sun and the moon. (ISk, S, A, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) White; (S, K;) and beautiful: (K:) or of a bright white colour: (TA:) or of any shining colour: (AHn, R:) as also ↓ zaAhirN. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man white, or fair, in face: (Msb:) having a bright, or shining, face: (K:) having a white, or fair, and bright, or shining, face: (S:) a man having a white, or fair, complexion, characteristic of good birth: (Sh, S: *) or of a bright white or fair complexion, with a shining face: or mixed with redness: (TA:) and zahoraA='u a woman white, or fair, in face: (Msb:) having a bright, or shining, face: (K:) having a white, or fair, and bright, or shining, face: (S:) of a bright white or fair complexion intermixed with redness. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Bright, or shining, applied to an animal and to a plant. (AA.) ― -b5- Applied also to water [app. as meaning Bright and clear] (TA.) ― -b6- And i. q. HuwaAr [app. a mistranscription for Huw~aAraY, i. e. White, or whitened, applied to flour]. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) A wild bull: and zahoraA='u a wild cow. (S, K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A white lion. (K.) ― -b9- A white ewer or jug, in which wine is made. (TA voce garabN.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) Milk just drawn. (AA, K.) ― -b11- Alz~ahoraA='u is applied by Ru-beh to The white cloud (saHaAbap) lightning in the evening. (O, K.) ― -b12- dur~apN zahoraA='u (tropical:) A white and clear pearl. (TA.) ― -b13- Alz~uhoru Three nights of the beginning of the [lunar] month: (TA:) or so ↓ Alz~uharu. (Har p. 299.) ― -b14- Alyawomu AlA^azoharu Friday. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b15- Alz~ahoraAwaAni [The two chapters of the Kur-án entitled] Albaqarapu and A=lu EimoraAna. (O, K.) -A2- A camel parting his legs wide, cropping the trees. (K.)

mizoharN *
A certain musical instrument; (Msb;) the lute (Euwd) upon which one plays: (S, K:) pl. mazaAhiru. (Msb.) -A2- One who makes the fire bright, and turns it over [to prevent its going out or becoming dull,] (yuqal~ibuhaA, K and TA, in the CK yuwqiduhA,) for [the purpose of attracting] guests. (K.)
mazohuwrN * , applied by El-'Ajjáj to the lamp of the darkness [i. e. the moon], Made to shine; from A^azoharahu A@ll~`hu; like majonuwnN from A^ajan~ahu: or, as some say, shining. (TA.)

1 zahaqato nafosuhu * , and zahiqato, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the latter preferred by IKoot and Hr, but the former by A'Obeyd, (TA,) aor.
zahaqa , (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. zuhuwqN, (S, Mgh,) which is of both verbs, (S,) or this is of the former verb, and the inf. n. of the latter is zahaqN, (Msb,) [but in the K it seems to be indicated, by its being said of the latter verb that it is of the class of samiEa, that the inf. n. of this verb is zahoqN,] His soul went forth, passed forth, or departed: (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) it perished: it died: (TA:) nafosuhu ↓ Ainozahaqato and AinozihaAqu Alr~uwHi are not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 55 and 86] watazohaqa A^anofusuhumo wahumo kaAfiruwna [And that their souls may depart while they are unbelievers]. (S.) The primary meaning of zuhuwqN is The going forth, passing forth, or departing, with difficulty. (Bd in ix. 55.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zahaqa Al$~aYo'u (tropical:) The thing perished, passed away, or came to nought; (Msb, K, TA;) became null, void, or of no effect. (K, TA.) And zahaqa AlbaATilu (tropical:) What was false, or vain, passed away, or came to nought, (S, Msb, K, TA,) being overcome by the truth, or reality, or fact: or, accord. to Katádeh, by AlbATl is here meant the devil. (TA.) ― -b3- And zahaqa Als~ahomu (S, Msb, K, TA) and zahiqa (Msb) (tropical:) The arrow passed beyond the butt, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and fell behind it: (TA:) or went swiftly: (Ham p. 23:) or the former has this meaning: and the latter is syn. with zaliqa [app. meaning it slid along the ground]. (JK.) ― -b4- And zahaqa Alfarasu, aor.
zahaqa , inf. n. zuhuwqN, (assumed tropical:) The horse preceded, went before, got before, outwent, or outstripped. (S, * Msb.) And zahaqati Alr~aAHilapu, inf. n. zuhuwqN (ISk, S, K) and zahoqN, (TA as from the K, [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K,]) (tropical:) The saddle-camel preceded, went before, got before, outwent, or outstripped, the horses, or horsemen; (ISk, JK, * S, K, TA;) and ↓ Anzhqt signifies the same. (JK.) And zahaqa fulaAnN, inf. n. zahoqN and zuhuwqN, (tropical:) Such a one preceded, went before, &c.; (K, TA;) or zahaqa bayona A^ayodiynaA (tropical:) preceded us, went before us, &c., and preceded, &c., the horses, or horsemen; (TA;) and ↓ Anzhq signifies the same. (K.) -A2- zahaqa said of a bone, (S, K,) aor.
zahaqa , (K,) inf. n. zuhuwqN, Its marrow became compact and full; (S, K;) as also ↓ Azhq. (L, K.) And zahaqati Ald~aAb~apu, with the same aor. and inf. n., The beast was, or became, marrowy in the utmost degree, its marrow-bones being compacted and full. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of marrow, It was, or became, compact and full. (S, K.)
2 zah~aqa see 2 in art. zrq: and see 4 below.

3 zAhq AlHaq~u AlbaATila * (TA [there expl. by zahaqah, a mistranscription, app. for ↓ A^zohaqahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The truth, or reality, or fact, made what was false, or vain, to pass away, or come to nought.])

4 Azhq nafosahu *
He (God) caused his soul to go forth, pass forth, or depart. (Mgh, Msb.) The phrase Alqatolu A_izohaAqN means (assumed tropical:) Slaughter is a cause of making the soul to come to nought, and to depart.
