(Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Azhq AlbaATila (tropical:) He (God) caused what was false, or vain, to pass away, or come to nought. (S, K, TA.) See also 3. ― -b3- And Azhq Als~ahoma (S, K) mina Alhadafi (K) (tropical:) He made the arrow to pass beyond the butt. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And Azhqt Ald~aAb~apu Als~aroja (assumed tropical:) The beast shifted forward the saddle, and threw it upon its neck: (S, K:) and, or but, it is said to be with raA=': [i. e. one says also, or correctly, accord. to some, A^arohaqatohu:] a rájiz says,
A^axaAfu A^ano tuzohiqahu A^awo yanozariqo
[(assumed tropical:) I fear that she may shift it forward, and throw it upon her neck, or it may shift backwards]: [thus, says J,] cited to me by Abu-lGhowth, with zaAY. (S.) [Accord. to my copy of the KL, ↓ tazohiyqN, inf. n. of zh~q, signifies (assumed tropical:) The shifting backwards of a camel's saddle from his back: see 2 in art. zrq.] ― -b5- And Azhq fiY Als~ayori
(assumed tropical:) He was quick [as though urging himself forward] in pace, or journeying. (K.) -A2- Azhqhu also signifies He filled it; (S, O, K;) namely, a vessel: (S, O:) but accord. to the L, he overturned it; i. e. a vessel. (TA.) -A3- See also 1, near the end.

7 A_inozahaqa see 1, in three places. ― -b2- One says also Anzhqt Ald~aAb~apu (assumed tropical:) The beast leaped, or leaped upwards, (S,) or went forward, or preceded, (O, K,) in consequence of beating, or taking fright. (S, O, K.) And The beast fell into a deep place, or from a mountain; or fell from a mountain and died; syn. tarad~ato. (TA. [See the next paragraph.])

zahaqN *
A low, or depressed, part of the ground. (S, O, K.) A hollow, or cavity, or deep hollow or cavity, in the ground; syn. wahodapN: (JK, TA:) sometimes, or often, beasts fall into it, and die. (TA. [See 7.])
zahiqN * (tropical:) Light, and unsteady, or lightwitted; (S, K, TA;) applied to a man. (S.) -A2- And A beast not exceeded in fatness. (TA.)
zahaqaY * (assumed tropical:) A mare that precedes, or outgoes, the [other] horses, or the horsemen. (Sh, K.)
humo zuhaAqu miAy^apK * and zihaAqu mAy^p i. q. zuhaA='u miAy^apK, (K, * TA,) i. e. They are of the number of a hundred. (TA.)

zahuwqN * (tropical:) A thing passing away, or coming to nought; or that passes away, or comes to nought; as also ↓ zaAhiqN. (K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvii. 83], A_in~a AlbaATila kaAna zahuwqFA, i. e. (tropical:) [Verily what is false, or vain,] is a thing that passes away, or comes to nought. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A deep well; (JK, S, K;) as also ↓ zaAhiqapN; [in the TA zaAhiqN;] and in like manner both are applied to a place of destruction (matolafapN); (JK;) and to a matolafap [app. meaning a desert in which people perish] as meaning far-extending. (Ham p. 23.) And in like manner, (S,) the former is also applied [app. as an epithet] to a faj~ [or road, or depressed road,] of an overpeering, or overhanging, mountain. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Light, or active; syn. xafiyfN. (JK.)

zaAhiqN *
Perishing, or dying. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- See also zahuwqN, in two places. ― -b3- (tropical:) An arrow passing beyond the butt, and falling behind it: (Mgh, TA:) whence the saying, in a trad., A_in~a HaAbiyFA xayorN mino zaAhiqK [expl. in art. Hbw]. (TA.) ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) Preceding, or outgoing.] You say, jaA='a zaAhiqFA (assumed tropical:) He came before, or in advance of, the horses, or horsemen. (JK.) And raAHilapN zaAhiqapN (assumed tropical:) A saddlecamel preceding, going before, getting before, outgoing, or outstripping, the horses, or horsemen. (S.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A man put to flight: (S, O, K:) pl. zuhaqN, (so in my copies of the S,) or zuh~aqN, (so in the O,) or zuhoqN and zuhuqN, with damm and with two dammehs. (K.) ― -b6- (tropical:) Water running vehemently: (JK, K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a canal (xaliyjN) running swiftly. (TA.) -A2- Applied to a beast (daAb~ap), Fat, (JK, Az, S, K,) and marrowy: (S, K:) or marrowy, but not fat in the utmost degree: or having thin, or little, marrow: (TA:) and dry, or tough, (K, TA,) by reason of leanness; so says As: (TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (JK,) very lean; (JK, K, TA;) Such that a foul odour is perceived arising from the meagreness of its flesh: (TA:) thus it bears two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- And, applied to marrow, Compact and full: (S, TA:) or, so applied, good in respect of fatness: and some say, i. q. raArN [i. e. in a melting state, or corrupt, by reason of emaciation; or thin; &c.]: so that [thus applied also] it bears two contr. meanings. (JK.) In the saying of a rájiz, (S, TA,) namely, 'Omárah Ibn-Tárik, (TA,)
wamasadK A^umir~a mino A^ayaAniqi
lasona biA^anoyaAbK walaA HaqaAy^iqi
walaA DiEaAfK mux~uhun~a zaAhiqu
accord. to Fr, it is in the nom. case, the poetry being what is termed mukofaA^, [by which is here meant having one rhyme made to end with kesreh (which is substituted for fet-hah by poetic license) and another with dammeh,] the poet meaning [And a rope, or many a rope, tightly twisted, of the fur of she-camels, that were not aged ones, nor such as had their teeth fallen out by reason of extreme age, nor weak,] but whose marrow was compact and full: [or, agreeably with an explanation given above from the JK, zAhq may mean in a melting state, &c.:] another explanation is, that zAhq here means *aAhib [going away]: (S, TA:) but, as Sgh says, the [right] reading is
EiysK EitaAqK *aAti mux~K zaAhiqi
[meaning but of a reddish, or yellowish, or dingy, white hue, of generous race, having compact and full marrow]. (TA.)

A^uzohuwqapN * sing. of A^azaAhiyq in the phrase farasN *aAtu A^FzaAhiyqa (tropical:) A mare having wonderful, or admirable, qualities in running: (A, TA:) or this means a mare having a swift running. (S, K.) ― -b2- One says also, jaA='a ti Alxayolu A^azaAhiqa and A^azaAhiyqa, meaning (assumed tropical:) [The horses, or horsemen, came] in troops in a state of dispersion. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b3- A^azaAhiyqu is also the name of A horse of Ziyád Ibn-Hindábeh. (K.)

muzohaqN *
Slain. (El-Muärrij, S.)

muzohiqN *
Slaying, or a slayer. (El-Muärrij, S.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man quick [as though urging himself forward] in his pace, or journeying. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Loquacious. (JK.)

mazohaqapN * [A cause of the departure of the soul: a word of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of a camel which others strive in vain to overtake, h`*aA Aljamalu mazohaqapN liA^arowaAHi AlmaTiY~i (tropical:) [This camel is one that takes away the breath of the other beasts, or saddle-camels]. (A, TA.)
rajulN mazohuwqN * (assumed tropical:) A man who is straitened. (TA.)

1 zahima * , inf. n. zuhuwmapN and zahamN, It stank: [in which sense zahuma, inf. n. zuhuwmapN, is mentioned by Freytag on the authority of the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen:] said of flesh-meat. (MA. [See also zuhuwmapN and zahamN below.]) And zahimato yaduhu (S, MA, K,) aor.
zahama , (K,) inf. n. zahamN, (S, K,) His hand was, or became, greasy, (S, MA, K,) mina Al$~aHomi from the fat: (MA:) or had in it the odour of fat. (TA) ― -b2- zahima; also signifies He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it was too weak to digest: (JK, K:) said of a man. (JK.) ― -b3- zahama, (K,) aor.
zahuma , inf. n. zahomN, (TK,) It (a bone) was, or became, marrowy; had, or contained, marrow; as also ↓ Azhm. (K, TA.)
4 A^azohama see what next precedes.

zuhomN *
Fat, as a subst.: (S:) or so ↓ zahamN; a particular term for it, not implying there being in it the odour of fat and stinking flesh-meat: (JK: [and the same is said in the TA in relation to the former word:]) or the latter signifies fat of a beast of prey: (TA:) or, as some say, flesh-meat that is raw, or not thoroughly cooked: (JK:) and the former, fat of a wild animal: or of the ostrich: or of horses: (K:) or, as some say, of a wild animal that does not chew the cud: (TA:) or in a general sense. (K.) ― -b2- And The perfume known by the name of zabaAd [i. e. civet], which comes forth from the [cat called] sin~aworu Alz~abaAdi, from beneath its tail, in the part between the anus and the meatus urinarius. (K.) -A2- Also A fetid odour. (K.) [See also zahamN and zuhuwmapN.]

zahamN * The fetid odour of corpses or carcases. (TA. [See also 1, first sentence; and the last explanation of zuhomN; and see zuhuwmapN.]) ― -b2- And The remains of fat in a horse or similar beast (fiY daAb~apK). (TA.) See also zuhomN.

zahimN * [part. n. of zahima]. You say, laHomN zahimN Stinking, fat, flesh-meat. (JK.) And yaduhu zahimapN His hand is greasy: (S, K:) or has in it the odour of fat. (TA.) ― -b2- And Very fat; having much fat: or having some remains of fatness. (K.)
zuhomapN * : see zuhuwmapN.

zahomaAnu *
Suffering from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it is too weak to digest: (JK, K:) and zhmAn with damm [i. e. ↓ zuhomaAnN, with tenween, for, as is said in the S (voce EuroyaAnN), a word of the measure fuEolaAn has its fem. with p meaning, if an epithet,] signifies [the same, or] satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; as also ↓ zuhomaAniY~N. (Z, cited by Freytag in his Arab. Prov., ii. 196.) And [hence, app.,] zahomaAnu, (Abu-n-Nedà, IAar, TA,) or ↓ zuhomaAnu, [imperfectly decl. (like the first word) as a proper name ending with An] (AHeyth, IDrd, S, TA,) or each, (K,) the name of A certain dog. (S, K, &c.) It is said in a prov., zaAduhu ↓ fiY baToni zahomaAna In the belly of the dog zhmAn is his provision: applied to a man who has with him his apparatus, and what he needs: or, accord. to AA, the case was
this: a man slaughtered a camel, and divided it, and gave to [one whose name was] zhmAn his share, and then zhmAn returned to receive again with the [other] people; and it is applied to a man who seeks a thing when he has received once: (Meyd:) Z says that zahomaAnu is the name of a man who came to a people that had slaughtered a camel, and asked them to give him some food thereof, and they gave it him: then he returned to them, and they said to him thus, meaning “ Thou has had thy provision thereof, and it is in thy belly; ” and it is applied to any one who has received his share of a thing, and then come, after that, seeking it: or, as some relate it, it is with damm, [↓ zuhomaAn] and is applied to one who is invited to a repast when he is satiated: or it relates to one suffering from indigestion: or zhmAn is the name of a dog; and it originated from the fact that a man prepared for himself some provision, and was unmindful of it, and a dog ate it; and it is applied to him for whom there is no share. (Z cited by Freytag ubi suprà.)
zuhomaAnN * and zuhomaAnu: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
zuhomaAniY~N * : see zahomaAnu, first sentence.

zuhuwmapN * The odour of fat and stinking flesh-meat; (JK, K; [and mentioned also, but not explained, in the S;]) as also ↓ zuhomapN: (K:) or the latter signifies a fetid odour [in a general sense]: (S:) but accord. to Az, the former signifies the disagreeableness of odour, without the being fetid, or altered [for the worse]; such as the odour of lean flesh-meat, or the odour of the flesh of a beast of prey, or strong-smelling sea-fish; the fish of the rivers having no zhwmp. (TA.) [See also 1, first sentence; and ruhomN, last signification; and zahamN.]

1 zahaA * , said of seed-produce, It increased, or augmented; received increase and blessing from God; or throve by the blessing of God: (JK, TA:) [or,] said of herbage, aor. yazohuw, inf. n. zahowN, it attained its full growth: (Msb:) or it put forth its fruit: or it became tall: (TA:) and, said of palm-trees, (naxolN, S, Msb, K, TA,) and likewise of plants, (TA,) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, Msb, TA,) they became tall; (K, TA;) became tall and fullgrown; or became of their full height, and blossomed; (TA;) and ↓ AzhY signifies the same: (K:) or both signify they (i. e. palm-trees) showed redness, and yellowness, in their fruit; (S, Msb;) the latter verb mentioned by AZ, but [it is said that] As did not know it: (S: [see, however, what follows:]) or, as some say, the former signifies they put forth their fruit; and ↓ the latter, as expl. next before: (Msb:) accord. to Abu-lKhattáb and Lth, one says of palm-trees (naxol) only yuzohiY; not yazohuw: and As [is related to have] said, [contr. to what has been asserted of him above,] that when redness appears in [the fruit of] palm-trees, one says AzhY. (TA.) And zahaA Alt~amoru, (JK,) or Albusoru; and ↓ AzhY; (Mgh, K;) and ↓ zh~Y, (K,) inf. n. tazohiyapN; (TA;) [The dates, or dates beginning to ripen,] showed their goodness by redness, and yellowness: (JK:) became red, and yellow: (Mgh:) became coloured. (K.) Hence the trad., nahaY Eano bayoEi vamari Aln~axoli Hat~aY yazohuwa, or ↓ yuzohiYa, [He forbade the selling of the fruit of the palm-trees until its becoming red or yellow], thus differently related. (Mgh.) ― -b2- You say also, zahaA AlgulaAmu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) The boy grew up; or attained to youthful vigour, or the prime of manhood. (K.) ― -b3- And zahati Al$~aApu, (JK, S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (JK, S,) The ewe, or she-goat, became large in her udder: (JK:) or secreted milk in her udder, and was near to bringing forth. (AZ, S, K. *) ― -b4- And zahati Alr~iyHu The wind rose, blew, or became in a state of commotion. (S.) ― -b5- And zahati AlA_ibilu, (JK, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (JK, M,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) The camels journeyed, after coming to water, (JK, S, M, K,) a night or more, (JK, S, M,) so says A'Obeyd, (S,) or a night or two nights. (K.) And The camels passed along, (mar~at,) so in the copies of the K, but correctly mad~at [i. e. made much advance in journeying], as in the M, (TA,) in search of pasturage, after they had drunk, (K, TA,) not pasturing around the water. (TA.) The verb used in relation to camels is also trans., as will be shown below. (S, &c.) -A2- zahowN [as inf. n. of the trans. v. zahaA, aor. yazohaY,] primarily signifies The act of raising, or elevating: and the act of shaking; or putting in motion, or into a state of commotion: whence zahaAhu Als~araAbu and zahati Alr~iyHu Aln~abaAta [both expl. in what follows]. (Har p. 171.) You say, zahati AlA^amowaAju Als~afiynapa The waves raised the ship. (TA.) And zahaA Als~araAbu Al$~aYo'a, aor. yazohaAhu, The mirage raised, or elevated, [to the eye,] the thing [seen in it or beyond it; or rather, made it to appear tall, and as though quivering, vibrating, or playing up and down; as is perhaps meant to be indicated by the citation above from Har]; syn. rafaEahu; written only [thus] with A [in the pret. and in the aor.]: (S:) and Als~araAbu yazohaY Alqubuwra waAlHumuwla The mirage is as though it raised the tombs and the women's camel-vehicles; or elevated them; expl. by the words kaA^an~ahu yarofaEuhaA. (TA.) ― -b2- And zahaA AlmirowaHapa, said of a person fanning, He put in motion the fan; or put it into a state of commotion; as also ↓ zah~aAhaA. (TA.) And zahati AlriyHu Al$~ajara, (S,) or Aln~abaAta, (K, * TA,) aor. tazohaAhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. zahowN, (K, TA,) The wind shook, or put in motion or into a state of commotion, (S, K, * TA,) the trees, (S,) or the plants, or herbage, after the dew or rain (gib~a Aln~adaY). (K, TA.) ― -b3- And zahaAhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. zahowN; (K, TA;) and ↓ AzdhAhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. AizodihaA='N; (K, TA;) [not AzhAhu, as in the TK, followed by Freytag;] i. q. Aisotaxaf~ahu: (S, K, * TA:) and tahaAwana bihi: (S:) [the former of these two explanations as meaning He, or it, incited him, or excited him, to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; or to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness: and the latter of them, or both of them, for the former is often syn. with the latter, as meaning he held him, or it, in little, or light, estimation or account, or in contempt; he contemned, or despised, him, or it: but of this latter meaning I do not remember to have met with any ex.:] and bihi ↓ AzdhY signifies the same as AzdhAh (TA) meaning tahaAwana bihi. (JK.) You say, zahaAhu Al$~aYo'u and ↓ AzdhAhu, meaning [agreeably with the former of the two explanations in the sentence immediately preceding] Aisotaxaf~ahu TarabFA: (Har p. 359:) and ↓ yazodahiyniY as meaning [agreeably with the same explanation] yasotafiz~uniY and yasotaxif~uniY: (Id. p. 131:) and Alqawoma ↓ AzdhY as meaning [in like manner] Aisotaxaf~ahumo mina AlT~arabi; and also as meaning He pleased the people, or party: (Id. p. 427:) and ↓ AizodahaAhu also as meaning Hamalahu EalaY Alz~ahowi [He incited him, or excited him, to pride, or conceit, or the like]: (Id. p. 131:) and zahaAhu Alkiboru (K) Pride rendered him self-conceited. (TK.) 'Omar Ibn-'Abee-Rabeea says,
walam~aA taqaAwaDonaA AlHadiyva waA^asofarato
wujuwhN zahaAhaA AlHusonu A^ano tataqan~aEaA
meaning And when we discoursed together, and faces shone, beauty excited the possessors of them to levity (Aisotaxaf~a A^arobaAbahaA) and prevented their veiling them with the qinaAE [or head-covering], by reason of self-admiration: or, as some say, the hA in zhAhA refers to a woman mentioned before, not to wjwh; and the meaning is, beauty excited her &c.: and thus the women of the Arabs used to do when they were beautiful: or you may consider the complement of lam~aA as suppressed; as though he said, when we did all that, we behaved with mutual familiarity, or the like; for the complements of lawo and lam~aA and Hiyna may be suppressed, and their vagueness by reason of their suppression is more forcible in respect of the meaning: A^ano tataqan~aEaA means mino A^ano tataqan~aEaA; for they often suppress the preposition with A^ano: (Ham pp. 552-3:) [J gives two readings of this verse, accord to one of my copies of the S: one is with tanaAzaEaA in the place of taqaAwaDonaA, and A^a$oraqato in the place of A^asofarato; which make no difference in the meaning: but this is omitted in my other copy: the other is as follows:]
falam~aA tawaAfaqonaA sal~amotu A^aqobalato
wujuwhN zahaAhaA AlHusonu A^ano tataqan~aEaA
[And when we agreed together, and I saluted, faces advanced, which beauty excited &c, or the possessors of which beauty excited &c.]. (S.) And hence their saying, bixadiyEapK ↓ fulaAnN laA yuzodahaY [Such a one will not be incited, or excited, to briskness, &c., by means of deceit, or guile]. (S.) And AlfaraHu ↓ AzdhAhu, meaning Aisotaxaf~ahu [Joy incited him, &c.]. (MA.) [And hence, perhaps, may be derived most of the following significations.] ― -b4- zahaA AlT~al~u Alnawora The Tl~ [or fine drizzling rain] made the flowers, or blossoms, to increase in beauty of aspect. (TA.) ― -b5- zahaA Als~iraAja, (K,) aor. yzhwhu [perhaps a mistranscription for yazohaAhu], inf. n. zahowN, (TA,) He made the srAj [or lamp, or lighted wick,] to give a bright light. (K.) ― -b6- zahawotu AlA_ibila
I made the camels to journey, after coming to water, (A 'Obeyd, JK, S, K,) a night or more, (A 'Obeyd, JK, S,) or a night or two nights. (K.) Thus the verb in relation to camels is trans. as well as intrans. (S.) ― -b7- zahaA biAls~ayofu He made a sign with the sword by waving it, or brandishing it. (K, TA.) ― -b8- zahaA biAlEaSaA He struck with the staff, or stick. (K.) ― -b9- zahaA bimiAy^api riTolK He computed, or computed by conjecture, [to be of the weight of] a hundred pounds. (K.) You say, zahaAhu bimiAy^api riTolK meaning xrzh [a mistake for Hazarahu i. e. He computed it, &c., to be of the weight of a hundred pounds]. (TK. In the TA, zhA flAn bmAy^p rTl, [Al$~aYo'a or the like being omitted by an oversight,] aor. yazohaAhu [which indicates an omission after flAn].) And zahawotu Alqawoma I computed, or computed by conjecture, the number of the people, or party. (JK.) -A3- zuhiYa, (JK, S, K,) like EuniYa; (S, K;) and zahaA, (IDrd, S, K,) like daEaA, but this is rare, (K,) and was dissallowed by As in the sense of zuhiYa, (TA in art. nxw,) aor. yazohuw, inf. n. zahowN; (IDrd, S;) and ↓ A^azohaY; (K;) said of a man, (JK, S,) He behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; (S, K, * TA;) he was proud, vain, and boastful; (K;) or was pleased with himself, or self-conceited: (JK:) AzdhY [i. e. ↓ AuzoduhiYa], in like manner, means takab~ara: (Har p. 264: [but this more properly signifies, as shown above by an explanation of AizodahaAhu, he was incited, or excited, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness:]) the first of these verbs [may be originally pass. of zahaA in the phrase zahaAhu Alkiboru, mentioned before, but, as J says,] is one of a class of verbs used in the pass. form though having the sense of the act. form: in using it imperatively, you say, lituzoha yaA rajulu [Behave thou proudly, &c., O man; see art. t]; and like this is the aor. [used as an imperative] of every verb of which the agent is not named; for when it is reduced to its essential import, you thereby command something, other than the person whom you address, to affect, or befall, that person; and the third person of the [aor. used as an] imperative is never without l, as when you say, liyaqumo zayodN: (S, TA:) J also says, (TA,) I said to an Arab of the desert, of [the tribe of] Benoo-Suleym, What is the meaning of zuhiYa Alr~ajulu? and he answered, The man was pleased with himself, or self-conceited: I said, Dost thou say, zahaA as meaning Aifotaxara [He gloried, or boasted, &c.]? and he answered, As for us, we do not say it. (S, TA.) One says also, zuhiYa fulaAnN bika*aA i. e. nuxiYa [Such a one gloried, or boasted, and magnified himself, or behaved proudly, by reason of such a thing]; as though meaning zahaAhu AlA_iEojaAbu binafosihi [i. e. self-conceit elevated him by reason of such a thing]. (Har p. 171.) ― -b2- And one says, zuhiYa Al$~aYo'u biEayonayoka or liEayonayoka The thing was beautiful in aspect in, or to, thine eyes. (S, accord. to different copies. [The meaning is there shown by what immediately precedes. In three copies of the S, I find the verb in this phrase thus written, zuhiYa; and only in the PS, zhA, for zahaA, which is the form given by Golius: Freytag writes the phrase zahaY Al$Y bEynk.])
2 zah~awa see 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph.

4 A^azohawa see 1, in four places, in the first three sentences: ― -b2- and again, in one place, in the last quarter of the same paragraph. -A2- maA A^azohaAhu [meaning How proud, vain, boastful, or selfconceited, is he!] is from zahaA as syn. with zuhiYa; not from the latter of these two verbs, because the verb of wonder is not formed from a verb of which the agent is not named. (S.)
8 AizodahaY * [originally AizotahaY]: see 1, as a trans. verb, in eight places. And AuzoduhiYa: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.

zahowN * [is the inf. n. of zahaA (q. v.): and also has the significations here following. ― -b2- ] Pride [as implying self-elevation]: (JK, S, K:) vanity, or vain behaviour: (K:) boasting, or glorying: (S, K:) and wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (TA.) ― -b3- A false, or vain, saying; syn. baATilN; (S, K, and Ham p. 24;) a lie, or falsehood; (JK, S, K, and Ham * ubi suprà;) or an exaggeration in speech. (Ham ubi suprà.) You say, qaAla zahowFA [He said a false, or vain, saying, &c.]. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b4- A beautiful aspect. (S, K.) ― -b5- The blossoms, or flowers, of a plant. (Lth, K.) ― -b6- The brightness of a plant (K, TA) by its becoming red or yellow; (TA;) as also ↓ zuhuw~N, (K, TA,) like Euluw~N, (TA,) [in the CK kAlz~ahowi is here put in the place of kaAlz~uhuw~i,] and ↓ zahaA='N, (K, TA,) like saHaAbN, as the unrestricted mention of it requires, but in some of the copies of the K with damm [i. e. zuhaA='N]. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, [or nabaAtN zahowN, as in the TK,] A plant beautiful and bright, (K,) or fresh. (TA.) ― -b8- And Dates beginning to ripen (busorN) that are becoming coloured (mulaw~inN), (so in some copies of the S and K, and in the Mgh, or mutalaw~inN [which signifies the same], Har p. 416), or that have become coloured (mulaw~anN); (so in other copies of the S and K;) as also ↓ zuhuw~N, (K, TA,) like Euluw~N, thus in the handwriting of Az in the T: (TA:) [here, again, in the CK we find kAlz~ahowi put in the place of kaAlz~uhuw~i: or perhaps it should be ↓ kaAlz~uhowi; as appears from what follows in the next sentence:] in this sense, zahowN is an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mgh.) One says, when redness and yellowness appear in palm-trees, qado Zahara fiyhi Alz~ahowu [Dates becoming, or become, red, or yellow, have appeared in them; i. e. fiY Aln~axoli]: and the people of El-Hijáz say, ↓ Alz~uhowu, with damm: (S:) [Fei says,] the subst. from zahaA Aln~axolu meaning “ the palm-trees showed redness and yellowness in their fruit ” is Alzhw [i. e. ↓ Alz~uhowu], with damm; and AHát says that this term is used only when the colour of the date has become free from admixture in redness or yellowness. (Msb.) ― -b9- You say also vawobN zahowN A red and beautiful garment or piece of cloth: and viyaAbN zahowapN and ↓ zaAhiyapN [red and beautiful garments &c.]. (JK.)
zuhowN * : see the next preceding paragraph, latter half, in three places.

zuhaA Ald~unoyaA *
The ornature, finery, show, pomp, or gaiety, of the present life or world. (K, TA.) The former noun [when indeterminate] is [with tenween, zuhFA,] like hudFY. (K.)

zahowapN *
A shining, glistening, or brilliancy; whatever be the colour. (TA.)
zahaA='N * : see zahowN, in the former half of the paragraph.

zuhaA='N *
Number, or amount. (JK, Msb.) You say, kamo zuhaAw^uhumo How many is their number? or how much is their amount? (Msb, TA:) or, the computation of them? (TA.) And humo zuhaA='u miAy^apK [They are as many as a hundred;] they are the number, or amount, of a hundred; (El-Fárábee, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) or their number, or amount, is a hundred: (Mgh:) and miAy^apK ↓ zihaA='u, also, with kesr: (El-Fárábee, Msb:) but the saying of the [common] people humo zuhaA=' EalaY miAy^ap is not [correct] Arabic. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A large number: whence in a trad. respecting the time of the resurrection, A_i*aA samiEotumo binaAsK mino qibali Alma$oriqi A^uwliY zuhaA='K i. e. [When ye hear of men coming from the direction of the east,] having a large number. (TA.) ― -b3- And zuhaA='u Al$~aYo'i signifies The $axoS [i. e. corporeal form or figure or substance, which one sees from a distance,] of the thing. (TA.)
zihaA='u miAy^apK * : see the next preceding paragraph.
zuhuw~N * : see zahowN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The redness of colour, and beauty, of garments or cloths. (JK.)

zaAhK * [act. part. n. of zahaA]. ― -b2- A_ibilN zaAhiyapN Camels that will not pasture upon the [plants, or trees, termed] HamoDi: (ISk, S:) pl. zawaAhK. (TA.) ― -b3- zaAhiY All~awon Bright in respect of colour. (TA.) viyaAbN zaAhiyapN: see zahowN, last sentence.

A^azohaY * [meaning More, and most, proud, vain, boastful, or self-conceited, is, like maA A^azohaAhu (q. v.), from zahaA as syn. with zuhiYa; not from the latter of these two verbs]. You say A^azohaY mino guraAbK [More proud, &c., than a crow]; (S, Meyd;) because the crow, in walking, ceases not to go with a proud, or self-conceited, gait, and to look at itself: and mino waEilK [than a mountain-goat]: and mn TaAw^uwsK [than a peacock]: and diykK and *ubaAbK and vaworK and vaEolabK [a cock and a fly and a bull and a fox]: all these are provs. (Meyd.)

A_inozahowN * , in which each of the first two letters is augmentative, and which is said to be the only word of its kind except A_inoqaHolN from qaHala, (MF, TA,) applied to a man, Proud, haughty, or insolent; (Lh, K;) as also ↓ muzodahFY [which more properly means incited, or excited, to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness]; (Har p. 264:) pl. of the former A_inozahowuwna. (Lh, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

mazohuw~N * , from zuhiY, applied to a man, Proud, haughty, or insolent; (S, TA;) [vain, and boast-
ful;] pleased with himself, or self-conceited. (TA.) [See also what next precedes.]
muzodahFY * : see A_inozahowN, above.

1 zuY~a EalayonaA * , or ziY~a, (accord. to different copies of the S, in the TA zuY~a,) [from zaw~N, originally zuwiwa, then zuwiYa, and then zuY~a or ziY~a,] or it is zuwiYa, (thus in some copies of the S,) It was decreed against us. (S.)

4 A^azowaY * , (K,) said of a man, (TA,) [from zaw~N,] He came having with him another: (K, and T in art. tw:) mentioned by Az and Sgh on the authority of IAar: (TA:) opposed to A^atowaY meaning “ he came alone; by himself. ” (T in art. tw.)

zaw~N *
A pair, or couple; two coupled together; (S, K, TA;) [of men, and] of ships and other things; (TA;) i. q. zawojN: (K, and T in art. tw:) opposed to taw~N meaning “ one, and no more. ” (K, and TA in this art. and in art. tw.) You say, jaA='a fulaAnN zaw~FA, meaning Such one came with his companion. (S.) [See also art. tw.] -A2- Alz~aw~u is also the name of A ship constructed by ElMutawekkil, (K, TA,) the 'Abbásee; in which he associated in drinking with the poet El-Boh- turee. (TA.) Accord. to the S, it is the name of a mountain in El-'Irák: but Aboo-Zekereeyà EtTebreezee, and after him the author of the K, deny this, and suppose J to have been led into error in asserting such to be the case by the following saying of the poet above mentioned:
walaA jabalFA kaAlz~aw~i yuwqafu taArapF
wayanoqaAdu A_im~aA qudotahu bizimaAmi
[Nor have I seen a mountain like Alz~aw~, that is made stationary at one time, and becomes led on at another time if thou draw it along with a leading-rope]: J, however, does not say that he took this from the poetry of El-Bohturee. (TA. [In the CK, in the verse above cited, Ai*o mA is put in the place of A_im~aA.]) -A3- [J also says that,] accord. to As, zaw~u Almaniy~api signifies What happens of decreed perdition or death: and zaw~N is also said to signify a decree [of God]: (S, TA:) and in the M it is said that zaw~N signifies perdition, or death: and zaw~u Almaniy~api, the accidents, or calamities, of destiny or death: but accord. to the T, As said zawo'u Almaniy~api, with' (TA.)

2 zw~j $ayoy^FA bi$aYo'K * , and zw~jhu A_ilayohi, [inf. n. tazowiyjN,] He coupled, or paired, a thing with a thing; united it to it as its fellow, or like. (TA.) So in the Kur [xliv. 54 and lii. 20], zaw~ajonaAhumo biHuwrK EiynK We will couple them, or pair them, [with females having eyes like those of gazelles:] (S, Mgh, K, TA:) the meaning is not the tazowiyj commonly known, [i. e. marriage,] for there will be no [such] tzwyj in Paradise. (MF, TA.) And so in the Kur [lxxxi. 7], waA_i*aA Aln~ufuwsu zuw~ijato And when the souls shall be coupled, or paired, or united with their fellows: (TA:) i. e., with their bodies: (Bd, Jel:) or, each with its register: (Bd:) or with its works: (Bd, TA:) or the souls of the believers with the Huwr, and those of the unbelievers with the devils: (Bd:) or when each sect, or party, shall be united with those whom it has followed. (TA.) And so in the phrase, zaw~ajotu A_ibiliY I coupled, or paired, my camels, one with another: (A:) or zaw~ajotu bayona AlA_ibili I coupled, or paired, every one of the camels with another. (TA.) So too in the Kur [xlii. 49], A^awo yuzaw~ijuhumo *ukoraAnFA waA_inaAvFA Or He maketh them couples, or pairs, males and females: or, accord. to AM, maketh them of different sorts [or sexes], males and females: for ― -b2- tazowiyjN signifies [also] The making to be of different sorts or species [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- zaw~ajotuhu A@moraA^apF, (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) thus the Arabs say accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) making the verb doubly trans. by itself, [without a particle,] meaning I married him, or gave him in marriage, to a woman; (Msb, TA;) as also biA@moraA^apK; (A, K;) Akh says that this is allowable [app. as being of the dial. of Azd-Shanooäh (see 5)]: (Msb, TA:) [when the verb is trans. by means of bi, it generally has the meaning expl. in the first sentence of this art.:] zaw~ajotu minohu A@moraA^apF is not of the language of the Arabs: (T, Mgh, TA:) [but see a similar phrase in a verse cited in art. HSn, conj. 4:] the lawyers say, zaw~ajotuhu minohaA [meaning I married him to her]; but this is a phrase for which there is no reasonable way of accounting, unless that it is accord. to the opinion of those who hold that mino may be redundant in an affirmative proposition, or that of those who hold that it may be substituted for bi. (Msb.)

3 zAwjhu * , [inf. n. muzaAwajapN and ziwaAjN] It, or he, was, or became, a couple, or pair, with it, or him: or made a coupling, or pairing, with it, or him. (MA.) [And zaAwajaA They two formed together a couple, or pair.] ― -b2- [And zAwjA, inf. n. as above, They married each other.] You say, hu*ayolN yuzaAwiju Eikorimapa [The tribe of Hudheyl intermarry with that of 'Ikrimeh]. (A. [See also 6.]) ― -b3- zAwj bayonahumaA and ↓ Azwj (tropical:) [He made them two (referring to sentences or phrases) to have a mutual resemblance in their prose-rhymes, or in measure: or to be connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other]. (A, TA.) See also 8, in three places.
4 A^azowaja see the next preceding paragraph.

5 tazaw~ajotu A@moraA^apF * , (T, S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) thus the Arabs say accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) meaning I married a woman; i. e., took a woman in marriage; took her as my wife; (Msb, TA;) as also biA@moraA^apK; (A, * K;) or this is rare; (K;) Akh says that it is allowable; (Msb, TA;) and it is said to be of the dial. of AzdShanooäh, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) by Fr; (S, TA;) but accord. to Yoo (S, Mgh) and ISK, (Mgh,) it is not of the language of the Arabs. (T, S, Mgh.) And tzw~j fiY baniY fulaAnK (A, Msb, TA) He married, or took a wife, among the sons of such a one. (Msb, TA.) And tzw~j A_ilayohi i. q. xaAtanahu [He allied himself to him by marriage]. (K in art. xtn.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tzw~jhu Aln~awomu (assumed tropical:) Sleep pervaded him; syn. xaAlaTahu. (K.)
6 tzAwj Alqawomu * and ↓ AizodawajuwA The people, or party, married one another; intermarried. (TA. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

8 Aizodawajati AlT~ayoru * [The birds coupled, or paired, one with another]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6. ― -b3- AizodawajaA and ↓ tazaAwajaA [and ↓ zaAwajaA], said of two phrases, or sentences, (A, TA,) (tropical:) They bore a mutual resemblance in their prose-rhymes, or in measure: or were connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other: and in like manner, Azdwj and ↓ tzAwj, said of a phrase, or sentence, (tropical:) It was such that one part of it resembled another in the prose-rhyme, or in the measure: or consisted of two propositions connected, each with the other; or dependent, each on the other: (TA:) AizodiwaAjN and ↓ muzaAwajapN (S, A, K) and ↓ tazaAwujN (S) are syn.: (S, A, * K:) AzdwAj signifies A conformity, or mutual resemblance, [with respect to sound, or measure,] of two words occurring near together; as in the phrase mino sabaA^K binabaA^K [in the Kur xxvii. 22]: (Kull p. 31:) and this is also termed ↓ muzaAwajapN and muHaA*aApN and muwaAzanapN and muqaAbalapN and muw^aAzaApN. (Marginal note in a copy of the Muzhir, 22nd nwE.)

zaAjN * [Vitriol;] a well-known kind of salt; (K, TA;) called $ab~N yamaAniY~N; [but see $ab~N;] which is a medicinal substance, and one of the ingredients of ink: (Lth, TA:) [pl. zaAjaAtN, meaning species, or sorts, of vitriol; namely, green, or sulphate of iron, which is an ingredient in ink, and is generally meant by the term zAj when unrestricted by an epithet; blue, or sulphate of copper; and white, or sulphate of zinc:] it is a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, (S, K,) originally zAG. (TA.)

zawojN * primarily signifies A sort of thing of any kind [that is one of a pair or couple]: and zawojaAni signifies a pair, or couple, i. e. any two things paired or coupled together, whether they be likes or contraries: zawojN signifying either one of such two things: (Az, TA:) or, accord. to 'Alee Ibn- 'Eesà, a sort of thing [absolutely]: (Mgh:) or a sort of thing having its like, (El-Ghooree, Mgh, Msb,) as in the case of species; (Msb;) or having its contrary, (El-Ghooree, Mgh, Msb,) as the moist and the dry, and the male and the female, and the night and the day, and the bitter and the sweet; (Msb;) though sometimes applied to any sort of thing; and to a single thing: (El-Ghooree, Mgh:) or it is applied to a single thing only when having with it a thing of the same kind; (Mgh, Msb;) zawojaAni signifying a pair, or couple, of such things: (Mgh:) the pl. is A^azowaAji: (TA:) you say zawojaAni mino HamaAmK and zawojaA HamaAmK [A pair
of pigeons]: (A:) and Ai$otarayotu zawojaY HamaAmK [I bought a pair of pigeons], meaning a male and a female: (S:) and zawojaA niEaAlK [A pair of sandals]: (S, A:) and in like manner zawojayoni is used in the Kur xi. 42 and xxiii. 28; (S;) meaning a male and a female: (Bd, Jel:) or, accord. to the M, zawojN signifies one of a pair or couple: and also a pair or couple together: (TA:) and in like manner says AO, (Mgh, Msb,) and IKt, and IF: (Msb:) and ISh says that it signifies two; (Mgh;) and so says IDrd: (Msb:) so that you say, humaA zawojN as well as humaA zawojaAni [meaning They two are a pair, or couple]; (S, K, TA;) like as you say, humaA sawaA='N and humaA siy~aAni: (S, TA:) and EinodiY zawoju niEaAlK, meaning [I have] two [sandals]; and zawojaAni, meaning four: (Msb:) or zawoju HamaAmK as meaning a male and a female [of pigeons] is a phrase which should not be used; one to which the vulgar are addicted: (TA:) IAmb says, the vulgar are wrong in thinking that zawojN signifies two; for the Arabs used not to employ such a phrase as zawoju HamaAmK, but used to say zawojaAni mina AlHamaAmi, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) meaning a male and a female; (TA;) and zawojaAni mina AlxifaAfi, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) meaning the right and the left [of boots]: (TA:) nor did they apply the term zawojN to one of birds, like as they applied the dual, zawojaAni, to two; but they applied the term farodN to the male, and farodapN to the female: (Mgh, Msb:) Es-Sijistánee, also, says that the term zawojN should not be applied to two, neither of birds nor of other things, for this is a usage of the ignorant; but to every two, zawojaAni: (Msb:) Az says that the grammarians disapprove the saying of ISh that zawojN signifies two of any things, (Mgh, * TA,) and that zawojaAni mino xifaAfK signifies [Two pairs of boots, or] four [boots]; for zawojN with them signifies one [of a pair or couple]: a man and his wife [together] are termed zawojaAni: and vamaAniyapa A^azowaAjK in the Kur [vi. 144 and xxxix. 8] means Eight ones [of pairs or couples]: the primary meaning of zawojN being that first mentioned in this paragraph; (TA:) in the Kur xxii. 5 and 1. 7 [it seems to be implied that it means pair or couple; but more probably in these instances] it means sort, or species: (Bd, Jel:) it is also expl. by the word lawonN [used in this last sense]: (T, TA;) in the Kur xxxviii. 58, its pl. A^azowaAjN means A^alowaAnN and A^anowaAEN [i. e. sorts, or species] of punishment: F explains the sing. as meaning lawonN mina Ald~iybaAji wanaHowihi [a sort, or species, of silk brocade and the like]; but his restricting the signification by the words mn AldybAj wnHwh is not right, as is shown by a citation, in the T, of a verse of El-Aashà, in which he uses the phrase kul~u zawojK mina Ald~iybaAji [every sort, or species, of silk brocade], as an ex. of zwj in the sense of lwn. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A woman's husband: and a man's wife: in which latter sense ↓ zawojapN is also used; (S, M, A, Mgh, * Msb, K; *) as in a verse of El-Farezdak cited in art bwl, conj. 10; (S, Mgh;) but it is disallowed by As; (TA;) and the former word is the one of high authority, (Mgh, Msb,) and is that which occurs in the Kur, in ii. 33 and vii. 18, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and in iv. 24, (Mgh, TA,) and in xxxiii. 37: (Mgh:) AHát says that the people of Nejd call a wife ↓ zawojapN, and that the people of the Haram use this word: but ISk says that the people of El-Hijáz call a wife zawojN; and the rest of the Arabs, ↓ zawojapN: the lawyers use this latter word only, as applied to a wife, for the sake of perspicuity, fearing to confound the male with the female: (Msb:) the pl. of zawojN is A^azowaAjN (Msb, K *) and ziwajapN; (K;) and the pl. of ↓ zawojapN is zawojaAtN (A, Mgh, Msb) and A^azowaAjN also; (A, Msb;) and A^azaAwiyju occurs [as a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of A^azowaAju,] in a verse cited by ISk. (TA in art. nA^j.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A consociate, an associate, or a comrade: (A:) its pl. in this sense is A^azowaAjN, (S, A, K,) occurring in the Kur xxxvii. 22. (S, A.) ― -b4- And A fellow, or like: pl. A^azowaAjN: in this sense, each one of a pair of boots is the zwj of the other; and the husband is the zwj of the wife; and the wife, the zwj of the husband. (TA.) You say, EinodiY mino h`*aA A^azowaAjN I have, of this, fellows, or likes. (TA.) ― -b5- As used by arithmeticians, (Mgh, Msb,) contr. of farodN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e. it signifies An even number; a number that may be divided into two equal numbers; (Msb;) as, for instance, four, and eight, as opposed to three, and seven: (Mgh:) pl. A^azowaAjN. (S, Mgh.) One says zawojN A^awo farodN [Even or odd?], like as one says xasFA A^awo zakFA [or rather zakFA A^awo xasFA] and $afoEN A^awo witorN. (S, Mgh.) ― -b6- Also A [kind of cloth such as is termed] namaT [q. v.]: or silk brocade; syn. diybaAjN: (TA:) or a namaT that is thrown over the [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj. (S, K, TA.)
ziyjN * : see art. zyj.
zawojapN * : see zawojN, in four places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

zawojiy~apN * and ↓ zawaAjN [The marriage-state, or simply marriage]: the latter is a subst. from zaw~aja, [i. e. a quasi-inf. n.,] like salaAmN from sal~ama, and kalaAmN from kal~ama. (Msb.) You say, bayonahumaA Haq~u Alz~awojiy~api and ↓ Alz~awaAji [Between them two is the right of the marriage-state, or of marriage]: (A, Msb:) and Alz~iwaAji is also allowable as [an inf. n. of 3,] coordinate to AlmuzaAwajap. (Msb.)
zawaAjN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
zaAy^ijapN * : see art zyj.
mizowaAjN * A woman who marries often: (S, K:) one who has had many husbands. (K.)

1 zaAda * , aor. yazuwdu, (L,) inf. n. zawodN, (L, K,) He laid in a stock of provisions for travelling or for a fixed residence; syn. A^as~asa zaAdFA: (L, K:) or zaAdahu is syn. with zaw~adahu; q. v.; and this is what is meant in the K by taA^osiysu Alz~aAdi as the explanation of Alz~awodu. (MF.)

2 zw~dhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazowiydN; (KL;) as also ↓ AzdAhu, (K,) inf. n. A_izowaAdN; (TA;) and ↓ zaAdahu, inf. n. zawodN; (MF;) He furnished him with, or gave him, provisions (S, Msb, K, * KL) for travelling [or for a fixed residence]. (S, Msb.) [It is doubly trans.:] you say, zaw~adahumo milo'a AlmazaAwidi [He furnished them with what filled the provision-bags for travelling-provision]: (A:) and zw~dhu Alz~ayotu [He furnished him with olive-oil for travelling-provision]. (S in art. zyt.) And Aboo-Khirásh says,
waqado yaA^otiyka biAlA^axobaAri mano laA
↓ tujah~izu biAlHi*aA='i walaA tuziydu
[And sometimes, or often, he will bring thee tidings whom thou wilt not furnish with the sandal nor furnish with travelling-provisions]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zaw~adotuhu kitaAbFA (tropical:) [I provided him with a letter]. (A, TA.)
4 A^azowada see 2, in two places.

5 tzw~d * [He became furnished, or he furnished himself, with provisions for travelling or for a fixed residence;] he took, or prepared, for himself provisions (S, * KL, TA) for travelling or for a fixed residence: (TA: [Golius makes it to be trans. by means of bi as on the authority of the KL; in which the only explanation, as that of the inf. n., is tw$h brGrftn:]) and he chose a thing as zaAd [or provision] for himself. (Har p. 92.) You say, tazaw~ada min~aA fulaAnN [Such a one was furnished, or such a one furnished himself, with provisions from us]. (A.) And tzw~d lisafarihi [He was furnished, or he furnished himself, with provisions for his journey]. (Msb.) And see another ex. voce zaAdN. You say also, tazaw~ada mina Ald~unoyaA liloA=xirapi (tropical:) [Take thou provisions from the present world, i. e. make thou provision in it, for the world to come]. (A, TA.) And tazaw~ada mina AlA^amiyri kitaAbFA liEaAmilihi (tropical:) [He provided himself with a letter from the commander, or governor, or prince, to his prefect]. (A, TA.) And tazaw~ada min~iY TaEonapF bayona A^u*unayohi (tropical:) [He got from me a stab, or spear-wound, or the like, between his ears]. (A, TA.)

zaAdN *
Provisions, or a stock of provisions, for travelling (S, L, Msb, TA) and for a fixed residence: (L, TA:) pl. A^azowaAdN (L, Msb) and A^azowidapN; the latter anomalous. (L.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) Any deed, or acquirement, whether good or evil, whereby one becomes changed in state, or condition; (L;) [or rather, whereby one provides for a change of state, or condition, like as a traveller provides for a journey.] It is
said in the Kur [ii. 193], faA_in~a xayora Alz~aAdi ↓ watazaw~aduwA Alt~aqowaY (L) meaning, [as is implied in the L, (tropical:) And make ye provision; but verily the best acquirement whereby to provide for a change of state, or condition, is fear of God, or piety: or the meaning is] and prepare ye provisions for your journey; and verily the best provision is that whereby one provides against begging from others, &c. (Jel.) ― -b3- [It is also said to be used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Salutation and the returning of a greeting. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., ii. 415, q. v.)]
mazaAdN * : see mazaAdapN.

mizowadN *
A bag, or other receptacle, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) for travelling-provisions, (S, K, TA,) or for dates, made of leather: (Msb:) pl. mazaAwidu. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] riqaAbu AlmazaAwidi [lit. The necks of provision-bags;] a nickname applied to the Eajam [or Persians, or foreigners in general,] (S, K) by the Arabs. (S.) [See art. rqb.]

mazaAdapN * [A leathern water-bag, one of a pair which is borne by a camel or other beast;;] the half ($aTor) of a raAwiyap: pl. mazaAy^idu; [regularly mazaAwidu; or the medial radical is Y and therefore the reg. pl. is mazaAyidu;] and sometimes they said ↓ mazaAdN, [a coll. gen. n.,] without p: [accord. to some,] it is of the measure mafoEalapN, [originally mazowadapN,] from Alz~aAdu, because one furnishes himself with water in it for travelling-provision: (Msb:) [and therefore it is mentioned in this art.:] but this is a mistake. (TA in art. zyd, q. v.)

1 zaArahu * , aor. yazuwru, inf. n. ziyaArapN (S, A, Msb, K) and zaworN (S, A, K) and mazaArN (S, Msb, K) and zuwaArapN (Ks, S) or zuwaArN; (K;) and ↓ AzdArhu, (S, A, TA,) of the measure AifotaEala from Alz~iyaArapu, (S, TA,) is syn. with zaArahu; (A, TA;) [He visited him: lit.] he met him with his zawor [i. e. chest, or bosom]: or he repaired to his zawor, i. e. direction: (B, TA:) [or] he inclined towards him: (TA:) [see also zawira:] or he repaired to him: (A:) or he repaired to him from a desire to see him. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] zaAra $aEuwba (tropical:) [lit., He visited death; i. e., he died]. (TA.) [See 4.] -A2- zaArahu, (K,) aor. yazuwru, inf. n. ziwaArN, (TA,) He bound upon him (namely a camel) the rope called ziwaAr, q. v. (K.) -A3- zawira, aor. yazowaru, inf. n. zawarN, He, or it, inclined. (TA.) [App. always used in a proper, not a tropical, sense. See zawarN below.] ― -b2- He had the kind of distortion termed zawarN [which see, below]. (TA.)

2 zw~rhu * , (A, K,) inf. n. tazowiyrN, (S,) He honoured him; namely, a visiter; treated him with honour, or hospitality; (S, A, K;) made account of his visit; (A;) treated him well, and acknowledged his right as a visiter; (TA;) slaughtered for him, and treated him with honour or hospitality. (AZ.) -A2- zw~r Al$~ahaAdapa He annulled the testimony; (K, TA;) impugned and annulled it. (TA.) ― -b2- El-Kattál says,
wanaHonu A^unaAsN EuwdunaA Euwdu naboEapK
SaliybN wafynaA qasowapN laA tuzaw~aru
[And we are men whose wood of which our bows are made is hard wood of a neb'ah, and in us is hardiness not to be impugned and denied]: Aboo- 'Adnán says, [perhaps reading nuzaw~aru, which may be the correct reading,] that he means, we are not to be calumniated, because of our hardness, or hardiness, nor to be held weak. (TA.) ― -b3- zw~r nafosahu He stigmatized himself by the imputation of falsehood. (K.) [See also other explanations, below.] ― -b4- zw~r kalaAmahu (assumed tropical:) He falsified his speech; he embellished his speech with lies; syn. zaxorafahu. (Msb.) [See also below.] ― -b5- zw~r Alka*iba, (K,) inf. n. tazowiyrN, (S,) (tropical:) He embellished the lie. (S, K, TA.) ― -b6- zw~r $ayoy^FA (tropical:) He removed, or did away with, the obliquity of a thing; (TA;) he rectified, adjusted, or corrected, it; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) whether good or evil; (IAar, Msb;) he beautified, or embellished, it. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b7- zw~r kalaAmFA (tropical:) He made speech right and sound, (As,) prepared it, (As, Msb,) and measured it, (As,) fiY nafosihi in his mind, (Msb,) before he uttered it: (As:) he rectified, adjusted, or corrected, it; and beautified, or embellished, it; as also ↓ tzw~rhu, occurring in a verse of Nasr. Ibn-Seiyár. (TA.) And [in like manner] zw~r AlHadiyva (tropical:) He rectified, or corrected, the story, narrative, or tradition, removing, or doing away with, its obliquity: and ↓ tzw~rhu he did so (ziw~rhu) to himself. (A.) ― -b8- raHima A@ll~`hu A@moraA^F zaw~ara nafosahu EalaY nafosihi, a saying of El-Hajjáj, May God have mercy upon a man who rectifies, or corrects, himself, against himself: (S, * TA:) or, as some say, who stigmatizes himself by the charge of falsehood against himself: or who accuses himself against himself: like as you say, A^anaA A^uzaw~iruka EalaY nafosika I accuse thee [of wrong] against thyself. (TA.) -A3- tazowiyrN is also syn. with ta$obiyhN [The likening a thing to another thing; &c.]. (TA.) -A4- zw~r said of a bird, inf. n. as above, His crop (HawoSalatuhu) became high: (AZ, TA:) or became full. (TA.)

4 AzArhu *
He incited him, or made him, to visit. (S, K.) You say A^azarotuhu gayoriY I made him, or caused him, to visit another, not myself. (A.) ― -b2- A^azarotuhu $aEuwba (tropical:) I made him to visit death; [i. e., I killed him.] (TA.) [See 1.] ― -b3- A^anaA A^uziyrukumo vanaAy^iY (tropical:) [I will introduce you, or your name, in my eulogy; meaning I will praise you]. (A.) And A^azarotukumo qaSaAy^idiY (tropical:) [I have introduced you, or the mention of you, in my odes]. (A.)

5 tzw~r *
He said what was false; spoke falsely. (A.) -A2- See also 2, in two places.

6 tzAwrwA *
They visited one another. (S, A, K.) You say, bayonahumo tazaAwurN Between them is mutual visiting. (A.) ― -b2- See also 9, in two places.
8 AizodaAra * : see 1. -A2- Also, accord. to Aboo-'Amr El-Mutarriz, He swallowed a morsel, or mouthful; like Aizodarada. (TA in art. zrd.)

9 Azwr~ Eanohu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. AizowiraArN; (S, A;) and ↓ AzwAr~, (S, A, K,) inf. n. AizowiyraArN; (S;) and ↓ tzAwr; (S, A, Msb, K;) He declined, or turned aside, from it. (S, A, * Msb, K.) ↓ taz~aAwaru, in the Kur xviii. 16, is a contraction tatazaAwaru: (S;) tazowar~u is another reading. (TA.) ― -b2- fiY Sadorihi A@zowiraArN In his breast, or chest, is crookedness, curving, or distortion. (A.)

10 AstzArhu *
He asked him to visit him. (S, A, * K.)
11 A_izowaAor~a see 9.
zaArN * : see zaArapN.

zaworN * : see zaAy^irN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A camel having the hump inclining. (TA.) ― -b3- And, with p, A she-camel that looks from the outer angle of her eye, by reason of her vehemence and sharpness of temper: (K, * TA: [see zaworapN below: and see also A^azowaru:]) and a strong and thick she-camel. (TA.) ― -b4- And falaApN zaworapN A desert not of moderate extent, or not easy to traverse. (TA.) -A2- The direction of a person to whom one repairs. (B.) ― -b2- The breast, or chest: (TA:) or its upper, or uppermost, part: (S, A, Mgh:) in a horse, narrowness in this part is approved, and width in the labaAn; as the poet 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Suleymeh says, making a distinction between these two parts: (S:) or its middle: or the elevated part of it, to the shoulder-blades: or the part where the extremities of the breast-bones meet together: (K:) or the whole of the breast of the camel: pl. A^azowaArN. (TA.) Hence, banaAtu Alz~awori The ribs and other parts around the breast. (TA.) [Hence also, app. from the action of the camel when he lies down,] A^aloqaY zaworahu (tropical:) [lit. He threw his breast upon the ground;] he remained, stayed, or abode. (A.) ― -b3- The lord, or chief, of a people; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ zuwrN (Sh, K) and ↓ zuwayorN (IAar, S, K) and ↓ zawiyrN (TA, as from the K, [in a copy of which SM appears to have found kaAlz~awiyri waAlz~uwayori kazubayorK waxidab~K, instead of kaAlz~uwayori waAlz~iwar~i Alx,]) and ↓ ziwar~N. (K, TA.) -A3- Determination: (T, M:) or strength of determination. (K.) ― -b2- See also zuwrN -A4- A palm-branch, or straight and slender palm-branch, from which the leaves have been stripped off: (Sgh, K, TA:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Sgh, TA.) -A5- Stone which appears to a person digging a well, and which, being unable to break it, he leaves apparent: (K:) or, as some say, a mass of rock, in an absolute sense. (TA.)

zawarN * inf. n. of zawira. (TA.) ― -b2- Inclination; (S, Msb, K;) such as is termed SaEarN; (S;) crookedness; wryness; distortion. (A.) ― -b3- Distortion of the zawor, (Mgh, K,) which is the upper, or uppermost, part of the breast, (Mgh,) or the middle of the breast [&c.]: (TA:) or the prominence of one of its two sides above the other: (K:) in a horse, the prominence of one of the two portions of flesh in the breast, on the right and left thereof, and the depression of the other: (S:) in others than dogs, it is said by some to signify inclination [or distortion] of a thing or part which is not of a regular square form; such as the kirokirap and the libodap. (TA.)

ziyrN * , (S, K, &c.,) originally with w, written by the Sheykh-el-Islám Zekereeyà, in his commentaries on Bd, with hemz, contr. to the leading lexicologists; (TA;) or zyru nisaA='K; A visiter of women: (Az, TA in art. tbE:) a man who loves to discourse with women, and to sit with them, (S, K,) and to mix with them: (TA:) so called because of his frequent visits to them: or who mixes with them in vain things: or who mixes with them and desires to discourse with them: (TA:) without evil, or with it: (K:) and a woman is termed ziyrN also: (K:) you say AimoraA^apN ziyru rijaAlK: (Ks:) but this usage is rare: (TA:) or it is applied to a man only: (K:) a woman of this description is termed maroyamN: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^azowaArN and A^azoyaArN, (K,) the latter like A^aEoyaAdN pl. of EiydN, (TA,) and [of mult.] ziyarapN. (S, K.) -A2- Custom; habit; wont. (Yoo, K.) -A3- A slender watar [or bow-string]: (S, K:) or the most slender of such cords, (A^aHad~uhaA: (K, TA: in the CK A^aHaduhaA:) and the most firmly twisted. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the ziyr [or smallest string] of a mizohar [or lute] is thus termed. (TA.) [In this and the next preceding senses, it is app. of Persian origin.] -A4- Flax: (Yaakoob, S, K:) and with p a portion thereof: (K:) pl. A^azowaArN. (TA.) -A5- See also art. zyr.

ziwar~N * A vehement pace. (S, K.) ― -b2- Vehement; or strong: (K:) but to what applied is not particularized. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a camel, Strong; hardy; (TA;) prepared for journeys. (K.) And ziwar~apu A^asofaArK, applied to a she-camel, Prepared for journeys: or having an inclination to one side, by reason of her briskness, or sprightliness. (TA.) [See A^azowaru.] ― -b4- See also zaworN.
zayirN * , in the K zay~irN: see art. zyr.

zaArapu * The HawoSalap [or crop] (AZ, K) of a bird; (AZ, TA;) as also ↓ zaAwarapN, (K, TA,) with fet-h to the w, (TA,) [in the CK zAwirap,] and ↓ zaAw^uwrapu (K, TA) [in the CK zAwurap]: and AlqaTaA ↓ zaAwarapu The receptacle in which the [bird called] qTA carries water to its young ones. (TA.) -A2- zaArapu AlA^asadi The thicket, wood, or forest, or bed of reeds or canes, (A^ajamap,) that is the haunt of the lion: so called because of his frequenting it. (IJ.) [See also zaA^orapN, in art. zA^r.] And ↓ zaArN A thicket, wood, or forest, (A^ajamap,) containing [high coarse grass of the kind called] HalofaA=', and reeds or canes, and water. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A collected number, (K,) or a large collected number, (TA,) of camels, (K,) and of sheep or goats, and of men: or of camels, and of men, from fifty to sixty. (TA.) [See, again, zaA^orapN, in art. zA^r.]

zaworapN *
A single visit. (S, TA.) -A2- Distance; remoteness: (S, K:) from AlAizowiraAru. (S.) A poet (Sakhr El-Ghei, TA) says,
wamaA='K waradotu EalaY zaworapK
[To many a water have I come, notwithstanding its distance]: (S:) or, accord. to AA, EalaY zaworapK, in this ex., accord. to one relation zuwrap, but the former is the better known, means upon a she-camel that looked from the outer angle of her eye, by reason of her vehemence and sharpness of temper. (TA.)

ziyrapN *
A manner of visiting. (K.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu Alz~iyrapi Such a one is good in his manner of visiting. (TA.)

ziwaArN * (AA, S, K) and ↓ ziyaArN (IAar, K) A rope, or cord, which is put between the camel's fore-girth and kind-girth, (AA, S, K,) to prevent the kindgirth from hurting the animal's viyl, and so causing a suppression of the urine: (AA, TA:) pl. A^azowirapN. (S, K.) In a trad., Ed-Dejjál is described as bound with A^azowirap; meaning, having his arms bound together upon his breast. (IAth.) ― -b2- Also, both words, (tropical:) Anything that is a [means of] rectification to another thing, (K,) and a defence, or protection; (IAar, K;) like the ziyaAr of a beast. (IAar.)
ziyaArN * : see ziwaArN: -A2- and see art. zyr.
zuwayorN * and zawiyrN: see zaworN.
zaw^uwrN * : see what next follows, in two places.

rajulN zaw~aArN * and ↓ zaw^uwrN [A man who visits much]: a poet says,
A_i*aA gaAba EanohaA baEoluhaA lamo A^akuno lahaA
walamo taA^onaso A_ilaY~a kilaAbuhaA ↓ zaw^uwrFA
[When her husband is absent from her, I am not to her a frequent visiter, nor do her dogs become familiar to me]. (TA.)

zaAy^irN * A person visiting; a visiter: (S, * Msb, K: *) fem. zaAy^irapN: (Sb:) pl. zaAy^iruwna, masc., (S, K,) and zaAy^iraAtN, fem., (S, Msb,) and zuw~aArN, masc., (S, Msb, K,) and zaw~arN, masc., (K,) and fem.: (Sb, S, Msb:) and ↓ zaworN signifies the same as zaAy^irN (A, Msb, K, TA) and zaAy^irapN (TA) and zaAy^iruwna (S, A, K, TA) and zaAy^iraAtu; (S, A, Msb, TA;) being originally an inf. n.; or, as syn. with zAy^rwn, it is a quasi-pl. n.; by some called a pl. of zaAy^irN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Ealayoka Haq~FA ↓ A_in~a lizaworika [Verily there is to thy visiter, or visiters, a just claim upon thee]. (TA.) [And hence,] ↓ zaworN also signifies A phantom that is seen in sleep. (K.)
zaAwarapN * : see zaArapN; the former, in two places.
zaAw^uwrapN * : see zaArapN; the former, in two places.

A^azowaru *
Inclining; (K;) crooked; wry; distorted: (A:) [fem. zaworaA='u:] pl. zuwrN. (K.) ― -b2- Having that kind of distortion in the zawor (or middle of the breast [&c.] TA) which is termed zawarN. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A dog whose breast (jawo$anu) Sadorihi) is narrow, (K,) and the kalokal [app. meaning the part between the two collar-bones] projecting, as though his, or its, sides had been squeezed. (TA.) ― -b4- A wry neck. (TA.) ― -b5- [A beast] that looks from the outer angles of his eyes (K) by reason of his vehemence and sharpness of temper: (TA: [see also zaworN:]) or a camel (TA) that goes with an inclination towards one side, when his pace is vehement, though without any distortion in his chest. (K.) [See also ziwar~N. Hence, app.,] Alz~aworaA='u is a name of Certain camels (maAl) that
belonged to Uheyhah (S, K) Ibn-El-Juláh ElAnsáree. (S.) ― -b6- zaworaA='u (tropical:) A bow: (S, A, K:) because of its curving. (S.) ― -b7- (tropical:) A bent bow. (TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) A menáreh (manaArap) deviating from the perpendicular. (A.) ― -b9- (tropical:) A well (biy^or) deep: (S, K, * TA:) or not straightly dug. (TA.) ― -b10- (tropical:) A land, (A^aroD, S, K,) and a desert, (mafaAzap, A, or falaAp, TA,) far-extending, (S, A, K, TA,) and turning aside: (TA:) and A^azowaru is applied [in the same sense] to a country, (TA,) and to an army. (S, TA.) ― -b11- (tropical:) A saying, or phrase, (kalimap,) bad, and crooked, or distorted. (A.) -A2- Also zaworaA='u [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] (assumed tropical:) A [drinking-cup or bowl of the kind called] qadaH. (S, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A certain vessel (K) for drinking, (TA,) oblong, like the talotalap. (TA.) -A3- huwa A^azowaru Eano maqaAmi Al*~ul~i (A) (tropical:) He is most remote from the station, or state, of baseness, or ignominiousness. (TA.)

mazaArN *
A place [and a time] of visiting. (S, Msb.)

mazuwrN *
Visited. (A.)

muzaw~arN * A camel distorted in the breast, or chest, when drawn forth from his mother's belly by the mu*am~ir [q. v.], who therefore presses, or squeezes, it, in order to set it right, but so that an effect of his pressing, or squeezing, remains in him, whereby he is known to be muzaw~ar. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- And kalaAmN muzaw~arN (assumed tropical:) Speech falsified, or embellished with lies. (TA.) And (tropical:) Speech rectified, adjusted, or corrected, [and prepared, (see 2,)] before it is uttered: or beautified, or embellished; as also ↓ mutazaw~arN. (TA.)

muzodaArapN *
Visiters of the tomb of the Prophet. (A.)
mutazaw~arN * : see muzaw~arN.

1 zaAga * , (IDrd, O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, (IDrd, O,) inf. n. zawogN, (IDrd, O, K,) He declined, deviated, swerved, or turned aside, (IDrd, O, K,) from the right course or direction, (IDrd, O,) and from the road; as also zAg, aor. yaziygu, inf. n. zayogN, which latter is the more chaste: (O, TA:) the former is a dial. var. of the latter. (Msb in art. zyg.) ― -b2- And zAg fiY AlmanoTiqi, (Yz, O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, (Yz, O,) inf. n. zawagaAnN, He declined, or deviated, from the right way in speech. (Yz, O, K.) ― -b3- See also 4. -A2- It is also trans.: (O, TA:) you say, zAg qalobahu, (O, K, * TA,) aor. yazuwgu, (O, TA,) He made his heart to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside. (O, K, * TA.) rab~anaA laA tazugo quluwbanaA, with fet-h to the t and damm to the z, [O our Lord, make not our hearts to decline from the right way, in the Kur iii. 6, commonly read tuzigo, (see 4 in art. zyg,)] is an extr. reading of Náfi. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., if it be correct,] zAg Aln~aAqapa, (O, K,) aor. yazuwgu, inf. n. zawogN, (O,) He pulled the she-camel by the nose-rein: (O, K:) so says Ibn- 'Abbád: but [Sgh says,] the verb in this sense is with the unpointed E only; which Ibn-'Abbád states to be the better known. (O, TA.)
3 zaAowaga see what next follows.

4 A^azowaga
AzAghu fiY AlmanoTiqi, inf. n. A_izaAgapN, [He made him to decline, or deviate, from the right way in speech, (see 1,)] and ↓ zawaAgotuhu, inf. n. muzaAwagapN and ziwaAgN, [being mentioned immediately after, without any explanation, seems to signify I made him to decline, or deviate, from the right way therein, like as baAEadotuhu is used in the same sense as A^aboEadotuhu,] (TA,) and bihi ↓ zugotu. (O, TA.)
zaAgN * is said by Sgh to belong to art. zyg [q. v.]. (Msb in the present art.)
A^azowagu * [More, and most, wont to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside, from the right course &c.]. (IJ, TA.)

2 zw~qhu * , (O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tazowiyqN, (Msb, K,) [seems to signify primarily He washed it over with zaAwuwq, i. e. quicksilver; he silvered it therewith.] One says, zw~q Ald~araAhima [He washed over the dirhems with quicksilver]; from Alz~aAwuwqu. (MA.) ― -b2- [Then, He gilded it with an amalgam of quicksilver and gold: see zaAwuwqN. ― -b3- And hence,] He decorated it, and embellished it; namely, a thing [of any kind: and particularly he painted it]: but IF says that zw~qhu, meaning thus, is without foundation; that they say it is from Alz~awuwqu meaning Alziy^obaqu; [as it is said to be in the K;] but that this is [mere] assertion. (O, TA.) [Whether properly or improperly, however,] one says, zaw~aqa Albayota biAlz~aAwuwqi, i. e. He decorated the house, or chamber, [perhaps meaning the House of God, at Mekkeh, i. e. the Kaabeh, as appears to be probable from what here follows,] and changed its colour and its fashion or semblance, with zAwwq, i. e. zy^bq. (Har p. 107.) And it is related in a trad. that he [Mohammad] said to Ibn-'Omar, A_i*aA raA^ayota qurayo$FA qado hadamuwA Albayota vum~a banawohu fazaw~aquwhu faA_ini A@sotaTaEota Almawota famuto [When thou seest Kureysh shall have demolished the House of God, then built it again, and decorated it, if thou be able to die, then die]: he disliked the tazowiyq of mosques because of its inducing desire for the things of the present world, and its finery, or because of its diverting the person praying. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, (TA,) zaw~aqotu AlkalaAma, and AlkitaAba, (assumed tropical:) I embellished the speech, or language, and the writing, or book; and (tropical:) I rectified, or corrected, it. (S, TA.) And zaw~ara fulaAnN kitaAbahu and zaw~aqahu both mean (tropical:) Such a one rectified, or corrected, his writing, or book. (TA.) ― -b5- And zaw~aquwA AljaAriyapa They embellished the girl, or young woman, with nuquw$ [or decorations, app. such as are made by tattooing, or staining with Hin~aA=']: such decoration is termed ↓ zawaAqN, like saHaAbN: and hence, ↓ tazay~aqiY, [Embellish thyself &c.,] said to a woman; [so that it is originally ↓ tazaw~aqiY;] or this is from zyq, [i. e. ziyqN,] with Y. (TA.)
5 tazaw~aqa see the last sentence above, in two places.
zuwaqN * : see zaAwuwqN.
zawaqapN * [pl. of zaAy^iqN, act. part. n. of the unused verb zaAqa,] Decorators, or embellishers, of the ceilings of houses or chambers. (AA, TA.) [See also zaw~aAqN.]
zawaAqN * : see 2, last sentence.

[
zaw~aAqN *
A decorator; an embellisher: and particularly a painter. See also zawaqapN, above.]

zaAwuwqN * , (S, O, K, [in the CK written zAw^uqo, as though it were zaAw^uwqN, the quiescent w being indicated by the sign of sukoon after the dammeh,]) of the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh, (AA, S, O,) i. q. ziy^obaqN [i. e. Quicksilver]; (AA, S, O, K;) as also ↓ zuwaqN; (AA, O, K;) but from what is said by IB, it would seem that this last word is pl. of zaAwuwqN: (TA:) it is used in ↓ tazaAwiyq [meaning decorations, or embellishments, pl. of tazowyqN used as a simple subst., or of the n. un. tazowiyqapN]; (S, O;) and hence, [accord. to some,] Alt~azowiyqu signifying “ the act of decorating, and embellishing; ” (K;) for it is put, together with gold, (S, O, K,) for overlaying therewith, (K,) upon iron, (S, O,) and then it is put into the fire, whereupon the zy^bq [or quicksilver] goes from it [by evaporation], and the gold remains: (S, O, K:) and hence anything decorated, or embellished, is termed ↓ muzaw~aqN, (S, O,) though not having in it zy^bq. (S.)
tazowiyqN * inf. n. of 2. (Msb.) [Used as a simple subst., this, or the n. un. tazowiyqapN, has for its pl. tazaAwiyqu:] see the next preceding paragraph.

muzaw~aqN *
Washed over with [zaAwuwq or] ziy^obaq [i. e. quicksilver]; applied to a dirhem. (TA.) Decorated therewith (TA) [or with an amalgam of quicksilver and gold subjected to the action of fire so that the quicksilver is evaporated]. ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) Anything decorated, or embellished, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) though not having in it ziy^obaq. (S, O.) See zaAwuwqN. ― -b3- Also, applied to speech, or language, (assumed tropical:) Embellished: (Kr, TA:) and applied to a book, or writing, [in the same sense: (see 2:) or] as meaning (tropical:) rectified, or corrected; like muzaw~arN. (AZ, TA.)

1 zaAla * , aor. yazuwlu, (K,) and, accord. to the K, also yazaAlu, which is rare, on the authority of Aboo- 'Alee, but this is the aor. of zaAla like xaAfa, [which has a different meaning from the former verb,] (MF, TA,) inf. n. zawaAlN (K) and zuwuwlN (Lh, K) [which in all its senses except one mentioned below may app. be pronounced also zuw^uwlN, like Huw^uwlN for HuwuwlN, pl. of HawolN,] and zawiylN and zawolN, (K, TA,) the last thus, with fet-h, accord. to a rule of the K, but in some of the copies zuwlN, with damm, (TA,) and zawalaAnN, (K,) It went away; passed away; departed; removed; shifted; (K, TA;) was, or became, remote, or absent; ceased to be or exist, or came to nought; (TA;) as also ↓ Aizowal~a, inf. n. AizowilaAlN; (K;) or, accord. to the O, ↓ AizowaA^al~a, like AiTomaA^an~a. (TA.) [See also 7.] Hence,
Ald~unoyaA wa$iykapu Alz~awaAli [The world, or worldly enjoyment or good, is quick in passing away, or coming to nought]. (TA.) And zAl zawaAluhu, and zawaAluhaA: see zawaAlN: and for the former see also zawiylN. And zAl zawiyluhu, and zawiyluhaA: see zawiylN. And zAl Al$~aYo'u Eano makaAnihi, (S, TA,) or mawoDiEihi, (Msb,) aor. yazuwlu, inf. n. zawaAlN (S, Msb, TA) &c., as above, (TA,) The thing removed, went away, [or ceased,] from its place; it left, or quitted, its place. (TA.) And zulotu Eano makaAniY, inf. n. zawaAlN and zuwuwlN, [I went away, &c., from my place.] (K.) [And zAl Eanohu, said of any affection of the mind or body, It went away, passed away, or ceased, from him; it left him, or quitted him.] And zaAluwA Eano makaAnihimo They turned away from their place; or returned, or went back, and fled, from it. (TA.) And zAl Eani Alr~aA^oYi, aor. yazuwlu, inf. n. zuwuwlN, [He turned, or swerved, from the opinion, or judgment, or sentiment.] (Lh, TA.) And zAl alone, aor. yazuwlu, He, or it, quitted his, or its, place. (AHeyth, TA.) And He removed from one town, or country, to another. (TA.) And zAlt Alxayolu birukobaAnihaA, (K,) inf. n. ziyaAlN, (TA,) The horses removed from their place with their riders. (K, TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but I see not why.]) ― -b2- Hence, zAlt Al$~amosu, inf. n. zawaAlN and zuwuwlN, without ', (K,) as Th says, (TA,) and ziyaAlN and zawalaAnN, (tropical:) The sun declined from the meridian. (K, TA.) [And sometimes it signifies (assumed tropical:) The sun set: see 1 in art. dlk.] ― -b3- And hence, but not with zuwuwlN for an inf. n. in the senses expl. in this sentence and the next following it, (TA,) zAl Aln~ahaAru, (K, TA,) inf. n. zawaAlN (TA) [and app. ziyaAlN and zawalaAnN], (tropical:) (tropical:) The day became advanced, the sun being somewhat high; syn. AirotafaEa: (K, TA:) or, as some say, went away; or departed. (TA.) And zAl AlZ~il~u, (TA,) or AlZ~il~i ↓ zAl zaAy^ilu, (K, TA,) (tropical:) (tropical:) The sun became high, and the shade contracted, or decreased, or went away, at midday. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- zAl ZEnhm, [thus in the TK (ed. of Boolák), i. e. ZaEonuhumo, thus in the K, and thus only, the verb being indicated by a preceding phrase; in the TA zAlt ZEnhm. which is an evident mistranscription;] inf. n. zayoluwlapN, (K,) like qayoluwlapN [an inf. n. of qaAla, aor. yaqiylu; but more properly compared to dayomuwmapN, an inf. n. of daAma, aor. yaduwmu]; (TA;) [a phrase which may be rendered Their journeying ceased for a while;] expl. as meaning Aiy^otawawoA makaAnahumo vum~a badaA lahumo [i. e. they abode in their place: then an opinion occurred to them different from their former opinion, so that it turned them therefrom, inducing them to remove]: (K:) in the K is added Eanohu; but this should be omitted: the passage is taken from the M; in which Eanohu refers to Lh as the authority. (TA.) ― -b5- zAl [having for its inf. n., app., zawaAlN and zawiylN and zawolN (see the first of these below)] signifies also It moved; or was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; syn. taHar~aka: so in the saying, raA^ayotu $abaHFA vum~a zaAla [I saw a bodily form or figure: then it moved, &c.]. (TA.) And one says, huwa yazuwlu fiYAln~aAsi, meaning He moves much among men, or the people, and does not remain still, or stationary. (TA.) ― -b6- zaAlato lahu ↓ zaAy^ilapN means $axaSa lahu $axoSN [A figure seen from a distance rose to his view]. (TA.) ― -b7- And zAl bihi Als~araAbu The mirage raised, or elevated, (rafaEa,) and made apparent, him, or it. (TA.) -A2- maA zaAla yafoEalu ka*aA &c.: see in art. zyl. -A3- zAl, aor. yazuwlu, also signifies He affected acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence: or did so, not having it: syn. taZar~afa. (IAar, TA.) [See also 5.] -A4- [As a trans. verb, it belongs to art. zyl, and app. to the present art. also.] See 4. You say, zAl zawaAlahu, or zAl A@ll~`hu zawalahu; and zAl zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN. And ziyla zawiyluhu and zawiyluhaA and zawaAluhu: see zawiylN: and for the first, see also zawaAlN. ― -b2- And zAlhu He separated himself from him; (K;) as also zAylhu. (S and K in art zyl [to which the latter exclusively belongs.])
2 zaw~ala see 4: ― -b2- and see also 5.

3 zAwlhu * , inf. n. muzaAwalapN (S, K) and ziwaAlN, (K,) i. q. EaAlajahu [as meaning He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, or it, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object: and accord. to the KL and PS and some other lexicons, it signifies also he treated him medically; which is another meaning of EAljh; but of this meaning I have not found any ex.]: and HaAwalahu [as meaning he sought to obtain it, or effect it; or did so by artful, or skilful, management]: (S, * K:) and TaAlabahu [he made a demand on him, or prosecuted a claim upon him]. (K.) [Accord. to the TA, it seems to be used properly in relation to real things, and tropically in relation to ideal things. One says, zAwl AlS~ayoda He strove to gain possession of, or to catch, i. e. he hunted, the animals of the chase. (See Tarada.)] And zaAwalotuhu Eani AlA^amoru [I strove with him to avert him, or to turn him back, from the affair]. (S, in art. jHs.) Zuheyr says,
fabitonaA wuquwfFA Einoda raA^osi jawaAdinaA
yuzaAwilunaA Eano nafosihi wanuzaAwiluho
[And we passed the night standing at the head of our courser, he striving with us to repel us from himself, and we striving with him to master him]. (S.) And a man said to another, who upbraided him with cowardice, waA@ll~`hu maA kunotu jabaAnFA wal`kin~iY zaAwalotu mulokFA muw^aj~alFA (assumed tropical:) [By God I was not a coward, but I strove, or sought, to preserve a possession appointed for a fixed time; i. e., to preserve my life though its term is fixed: see the Kur iii. 139]. (S.) One says also, yuzaAwilu HaAjapF lahu i. e. yuHaAwiluhaA (tropical:) [He seeks to accomplish a thing that is an object of want to him; or does so by artful, or skilful, management]: a tropical phrase. (TA.) And malilotu muzaAwalapa h`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) [I loathed, or was averse from, striving, or seeking, to accomplish this affair]. (TA.)

4 AzAlhu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_izaAlapN; (TA;) and ↓ zw~lhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazowiylN; (O, TA;) and ↓ AizodaAlahu, [originally AizotaAlahu,] inf. n. AizodiyaAlN (O,) this being syn. with A_izaAlapN; (K;) He removed it; made it to go away, pass away, depart, remove, or shift; (O, K, TA;) [and made it to cease to be or exist, or to come to nought: did away with it; annulled it: effaced, or obliterated, it:] and ↓ zilotuhu, aor. A^azaAluhu and A^aziyluhu, [which see in art. zyl,] signifies the same as A^azalotuhu and zaw~alotuhu. (K.) You say, AzAlhu Eani AlmawoDiEi He removed it from the place. (MA: and the like is said in the K.) [And AzAl Eanohu ka*aA He removed from him such a thing; made it to go away, pass away, or cease, from him; or to leave him, or quit him; he freed him from it, or rid him of it. And AzAlhu En raA^oyihi He, or it, made him to turn, or swerve, from his opinion, or judgment, or sentiment.] And AzAl A@ll~`hu zawaAlahu and zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN. [See also 4 in art. zyl.]

5 tzw~lhu * and ↓ zw~lhu i. q. A^ajaA='ahu [He made him, or it, to come]: so says AAF, on the authority of AZ: in the copies of the K, erroneously, A^ajaAdahu. (TA.) -A2- And tzw~l, (K,) said of a young man, (TA,) He attained the utmost degree of acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, or of cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence. (K.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]

6 tzAwlwA *
i. q. taEaAlajuwA [They laboured, exerted themselves, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, one with another, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object]. (S, K. [See also 3.])

7 AnzAl *
It was, or became, removed; or made to go away, pass away, depart, remove, or shift. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- And AnzAl Eanohu He became separated from him. (K.) [See also 7 in art. zyl.]
8 AzdAlhu * : see 4, first sentence.
9 Azwl~ * : see 1, first sentence.

10 A_isotazowala [AistzAlhu He looked at it to see if it quitted its place.] One says, AisotaHilo h`*aA Al$~axoSa waA@sotazilohu, meaning Look thou at this figure seen from a distance to see if it move and if it quit its place. (AHeyth, O, TA.)
Q. Q. 4 AizowaA^al~a * : see 1, first sentence.

zawolN * an inf. n. of 1 in the first of the senses expl. above. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also zawaAlN. -A2- As an epithet applied to a man, (S,) Light, agile, or active: acute or sharp or quick in intellect, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (S, K:) at whose acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, &c., one wonders: (ISk, S:) fem. with p; (S, K;) said to mean skilful, knowing, or intelligent, (S, TA,) as also the masc., (TA,) and cunning: (S, TA:) and a servant-girl who is sharp and effective in the conveying of messages: and applied to a woman as meaning barozapN lilr~ijaAli [who goes or comes forth to men, and with whom they sit, and of whom they talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and is intelligent; &c.: see art. brz]:
(TA:) pl. masc. A^azowaAlN (K, TA) and fem. zawolaAtN; the former applied to young men, and the latter to young women. (TA.) ― -b2- Courageous; (K, TA;) in consequence of whose courage, men are abashed (yatazaAyaluwA [as though zawolN in this sense belonged to art. zyl]). (TA.) ― -b3- And Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (K, * TA:) pl. A^azowaAlN. (TA.) -A3- (tropical:) A wonder, or wonderful thing: (S, K, TA:) pl. A^azowaAlN. (S.) One says, h`*aA zawolN mina AlA^azowaAli (tropical:) This is a wonder of the wonders. (TA.) And one says also, [using it as an epithet,] sayorN zawolN (assumed tropical:) A journeying, or pace, wonderful in respect of its quickness and briskness or lightness: and $atowapN zawolapN (assumed tropical:) A winter, or winters, wonderful in respect of the severity and cold thereof. (TA.) [See also A^azowalu.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A trial, or an affliction; syn. balaA='N. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A form, or figure, that appears in the night [and by which one is frightened: see muzaAwalN]. (TA.) (tropical:) A form, or figure, of a man or some other thing, that one sees from a distance: or a person: syn. $axoSN: (K, TA:) as also ↓ zaAy^ilapN: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. (TA.) -A4- The faroj [i. e. the anterior pudendum, or the pudenda,] of a man. (K.) One says, ka$afa zawolahu [He uncovered his frj]. (TK.) -A5- And A hawk. (K.)

zawaAlN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ zawiylN and ↓ zawolN (K) are inf. ns. of zaAla [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And all signify Motion, commotion, or agitation. (TA in explanation of the first and last, and K in explanation of the second.)
