[Hence,] ↓ zaAla zawaAluhu, or zawaAlahu ↓ zaAla, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or A@ll~`hu zawaAlahu ↓ zaAla, (S in art. zyl, and TA,) and A@ll~`hu zawaAlahu ↓ A^azaAla, (S in art. zyl, and K and TA,) are imprecations of destruction, or perdition, or death, (S, K,) and trial, or affliction, upon him to whom they relate: (S:) or such are the [second and] third and fourth of these phrases: but the first is a prayer for one's continuance where he is, [or his continuance in life; lit.] meaning May his motion cease; [and hence, may he continue where he is, or continue in life:] and, as expl. by ISk, the [second and] third and fourth [lit.] signify May [He i. e.] God cause his motion to cease; [and hence, may He, or God, put an end to his life;] these phrases being similar to the saying A^asokata A@ll~`hu naAm~atahu. (TA.) [Thus all four have virtually the same lit. signification. And the first has also another meaning; as will be seen below.] El-Aashà says,
h`*aA Aln~ahaAru badaA lahaA mino ham~ihaA
zawaAlahaA ↓ maA baAluhaA biAll~ayoli zaAla
(S, TA,) [app. meaning This is the day-time: an opinion has arisen in her mind such as to turn her from her former opinion and induce her to absent herself, (badaA='N, I suppose, being understood after badaA lahaA, like as it is after badaA lahumo in the Kur xii. 35,) in consequence of her anxiety: what will be her case in the night? may it (her phantom) be absent, like as she is absent: for] the meaning is said to be, zaAla AlxayaAlu zawaAlahaA: IAar says, he disliked the phantom only because it roused his desire: or [zaAla may be here syn. with A^azaAla, so that] the meaning may be A@ll~`hu zawaAlahaA ↓ A^azaAla [may God make her motion to cease]; and this is corroborated by the reading of AA, zawaAluhaA, in the nom. case, [i. e. zawaAluhaA ↓ zaAla may her motion cease;] which makes this an instance of [the license termed] AlA_iqowaA=': this, he says, is an old proverbial phrase of the Arabs, and El-Aashà has used it as he heard it: others than AA read [zawaAlahaA,] in the accus. case, without A_iqowaA=', holding the meaning to be, may her phantom be absent from us in the night like as she herself is absent in the day-time. (TA.) ↓ zawiyluhu ↓ ziyla, likewise, means His motion ceased, or may his motion cease: or, accord. to Z, he became fixed, or motionless, from fear; or may he become so. (TA in art. zyl.) [See also another rendering of this phrase in the next paragraph.] One says also, waAlEawiylu ↓ A^axa*ahu Alz~awiylu Commotion, or agitation, (K, TA,) and disquietude of mind, (TA,) and wailing, or raising of the voice in weeping, overcame him. (K, TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

zawiylN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. -A2- Also The side; syn. jaAnibN; and so ↓ zawaAlN: thus in the sayings, zawiyluhu ↓ zaAla and ↓ zawaAluhu ↓ zaAla, meaning [app. His side became in a state of commotion, or it quivered,] by reason of fright: (K:) [or] zawiylN signifies the heart: so in the saying, zawiyluhu ↓ ziyla [His heart became removed from its place]: (S:) a prov., applied to one whom an event that has disquieted him has befallen: as also ↓ zawaAluhu ↓ ziyla: (Meyd:) [see also two other renderings of the former phrase in the next preceding paragraph:] Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing the egg of an ostrich,
wayayoDaA='u laA tanoHaA$u min~aA waA^um~uhaA
min~aA zawiyluhaA ↓ A_i*aA maA raA^atonaA ziyla
meaning ziyla qalobuhaA mina AlfazaEi [i. e. And a white thing (the egg which he is describing) will not take fright, and flee from us, or will not shrink from us, while its mother, when she sees us, her heart becomes removed from its place by fright in consequence of the approach of us]: (S in art. zyl, and Meyd:) or, as some relate it, min~aA ↓ zaAla zawiyluhaA [which means her heart quits its place &c.]: (TA:) and the former reading may mean the same as this. (IB, TA in art. zyl.)

zaw~aAlN *
Having much zawol, i. e. motion. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to J, it occurs in an A^urojuwzap, cited by AA, as meaning That moves much in his gait, but traverses a short space: but the right word in this case is zaw~aAk, as is shown by the rhyme. (IB, K.)

zwylY * , with damm, [app. zuw~ayolaY, like qub~ayoTaY &c., for, as it is not said to be a dim., I know no other form of word with which to compare it,] A thing like a ladle, belonging to sailors. (TA.)

zaAy^ilN * [Going away; passing away; departing; transient; shifting; becoming remote, or absent; ceasing to be or exist; nonexistent: &c.: part. n. of zaAla, q. v.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] layolN zaAy^ilu Aln~ujuwmi [properly A starless night, or night of which the stars are absent: but expl. as meaning] (assumed tropical:) a long night. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- zaAla zaAy^ilu AlZ~il~i: see 1.

zaAy^ilapN * [from zaAy^ilN, the p being affixed to transfer the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives,] Whatever has a soul, (K, TA,) of animals; that moves (yazuwlu) from its place: (TA:) or anything that moves; (K, TA;) that does not remain fixed in its place; applied to a man and to other things. (TA.) ― -b2- zawaAy^ilu is its pl.: (TA:) and signifies [particularly] Animals of the chase. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) Women. (O, K, TA.) One says rajulN raAmiY Alz~awaAy^ili (assumed tropical:) A man knowing in respect of the diseases, or faults, (A^adowaA=',) of women: (O:) or (tropical:) skilful in the making of women to incline to him: whence the saying of Ibn-Meiyádeh,
wakunotu A@moraA^F A^aromiY Alz~awaAy^ila mar~apF
faA^aSobaHotu qado wadaEotu ramoYa Alz~awaAy^ili
(tropical:) [And I was a man having the art of making women to incline to me, once; but I have become such that I have relinquished the art of making women to incline to me]: this was a man who used to beguile women in his time of youthful vigour by his beauty; but when he became hoary and aged, no woman inclined to him. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) The stars: (K, TA:) because of their motion from the east and the west in their revolving. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph; and zawolN, last sentence but three.

zawolN A^azowalu * (S, * TA) has an intensive signification [i. e. (assumed tropical:) A great wonder; or a very wonderful thing]: (TA:) [or a wonderful event that happens to one, preventing his fleeing;] accord. to Abu-sSemh, A^azowalu denotes the happening to one of an event such as prevents him from fleeing. (IB, TA.)

mizowalapN *
A certain instrument pertaining to astronomers, by means of which is known the declining of the sun from the meridian: [a sun-dial: used in this sense in the present day:] a vulgar term: pl. mazaAwilu. (TA.)

muzaAwalN * pass. part. n. of 3: one says, maA zaAla h`*aA AlA^amoru muzaAwalFA biA^ayodiyhimo (assumed tropical:) [This affair ceased not to be striven, or sought, to be accomplished by means of their hands]. (TA.) -A2- Also Frightened by a zawol, i. e. a form, or figure, appearing in the night. (TA.)

1 zawVna [zaAnahu, aor. yazuwnuhu, is a dial. var. of zaAnahu having for its aor. yaziynuhu.] An Arab woman of the desert is related to have said to IAar, A_in~aka latazuwnunaA A_i*aA TalaEota, meaning taziynunaA [i. e. Verily thou gracest us when thou comest to us (EalayonaA)]. (TA.)

zaAnN *
Indigestion; syn. ba$amN; for Aln~a$amu in the copies of the K is a mistranscription for Alba$amu; (TA;) expl. by Ed-Dubeyreeyeh as syn. with tuxomapN; as in the phrase, layosa ya$okuw Alz~aAna [He does not complain of indigestion]: (Fr, TA:) and so
↓ zaAnapN: (K and TA in art. zyn:) or this signifies a single fit of indigestion. (TA in that art.) -A2- [In the present day, applied to The beech-tree; and its wood: as a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: see also zaAnapN below.]
zawonN * : see ziwan~N.

zuwnN *
An idol: and anything that is taken as a deity and worshipped, (S, K, * TA,) beside God: as also zuwrN: [an arabicized word:] in Pers. \x{698}uwno. (TA.) ― -b2- And A place in which idols are collected and set up. (K.) It is said to be from ziynapN. (TA.) [But it may rather be from zuwnapN as a dial. var. of ziynapN.] -A2- See also ziwan~N.

zaAnapN *
A thing like a mizoraAq [or javelin], which the Deylem (Ald~ayolam) cast: [perhaps made of the wood of the beech, (see zaAnN, latter sentence,) and therefore so called:] pl. zaAnaAtN. (Msb.) -A2- See also zaAnN, former sentence.

zuwnapN *
i. q. ziynapN [An ornament, &c.], (K,) in one of the dialects. (TA.) ― -b2- And An intelligent woman. (IAar, K.)

ziwan~N *
Short; (S, K;) applied to a man; (S;) and so, thus applied, ↓ zawonN and ↓ zuwnN, (K,) of which two, the former is the more known: (TA:) fem. ziwan~apN, (S, K,) applied to a woman. (S.)
zuwaAnN * and ziwaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and zawaAnN (K) i. q. zuw^aAnN [q. v. in art. zA^n]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

TaEaAmN mazuwnN *
Wheat in which is zuwaAn [or the grain of a certain noxious weed, app. darnel-grass: mzwn being a pass. part. n. of which no verb is mentioned]. (TA.)

1 zawaAhu * , (K,) aor. yazowiyhi, (TA,) inf. n. zaY~N and zuwiY~N, (K, TA,) the latter [accord. to the CK zawoYN, but it is correctly] like EutiY~N, (TA,) He put it aside, or away, or apart; or removed it from its place. (K.) You say, zawaYa Eanohu ka*aA, inf. n. zuwiY~N, He averted, diverted, or removed, from him such a thing; turned, put, or sent, it away, or back, from him. (TA.) ― -b2- And zawaY sir~ahu Eanohu He concealed his secret from him. (K.) ― -b3- Also (K) zawaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. zaY~N, (Msb, TA,) He drew it, collected it, or gathered it, together; contracted it, or grasped it. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., zuwiyato liYa AlA^aroDu faA^oriytu ma$aAriqahaA wamagaAribahaA [The earth was collected together to me, and I was shown its eastern parts and its western parts]. (S, TA.) And you say, zawaY AlmaAla, (S, Msb,) inf. n. zaY~N, (S,) He drew, or collected, together, or he grasped, the property, (Msb,) Eano waArivihi [from its inheritor]. (S.) And zawaY maA bayona Eayonayohi (S, TA) He (a man, S) drew together, or contracted, the part between his eyes. (TA.) And jaA='anaA biSarobapK tazowiY Alwajoha [He brought us some very sour milk such as contracts the face, or makes it to wrinkle]. (S in art. Srb.) And tazowiY Alwujuwha said of a cold north wind, It contracts [or wrinkles] the faces: a phrase used by Tarafeh Ibn-El-'Abd. (Ham p. 632.)

2 zw~Y * , inf. n. tazowiyapN: see 5. -A2- zay~ayotuhu, (S, Msb, K,) which by rule should be zaw~ayotuhu, (S, Msb,) but is made to accord with ziY~N in order to facilitate the pronunciation, (Msb,) inf. n. accord. to the K tazoyiyapN, but correctly, as Lth says, taziy~apN, in measure like taHiy~apN, (TA,) I invested him with, or made him to have, a ziY~ [i. e. garb, guise, &c.]; (S, * Msb, K, * TA;) by means of, or with, such a thing: you say, zay~ayotuhu bika*aA [which may be rendered I invested, decked, or adorned, him with such a thing; agreeably with what follows]. (Msb.) Accord. to Fr, they say, zay~ayotu AljaAriyapa, meaning I invested the girl, or young woman, with a garb, or guise, &c.; and decked, or adorned, her. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, zw~Y AlkalaAma, meaning He prepared the speech in his mind; like zaw~arahu. (TA.) -A3- zay~ayotu zaAyFA and zaw~ayotu zaAyFA [mean I wrote, or uttered, a z]: some [hold the A in zAY to be originally Y, and therefore] say zay~ayotu: others [hold it to be originally w, and therefore] say zaw~ayotu. (IB, on the letter A^alif.) Zeyd Ibn-Thábit said, in relation to the expression in the Kur [ii. 261] nuno$izuhaA, [accord. to one reading, or reciting,] hiYa zaAYN fazay~ihaA, meaning [It is zAY, therefore make thou it zAY in thy reading, or reciting; or] read thou it, or recite thou it, with the zAY. (S.)
4 AzwY * : see art. zw.

5 tzw~Y *
He was, or became, [or placed himself,] in a zaAwiyap, i. e. corner, of a house or chamber; as also ↓ zw~Y, (K,) inf. n. tazowiyapN; (TA;) and ↓ AnzwY. (K.) -A2- tazay~aA, from Alz~iY~u; (K, KL;) or tazay~aA biziY~K; (Lth, MA;) He invested himself with a garb, guise, or dress; [or with an external appearance;] (MA, KL;) he decked, or adorned, himself. (MA.) You say of a man, tzy~A biziY~K HasanK [He invested himself with a beautiful, or goodly, garb, &c.]. (Lth, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Mutanebbee,
waqado yatazay~aA biAlhawaY gayoru A^aholihi
wayasotaSoHibu AlA_inosaAnu mano laA yulaAy^imuho
(TA:) i. e. [And verily, or sometimes, or often, one who is not entitled to it] assumes the guise of love; and the man asks to be his companion him who is not suited to him: (W p. 374:) his disciple Ibn-Jinnee, however, objected to him his saying ytzy~A, and expressed his opinion that the correct word is yatazaw~aY; and El-Mutanebbee admitted that he did not know the former word in any [classical] poetry, nor in any lexicological book, but asserted the verb in use to be only tazay~aA: (MF, TA:) in the M it is said that IJ held tazay~aA to be originally tazawoyaA, and the w to be changed into Y because quiescent, and incorporated into the Y preceded by it. (TA.)

7 AnzwY *
It was, or became, put aside, or away, or apart; or removed from its place. (K.) ― -b2- Ainozawati Aljilodapu fiYAln~aAri The piece of skin became contracted, or shrivelled, or shrunk, in the fire. (S.) And AnzwY maA bayona Eayonayohi The part between his eyes became drawn together, or contracted. (TA.) And AnzwY Alqawomu baEoDuhumo A_ilaY baEoDK The people, or party, drew together, one portion of them to another portion. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5, first sentence.
zaA * and zFA and zaA='N and see zaAYN, below.
zaYo * and zaY~N: see zaAYN, below.

ziY~N * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally ziwoYN, (S, Msb,) Garb, guise, dress, habit, fashion of dress, and aspect, or outward appearance; syn. libaAsN, (S, TA,) and hayoy^apN, (Fr, Msb, K, TA,) and manoZarN: (Fr, TA:) pl. A^azoyaA='N. (K.) [In the Kur xix. 75,] some read A^aHosanu A^avaAvFA waziy~FA [Better in respect of household-goods and in respect of garb, &c.]: others read riy~FA, with r: (TA:) and riy^oyFA: and riyoy^FA: and riyFA. (Bd.)

zaAYN * , (Kr, S, K, &c.,) in which the A, accord. to Lth, is originally Y, but accord. to Sb and IJ it is w, (TA,) A certain letter (i. e. z); (S, TA;) [in spelling, pronounced zaAYo; and] also called ↓ zaA='N, (Kr, S, K,) and ↓ zFA, and [in spelling (see the first sentence of art. b)] ↓ zaA, (Kr, K, but omitted in some copies of the K,) this last being indecl., (Kr, TA,) and ↓ zaY~N (K) and [in spelling] ↓ zaYo: (Kr, K:) of all which, the first is that which is held in [most] repute: (TA:) and this and zaA='N may be meant by J's saying, Alz~aAYu HarofN yumad~u wayuqoSaru walaA yukotabu A_il~aA biyaA='K baEoda AlA^alifi; though the author of the K asserts J to have erred in saying this: (MF, TA:) the pl. is A^azowaA='N and A^azoyaA='N, (Kudot;,) the former or the latter accord. to different opinions, (TA,) and A^azowK and A^azoYK, (K,) each [originally] of the measure A^afoEulN. (TA.) One says, h`*ihi zaAYN HasanapN [This is a beautiful; z]: and katabotu zaAyFA SagiyrapF [I wrote a small; z]: and the like. (IJ, TA.) -A2- zaAYo is also said by the vulgar on an occasion of wonder, and of disapproval: but [SM says,] I know not what is its origin. (TA.) [It may be from the Pers. zaYo, or zihiY; which are likewise said on an occasion of wonder. A_iz~aAYo and A_iz~aY~ and A_iz~aYo, and with A^a in the place of A_i, are also said by the vulgar in Egypt on an occasion of wonder, and of denial, meaning How? And zaYo is used by them for the prefix ka, meaning Like.]
zuway~apN * : see what next follows.

zuyay~apN * dim. of zaAY~N [accord. to those who hold the A in the latter to be originally Y, or ↓ zuway~apN accord. to those who hold that letter to be originally w; like A^uyay~apN and A^uway~apN as dims. of A='N accord. to different opinions: see art. A, in the middle of the first column]. (TA.)

zaAwiyapN *
A corner, or an angle, (rukon,) of a house or room or the like: (K:) of the measure faAEilapN from zawaY signifying jamaEa; because of its em-
bracing (liA^an~ahaA jamaEato) a part, or portion, (quTorFA,) thereof: (Msb, TA:) pl. zawaAyaA [which is irreg.; for by rule it should be zawaA='K, being originally of the measure fawaAEilu, not faEaAy^ilu]. (S, K.) They say, kamo fiY Alz~awaAyaA mina AlxabaAyaA [How many hidden things are there in the corners!]. (TA.) ― -b2- [In geometry, An angle. ― -b3- And hence, zaAwiyapu AlEaw~aA='i The star γ of Virgo; AlEaw~aA='u being composed of four stars, γ,δ,ε and η of Virgo, disposed nearly in the form of a capital L, with ε, δ, γ from top to bottom and η to the right. ] ― -b4- In a saying cited voce raAwiyapN, the pl. zawaAyaA is used as meaning Houses, or tents. (T in art. rwY.) ― -b5- [And in the present day, the term zaAwiyapN is also applied to A small mosque, or chapel: and in some instances, a building of this kind, thus called, serves as a hospice, or an asylum for poor Muslims, students and others; like ribaATN.]
1 zuY~a * , or ziY~a: see art. zw.
2 zay~ayotu * : see 2 in art. zwY, in two places.
5 tazay~aA * : see 5 in art. zwY.
zaYo * : see zaAYN, in art. zwY.
ziY ziY * an onomatopoeia significant of The sound of the jinn, or genii. (TA.) [See also ziyzamN and ziyziymN, in art. zm.]
zaY~N * : see zaAYN, in art. zwY.
ziY~N * : see art. zwY.
zuyay~apN * : see art. zwY.

A^azoyabu * is of the measure A^afoEalu, (S,) like A^aHomaru: (K:) or, as some say, of the measure faEoyal; but this is a weak assertion, for it is said that there is no Arabic word of this measure; maroyamu being a foreign proper name, and DahoyaA^ being disputed. (MF, TA.) [In some of its senses it is an epithet, and used as such: in some, app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: and in some, a simple subst.: but in all its senses it is imperfectly decl.; and therefore seems to be originally an epithet.] ― -b2- Brisk, lively, sprightly, agile, or quick. (K.) ― -b3- A man who walks with short steps: (TA:) and short in stature and in step; (K, TA;) likewise applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b4- Ignoble, base, or base-born. (K.) The offspring of fornication or adultery; or the offspring of fornication, begotten on a slave. (Abu-l-Mekárim, TA.) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; or one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; or who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; syn. daEiY~N. (S, K.) ― -b5- A devil: (K:) accord. to some, a dial. var. of A^azab~u. (TA.) ― -b6- The hedge-hog. (IAar, K.) ― -b7- A disagreeable, a disapproved, or an abominable, thing or affair. (K.) ― -b8- A calamity, or misfortune. (K.) ― -b9- Much water: (AA, S:) and so A^a*oyabu. (K in art. *yb.) ― -b10- [A south-easterly wind; i. e.] the [wind termed] nakobaA=' [q. v.] that blows between the SabaA and the januwb: (S, M, K:) or the south wind, or a southerly wind; syn. januwbN; (M, K;) of the dial. of Hudheyl; so affirm Mbr in his “ Kámil ” and IF and Et-Tarábulusee: IAth says that the people of Mekkeh use this appellation much; and it is related to be God's name for what men call the jnwb: Sh says that the people of El-Yemen, and those who voyage upon the sea between Juddah and 'Adan, cali the jnwb by the name of AlA^azoyabu, and know not any other name for it; and that is because it is boisterous, and stirs up the sea, turning it upsidedown: [whence it seems to mean the boisterous, or violent:] ISh says that *aAtu A^azoyaba signifies any violent wind. (L,TA.) ― -b11- [Hence it appears that it signifies also Violence.] ― -b12- Also Enmity. (S, K.) ― -b13- And Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, agility, or quickness: (ISk, S, K, TA:) [see also A^a*oyabu:] it is fem.: one says, mar~a fulaAnN walahu A^azoyabu munokarapN [Such a one passed having a disapproved briskness, &c.]: this is said when one passes quickly by reason of briskness, &c. (ISk, S.) ― -b14- And Fear, or fright: (AZ, S, K:) and so A^a*oyabu. (K in art. *yb.) One says, A^axa*aniY mino fulaAnK AlA^azoyabu [Fear, or fright, arising from such a one, seized me]. (AZ, S.)

1 zaAtahu * , aor. yaziytuhu, [inf. n. zayotN,] He anointed him, or it, with zayot, i. e. oil of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (Msb.) You say, zit~N, meaning I anointed my head, and the head of another, with oil of the zytwn. (L.) ― -b2- And zit~uhu, (Lh, S, K,) aor. A^aziytuhu, (S, K, TA, in the CK Aazit~uh, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) inf. n. zayotN, (K,) I put zayot [i. e. olive-oil] into it; namely, the food; (S, K;) or the crumbled bread: or I prepared it therewith: (TA:) or I moistened it, or stirred it about, or moistened and mixed it, with zyt; namely, bread, and crumbled bread. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- And zaAtahumo (Lh, S, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] zaA^atahumo) He fed them with zayot: (Lh, K:) or he made zyt to be the seasoning of their food. (S.)

2 zay~atahumo *
He furnished them with zayot [i. e. olive-oil] for travelling-provision; (Lh, S, A;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lh, TA.)

4 A^azaAtuwA * (in the CK [erroneously] AazoiAatuwA) They had much zayot [i. e. olive-oil]; their zayot became much; (Lh, K;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lh, TA.)
8 AizodaAta * [so in the TA and in my MS copy of the K; in the CK, erroneously, AizodaA^ata;] He anointed himself with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (K.)

10 AstzAt *
He sought, or demanded, zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (K.) You say, jaAw^uwA yasotaziytuwna They came asking for zayot as a gift; (S, L;) or seeking, or demanding, zyt. (A.)

zayotN * The oil, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or expressed juice, (M, TA,) or mux~ [i. e. best, or choicest, of the constituents], (A, TA,) of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) [In the present day it is applied to Any oil.]

zayotuwnN * [The olive-tree;] a certain kind of tree, (Msb, K, *) well known, (S, Msb,) whence zayot is obtained; (S, Msb, K;) [a tree] of the kind called EiDaAh; (AHn, Mgh, TA;) As says, on the authority of 'Abd-El-Melik Ibn-Sálih Ibn-'Alee, that a single tree of this kind lasts thirty thousand years; and that every tree of this kind in Palestine was planted by the ancient Greeks who are called the Yoonánees: (TA:) and the fruit of that tree: (Mgh:) or it has the latter signification, and is tropically applied to the tree: or it properly has both of these significations: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (S, TA:) accord. to some, the n is a radical letter, and the Y is augmentative, because they said ArD ztnp [i. e. A^aroDN zatinapN, like A^aroDN EaDihapN from AlEiDaAhu], meaning “ a land in which are zayotuwn; ” so that the measure is fayoEuwlN; and if so, its proper place is art. ztn. (TA.) Respecting the phrase in the Kur xcv. l, waAlt~iyni waAlz~ayotuwni, see tiynN. ― -b2- [zayotuwnu baniY A_isoraAy^iyla Lapis Judaicus: so called because resembling an olive in shape, and found in Judæa.]

[
zayotuwniY~N *
Of, or relating to, the olive: olivecoloured.]

zay~aAtN *
One who sells, or expresses, zayot [i. e. olive-oil, and, vulgarly, any oil]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaA='a fulaAnN fiY viyaAbi zay~aAtK (assumed tropical:) Such a one came in dirty clothes. (A.)
maziytN * and ↓ mazoyuwtN Food into which zayot [i. e. olive-oil] has been put: (S, A, K:) or prepared therewith. (TA.)
mazoyuwtN * : see what next precedes.
muzodaAtN * A man anointing himself, or who anoints himself, with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (TA.)
muzayotiytN * dim. of muzodaAtN. (TA.)

ziyj * The builder's string, or line, (K in art. zwj, improperly there mentioned, TA,) which he extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones, or bricks, of the building; syn. miTomarN [q. v.]: (TA:) [also called ziyqN:] an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Pers.] ziho, signifying “ a bowstring: ” so in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel. ” (TA.) ― -b2- Also, as is said in the “ Mefáteeh el-'Uloom, ” [An astronomical almanac; or a set of astronomical tables;] a book, or writing, containing stellar calculations, year by year: in which sense, likewise, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. ziho: pl. ziyajapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And The science of astronomy, or of the celestial sphere. (TA.)

zaAy^ijapN *
A four-sided, or round, scheme, made to exhibit the horoscope, or places [or configurations] of the stars at the time of a birth: an astrological
term [arabicized from the Pers. zaAyoJaho]: so in the “ Shifá el-Ghaleel, ” from the “ Mefáteeh el- 'Uloom, ” by Er-Rázee. (TA.)

1 zaAHa * , (S, A, K,) aor. yaziyHu, inf. n. zayoHN (S, K) and zuyuwHN (MA, K) and ziyuwHN (K) and zayaHaAnN; (MA, K; [in the CK, erroneously, zayoHAn;]) and ↓ AnzAH; (A, K;) It (a thing, S) became distant, or remote: (S, A, K:) it went, went away, passed away, or departed. (S, K.) You say, zaAHato Eil~atuhu (S, A, MA) and ↓ AnzAHt (A) His pretext, pretence, or excuse, [or his malady,] became remote [or removed], or went away. (MA.) And zaAHa Ean~iY AlbaATilu What was false, or vain, ceased, passed away, or went away, from me. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- And zaAHa, aor. as above, i. q. taA^ax~ara [He, or it, went back or backwards, &c.]. (TA in art. zH.)

4 AzAHhu *
He made it (a thing, S) to be distant, or remote: [he removed it, did away with it, or caused it to cease:] he made it to go, go away, pass away, or depart. (S, K.) Hence the saying of El-Aashà, qado A^azaHonaA huzaAlahaA [We had caused her leanness to cease]. (S.) And A^azaHotu Eil~atahu: (S, A:) AzAH Eil~atahu signifies He removed his pretext, pretence, or excuse; [or his malady;] or did away with it. (MA.)
7 A_inozayaHa see 1, in two places.

mazaAHN *
A place to which one [goes away, or may go away; or] removes, or may remove, far away. (Ham p. 329.)

1 zaAda * , (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaziydu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. ziyaAdapN (S, A, * Msb, K *) and zayodN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) with which are syn. ziydN (S, K) and zayadN (K) and maziydN (S, K) and zayodaAnN, which last is anomalous, like $anoA=nN (K) and lay~aAnN, said to be the only instances of the kind, (TA,) all as inf. ns., (TK,) and so is mazaAdN, (TA,) and J adds that zuwaAdapN is mentioned by Yaakoob, from Ks, from El-Bekree, as syn. with ziyaAdapN, but this is a mistake, which is unfairly imputed to J by the author of the K, (MF,) [who says,] as to Alz~uwaAdapu, it is a mistranscription by J, for the words are Alz~uwaArapu and Alz~iyaArapu, [in the CK Alr~uwAdpu and Alr~iyAdpu,] with r, and without the mention of [the signification of] Aln~umuw~u, (K, TA,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, Msb, [as, for ex.,] water, and property, A) increased, or augmented, or grew; (S, A, TA;) [and in like manner said of a man, and of any animal;] as also ↓ AizodaAda: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or this latter has a more intensive signification than the former, like Aikotasaba in relation to kasaba. (MF. [See also 5.]) In this sense it has a single objective complement; as in zaAda ka*aA It, or he, increased, or augmented, or grew, in such a thing; as also ↓ AizodaAda. (TA.) [The latter is more commonly used in this manner.] You say, ↓ Aizodadotu maAlFA (A, Mgh, Msb) [I increased in property: also] meaning I increased to myself, or for myself, property. (Mgh, * Msb.) And AlA^amoru ↓ AzdAd SuEuwbapF [The affair increased in difficulty]. (A.) ― -b2- [Also It exceeded; it was, or became, redundant, or superfluous; it remained over and above. And zaAda Ealayohi It exceeded it; as also ↓ tzAyd.] You say, zaAda EalaY Al$~aYo'i DiEofahu [It exceeded the thing by the like thereof, or more]. (A.) And zaAda EalaY maA A^araAda [It exceeded what he desired]. (A.) ― -b3- Also He gave an addition: so in the saying, faqado A^arobaY ↓ mano zaAda waA@zodaAda He who gives an addition, and who takes it, [each of these] practises usury. (Msb.) ― -b4- [And He added, or exaggerated.] yaziydu fiY Hadiyvihi [He adds, or exaggerates, in his narration, or talk, or discourse,] is said of a liar. (A and TA voce sar~aAjN. [See also 5.]) -A2- It is also trans.: (Msb:) you say, zaAdahu, aor. yaziyduhu, inf. n. ziyaAdapN, He increased it, or augmented it. (L.) And in this sense it is doubly trans.: (MF:) you say, zaAdahu A@ll~`hu xayorFA, (S, K,) or maAlFA, (A,) [God increased to him, or added to him, good fortune or prosperity or the like, or property; increased, or added to, his good fortune, &c.; or may God increase &c.;] as also ↓ zay~adahu: (K:) and zaAda fiymaA Einodahu, (S,) or fiY maAlihi, (A,) [He increased, or added to, what he possessed or his possessions, or his property; or may He (i. e. God) increase &c.] ― -b2- zaAdahu also signifies He gave him an increase, or an addition, or more. (Msb.) See 10. ― -b3- You say also, maA yaziyduka A^aHadN Ealayohi [No one is more sufficient for thee than he]. (K in art. znd. [See 4 in that art.]) And laA yaziyduka Ealayohi jamalN No camel will be more sufficient for thee than he; i. q. laA yaDur~uka. (ISk, S in art. Dr [in which see other exs.].)
2 zy~d * , [inf. n. tazoyiydN,] said of property, It increased, or augmented, much. (A.) -A2- See also 1, latter part.
3 zAyd A^aHadu AlmutabaAyiEayoni AlA=xara * , inf. n. muzaAyadapN, [One of the two persons buying together outbade the other: see also 6.] (A.)

5 tzy~d *
It (a price, S, A) was, or became, excessive, or dear; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ tzAyd. (A, TA.) ― -b2- He added, or exaggerated, (MA,) or lied, (S, MA, K,) in narration, or discourse. (S, MA. [See also 1, latter half.]) And He affected to exceed the due bounds in his narration, or discourse, and his speech; (TA;) he affected excess in speech, &c.; (K, TA;) i. e. in speech and in action; (TA;) as also ↓ tzAyd: (K:) or Alt~azay~udu fiY AlHadiyvi means the embellishing narration, or discourse, with lies, and adding in it what does not belong to it. (Har p. 195.) In the verse of 'Adee cited in art. znd, the last word is tazay~adi as some relate it, or tazan~adi as others relate it. (TA.) ― -b3- He went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq. (S, K. [See also *amala, and naSaba Als~ayora, and wasaja.]) And tzy~dt She (A camel) stretched forth her neck, and went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq, as though she were swimming with her rider: (A, TA:) and in like manner one says of a mare, or horse. (TA.) And tzy~dt AlA_ibilu fiY sayorihaA The camels tasked themselves in their pace beyond their ability. (TA.)

6 tzAyd * [It increased, augmented, or grew, gradually; contr. of tanaAqaSa]. See also 1. And see 5, in two places. tzAydwA EalaY Als~iloEapi [They bade, one against another, for the commodity, or article of merchandise, successively raising the price]: said of the people of a market when a commodity is sold to him who bids more than others. (L.) And tzAydwA fiY Alv~amani Hat~aY balaga munotahaAhu [They augmented the price, one outbidding another, until it attained its utmost]. (A, TA.)

8 AizodaAda * [originally AizotaAda]: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- Also He took an addition. (Msb.) See, again, 1. ― -b3- Also He took in addition: so in the saying, A_i*aA A@zodaAda Alr~aAhinu daraAhima mina Almurotahini [When the pledger takes money in addition from the receiver of the pledge]. (Mgh.) One says also, Aizodado mina Alxayori [Obtain thou, or gain thou, somewhat in addition of what is good: or it may mean seek thou, or desire thou, an increase, or addition, of what is good]. (A.) See what next follows, in two places. 10. AstzAd He sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase, an addition, or more; (A, Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ AizodaAda; whence the saying, to a man to whom a thing has been given, ↓ halo tazodaAdu Dost thou seek, or desire, or demand, more than what I have given thee? (L.) ― -b4- [Hence,] huwa yasotaziydu fiY Hadiyvihi [He seeks, or desires, to add, or exaggerate, or to exceed the due bounds, or to embellish with lies and additions, in his narration, or discourse]. (A, TA. [See also 5.]) ― -b5- AstzAdhu He sought, or desired, or demanded, of him an increase, an addition, or more. (Msb, K.) You say, ↓ lawi A@sotazadotuhu lazaAdaniY If I had sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase, &c., he had given me an increase, &c. (Msb.) ― -b6- [And hence,] (tropical:) He reckoned him, or held him, to have fallen short of doing what he ought to have done, (S, A, K, TA,) and complained of him, (A, TA,) or reproved him, for a thing that he did not approve. (TA.) And kataba A_ilayohi kitaAba A@sotizaAdapK (tropical:) [He wrote to him a letter of complaint, or reproof, for his having fallen short, &c.; requiring him to do more]. (A.)
zayodN * an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] humo zayodN EalaY miAy^apK (S, A, L) and ↓ ziydN (S, L) and ↓ ziyAadapN (A) (tropical:) [They are more than a hundred].
ziydN * an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, * K, * TK.) ― -b2- See the next preceding paragraph.

ziyaAdapN * an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, Msb.) Using it as an inf. n., (Msb,) you say, AifoEalo *`lika ziyaAdapF [meaning Do thou that in addition]: (S, Msb:) the vulgar say ↓ zaAy^idapF, (S,) which one should not say. (Msb.) [Hence also,] Huruwfu Alz~iyaAdapi [The letters of augmentation; or the augmentative letters; i. e. the letters that are added to the radical letters in Arabic words]: they are ten, and are
comprised in the saying, saA^alotumuwniyhaA [“ Ye asked me for them ”], (TA,) and in A^aloyawoma tanosaAhu [“ Today thou wilt forget it ”]; (K, TA;) and more than a hundred and thirty other combinations comprising them have been mentioned: (MF:) [these letters are also called zawaAy^idu, of which the sing. is ↓ zaAy^idapN.] See also zayodN. ― -b2- [As a simple subst., or a subst. properly so termed, it signifies An increase, or increment; and augmentation, or augment; an addition, additament, adjunct, or accessory: an accession: excess, redundance, or superfluity: and a redundant part or portion or appertenance; a surplus; a residue: an excrescence: pl. ziyaAdaAtN and zayAy^idu. ― -b3- Hence,] A_ibilN kaviyrapu Alz~ayaAy^idi i.e. Alz~iyaAdaAt [Camels having much increase; lit., much, or many, increases]. (K.) A poet says,
bihajomapK tamolaA^u Eayona AlHaAsidi
*aAti suruwHK jam~api Alz~ayaAy^idi
[With a herd of forty or more camels, that fill, or glut, the eye of the envier, enjoying pasturing by themselves, having much increase]: some say, [in citing this verse,] Alz~awaAy^idi, which is pl. of ↓ zaAy^idapN; but AlzwAy^d is said only in relation to the legs of a beast. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] ziyaAdapu Alkabidi, (so in a copy of the S, and in the A and L, and in several places in the K,) or Alkabidi ↓ zaAy^idapu, (so termed by Zj, and so in the T, and in two copies of the S, and in the L,) both of which are correct, (TA,) [The redundant appertenance of the liver;] a certain small piece to which the liver is attached, or suspended: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or a certain small appertenance of the liver (hunay~apN minohaA SagiyrapN), at its side, going away from it (mutanaH~iyapN EanohaA): (S, L:) or a certain piece appended, or attached, to the liver (muEal~aqapN bihaA): (A:) or a certain appendage of the liver; [so I render hanapN mutaEal~iqapN minohaA, agreeably with the next preceding explanation; though it may be rendered a thing suspended from it, i.e. from the liver; or the right reading may be hnp mtEl~qp bihaA, which is virtually the same as the explanation in the A, and agreeable with what here follows: so called] because it is a redundance (taziydu) upon its upper surface: (L:) [all of these explanations seem to denote the round ligament of the liver: the Hebrew יֹחֶרֶח הַכּבֵד, in Ex. xxix. 22, literally signifies the same; like the slightly-varying appellations in Ex. xxix. 13 and Lev. iii. 4, and Lev. ix. 10: but the real meaning thereof is much disputed: the rendering of the LXX. is λοβὸσ τοῦ ἥπατοσ; which is said to mean extrema pars hepatis: that of the Vulg., reticulum hepatis: that of our authorized Engl. Vers., the caul above the liver; (with this marginal note: “ it seemeth by anatomy, and the Hebrew Doctors, to be the midriff: ”) and it is remarkable that this is one of the meanings assigned to Alxilobu, which some hold to be syn. with zayaAdapu Alkabidi: (see xilobN:) Bochart (in his Hieroz. t. i., p. 498, seq.,) and Gesenius (in his Lex.) explain the Hebrew term as meaning the greater lobe of the liver: but this is hard to reconcile with the Hebrew or the Arabic; and utterly irreconcileable with the explanations given by the Arabs; among whom, it should be observed, were many of the Jewish religion, who cannot reasonably be supposed to have not known the correct meaning of a term relating to their sacrifices:] the pl. of zyAdp is zayaAy^idu, (L,) and that of ↓ zAy^dp is zawaAy^idu. (S, L.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu kabidu *iY Alwaladi wawaladu Alwaladi ziyaAdapu Alkabidi [The child is as the liver of the parent, and the grandchild is as the redundant appertenance of the liver]. (A, TA.)

zaAy^idN * act. part. n. of zaAda, (Msb,) [Increasing, augmenting, or growing. ― -b2- Exceeding; in excess; redundant; superfluous; remaining over and above: excrescent: additional; in addition; adscititious.] You say, A^axa*otuhu bidirohamK fazaAy^idFA [I took it, i. e. bought it, for a dirhem and more]. (A.) [See also the next paragraph.]

zaAy^idapN * [fem. of zaAy^idN: and also a subst.; being transferred from the category of epithets to that of substs. by the affix p: pl. zawaAy^idu]: see ziyaAdapN, in five places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Alz~awaAy^idu [Certain excrescences, or pendent hairs, termed] zamaEaAt, in the hinder part of the kind leg or foot. (K. [In the explanations there given, I read Alr~ijol, as in one copy, instead of Alr~aHol. It has been stated above, voce ziyaAdapN, on the authority of the L, that Alz~awaAy^id is said only in relation to the legs of a beast.]) ― -b3- [But] *uw Alz~awaAy^idi means The lion: (S, K:) by the zwAy^d being mean this claws and his canine teeth and his roaring and his impetuosity. (S.) ― -b4- zaAy^idapu Als~aAqi The shin-bone. (L.)

[
zawaAy^idiY~N * a rel. n. from zawaAy^idu pl. of zaAy^idapN; and used, app., as meaning Having something redundant; for] Sa'eed Ibn-'Othmán was surnamed Alz~awaAy^idiY~u because he had three bayoDaAt: so they assert. (S.)

buruwdN taziydiy~apN * , (S, K,) and taziydiy~aAtN [alone], (S,) [Garments of the kind termed] buruwd having in them red stripes, (S, K,) to which streaks of blood are likened: (S:) so called in relation to taziyd the son of HulowaAn, the father of a tribe: (S, K:) or, as some say, taziyd the son of HayodaAn: (MF:) or from taziyd, a city, or town, of ElYemen, in which such brwd were woven: (TA:) or, accord. to some, J and F are in error; and the truth is, that there were some merchants in Mekkeh, called banuw yaziydK, thus with Y and in relation to them certain [camel-vehicles for women of the kind called] hawaAdij were termed ↓ yaziydiy~apN. (MF.)
mazaAdN * : see mazaAdapN, in two places.

maziydN * an inf. n. of zaAda. (S, K.) You say, laA maziyda EalaY maA faEalota and ↓ laA musotazaAda, (A, Msb,) both meaning the same [i.e. There is no exceeding what thou hast done: or rather the latter means there is no desire for more than thou hast done, or there is no one of whom is desired more than thou hast done; for ↓ musotazaAd may be here an inf. n., and it may be a pass. part. n.]. (Msb.) -A2- [It is also the pass. part. n. of zaAda, signifying Increased, or augmented; as also maziydN fiyhi.]

mazaAdapN * [A leathern water-bag, one of a pair which is borne by a camel or other beast;] the half ($aTor) of a raAwiyap: (Msb in art. zwd:) [a water-bag of this kind is represented in a sketch of “ Sakkàs ” in my work on the Modern Egyptians:] it has two loops, and two kidney-shaped pieces of leather (kuloyataAni), the former of which are sewed to the latter: (TA voce xurobapN:) the raAwiyap consists of two mezádehs (mazaAdataAni), which are bound upon the two sides of the camel with the [cord called] riwaA=': the pl. is mazaAyidu [often written mazaAy^idu]; and sometimes the Arabs elided the p, saying ↓ mazaAdN: (T, TA:) [both of these forms are mentioned in the S and K as pls.:] and ↓ mazaAdN without p, is [also] applied to the single one (farodap [meaning the single water-skin]) which the rider attaches behind his camel's saddle, having no EazolaA=', [or spout (which is closed by means of a thong tied round it) at one of the lower extremities for pouring out the water; thus] differing from the mazaAdap: (T, TA:) or the mzAdp is a raAwiyap, [app. accord. to some who applied this latter term to a single water-bag,] (S, A, K,) or only (K) such as is composed of two skins with a third inserted between them to widen it: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, A, K:) and so are the saTiyHap and the $aEiyb: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or the saTyHp is made of two skins put face to face; and the mzAdp is of two skins and a half, or of three skins: (ISh, TA:) or it is [a water-bag] joined (ma$oEurbap) at one side; if consisting of two faces (An xrjt mn wjhyn [i. e. of two pieces of skin whereof each forms one face or side]) it is called a $aEiyb: or it is like a rAwyp having no EazolaA=' [expl. above]: AM and the author of the Msb and some others assert that its medial radical letter is w, and that it is from Alz~awodu, (TA,) being so called because one furnishes himself with water in it for travellingprovision: (Msb in art. zwd:) but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is thus called because it is enlarged by the addition of a third skin: (AO, El-Khafájee, TA:) [Fei says that] accord. to analogy it should be mizaAdapN. (Msb in art. zwd.)
musotazaAdN * : see maziydN, in two places.
yaziydiy~apN * , applied to hawaAdij: see taziydiy~apN.

2 zy~r Ald~aAb~apa *
He (a farrier) twisted the lip of the beast with a ziyaAr: (S in art. zwr, and TA:) and he put a ziyaAr upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin] of the beast. (TA.) [In the present day, the instrument here mentioned is generally applied to the upper lip.]

ziyrN * [A large water-jar, wide in the upper part and nearly pointed at the bottom;] a [vessel of the kind called] dan~: or a [vessel such as is called] Hub~, (K,) in which water is put: (TA: [but yEml is there put by mistake for yujoEalu:]) of the dial. of El-'Irák [and that of Egypt]: pl. A^azoyaArN:
a foreign word. (TA in art. zwr, in which, and in art. zyr, the word is mentioned in the K.) -A2- See also art. zwr. -A3- Also I. q. zir~N; (IAar, TA in art. zwr;) the former r in the latter word being changed by some of the Arabs into Y in this and similar instances. (Az, TA.) -A4- [See also baSalN.]
zayirN * , (Sgh, TA in art. zwr,) in the K, erroneously, zay~irN, (TA,) Angry, (IAar, Sgh, K, TA,) and severing himself from his companion: (IAar, TA:) originally zay^irN. (Az, TA.)
ziyrapN * : see art. zwr.

ziyaArN * [A kind of barnacle, used by a farrier;] an instrument with which a farrier twists the lip of a beast; (S in art. zwr;) a thing that is put upon the mouth of a beast when he is refractory, in order that he may become submissive. (IAth, TA. [See 2.]) ― -b2- See also art. zwr.
zayozafuwnN * : see art. zfn.

1 zaAga * , aor. yaziygu, inf. n. zayogN (S, O, Msb, K) and zayagaAnN and zayoguwgapN (O, K) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) He, or it, (a thing, Msb,) declined, deviated, swerved, or turned aside, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the right course or direction, accord. to an explanation of zayogN by Er-Rághib; and from the truth: (TA:) and zAg, aor. yazuwgu, inf. n. zawogN, is a dial. var. thereof. (Msb, TA. *) In the Kur iii. 5, (O,) zayogN means A doubting, and a declining, or deviating, from the truth. (O, K.) ― -b2- You say also, zaAgati Al$~amosu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. taziygu, inf. n. zayogN (Msb, TA) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) The sun declined [from the meridian], (S, * Msb, K,) so that the shade turned from one side to the other. (S, * K.) ― -b3- And zAg AlbaSaru, (S, O, K,) inf. n. zayogN, (TA,) (tropical:) The eye, or eyes, or the sight, became dim, or dull: (S, O, K, TA:) so in the phrase maA zaAga AlbaSaru in the Kur [liii. 17]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, zaAgati AlA^aboSaAru signifies the eyes turned aside from their places; as in the case of a man in fear. (TA.)
2 zay~agotu fulaAnFA * , inf. n. tazoyiygN, I rectified the zayog [or declining, or deviating, &c.,] of such a one. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K. *)

4 AzAghu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) Eani AlT~ariyqi, (S, O,) inf. n. A_izaAgapN, (Msb,) He made him to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the way. (S, O.) Hence, in the Kur [iii. 6, accord. to the usual reading], rab~anaA laA tuzigo quluwbanaA, (O, TA,) meaning O our Lord, make us not [or make not our hearts] to decline from the right way and course: make us not to err, or go astray. (TA. [See another reading in the first paragraph of art. zwg.]) ― -b2- And He made him to fall into Alz~ayog [app. as meaning deviation from the truth, or the right way of belief or conduct]. ((TA.) ― -b3- falam~aA zaAguwA A^azaAga A@ll~`hu quluwbahumo, in the Kur [lxi. 5], means, accord. to Er-Rághib, And when they quitted the right way, God dealt with them according to that: (TA:) or God turned their hearts from the acceptance of the truth, and the inclining to the right course. (Bd.)

5 tazay~agato *
She (a woman) ornamented, or adorned, herself, and showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and beauties of person or form or countenance, to men, or strangers, (AZ, S, K,) and decked herself with apparel; like tazay~aqato: (AZ, TA:) IF says that its g is a substitute for n. (TA.)

6 tazaAyugN *
i. q. tamaAyulN, (JK, S, O, K,) An inclining towards each other, (PS,) accord. to some, peculiarly, (TA,) in the teeth. (JK, TA.)

zaAgN * [The rook;] a small guraAb [or bird of the crow-kind], inclining to white, (O, Mgh, K, TA,) that does not eat carrion, (O, Mgh, TA,) and is allowed to be eaten; now called in Egypt the guraAb nuwHiY~ [or Noachian crow]: (TA:) or a guraAb like the pigeon, black, with a dusty colour in its head; or, as some say, inclining to white; that does not eat carrion: (Msb in art. zwg:) or a small black guraAb, that is eaten; also called Ha*afN, of which the n. un. is with p: (ISh, TA in art. H*f:) [these descriptions correctly apply to different varieties of the rook; some of which are distinguished by more or less whiteness in the head and other parts: in the present day, the word is, by some, perhaps generally, erroneously applied to the carrion-crow:] Az says, “ I know not whether it be Arabic or arabicized: ” (Msb in art. zwg, and TA:) the truth is, that it is a Pers. word, [zaAgo,] arabicized; originally applied to crows (girobaAn), whether small or large; but when arabicized, applied peculiarly to one species thereof: (TA:) pl. ziygaAnN. (O, Mgh, Msb, K.)

zaAy^igN *
Declining, deviating, swerving, or turning aside: (TA:) pl. zaAgapN, applied to a number of men, (S, O, K, TA,) i. q. zaAy^iguwna, (S, O, TA,) like baAEapN meaning baAy^iguwna. (O, TA.)

1 zaAfa * , aor. yaziyfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. zayofN and zayafaAnN (O, K) and zuyuwfN, (TA,) said of a camel, (S, TA,) and of a man, &c., (TA,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (S, O, K:) or he went quickly, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) And zaAfato fiY mi$oyatihaA, said of a woman, She appeared as though she were turning round, or circling, in her gait. (Z, TA.) [This is app. from what next follows.] One says of a male pigeon, zAf Einoda AlHamaAmapi He dragged the tail, and impelled his fore part with his hinder part, and turned, or circled, around the female pigeon: (S, O, L, K, * TA:) and of a female pigeon one says, taziyfu bayona yadaYi AlHamaAmi Al*~akari, meaning She walks with boldness and presumptuousness before the male pigeon. (TA.) And a poet describing a battle says of it zaAfato, meaning The hinder part thereof impelled the fore part. (L, TA.) ― -b2- zAf, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. zayofN, (Kr,) said of a building, (Kr, TA,) &c., (TA,) It was, or became, high. (Kr, TA.) -A2- zAft Ald~araAhimu, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. taziyfu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayofN, (Msb,) or zuyuwfN, (Mgh, K,) for which the lawyers say ziyaAfapN, (Mgh,) The dirhems, or pieces of money, were bad: (MA, Msb:) or were rejected, or returned, (Mgh, K,) Ealayohi [to him], (S, Mgh, K,) because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, K:) or, accord. to the M, simply, were rejected, or returned; (TA;) [and] so ↓ zuy~ifat. (Mgh.) -A3- See also 2. -A4- zAf AlHaAy^iTa, (O, K,) inf. n. zayofN, (TA,) He leaped the wall; syn. qafazahu; (O, K;) said of a man. (O.)

2 tazoyiyfN * is said to signify primarily The separating, or setting apart, such [money] as is passable, or current, from such as is termed zaAy^if: and hence, the rejecting [money], or returning [it]: and the making [it], or proving [it] to be, false, or spurious. (TA.) One says, zy~f Ald~araAhima, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazoyiyfN, (Msb,) He made, (MA, K,) or pronounced, (K,) or showed, (Msb,) the dirhems, or pieces of money, to be bad, (MA, Msb,) or to be such as are termed zuyuwf; (K;) as also ↓ zaAfahaA. (Lh, K.) See also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence, Alt~azoyiyfu in relation to speech, or language: see 2 in art. rml.] ― -b3- And zy~fhu, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr,) (tropical:) He made his blood to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; or made it allowable to take, or shed, his blood: (TA:) or he made him to be contemptible, ignominious, base, or vile, in the estimation of others: (Kr, TA:) from dirohamN zaAy^ifN “ a bad dirhem, or piece of money. ” (TA.)

5 tzy~ft * , said of a woman, [like tzy~qt,] She ornamented, or adorned, herself. (O.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Freytag, tzy~f signifies It was adulterated: and in Har p. 612 it is expl. as signifying SAr zy~fA fY AHwAlh, which seems to have this or a similar meaning; zy~fA being app. a mistranscription for zayofFA or muzay~afFA.]

zayofN * : see zaAy^ifN, in four places. -A2- Also The A_iforiyz, i. e., (Kr, TA,) the Tanaf, (Kr, O, K, TA,) [meaning the coping, or ledge, or cornice,] that protects a wall, (O, K, TA,) surrounding the upper part of the wall, (Kr,) or surrounding the walls at the top of a house: (TA:) or, as some say, (O, in the K “ and, ”) the steps, or stairs, of places of ascent: (O, K:) or, as some say, (Kr, O, in the K “ and, ”) i. q. $urafN [meaning acroterial ornaments forming a single member of a cresting of a wall, or of the crown of a cornice]: n. un. with p. (Kr, O, K.)
zay~aAfN * , and with p: see the next paragraph, in three places.

zaAy^ifN * One who walks in the manner described in the first sentence of this art.; as also ↓ zayofN, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet: (TA:) [and so ↓ zay~aAfN, but properly in an intensive sense:] and ↓ zay~aAfapN a she-camel proud and self-
conceited [in her gait]. (S.) Hence, (TA,) Alz~aAy^ifu signifies The lion; as also ↓ Alz~ay~aAfu; (O, K;) but the latter has an intensive meaning: (TA:) so called because of his proud and selfconceited walk. (O, TA.) -A2- Also, and ↓ zayofN, (S, Kr, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) or, accord. to IDrd, this is a vulgar term, (O,) or bad, (K,) applied to a dirhem, or piece of money, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) to gold and to silver, (Har p. 369, referring to the latter word,) Bad: (Kr, Msb, and Har ubi suprà:) or such as are rejected, or returned, because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, O, K:) or, as some say, such as are less bad than what are termed bahoraj, being such as are rejected by [the officers of] the government-treasury; whereas the bhrj are such as are rejected by the merchants, or traders: (Mgh:) the pl. is ziyaAfN and A^azoyaAfN, (O, K,) [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] or the pl. of ↓ zayofN is zuyuwfN, and the pl. of zaAy^ifN is zuy~afN: (Mgh, * Msb:) accord. to some, the zuyuwf are such as are done over with a compound of quicksilver and sulphur. (Msb.) [It is implied in the Msb that ↓ zayofN is the more common term, though, as has been stated above, it is said by IDrd to be vulgar: and it is also applied to human beings: for ex.,] a poet says,
taraY Alqawoma A^a$obaAhFA A_i*aA nazaluwAmaEFA
wafiY Alqawomi zayofN mivolu zayofi Ald~araAhimi
[Thou seest the people to be likes when they alight together; but among the people are bad like the bad of dirhems.] (TA.)

5 tzy~q *
He ornamented, or adorned, himself, and applied kuHol to his eyes: (K:) or tzy~qt, said of a woman, (JK, S, O,) like tzy~gt, (S, O,) she ornamented, or adorned, herself, (JK, S, O,) and applied kuHol to her eyes, (S, O, TA,) and some add, and decked herself with apparel: accord. to Z, it is from Alzwq; [app. meaning Alz~uwaqu, syn. with Alz~awuwqu; or from zawaAqN, (see 2 in art. zwq, last sentence,) so that it is originally tzw~qt;] or it may be from zyq, [i. e. ziyqN,] with Y, [meaning the “ builder's string, or line, with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and with which the building is proportioned, ”] because she who embellishes herself makes her state right by adornment. (TA.)

ziyqN * The part, of a shirt, that surrounds the neck: (S, K:) the collar of a shirt: (KL:) or the border of a collar; (MA;) or the hemmed border of the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt: (JK:) [app. an arabicized word from the Pers. ziho:] J, holding the medial radical to be [originally] w, has mentioned it in art. zwq. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) The surrounding edge of the eyelid. (See HitaArN.)] ― -b3- And The string, or line, of the builder, [also called ziyjN, q. v., with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and] with which the building is proportioned. (JK.) ― -b4- ziyqu Al$~ayaATiyni, expl. by Lth as meaning A certain thing that flies in the air, called by the Arabs luEaAbu Al$~amosi, [i. e. the fine filmy cobwebs termed gossamer,] is a mistake for riyqu Al$~ayaATiyni, with raA='. (Az, O, K. *)

1 zaAlahu * is syn. with A^azaAlahu, q. v. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- zAl zawaAlahu, or zAl A@ll~`hu zawaAlahu; and zAl zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN, in art. zwl. And ziyla zawiyluhu and zawiyluhaA and zawaAluhu: see zawiylN, in art. zwl; and for the first, see also zawaAlN, in that art. ― -b3- zilotuhu, (S, K,) aor. A^aziyluhu, inf. n. zayolN, (S,) [first pers. of zaAlahu,] signifies also I put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (S, K, TA;) namely, a thing, (S, TA,) from another thing: (TA:) and ↓ AzAlhu also signifies he separated it; like zaAlahu. (TA.) See also 4. One says, zilo DaA^onaka mino miEozaAka Remove, or separate, thy sheep from thy goats. (S, * TA.) And ↓ zilotuhu falamo yanozalo I separated it [partly], but it did not become [wholly] separated. (S, K.) -A2- maA zaAla yafoEalu ka*aA (S in art. zwl, and Msb,) is like maA bariHa, both in its [original] measure, [which is maA zayila accord. to most authorities,] and in its meaning, which is [He ceased not to do such a thing, or he continued to do such a thing, for it denotes] the continuing to do a thing [as in the ex. above], and a constant state [as in the phrase maA zaAla zayodN qaAy^imFA Zeyd ceased not to be, or continued to be, standing]: (Msb:) [using the first pers.,] one says, maA zilotu A^afoEaluhu [and maA zalotu, as appears from what follows], meaning maA bariHotu [i. e. I ceased not to do it, or I continued to do it], (K,) aor. A^azaAlu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally faEilotu] (Msb, K) and A^aziylu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally fEalotu]: (K:) the verb is seldom [in the Msb “ never ”] used without a negative particle: (Az, TA:) one says zilotu A^afoEalu meaning maA zilotu A^afoEalu; but this is rare: (K:) and maA ziyla yafoEalu ka*aA, (S, Msb, K,) a phrase used by some of the Arabs, (Msb,) mentioned by Akh, (S, TA,) as is meant in [some of the copies of] the K by the addition Eanohu, though Akh is not mentioned in what precedes. (TA.) The verb in maA zaAla and laA yazaAlu is used in the manner of kaAna in governing the noun [which is its subject] in the nom. case and the predicate in the accus. case [as in maA zaAla zayodN qaAy^imFA, expl. above]; but one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN A_il~aA munoTaliqFA, like as one says, maA kaAna zayodN A_il~aA munoTaliqFA; for zaAla denotes a negation, [meaning he did not a thing, or he was not doing &c.,] and maA and laA denote negation, and two negations together denote an affirmation; so that mA zAl is affirmative like kaAna; and as one may not say, kaAna zayodN A_il~aA manoTaliqFA, so one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN A_il~aA munoTaliqFA. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says also, maA zilotu bizayodK Hat~aY faEala *`lika and maA zilotu wazayodFA [I desisted not with Zeyd until he did that], (Sb, K, * TA,) inf. n. ziyaAlN. (Sb, TA.) lamo yazalo [He, or it, has not ceased to be &c., i. e., has ever been &c., (see A^azalN,)] is said of God, as meaning He has never been nonexistent; and laA yazaAlu, said of Him, He will never be nonexistent. (Kull p. 31.) This [incomplete i. e. non-attributive] verb and the complete [i. e. attributive, which signifies “ it ceased to be ” or “ exist, ” &c.,] differ in their components; the latter being composed of l w z; and this, of l Y z: or the incomplete is altered from the complete; being made to be with kesr to its medial radical letter, [for it is generally held to be from zayila or zawila,] after its having been [originally zawala,] with fet-h: or it is from zaAlahu, aor. yaziyluhu, meaning “ he put it, ” or “ set it, apart, ” &c. (K.)

2 zy~lhu * , (S, K,) inf. n. tazoyiylN, (S,) He separated it [i. e. acompany of men, or an assemblage of things,] much (Fr, Az, S, * K, * TA,) [or greatly, or widely; or dispersed it;] differing in degree from zaAlahu like as may~azahu does from maAzahu. (TA.) Hence, fazay~alonaA bayonahumo [And we will separate them widely, one from another], (Fr, Az, S, K, TA,) in the Kur [x. 29]; (Fr, Az, S, TA;) where some read bayonahumo ↓ fazaAyalonaA; like laA tuSaE~iro and lA tuSaAEiro [in the Kur xxxi. 17]. (Fr, Az, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce duwna.] zay~alotu is of the measure faE~alotu because its inf. n. is as above; for were it fayoEalotu, one would say zay~alapN [of the measure fayoEalapN]. (S.) -A2- tazoyiylN is also [said to be] an [irreg.] inf. n. of 5, q. v. (Lh, K.)

3 zAylhu * , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. muzaAyalapN and ziyaAlN, (S, K,) He separated himself from him. (S, Msb, K. [See also 1 in art. zwl, last signification.]) One says, xaAliTuwA Aln~aAsa wazaAyiluwhumo, meaning [Mix ye with men in familiar, or social, intercourse, and] separate yourselves from them in deeds, or actions. (TA.) ― -b2- zaAyalatohu biwajohihaA She veiled her face from him. (IAar on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in art. bzr.) [See also 6.] ― -b3- zaAyalonaA bayonahumo: see 2. And see also what next follows.

4 AzAlhu * (S, Msb, K) mino makaAnihi (S) or Eano makaAnihi, (K,) inf. n. A_izaAlapN (K) and A_izaAlN; (Lh, K;) and ↓ zaAlahu, (S, Msb, K, and Har p. 393,) aor. yaziyluhu, (S, K, and Har ubi suprà,) or yazaAluhu, like yanaAluhu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayolN, (S, K, Har,) or ziyaAlN; (Msb;) both signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) He removed it [from its place; as the former is expl. in art. zwl]; (Msb in explanation of both, and Har ubi suprà in explanation of the latter;) and so ↓ zaAyalahu, of which the primary signification is that first assigned to it in the next preceding paragraph. (Har ubi suprà.) See also 1, fourth sentence. [And see 4 in art. zwl.]

5 tzy~lwA * , (S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. tazay~ulN and ↓ tazoyiylN, (K,) the latter [irreg., being properly inf. n. of 2,] of the dial. of El-Hijáz, mentioned by Lh; (TA;) and ↓ tzAylwA, inf. n. tazaAyulN; (K;) i. q.
tafar~aquwA [i. e. They became separated much, or greatly, or widely; or became dispersed: or rather, the former verb, being quasi-pass. of 2, has this meaning; and the latter verb, as quasi-pass. of 3, means simply they became separated, one from another]: (S, K:) [for] ↓ Alt~azaAyulu signifies Alt~abaAyunu: (S, K:) tzy~lwA is syn. with tamay~azuwA: thus in the Kur [xlviii. 25], where it is said, lawo tazay~aluwA laEa*~abonaA A@l~a*iyna kafaruwA [Had they been widely separated, one from another, we had assuredly punished those who disbelieved]: (Msb, * TA:) and some here read ↓ tazaAyaluwA. (Bd.) [See also 7.]

6 tazaAoyala see 5, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Alt~azaAyulu signifies also AlAiHoti$aAmu; (K, TA;) a tropical meaning: (TA:) one says, tzAyl Eanohu, meaning AiHota$amahu [i. e. (tropical:) He was, or became, abashed at him]: (O, TA:) because the muHota$im separates himself, and shrinks, from another. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also mutazaAyilapN, whence it seems that one says, of a woman, tazaAyalato, meaning She veiled her face from men: see likewise 3.]

7 AnzAl *
It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; removed; or separated; (S, K;) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (TA.) One says, zilotuhu falamo yanozalo: see 1. (S, K.) [See also 5. And see 7 in art. zwl.]

zayalN *
Width between the thighs; (S, K;) like fajajN. (S.)
A^azoyalN * , (K,) or A^azoyalu Alfaxi*ayoni, occurring in a trad., (TA,) Having the thighs wide apart. (K, TA.)

mizoyalN * A man acute or sharp or quick in intellect, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent; knowing with respect to the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, affairs, or cases; as also ↓ mizoyaAlN: (K:) or vehement in altercation, or litigation, who shifts (yazuwlu) from one plea, or argument, to another: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, with reference to two claimants, kaAna A^aHaduhumaA mixolaTFA mizoyalFA [One of them two was a person who mixed in, or entered into, affairs; vehement in altercation, &c.]: (IAth, TA:) accord. to which latter explanation, it should be mentioned in art. zwl, as it is by the author of the L; but Z mentions it in the present art., like F. (TA.)
mizoyaAlN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
Aljyb AlmuzaAyilu * [a mistranscription for AlHabiybu] means AlbaAy^inu [i. e. The beloved, or the friend, who is in a state of separation, or disunion]. (TA.)
mutazaAyilapN * A woman who veils her face from men. (IAar on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in this art. and in art. brz.)

1 zaAnahu * , (S, MA, Msb, K,) aor. yaziynuhu, (Msb,) inf. n. zayonN; (MA, Msb, KL, TA;) and ↓ zy~nhu, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. tazoyiynN; (Msb, KL, TA;) and ↓ A^azaAnahu, (Msb, K,) and ↓ A^azoyanahu, (K,) which is its original form, (TA,) inf. n. A_izaAnapN; (Msb;) signify the same; (S, MA, Msb, K;) He, or it, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced, him, or it. (MA, KL, PS: [and the like is indicated in the S and Msb and K.]) [zaAnahu said of a quality, and of an action, and of a saying, is best rendered It adorned him, or graced him, or was an honour to him; contr. of $aAnahu; as is indicated in the S and K: and sometimes means it was his pride: and ↓ zy~nhu means as expl. above: and he embellished it, dressed it up, or trimmed it; said in this sense as relating to language: and he embellished it, or dressed it up, namely, an action &c. to another (ligayorihi); often said in this sense of the Devil; (as in the Kur vi. 43, &c.;) i. e. he commended it to him:] zaAnahu ka*aA and ↓ zy~nhu [Such a thing adorned him, &c.,] are expl. as said when one's excellence [faDoluhu, as I read for fElh, an evident mistranscription,] appears either by speech or by action: and A@ll~`hi liloA^a$oyaA='i ↓ tazoyiynu [God's adorning, &c., of things] is sometimes by means of his creating them muzay~anap [i. e. adorned, &c.]; and Aln~aAsi ↓ tazoyiynu [The adorning, &c., of men], by their abundance of property, and by their speech, i. e. by their extolling Him. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, zaAnahu AlHusonu [Beauty adorned, or graced, him, or it]. And Mejnoon says,
fayaA rab~i A_i*o Say~arota layolaY liYa AlhawaY
fazin~iY liEayonayohaA kamaA zinotahaA liyaA
[And, O my Lord, since Thou hast made Leylà to be to me the object of love, then grace Thou me to her eyes like as Thou hast graced her to me]. (S, TA: but in the former, mina AlhawY in the place of liYa AlhawaY. [The reading in the S means of the objects of love: for hawFY, being originally an inf. n., may be used alike as sing. and pl.]) Als~iloEapi fiY AlbayoEi ↓ tazoyiynu [means The setting off, or commending, of a commodity in selling; and] is allowed, if without concealment of a fault, or defect, from the purchaser, and without lying in the attribution and description of the article. (TA.)
2 zay~ana see above, in six places.
4 A^azaAnahu * and A^azoyanahu : see 1, first sentence. -A2- See also the paragraph here following.

5 tzy~n * and ↓ AizodaAna, (S, K,) the latter of the measure AifotaEala, [originally Aizotayana, and then AizotaAna,] (S,) quasi-pass. verbs, [the former of zay~anahu and the latter of zaAnahu,] (K,) signify the same; (S;) [He, or it, was, or became, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embel-lished, beautified, or graced;] as also Aiz~ay~ana, (S, * K,) [a variation of the first, being] originally tazay~ana, the t being made quiescent, and incorporated into the z, and the A being prefixed in order that the inception may be perfect; (S, TA;) and ↓ AzyAn~; and ↓ Azyn~. (K.) One says, ↓ A^azoyanati AlA^aroDu biEu$obihaA [perhaps a mistranscription for ↓ Aizoyan~ati The earth, or land, became adorned, &c., with, or by, its herbage]; as also Aiz~ay~anat, originally tazay~anat [as expl. above]; (S;) and some, in the Kur x. 25, read tazay~anat; and some, ↓ AzyAn~t. (Bd.) And they said, A_i*aA TalaEati Aljabohapu tazay~anati Aln~axolapu [When Aljbhp (the Tenth Mansion of the Moon) rises aurorally, the palm-tree becomes garnished with ripening dates: that Mansion thus rose in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 12th of August, O. S; and in that region, at, or soon after, that period, the dates begin to ripen]. (TA.) [tzy~n is said of language, as meaning It was embellished, dressed up, or trimmed: and of an action &c., as meaning it was embellished, or dressed up, i. e. commended, to a person, by another man, and, more commonly, by the Devil.] ― -b2- And tzy~n also signifies He adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, &c., himself. (MA, KL.) [Hence,] tzy~n biAlbaATili [He invested himself with that which did not belong to him]. (S and TA in art. $bE.)
8 AizodaAna * , originally Aizotayana: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.
9 A_izoyan~a see 5, each in two places.
11 A_izoyaAon~a see 5, each in two places.
zaAnN * : see art. zwn.

zayonN * [as an inf. n., and also as a simple subst.,] is the contr. of $ayonN: (S, Msb, K:) [as a simple subst.,] i. q. ziynapN, q. v.: (Har p. 139:) [and commonly signifying A grace; a beauty; a comely quality; a physical, and also an intel-lectual, adornment; an honour, or a credit; and anything that is the pride, or glory, of a person or thing: in these senses contr. of $ayonN:] pl. A^azoyaAnN. (K.) ― -b2- Az says, I heard a boy of [the tribe called] Benoo- 'Okeyl say to another, wajohiY zayonN wawajohuka $ayonN, meaning My face is comely and thy face is ugly; for wajohiY *uw zayonK wawajohuka *uw $ayonK [my face is possessed of comeliness and thy face is possessed of ugliness]; using the inf. ns. as epithets; like as one says rajulN SawomN and EadolN. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The comb of the cock. (S.)
zaAnapN * [mentioned in this art. in the K]: see art. zwn.

ziynapN * , the subst. from zaAnahu, (Msb,) signifies maA yutazay~anu bihi [i. e. A thing with which, or by which, one is adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced; or with which, or by which, one adorns, &c., himself]; (T, S, K;) any such thing; (T, TA;) [any ornament, ornature, decoration, garnish, embellishment, or grace;] and so ↓ ziyAnN; (K;) and ↓ zayonN, also, [which see above,] signifies the same as ziynapN: (Har p. 139:) accord. to El- Harállee, ziynapN denotes the [means of] beautifying, or embellishing, a thing by another thing; consisting of apparel, or an ornament of gold or silver or of jewels or gems, or aspect: or, as some say, it is the beauty [seen] of the eye that does not reach to the interior of that which is adorned [thereby]: accord. to Er-Rághib, its proper mean-
ing is a thing that does not disgrace, or render unseemly, a man, in any of his states or conditions, either in the present world or in that which is to come: but that which adorns him in one state or condition, exclusively of another, is in one point of view $ayonN: summarily speaking, it is of three kinds; namely, mental, such as knowledge or science, and good tenets; and bodily, such as strength, and tallness of stature, and beauty of aspect; and extrinsic, such as wealth, and rank or station or dignity; and all these are mentioned in the Kur: (TA:) the pl. is ziyanN. (Bd in x. 25.) ziynapu AlHayaApi Ald~unoyaA [or simply ziynapu Ald~unoyaA generally means The ornature, finery, show, pomp, or gaiety, of the present life or world; and] particularly includes wealth and children. (Kur xviii. 44.) ziynapu AlA^aroDi [The ornature of the earth] means the plants, or herbage, of the earth. (TA.) yawomu Alz~iynapi [The day of ornature] is the festival (AlEiydu); (S, K;) when men used [and still use] to adorn themselves with goodly articles of apparel. (TA.) And also The day of the breaking [of the dam a little within the entrance] of the canal of Misr [here meaning the present capital of Egypt, El-Káhireh, which we call “ Cairo ”], (K, TA,) i. e. the canal which runs through the midst of Misr, and [the dam of] which is broken when the Nile has attained the height of sixteen cubits or more: this day is said to be meant in the Kur xx. 61: it is one of the days observed in Egypt with the greatest gladness and rejoicing from ancient times; and its observance in the days of the Fátimees was such as is inconceivable, as it is described in the “ Khitat ” of El-Makreezee. (TA. [The modern observances of this day, and of other days in relation to the rise of the Nile, are described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.])

qamarN zayaAnN *
A beautiful moon. (K.)
ziyaAnN * : see ziynapN.

[
ziyaAnapN * The art, or occupation, of the muzay~in: so in the present day.]
zaAy^inN * : see the last paragraph in this art.
muzay~anN * : see mutazay~inN. ― -b2- [Also,] applied to a man, Having his hair trimmed, or clipped, [or shaven, by the muzay~in.] (S, TA.)

muzay~inN *
i. q. Haj~aAmN [i. e. A cupper; who is generally a barber; and to the latter this epithet (muzay~inN) is now commonly applied; as it is also in the MA]. (S, TA.) -A2- See also mutazay~inN.
muzay~iynN * : see mutazay~inN.
muz~aAnN * : see each in two places in what follows.
muzodaAnN * : see each in two places in what follows.

mutazay~inN * and ↓ muzodaAnN and ↓ muz~aAnN signify the same [i. e. Adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, or graced; as also ↓ muzay~anN: and the first signifies also selfadorned &c.]: (TA:) the second and third are part. ns. of AizodaAna; the third being formed from the second by incorporation [of the d into the z]: and the dim. of muzodaAnN is ↓ muzay~inN, like muxay~irN the dim. of muxotaArN; and if you substitute [for the d], ↓ muzay~iynN: and in like manner in forming the pl. you say mazaAyinu and mazaAyiynu. (S.) You say, A^anaA biA_iEolaAmika ↓ muz~aAnN and ↓ muzodaAnN, meaning mutazay~inN biA_iEolaAmi A^amorika [i. e. I am graced by the making known of thy command, or affair]. (TA.) And ↓ AimoraA^apN zaAy^inN means mutazay~inapN [i. e. A woman adorned, &c.; or self-adorned &c.]: (K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, mutazay~inN. (TA.)
